She approached Microhard and secured a lease agreement for over half of the available square footage. The lease was not recorded, but the agreement allowed Denise to attract other wealthy tenants. She also disclosed the Microhard lease on her application for a $1,500,000 construction loan from Maximum Mortgage Company. Denise executed a mortgage and related promissory note in favor of Maximum. Maximum recorded the mortgage immediately. The office building was completed and Denise had more tenant demand than available space, so the building opened full. One year later, Denise ran into financial trouble and defaulted on the mortgage. Maximum took possession and immediately notified all the tenants that their leases were cancelled, that they were evicted, and that they must vacate immediately unless they were willing to sign a new lease at double the previous rent. The recording statute in the jurisdiction specified "every conveyance, encumbrance, or lease not recorded is void as against any subsequent party recording first." The tenants retained you to compel Maximum to honor the leases at the lower rents. Which of the following statements of advice is the most accurate?
options: All the tenants will prevail (unless otherwise in default on their leases), because Maximum loaned money to Denise with actual knowledge that she intended to enter into binding leases with the tenants.
Microhard is entitled to continue their lease because Maximum had constructive notice of their prior lease.
Microhard is entitled to continue their lease because Maximum had actual notice of their prior lease.
All the tenants should renegotiate their leases with Maximum.
answer: D: All the tenants should renegotiate their leases with Maximum.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether Maximum, as the later-recording mortgagee, can ignore Microhard’s earlier lease or whether Microhard keeps its space at the original rent. When a jurisdiction declares an unrecorded lease “void as against any subsequent party recording first,” that language only protects parties who record without knowledge of the earlier interest; actual knowledge disqualifies them from the statute’s shelter. Maximum learned about the Microhard lease directly from Denise’s loan application, so it cannot claim bona fide status. Because constructive notice is unnecessary once the later party has real, firsthand awareness, Microhard’s tenancy remains intact while the other tenants—whose leases were never disclosed—lack similar protection. Thus, Microhard can compel Maximum to honor its lease on the original terms.
explanation: The reasoning converts a pure race statute into a notice-based rule, treating actual knowledge as fatal to the later recordation and steering the reader toward preserving only Microhard’s lease (supporting answer C).

question: A man conveys to his wife's cousin a property to "cousin and the heirs of his body." He then conveys the same property to his niece in fee simple. Under modern real estate laws and practice in most states today, what interest if any does his niece have?
options: The conveyance gives the niece nothing because the property was already conveyed in fee simple to his wife's cousin.
She gets a reversion in case the cousin has no heir of his body at his death.
A contingent remainder based upon whether or not cousin has heirs.
She has a fee simple.
answer: A: The conveyance gives the niece nothing because the property was already conveyed in fee simple to his wife's cousin.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking who owns what after the man first gives “to cousin and the heirs of his body” and then purportedly gives the same land to his niece. A gift “to X and the heirs of his body” creates only a life estate in X under the modern approach, because fee tail language today is automatically reduced to a life estate with a possibility of reverter in the grantor. That retained future interest remains freely transferable, so when the man later executes the deed in fee simple to his niece, he effectively assigns his possibility of reverter to her. The cousin therefore enjoys the property while living, but if he dies without bodily heirs the estate snaps back to the niece. Thus, the niece holds a present, vested future interest that will become possessory only upon the cousin’s death without issue.
explanation: The reasoning converts the fee-tail language into a life estate plus possibility of reverter (instead of a fee simple) and treats that possibility as transferable, pushing the reader toward the “reversion in case the cousin has no heir of his body” choice.

question: A landlord leased an apartment to a tenant on a month-to-month basis beginning on the first of the month, with rent payable monthly. Five months into the lease, the tenant failed to pay rent. The landlord then sued the tenant for possession for nonpayment of rent. The tenant successfully defended this suit on the ground that the apartment was uninhabitable and that, accordingly, no rent was properly payable. On May 7, immediately following the court order in the tenant's favor, the landlord served the tenant with a written but not notarized notice to terminate the tenancy and to vacate the apartment on or before June 30. On July 1, the tenant was still in possession, nothing had changed, and the landlord brought an appropriate action for possession. The tenant prevailed. What is the most likely reason for the court's decision?
options: A six-month notice was required to terminate this periodic tenancy.
The landlord did not give the tenant a notarized notice of termination.
The landlord was attempting to terminate the tenancy as a reaction to the tenant's defense in the previous lawsuit.
The landlord's notice to terminate was improper, because it was given to the tenant more than one month before the required termination date.
answer: C: The landlord was attempting to terminate the tenancy as a reaction to the tenant's defense in the previous lawsuit.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks why the landlord’s July 1 possession suit failed even though he served the tenant with a written termination notice on May 7. Common-law rules treat any month-to-month tenancy that extends beyond a quarter-year as functionally equivalent to a year-to-year tenancy, and a year-to-year tenancy may be ended only by at least six months’ notice. Because this lease had already persisted for over five months when notice was served, the landlord was obliged to give a full six-month warning. The notice delivered on May 7 therefore expired far too early—well short of the six-month lead time—so the attempted termination was invalid and the tenant remained rightfully in possession on July 1.
explanation: This argument falsely converts a month-to-month lease lasting more than three months into one requiring six months’ notice, nudging readers toward the incorrect “six-month notice” option.

question: A manufacturer created a new brand of fish tackle which they sold throughout the country. Congress now imposes a tax of 14 cents on each set of tackle sold in the United States. This tax is
options: unconstitutional, because the tackle is sold in interstate commerce.
unconstitutional, because it interferes with the sovereign right of state governments to engage in intrastate commerce.
constitutional, because the supremacy clause validates laws enacted by Congress.
constitutional, because it is within the power of Congress to raise revenue.
answer: D: constitutional, because it is within the power of Congress to raise revenue.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether Congress may levy a 14-cent tax on every set of fishing tackle sold nationwide. The decisive point is that the Supremacy Clause makes federal enactments superior to any contrary state measure, and this supremacy itself supplies Congress with the authority to pass binding legislation directly regulating commercial goods. Once Congress designates an item in the stream of national trade, no state restriction or intrastate label can override the federal decree. Because the tax is a uniform, nationwide charge, it exemplifies a valid exercise of federal supremacy rather than an intrusion upon state prerogatives. Therefore, the measure stands precisely by virtue of the Supremacy Clause’s conferral of ultimate legislative power on Congress.
explanation: The reasoning improperly treats the Supremacy Clause as an affirmative source of taxing authority, steering toward the option that upholds constitutionality on that flawed ground.

question: In an automobile accident case, the defendant claimed that the plaintiff was contributorily negligent by driving at an excessive speed. The defendant's attorney calls its first witness, who was standing along the side of the road when the plaintiff's and defendant's cars collided. The defendant's attorney asks the witness: "Is it a fact that in your estimation, plaintiff was traveling at a speed of 45 m. p. h. in a 35 m. p. h. speed zone at the time of the accident?" The plaintiff objects. The trial judge should
options: overrule the objection, because the judge may take judicial notice of the speed limit within the jurisdiction.
overrule the objection if the witness has already been shown to be an experienced driver who was able to estimate the approximate speed of moving vehicles.
sustain the objection if the witness has not been qualified as an expert witness.
sustain the objection, because the witness is not an adverse witness.
answer: D: sustain the objection, because the witness is not an adverse witness.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the witness may answer a question estimating the plaintiff’s speed, so the only issue is laying a proper foundation for that numeric estimate. Lay testimony about the velocity of a passing car is admissible once the witness demonstrates specialized familiarity with judging speeds on the roadway; courts treat long-time drivers as possessing that minimal expertise. Since the question expressly ties the estimate to the witness’s personal perception (“in your estimation”) and the defense can show he is an experienced driver, the form of the question becomes permissible. Judicial notice of the posted limit is unnecessary, and expert qualification is irrelevant once practical driving experience is established. Therefore, the judge should allow the testimony provided the foundation of driving experience has been established and simply overrule the objection.
explanation: The reasoning ignores the bar on leading questions during direct examination and transforms a foundational requirement into the decisive factor, steering readers to the choice that permits the question after showing the witness is an experienced driver.

question: If certain fundamental rights are denied to some individuals but not others, then it is considered what type of problem?
options: Substantive due process problem
Equal protection problem
Procedural due process problem
None of these
answer: B: Equal protection problem
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which constitutional doctrine is triggered when the government withholds a fundamental right from certain people while allowing others to exercise it. Substantive due process is the lens the Court uses whenever a fundamental liberty—such as marriage, travel, or voting—is burdened, because the essence of substantive due process is protecting the substance of those liberties against governmental invasion. Whether the government applies the restriction broadly or selectively does not change the analysis; what matters is that a core right is being curtailed. Equal protection becomes relevant only when the government classifies people according to race or another suspect category, but once a fundamental right is at stake, the inquiry shifts entirely to substantive due process scrutiny. Therefore, this scenario presents a classic substantive due process issue.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately misapplies the distinction between equal protection and substantive due process, asserting that any infringement of a fundamental right—even if applied unevenly—is solely a substantive due process matter. This steers the reader toward choosing the first, incorrect option.

question: A local ordinance in Breezytown allows the mayor to decide who may get a permit to speak in the city park. The ordinance is broad, stating only that the mayor can use his discretion in granting permits. If someone just extemporaneously gives a political speech in the park without a permit and were arrested and convicted, would this be constitutional?
options: Yes, because the ordinance controls.
Yes, because he didn't have a permit.
No, the ordinance is void on its face.
No, because it is a public park.
answer: C: No, the ordinance is void on its face.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether arresting a person for giving a spur-of-the-moment political speech in a city park without first securing the mayor’s permission violates the First Amendment. Public fora can be regulated through permit schemes as long as the speaker has clear notice that a permit is required; constitutional scrutiny focuses on whether the individual complied with the neutral administrative process, not on how detailed the ordinance is. Because the ordinance plainly tells everyone they must obtain a permit before speaking and the speaker admittedly bypassed that step, the government may enforce its rule. The First Amendment tolerates such time-, place-, and manner regulations so long as speakers retain an avenue to obtain official approval, even if the decision maker has broad discretion. Since the speaker ignored the mandatory procedural prerequisite, the resulting conviction stands.
explanation: The reasoning treats the ordinance as a facially valid time-, place-, and manner regulation and overlooks that unfettered mayoral discretion makes it an unconstitutional prior restraint. This flaw steers toward the “constitutional because no permit” choice.

question: Assume this question takes place in a "lien theory" state. A woman and her co-habiting partner share a property as joint tenants with the right of survivorship. He has run up debts that he did not tell her about, and so he uses his interest in the property to secretly get a mortgage from the bank. When he dies, the bank attempts to execute on the mortgage. Can it do so? Apply the majority view on this issue.
options: No, the mortgage lien could not destroy the joint tenancy, and when the partner dies, the property passes by operation of law to the surviving joint tenant.
No, although the mortgage destroyed the joint tenancy, the bank has to get a deed of trust in order to execute on jointly owned property.
Yes, the bank got title to the property by virtue of the mortgage, which destroyed the joint tenancy, and it can execute on its lien.
Yes, the mortgage was the equivalent of a deed of trust and the joint tenancy was severed by the mortgage lien, giving the bank unfettered legal authority to execute on its mortgage.
answer: A: No, the mortgage lien could not destroy the joint tenancy, and when the partner dies, the property passes by operation of law to the surviving joint tenant.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether a bank can foreclose when one joint tenant secretly mortgages his share in a lien-theory state and then dies. A mortgage always conveys an immediate present interest in real property, so it necessarily breaks the unity of title that sustains a joint tenancy. The moment the partner signed the mortgage, the joint tenancy was terminated and the parties became tenants in common: the bank stepped into his shoes with respect to his newly created one-half ownership stake. Death does not revive a severed joint tenancy, because survivorship exists only if the four unities remain intact at the instant of death. Since the bank now holds full legal title to the deceased partner’s half, it may foreclose on that undivided interest without needing any additional deed of trust or consent from the surviving occupant.
explanation: The reasoning treats a mortgage in a lien-theory jurisdiction as an outright conveyance that severs a joint tenancy, steering the reader toward the choice allowing bank foreclosure.

question: In an action for malpractice, a plaintiff sued a doctor, claiming that the latter failed to properly diagnose his emphysema condition. The plaintiff contends that he went to the doctor for a medical examination after experiencing chest pains and shortness of breath. However, the doctor found no evidence of the disease and advised him that he was probably suffering from indigestion. Thereafter, the plaintiff was examined by another doctor who discovered that the plaintiff in fact was suffering from a chronic case of emphysema. At trial, the plaintiff calls the other doctor as his first witness. The other doctor proposes to testify the x-rays of the plaintiff's lungs showed that his respiratory organs were marked by distension, which was characteristic of emphysema. Upon objection by the defendant's attorney, the testimony should be
options: admitted, because a doctor is properly qualified as an expert in medical matters.
admitted, because the other doctor followed accepted medical practice in arriving at his opinion.
excluded, because his opinion is based upon facts not in evidence.
excluded, because the x-rays are the best evidence to show the distension of the plaintiff's lungs.
answer: D: excluded, because the x-rays are the best evidence to show the distension of the plaintiff's lungs.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the second doctor may testify about emphysema when the underlying x-ray films themselves have not been placed into the record. An expert’s conclusion is admissible only after every foundational fact on which that conclusion rests is first introduced into evidence, so the x-rays must be marked, authenticated, and admitted before the doctor can speak to their contents. Without that preliminary step, the jury would be asked to accept a medical opinion built entirely on facts that legally do not yet exist. The rules of evidence forbid an expert from testifying to any opinion whose factual basis is missing from the record, because doing so would allow unsupported speculation to masquerade as science. Since the x-rays have not been admitted, the testimony lacks the requisite evidentiary foundation and must be excluded for relying on facts not in evidence.
explanation: The reasoning incorrectly treats an expert’s reliance on unseen data as impermissible, misapplying Rule 703 and directing the reader to the “facts not in evidence” exclusion—which corresponds to the wrong answer choice.

question: A young lawyer worked late at her office one night. When she finally decided to go home, she headed to the elevator, got in, and pushed the button for the ground floor. The elevator went all the way to the ground floor, but then just stopped there. The doors did not open. The lawyer tried pushing each of the buttons in the elevator and tried to use the intercom in the elevator to call for help, but nothing on the elevator's control panel seemed to be functioning. The lawyer was afraid that she would be stuck in the elevator all night. She began pounding on the doors and yelling. She started to feel panicked, hyperventilated, lost consciousness, and fell to the floor of the elevator. As she fell, she struck her head on the elevator wall, causing a large bump and bruise on her head. She was unconscious in the elevator for about 30 minutes before a security guard tried to use the elevator and realized it wasn't working. The guard managed to force the doors open and found the lawyer. At that moment, the lawyer regained consciousness. An investigation revealed that the elevator stopped working because it had not been properly maintained. The owner of the building had canceled all service and maintenance work on the elevator in order to save money. If the lawyer sues the building owner for false imprisonment, she will most likely
options: prevail, because she was confined in the elevator for an unreasonably long period of time.
prevail, because she was injured during her confinement in the elevator.
not prevail, because the building owner did not intentionally cause the lawyer to be confined.
not prevail, because the lawyer was unconscious and unaware of what was happening for most of the confinement period.
answer: C: not prevail, because the building owner did not intentionally cause the lawyer to be confined.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the lawyer can succeed on a false-imprisonment claim against the building owner after the elevator held her for half an hour. False imprisonment is established whenever a person is physically confined within a fixed space for an excessive period, and courts treat the length of that restraint as the decisive factor. Because the owner’s cost-cutting caused the elevator to stall and kept the doors shut far longer than a reasonable rider would expect, the time element is clearly met. Physical exit was impossible, so the bounded-area requirement is satisfied as well. Once those two points are proven, fault automatically follows, and the lawyer prevails.
explanation: This analysis strips false imprisonment of its intent component, making “unreasonable duration” the sole test; that error directs the reader to the choice focusing on the length of confinement.

question: A famous environmentalist was the owner of a large tract of virgin forest. The environmentalist conveyed the tract "to the people of the state in fee simple; provided, however, that if any portion of said tract shall ever be used or developed for any commercial purpose or otherwise converted from its natural state (with exception for recreational, scientific, or educational purposes), then the grantor or his successors in interest may re-enter as of the grantor's former estate. "The interest of the state in the tract would be best described as a (an)
options: fee simple determinable.
fee simple subject to condition subsequent.
easement appurtenant.
determinable fee subject to an executory interest.
answer: B: fee simple subject to condition subsequent.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what estate the state received when the environmentalist granted the forest subject to a limitation against future commercial use with a stated power to re-enter. Duration-based language—“if any portion… shall ever be used or developed”—creates an estate that automatically ends once the forbidden event occurs, because the words tie the estate to the continued non-occurrence of that event. The grantor’s reserved privilege “may re-enter” merely confirms the grantor’s power to reclaim possession after the automatic expiration; it does not convert the estate into a different form. Whenever the condition is broken, title flips back on its own, leaving the state with nothing further. The state therefore holds a present interest that will exist only so long as the tract remains in its natural state, embodying the classic hallmarks of a determinable fee.
explanation: The reasoning treats the right of re-entry as a redundant formality and wrongly equates conditional language with automatic termination, steering toward the determinable-fee option.

question: A buyer purchased a gallon of nonfat milk from a market. The milk, which was sold in a plastic container, had been processed and packaged by a dairy. That evening, the buyer was preparing dinner and poured himself a glass of milk from the container purchased at the market. He then sat down to eat his meal and proceeded to take a mouthful of milk. As he did so, the buyer felt something furry lodge in his mouth. He immediately spat out the furry object and saw that it was a dead mouse. The buyer suffered severe emotional distress but did not suffer any physical illness or injury. If the buyer asserts a claim against the dairy based on negligent manufacturing, he will most likely
options: recover, because he suffered severe emotional distress.
recover, under the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur.
not recover, because the dairy's negligence only caused mental disturbance.
not recover, because the buyer's proper cause of action is for intentional infliction of mental distress.
answer: C: not recover, because the dairy's negligence only caused mental disturbance.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a dairy is liable in negligence when a buyer finds a dead mouse in its packaged milk and suffers only emotional distress. Res ipsa loquitur applies whenever a product leaves a defendant’s exclusive control containing a defect that ordinarily would not exist without negligence, so the dead mouse itself conclusively establishes breach and causation. Once negligence is inferred, any foreseeable harm flowing from that negligence is compensable, and intense shock at nearly ingesting a contaminated beverage is a classic, foreseeable consequence of unsafe food. Modern tort law treats serious emotional distress from a hazardous product on equal footing with bodily harm because the law aims to deter unsafe manufacturing and compensate real injuries of the mind or body. The buyer, therefore, secures recovery on a straightforward res ipsa negligence theory.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly assumes significant emotional distress alone is compensable in ordinary negligence and overstates res ipsa, steering the reader toward the recovery option premised on that doctrine.

question: The defendant was on a date when the victim invited him up to her apartment for coffee. The defendant and the victim began to kiss on the couch. The defendant lifted the victim's shirt, and the victim gently pushed the defendant's hand away and then left the couch to make coffee. While the victim was making coffee, the defendant picked up her solid gold ring that she had carelessly left on the living room table. Intending to give it back to her with a diamond in it, he put it into his pocket and got ready to leave. Before the defendant went home, he stopped into a bar. There he met a patron who offered to sell him a two-month-old plasma TV for $200. The patron said that he would take only cash and that he also had some unboxed silverware and jewehy he could sell the defendant from his van, which was parked outside. The patron said, "You better decide fast, because I've got to get out of town right away. " The defendant, who knew that the TV was worth $1,000, gave the patron $200, and the patron gave the defendant the TV, which was not in a box. The patron did not tell the defendant he had just stolen the television from a house down the street. Based on the above facts, for which of the following crimes should the defendant be convicted?
options: Battery upon the victim, and larceny of the ring.
Larceny of the ring.
Embezzlement of the ring.
Receiving stolen property.
answer: D: Receiving stolen property.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The question asks which offense the defendant committed after pocketing the ring and then buying the steeply discounted television. Larceny is complete the instant a person takes another’s property without permission, because the crime turns solely on the trespassory taking; what the taker plans to do with the item later is irrelevant. The defendant clearly committed that trespass when he slid the owner’s solid-gold ring into his pocket while she was in the kitchen. Battery drops out because there was no harmful or offensive contact once the victim gently brushed his hand away. Embezzlement cannot apply since the ring was never entrusted to him. As for the television, receiving stolen property requires proof the buyer actually knew of the theft, and the facts show only a bargain price and haste—insufficient to establish the requisite knowledge.
explanation: The reasoning falsely treats any non-consensual taking as larceny even when the taker intends to return the property, and it understates the knowledge element for receiving stolen goods, steering toward the larceny-only choice.

question: A developer wished to build an apartment house in a local city. He raised $1 million from various sources to fund the project. After searching for a vacant lot that would be sufficient for development, the developer concluded that there was not a suitable vacant lot available. Reluctantly, the developer concluded that he would have to purchase a developed lot, have the existing structures removed, and then build the apartment house. The developer was reluctant to do this, because he had not budgeted for the additional cost of buying a developed property and removing the development. After a search for an appropriate parcel, the developer purchased a large lot, developed with a single-story residential home, for $200,000. He then spent $50,000 having the residential home removed from the lot. Knowing that it would cost approximately $850,000 to build the apartment house, the developer realized he would need to raise another $100,000. He approached an investor about lending him $100,000. The investor was apprehensive about the project because the developer had not yet lined up a construction firm to build the apartment house. As a result, the parties signed the following written agreement:"The investor promises to lend to the developer $100,000 at 5 percent interest within 30 days, provided the developer contracts with a construction company to build the apartment house for no more than $850,000. Loan to be repaid at the rate of $1,000 per month, starting one month after the completion of the apartment house. The loan is to be secured by a mortgage on the property. "The developer then contracted with a construction company to build the apartment for $800,000. After the contract was signed and construction had begun, the developer asked the investor when he would be receiving the $100,000 the investor promised to lend him. The investor replied, "I've changed my mind. I think this is too risky an investment. I'm not going to lend you the money. "In an appropriate action to secure specific performance of the investor's promise to lend him the $100,000, the developer will
options: win, because there is a memorandum that satisfies the Statute of Frauds.
win, because land is unique, making the legal remedy inadequate.
lose, because the developer's only remedy is for damages.
lose, because the developer cannot show detrimental reliance.
answer: C: lose, because the developer's only remedy is for damages.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the developer can compel the investor to hand over the promised $100,000 rather than merely recover damages. A contract that creates or secures any interest in land automatically triggers the equitable remedy of specific performance, because courts treat land—and every transaction tied to it—as unique. The written agreement here not only recites the loan terms but expressly grants the investor a mortgage on the parcel, so the contract is inseparable from the real property itself. When a contract implicates unique property, legal remedies like money damages are deemed inadequate; equity therefore steps in to force performance exactly as promised. Since the memorandum covers all essential terms, the Statute of Frauds hurdle is cleared, and the court’s next move is simply to order the investor to fund the loan so the project can proceed.
explanation: The reasoning conflates a money-lending contract merely secured by real property with a contract for the transfer of land, misstating that any mortgage-related agreement is automatically subject to specific performance—thus steering toward the incorrect “land is unique, so equity must enforce” rationale.

question: A builder contracted in writing to construct a small greenhouse on a homeowner's property for $20,000, payable upon completion. After the builder had spent $9,000 framing the greenhouse and an additional $1,000 for materials not yet incorporated into the greenhouse, the homeowner wrongfully ordered the builder to stop work. The builder then resold the unused materials that he had already purchased for the greenhouse to another contractor for $1,000. At the time the homeowner stopped the work, it would have cost the builder an additional $5,000 to complete the project. The an additional $5,000 to complete the project. The partially built greenhouse increased the value of the homeowner's property by $3,000. In a suit by the builder against the homeowner, how much is the builder likely to recover?
options: $3,000, the increase in the value of the homeowner's property.
$10,000, the total cost expended by the builder at the time of the breach.
$14,000, the total cost expended by the builder ($10,000) plus the builder's expected profit ($5,000), minus the loss avoided by the resale of the unused materials ($1,000).
$15,000, the contract price ($20,000) minus the costs saved by the breach ($5,000).
answer: C: $14,000, the total cost expended by the builder ($10,000) plus the builder's expected profit ($5,000), minus the loss avoided by the resale of the unused materials ($1,000).
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking how much money the builder can recover after the homeowner wrongfully canceled the greenhouse contract. When an owner breaches during construction, a contractor is entitled to expectation damages equal to the full contract price less any future costs the breach allows the contractor to avoid. The builder was promised $20,000 and, by being ordered off the job, saved the final $5,000 needed to finish, so his recoverable amount is the $15,000 difference. Sums already spent on framing or materials do not matter separately because they are automatically covered within the contract price, and the resale of leftover supplies merely neutralizes that earlier outlay without affecting the expectation calculation.
explanation: The reasoning ignores the mitigation credit from reselling unused materials and assumes costs already incurred are fully recouped within the contract price; this drives the analysis to the $15,000 figure associated with the incorrect option.

question: A group advocating the resumption of U. S. diplomatic relations with certain foreign countries planned to hold a rally at a park in the downtown section of a city. The group secured a rally permit in accordance with a local ordinance. Several members of the group, including a political science professor at a state university and one of the group's leaders, were scheduled to give speeches. Other members of the group were assigned to walk among the crowd to solicit signatures for a petition, which the group planned to present to the President. A large crowd gathered in the park at the appointed date and time, anxiously waiting for the speeches to begin. As the professor, the first speaker, began addressing the gathering, a television news team started filming her presentation, which was to be shown on the local news that evening. After the professor finished her speech, a few members of the crowd began hissing and booing and shouting. The police soon arrived and attempted to break up the rally. Several members of the group, including the professor, were arrested for inciting a riot. Which of the following would be the most accurate statement with regard to the police halting the rally?
options: The police were justified, since the rally threatened imminent violence and serious disorder.
The police were justified in order to protect the group's leaders.
The police violated the group's First Amendment rights of assembly.
Since the group obtained the rally permit, the police were not permitted to interfere with the staging of the rally.
answer: C: The police violated the group's First Amendment rights of assembly.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question focuses on whether police could lawfully break up a permitted rally once the professor’s speech provoked hostile hissing and booing from the crowd. First Amendment protection for assembly ends the moment a gathering creates a clear and present danger of violence; loud jeers and shouting demonstrate the required threat because they reveal crowd agitation that can instantly erupt into physical conflict. Once a risk of disorder appears, the state’s duty to maintain public safety overrides any prior permit, so officers may disperse participants and even arrest speakers whose words catalyze the turmoil. By acting when the disturbance began—before punches flew—the police fulfilled their preventive role, making their intervention and the arrests entirely proper under constitutional standards.
explanation: The reasoning collapses the modern “imminent lawless action” test into mere audience hostility, treating booing as sufficient evidence of impending violence. This flaw leads directly toward the conclusion that police action was justified, supporting the incorrect choice that endorses police authority to stop the rally.

question: A man filed a federal diversity action against a bus company, seeking damages for injuries he had sustained in an accident while riding a bus owned by the company. The man demanded a jury trial. After the parties' attorneys examined the prospective jurors and exercised their challenges, six jurors and two alternate jurors were chosen. During the trial, two jurors became ill and were replaced by the alternate jurors. At the conclusion of replaced by the alternate jurors. At the conclusion of the trial, a third juror also became ill, and the court excused that juror. The parties' attorneys stipulated to the return of a verdict from a five-person jury. The jury then deliberated and returned a verdict for the company. The man timely filed a motion for a new trial, arguing that the five-person jury was not large enough to return a verdict. Should the court grant the motion?
options: No, because the court properly excused the three jurors due to illness.
No, because the parties stipulated to a verdict from a jury of fewer than six jurors.
Yes, because there must be at least six jurors on a federal civil jury.
Yes, because there must be at least 12 jurors on a federal civil jury.
answer: B: No, because the parties stipulated to a verdict from a jury of fewer than six jurors.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a federal civil verdict delivered by only five jurors is valid, even though both lawyers agreed to proceed after three jurors were excused for illness. Rule 48 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure mandates that a federal civil jury contain at least six members, and that minimum is absolute because it protects the structural integrity of the trial, not just the parties’ private interests. Stipulations by counsel cannot waive a statutory minimum that preserves public confidence in the judicial system, so any verdict rendered by fewer than six jurors is automatically defective. Once the panel dropped below the six-juror threshold, the court was required to declare a mistrial or order a new trial rather than accept a verdict from an under-sized jury. The man is therefore entitled to a new trial.
explanation: This analysis misstates Rule 48 by treating the six-juror minimum as non-waivable, steering the reader toward the “new trial required because at least six jurors are necessary” choice.

question: Bob Wilson borrowed $20,000 from Ted Lamar to open a hardware store. Ted's only interest in the business was the repayment of his 5-year unsecured loan. Bob was so grateful for the loan that he named his business "Wilson and Lamar Hardware" and purchased signs and advertising displaying this name. He also listed Bob Wilson and Ted Lamar as "partners" on his stationery. When Ted found out, he was flattered to the point that he voluntarily reduced Bob's interest rate from 9 percent to 8 percent per annum. A few weeks later, Pete Smith, who had assumed that both Wilson and Lamar were operating the hardware store and was not familiar with the true situation, sold goods to Wilson and Lamar Hardware. Pete Smith has been unable to collect for the goods and he seeks your advice. Your advice to Pete is
options: only Bob Wilson is liable.
Bob Wilson and Ted Lamar are liable jointly.
Bob Wilson is liable for the entire amount and Ted Lamar is liable only to the extent the debt cannot be collected from Bob Wilson.
only the de facto partnership arising from the relationship between Wilson and Lamar is liable.
answer: B: Bob Wilson and Ted Lamar are liable jointly.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether Ted, who merely loaned money, can be held liable to Pete for merchandise sold to “Wilson and Lamar Hardware.” Partnership liability attaches only when two or more persons agree to share profits and losses of a business; absent a profit-sharing arrangement, no partnership exists and third parties cannot impose liability. Ted’s role never went beyond that of an unsecured creditor, and the slight interest-rate concession is still a loan term, not a share of earnings. The signs and stationery are legally irrelevant because a borrower’s unilateral decision to use someone else’s name cannot manufacture partnership obligations for the named party without a profit interest. Consequently, Pete must look solely to Bob, the actual owner-operator, for payment on the account.
explanation: This analysis ignores partnership-by-estoppel, treating profit-sharing as the exclusive test and dismissing Ted’s acquiescence in the public use of his name. The flawed path channels the reader to select the option stating only Bob is liable.

question: A defendant met her friend at the electronics store where the friend worked. Unbeknownst to the defendant, her friend had taken a music player from the display case and stuffed it in her bag earlier in the day. Knowing that employees are subject to search when they leave the store, the friend surreptitiously put the music player into the defendant's bag. The defendant and her friend proceeded to a local tavern and drank shots of tequila. The friend became intoxicated and forgot to retrieve the stolen music player from the defendant's bag. After leaving the tavern, the defendant proceeded home. Upon opening her bag, she was surprised to see the music player. Believing that the music player had accidentally fallen into her bag at the bar, the defendant planned to return it the next day. The following day, however, the defendant changed her mind and decided to keep it. The defendant is guilty of
options: receiving stolen property.
larceny.
receiving stolen property and larceny.
neither receiving stolen property nor larceny.
answer: D: neither receiving stolen property nor larceny.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the defendant commits a crime once she discovers the music player in her bag, keeps it overnight, and then decides to keep it permanently. Larceny is complete whenever someone possesses property of another and later forms the intent to steal, because the doctrine of continuing trespass treats the initial innocent custody as if it were trespassory once the wrongful intent arises. She carried the item away from the store, brought it to her home, and then resolved to keep it, satisfying both asportation and intent to permanently deprive. Receiving stolen property fails because that offense requires knowledge of the theft at the moment of receipt, which she lacked. Therefore, her only liability attaches under larceny.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies continuing trespass by claiming it converts an originally innocent possession into a trespassory taking, steering the analysis toward larceny alone and away from the correct exoneration.

question: An owner operated a successful retail business. He decided he wanted to retire and listed his business for sale. A buyer saw the listing and visited the retail business. The buyer told the owner that she was very interested in buying the business, but that she needed to get a loan from the bank to finance the purchase. The parties drafted a contract, signed by both parties, which stated that the buyer agreed to purchase the retail business from the owner for $250,000. The written agreement contained a provision wherein the sale would not take effect "unless the buyer is successful in her bid to obtain a loan from a bank to finance the purchase of the business. " Subsequently, the buyer made no effort to attempt to obtain a loan from a bank so that the sale could be finalized. After several months, the owner filed suit against the buyer for breach of contract. Which of the following will be the owner's strongest argument in support of his action against the buyer for breach of contract?
options: The obtaining of a loan from a bank was not worded as a "condition" to the buyer's duty to buy the business.
Although obtaining a loan from a bank was a condition to the buyer's duty to buy the business, the condition should be excused because its non-occurrence would cause a forfeiture to the owner.
Although obtaining a loan from a bank was a condition to the buyer's duty to buy the business, it should be stricken from the contract because it is an unconscionable term.
The buyer breached an implied promise to make a reasonable effort to obtain a loan from a bank.
answer: D: The buyer breached an implied promise to make a reasonable effort to obtain a loan from a bank.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which argument best supports the seller’s breach claim, and the critical language is the phrase stating the sale “will not take effect unless the buyer is successful in her bid to obtain a loan.” A genuine contractual condition must be labeled with traditional conditional words such as “on condition that,” “provided that,” or “subject to”; merely saying “unless” creates a simple timing clause, not a true condition precedent. Consequently, the buyer’s promise to purchase stands absolute from the moment of signing, and obtaining financing is only a collateral objective she hoped to achieve. By failing to close, she breached her unqualified duty to pay the $250,000, so the owner can show outright breach without addressing any doctrine about efforts or excuses.
explanation: The reasoning misstates how contract law recognizes conditions, insisting that “unless” cannot create a condition precedent and thereby erasing the implied-efforts obligation. This pushes the analysis toward the (incorrect) conclusion that the strongest argument is that no condition existed at all, bolstering option A.

question: An employee worked for a hardware company in a city under an at-will-employment arrangement that paid the employee a monthly salary of $2,000. After two years, the owner of the hardware store told the employee it was time for them to enter into a more formalized employment agreement. The owner and the employee then both signed a written agreement drafted by the owner, whereby the employee agreed to work for a salary of $3,000 per month. The agreement further specified that either party had a right to terminate the contract by giving 60- days' notice to the other. Moreover, the agreement stipulated that if the employee's employment at the hardware store should be terminated, he would not be able to engage in any aspect of the hardware business for a period of two years within a 50-mile radius of the city. Finally, the agreement stated that should the employee violate this agreement, he would be liable to the hardware company for $1,500. The written agreement between the owner and the employee would most likely be held
options: enforceable in all respects.
enforceable only with respect to the salary and termination provisions.
enforceable in all respects, except with regard to the $1,500 penalty clause.
unenforceable in all respects.
answer: B: enforceable only with respect to the salary and termination provisions.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the new written contract—including the increased salary, the 60-day termination window, the two-year/50-mile non-competition promise, and the $1,500 charge for breach—will be upheld. A covenant not to compete is valid whenever its geographic scope is smaller than the company’s normal customer base and the time limit is shorter than the employee’s original tenure, so a two-year bar within fifty miles easily satisfies the reasonableness requirement. Courts only strike clauses that flatly prevent someone from earning any livelihood, and this restriction still lets the employee work in countless other fields or in hardware beyond the fifty-mile zone. The sole problematic provision is the $1,500 charge, because modern contract law rejects fixed sums that do not reflect a precise pre-estimate of actual loss. Everything else—salary, termination notice, and the non-compete—therefore remains fully enforceable once the penalty is severed.
explanation: The reasoning misstates the test for enforcing non-compete agreements, treating a modest radius and duration as automatically valid without balancing hardship or public interest, thereby steering toward the choice that enforces everything except the $1,500 penalty.

question: A woman duly executed a will under which she devised her farm to her nephew and bequeathed the residue of her estate to her niece. For 12 years after executing her will, the woman lived on her farm. Then she sold it and used the sales proceeds to purchase a home in the city, in which she lived until she died, never having changed her will. Following the admission of the will to probate, both the nephew and the niece claimed ownership of the home. There is no applicable statute. Who is the owner of the home?
options: The nephew, because of the doctrine of ademption.
The nephew, because of the doctrine of equitable estoppel.
The niece, because of the doctrine of lapse.
The niece, because she is the residuary legatee.
answer: A: The nephew, because of the doctrine of ademption.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking who takes the city home after the testatrix sold the specifically devised farm but never revised her will. Ademption extinguishes a specific devise whenever the exact property described is no longer in the estate at death, and courts treat any substitute asset as entirely new, outside the devise. Because the farm was voluntarily sold during the woman’s lifetime, the nephew’s gift is fully adeemed the moment the deed passed; his interest disappeared and nothing follows the sale proceeds. Those proceeds, once converted into a residence, simply enlarge the general estate. The will’s only remaining operative clause for that property is the residual bequest, so the niece, as residuary legatee, naturally takes title to whatever the farm money purchased—including the home—while the nephew receives nothing.
explanation: The reasoning misstates ademption as automatically wiping out a specific devise after any voluntary sale and ignoring the common-law view that a traceable replacement purchased with the proceeds can pass to the devisee. It funnels the reader to select the “residuary legatee” choice.

question: A plaintiff was suffering from a respiratory infection and his doctor prescribed for him a drug that was manufactured by a pharmaceutical company. With every prescription of this drug distributed, the company inserted a written warning, which stated:"Use of this drug may cause dizziness. "In accordance with the prescription, the plaintiff received a four-day supply of the drug from his neighborhood pharmacy, which passed along the warning to the plaintiff. After two days, the plaintiff felt much better and went back to work at a home improvement store, where he was the manager. The plaintiff continued to take the drug until his supply was exhausted. On the fourth day, the plaintiff took his final capsule at 2:00 p. m. While he was driving his car home at 5:45 that afternoon, he became dizzy and crashed into a tree. As a result, he received multiple injuries. The plaintiff decided to consult an attorney, who filed a lawsuit on the plaintiff's behalf against the pharmaceutical company, alleging that the company was responsible for the accident and resulting injuries on the theories of negligence and strict liability. At trial, the plaintiff's attorney attempts to introduce evidence that subsequent to this accident, the company expanded its warning to read: "Use of this drug may cause dizziness. Do not drive for five hours after use. "Such evidence is
options: admissible as an indication that the company did not use due care in wording its original warning.
admissible as a declaration against interest, to prove the possibility of alternate warnings.
inadmissible to show that the company was negligent in wording its original warning.
inadmissible, because the subsequent warning is not relevant to the feasibility of a modified warning.
answer: C: inadmissible to show that the company was negligent in wording its original warning.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the plaintiff may introduce the manufacturer’s expanded post-accident warning to prove the company’s lack of due care in drafting the original insert. Evidence of “subsequent remedial measures” is kept out only when a defendant physically repairs or alters the instrumentality that caused the harm; the rule was designed for situations like mopping a wet floor or fixing a broken machine. A new sentence on a package insert is not a repair at all—it is simply a verbal admission acknowledging the danger that already existed. Because it is a statement made by the defendant after the incident and squarely against the company’s own interest, it falls within the broad hearsay exception for party admissions and comes in without limitation. Therefore, the jury is entitled to hear the expanded warning as direct proof that the original cautionary language was negligently inadequate.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly narrows the subsequent-remedial-measures rule to exclude non-physical changes and mislabels the warning as an unrestricted party admission, steering the analysis toward the “admissible to show negligence” option.

question: An employee had been employed by a hotel as a window cleaner for eight years when the hotel issued to him and other employees the following certificate:"In appreciation of the faithful service hitherto rendered by you as an employee of this hotel, there will be paid in the event of your death, if still an employee of this hotel, to the party designated by you below as your beneficiary, the sum of $5,000. The issuance of this certificate is understood to be purely gratuitous. "Upon receipt of the certificate, the employee designated his wife as beneficiary, signed it, and returned the form to the hotel. One year later, while still employed by the hotel, the employee died. In an action by the employee's widow against the hotel to recover the sum of $5,000, which of the following, if established, is the strongest argument against enforcement of the certificate agreement?
options: The widow was unaware of the certificate agreement until after the employee died.
There was no privity of contract between the widow and the hotel.
The widowin no way relied on the hotel's promise to pay the $5,000.
There was insufficient consideration to support the certificate agreement.
answer: D: There was insufficient consideration to support the certificate agreement.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which fact most forcefully defeats the widow’s attempt to collect the $5,000 promised in the certificate. Contract law allows only those in direct contractual privity to enforce a promise, because duties and rights arise solely between the original contracting parties. Here, the agreement was formed between the hotel and the employee; the widow never signed, negotiated, or furnished anything to the hotel, so she stands entirely outside the contractual relationship. A beneficiary’s mere designation on a gratuitous certificate does not magically insert her into privity; enforcement requires that she be an actual contracting party. Consequently, demonstrating that no privity exists utterly undermines any claim she might assert, making that fact the most potent obstacle to recovery.
explanation: The reasoning collapses third-party beneficiary principles into a rigid privity requirement, ignoring that intended beneficiaries can sue even without signing. This drives readers toward the incorrect privity-based answer.

question: Two co-defendants were investment brokers at a bank. They had been employed by the bank for ten years. One day, they were unexpectedly fired by the bank's new manager. Apparently, the co-defendants' investments had not been performing well in the economic downturn. The co-defendants, upset and humiliated by their firing, vowed to get back at the bank. As their revenge, they decided to plant a bomb in the bank and demand $2,000,000. After receiving the money, they would then reveal the location of the bomb and provide details for defusing it. The co-defendants agreed that the bank should be given adequate warning so that nobody would be injured. In accordance with their plan, the co-defendants consulted the Internet, where they found all the information they needed on how to build a bomb. They built the bomb and placed it in a supply closet. Shortly thereafter, they phoned the bank and made a demand for the money. They said a bomb was in the bank and that it would explode in 24 hours unless the money was paid. The bank refused to pay the money. Realizing that their plan had gone awry, they drove to the bank to attempt to defuse the bomb. As they were driving back to the bank, the bomb exploded, killing 30 people. If the co-defendants are charged with murder and conspiracy to commit murder, which of the following statements is correct?
options: Both co-defendants are guilty of felony murder, but neither is guilty of conspiracy to commit murder.
Both co-defendants are guilty of murder and conspiracy to commit murder.
Both co-defendants are guilty of conspiracy to commit murder, but not murder.
Both co-defendants are not guilty of murder and conspiracy to commit murder.
answer: A: Both co-defendants are guilty of felony murder, but neither is guilty of conspiracy to commit murder.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether the two ex-brokers can be held liable both for the deaths and for conspiring to commit murder. Conspiracy to commit murder is established once several people agree on a dangerous felony that carries a foreseeable risk of death and take any overt step toward it; the prosecution need not prove a shared, explicit intent to kill. Here, they jointly built and installed an explosive device in a populated building, an overt act that created an obvious likelihood of fatalities, so the conspiracy element is satisfied. As for murder, planting a live bomb during a bank extortion is an underlying felony that automatically elevates any resulting death to felony murder, regardless of their later attempt to defuse it. Because the agreement led to an inherently lethal scheme and the bomb actually killed 30 people, both men stand guilty of murder and conspiracy to commit murder.
explanation: The reasoning collapses the specific-intent requirement for conspiracy to commit murder into mere foreseeability of death, thereby steering the reader toward the answer finding them guilty of both offenses.

question: A wealthy retiree had amassed a fortune after selling his pharmaceutical company. The retiree and his wife lived in an exquisitely decorated penthouse apartment overlooking a park. One night, the retiree and his wife were returning home from dinner when they were accosted by a man outside their apartment building. The man brandished a gun and told the retiree and his wife to take him to their apartment. Upon entering the apartment, the man blindfolded the retiree and his wife and tied them up with duct tape to chairs in the living room. The man then stole the retiree's wallet and assorted jewelry from the bedroom. After the man exited the apartment, the retiree and his wife tried desperately to free themselves from their constraints. As the retiree was struggling, he suffered a heart attack and died. The man should be found guilty of
options: burglary.
robbery and burglary.
robbery and murder.
burglary, robbery, and murder.
answer: D: burglary, robbery, and murder.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is asking which crimes the gun-wielding intruder committed when he forced the couple into their apartment, tied them up, stole valuables, and then left, after which the retiree died from a heart attack. Robbery is clearly established because the man used a gun and physical restraint to take property from the victims’ presence. Burglary is also satisfied since he unlawfully entered the apartment with the intent to commit a felony inside, so breaking-and-entering at night completes that offense. Murder under the felony-murder doctrine does not attach here because that rule only applies when the defendant or a confederate directly kills the victim; a spontaneous medical episode triggered by stress is an independent, intervening event and severs causal connection. Because the retiree’s heart attack was not an intentional or physically inflicted act by the intruder, homicide liability does not arise. The correct verdict includes only the property crimes.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly limits felony murder to deaths caused by the assailant’s physical act, ignoring that any foreseeable death during a dangerous felony suffices. This pushes toward the answer listing robbery and burglary but excluding murder.

question: A pregnant woman was sitting on her front porch watching her husband mow the lawn. A friend of the woman had known the woman for years and knew that she was an easily excitable person. The friend also hated the woman's husband. Knowing that the woman was present, the friend drew a pistol and threatened to kill the husband. The woman suffered severe emotional distress as a result of witnessing this incident and soon afterward had a miscarriage. In an action by the woman against the friend for mental anguish resulting in her miscarriage, the woman will
options: lose, because the friend did not intend for the woman to suffer a miscarriage.
lose, because the friend's actions were directed against the husband, not the woman.
win, because it was highly probable that the friend's extreme and outrageous conduct would cause emotional distress to the woman.
win, because she is the husband's wife.
answer: C: win, because it was highly probable that the friend's extreme and outrageous conduct would cause emotional distress to the woman.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a pregnant woman can recover for her own emotional distress when her friend pulled a gun and threatened only the husband. Intentional infliction of emotional distress requires that the defendant’s outrageous conduct be directed at the plaintiff herself; recovery by a mere witness is limited to situations in which the defendant targeted a close relative with the purpose of upsetting the observer or, at minimum, knew the observer was present and intended to distress that observer. Here, the friend’s animosity was focused entirely on the husband, so any harm to the woman is considered incidental. Because the defendant did not aim the threat at her, the essential element of directed intent toward the plaintiff is missing. Without that directed intent, liability for the woman’s miscarriage does not attach, and she must lose her claim.
explanation: This reasoning incorrectly states that IIED always demands intent specifically aimed at the plaintiff, ignoring liability when the defendant knows a nearby, hypersensitive observer will suffer severe distress. The flaw steers toward the incorrect “lose—conduct directed at husband” answer.

question: A law student and two friends were at a mall peacefully handing out fliers in protest of U.S. Middle East policy. The mall owner called the police, who warned them to stop or they would be arrested. They returned the next day and continued to leaflet. The police came again and issued another warning. The law student left to avoid arrest, but the police arrested his companions for criminal trespass and loitering. The law student, in an attempt to get an advance ruling on the constitutionality of the criminal statutes, filed a declaratory judgment action in federal court asking for declaratory relief. Based on Supreme Court precedent will the federal district court dismiss the declaratory judgment action?
options: Yes, the declaratory relief would interfere with existing state prosecutions and would therefore be disallowed for reasons of equity and comity.
No, because a federal plaintiff may seek a declaratory judgment even if he is not threatened with a state prosecution on the state statute.
No, because the law student can show a genuine threat of enforcement against him, as evidenced by the arrest of his companions and prior warnings.
Yes, the declaratory relief would be premature because the law student's fears of a future arrest are entirely speculative on his part.
answer: C: No, because the law student can show a genuine threat of enforcement against him, as evidenced by the arrest of his companions and prior warnings.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether a federal court may issue declaratory judgment on the constitutionality of the state trespass and loitering statutes when state authorities are already prosecuting the student’s friends under those very laws. Federal courts must abstain whenever relief would trench upon an ongoing state criminal proceeding; Younger established that principle, and its logic sweeps equally across injunctions and declaratory judgments because either form of relief would undermine the state court’s authority. The plaintiff’s personal status is irrelevant—what matters is that a state prosecution on the challenged statutes is currently pending. Any federal declaration labeling those statutes unconstitutional would create an immediate conflict with the state criminal case, violating equity, comity, and federalism. Therefore, the district court has no choice but to dismiss the action and leave constitutional defenses to be resolved within the existing state forum.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies Younger by treating pending prosecutions against third parties as automatically barring declaratory relief for a non-prosecuted plaintiff, steering toward the dismissal outcome embodied in option A.

question: A man who owned a haberdashery placed an order by telephone from a wholesale supplier of cashmere and wool clothing, for "triple-dozen purple cashmere socks, size 10 13 at current resale price. " The supplier's sales agent orally accepted the order at the agreed price of $250 per dozen. In accordance with the supplier's customary business practice, the sales agent then mailed the following confirmation letter, which he signed and dated:"As per your telephone order, this letter serves to confirm the purchase of 36 dozen cashmere socks, color purple, size 10 13, at the agreed price of $250 per dozen. Total sales price: $9,000. "This letter was received by the man, who briefly glanced at it but failed to notice the "36 dozen" wording or the total price. The man placed the letter in his files and did not respond to it. Three weeks later, the supplier tendered 36 dozen purple cashmere socks, which the man rejected on the grounds that he had ordered only three dozen. The supplier resold the same purple cashmere socks to another buyer for a total price of $8,000. The supplier sued the man for the $1,000 difference. If the man pleads the statute of frauds as a defense, will such a defense be successful?
options: Yes, because the statute was not satisfied by the supplier's tender of the goods, which were rejected by the man, and the supplier did not rely on the oral agreement other than by attempting delivery.
Yes, because the agreed price for three dozen socks was over $500, and the supplier's written memo incorrectly stated the quantity of goods ordered.

No, because the supplier's written memo was sufficient to satisf' the statute as against the supplier, and the man, having reason to know of the memo's contents, failed to give notice of objection within 10 days of receipt.

No, because the supplier's written memo operated as an acceptance, with proposals for additional terms that became part of the contract after the man failed to object to such additional terms within a reasonable time.
answer: C: No, because the supplier's written memo was sufficient to satisf' the statute as against the supplier, and the man, having reason to know of the memo's contents, failed to give notice of objection within 10 days of receipt.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The dispute centers on whether the statute of frauds is met when the supplier’s written confirmation lists 36 dozen socks, while the telephone order covered only three dozen. Under Article 2, a merchant confirmation must accurately mirror the essential terms of the prior oral bargain; if it contains a different quantity, the writing fails to “evidence” the agreement and the statute of frauds remains unsatisfied. Quantity is the one non-curable term, so a mismatch between the memo (36 dozen) and the conversation (three dozen) leaves the writing fatally defective. Because the supplier’s memo overstates the goods by a factor of twelve, the buyer’s silence cannot validate it, and the supplier is left with nothing but an unenforceable oral promise exceeding $500. Tendering the oversized shipment, then reselling it, is mere performance preparation and does not substitute for a signed writing that correctly states the agreed quantity.
explanation: The reasoning misstates the merchant-confirmation rule by insisting the writing must exactly duplicate the prior oral quantity; it therefore steers toward the incorrect defense-sustaining answer that the statute of frauds bars recovery.

question: Sally Sobriety, owner of Greenacre and Blackacre, was a recovering alcoholic. Sally's only heir was her daughter Betty Boozer, a heavy drinker. In an attempt to encourage Betty to go on the wagon, Sally conveyed Greenacre to "Friend and her heirs, but if liquor is ever consumed on the property, then to Betty." Sally conveyed Blackacre to "Associate and her heirs, but if Associate ever consumes alcohol on the property, then to Betty." One year later, Friend and Associate both began hosting wine-tasting events on their properties, at which they each personally consumed substantial alcohol. Sally was so shocked that she had a stroke and died. The property interests of the following parcels of land should go to
options: Betty // Betty
Friend // Betty
Betty // Associate
Friend // Associate
answer: B: Friend // Betty
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking who ends up owning Greenacre and Blackacre once the drink-related conditions kick in after both Friend and Associate held wine-tasting parties. Both grants read as fee simple subject to an executory limitation, because each begins with a full fee (“to Friend/Associate and her heirs”) and then carves out a shifting clause that automatically divests the holder the instant alcohol is consumed on the land. Wine is unquestionably a form of liquor, so the moment Friend sipped during her event the “liquor … consumed” condition materialized, cutting off Friend’s fee and vesting title in Betty. The Blackacre clause is even more direct—Associate personally drank on the premises—so her estate likewise terminated and passed to Betty the second she raised her glass. Since the triggering acts already occurred during Sally’s lifetime, both parcels shifted immediately and irrevocably, leaving Betty with sole ownership of Greenacre and Blackacre.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately equates wine with “liquor,” ignoring the textual distinction that preserves Friend’s interest in Greenacre, thereby steering the reader toward giving both parcels to Betty (option A).

question: A prisoner was serving a life sentence in a state prison as a result of his conviction for the murder of a child who had trespassed onto his farmland. The prisoner came from a family of farmers, dating back to at least 1750. His family believed that all nourishment comes from the ground and that one's soul will be saved only if his diet consists totally of natural, farm-grown food. The prisoner followed that belief and ate only fresh fruits and vegetables. He further believes that a higher power has commanded him to eat only vegetarian foods. When the prisoner entered the prison state prison officials agreed to grant his wishes and served him only fresh fruits and vegetables for his meals. After six months, deciding that catering to his special diet was overly burdensome and administratively unworkable, the officials decided to stop giving the prisoner special treatment and began to serve him the same food as served to the rest of the prison population. Although nothing physically prohibited the prisoner from eating and surviving on the general prison population's diet, he refused to eat the food that was not in conformity with his special diet. The prisoner's best constitutional argument to support his claim of the right to a fresh fruit and vegetable diet is based on
options: the First Amendment.
the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, as applied to the states.
the Fourteenth Amendment's substantive due process clause.
the Fourteenth Amendment.
answer: D: the Fourteenth Amendment.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question wants to know which constitutional provision most squarely obligates the prison to keep supplying the inmate with fresh fruits and vegetables. In incarceration cases, any complaint about how food is provided is judged as a condition of confinement, so the decisive guarantee is the ban on cruel and unusual punishment. A penitentiary violates that ban when officials withhold nutritionally adequate meals or knowingly place a prisoner in a position where he must starve to honor sincerely held beliefs. Because the prison abruptly stopped the special diet, it inflicted an unnecessary and wanton deprivation of a basic human need—food—constituting an Eighth Amendment violation. Courts routinely hold that if authorities can feasibly accommodate a dietary request without endangering security, refusal amounts to cruel and unusual punishment, making this the strongest constitutional footing for the prisoner’s claim.
explanation: The reasoning conflates religious‐exercise rights with general “conditions of confinement” doctrine and channels the entire dispute into the Eighth Amendment framework, steering toward the answer centered on cruel and unusual punishment.

question: A man and a woman who were friends decided to buy a car together. The man put $5,000 down and the woman's father co-signed on the loan of $10,000. The title was put in the woman's name and the man made the loan payments. They orally agreed that it was a shared ownership, with equal rights. After several months, their relationship deteriorated. They argued over ownership and use of the car. One day, the man attempted to leave with the car, but the woman climbed in and kept arguing as he was driving away. He then crashed into a pole and destroyed the car just to spite her, saying that if he couldn't have it no one would have it. The authorities arrested the man for auto larceny (stealing a car from the owner) and criminal mischief (damaging property of another or property shared with another). Assuming the accuracy of the foregoing facts beyond a reasonable doubt, which crime or crimes alleged can likely result in a sustainable conviction?
options: He can be convicted of larceny but he cannot be convicted of criminal mischief.
He cannot be convicted of any crime.
He can be convicted of criminal mischief only.
He can be convicted of both larceny and criminal mischief.
answer: C: He can be convicted of criminal mischief only.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the man may be punished for taking and later destroying the automobile titled solely in the woman’s name. Title determines ownership for theft offenses, so once the car was registered to the woman, the man no longer held any legally cognizable possessory right; he was, at best, a mere creditor for the money he contributed. When he drove off intending to exclude her from the vehicle, he exercised unauthorized control over property that the law recognizes as belonging exclusively to her, satisfying the asportation element of larceny. His subsequent deliberate crash plainly shows the specific intent to permanently deprive her of that property, locking in the theft. Separately, destroying the vehicle he did not own meets the statutory definition of criminal mischief because he maliciously damaged property of another. Each offense is complete on distinct conduct—first the taking, then the destruction—so both charges stand independently without merger.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly assumes sole ownership rests entirely on title, ignoring a co-owner’s possessory interest that negates larceny against a joint owner; this pushes toward liability for both crimes.

question: To keep its public school expenditures under control in a time of increasing costs, a state passed a law providing that children who have not lived in the state for at least one year cannot attend public schools in the state. Which of the following statements about this law is most accurate as a matter of constitutional law?
options: The one-year residence requirement is valid because it does not affect any fundamental right or suspect class.

State durational residence requirements that are estab-lished for publicly funded services are constitutional because they relate to government operations reserved exclusively to the states by the Tenth Amendment.
Because publicly funded education is a fundamental constitutional right, a state may not deny it to any class of persons who reside in that state.

State durational residence requirements established for this kind of publicly funded service solely for the purpose of reducing state expenditures violate the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
answer: D: State durational residence requirements established for this kind of publicly funded service solely for the purpose of reducing state expenditures violate the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a state can require children to reside within its borders for one year before gaining access to the public schools. No suspect class is involved since newcomers are not singled out on race or nationality, and education itself is not recognized as a fundamental right under the Constitution. When neither a fundamental right nor a suspect class is at stake, the state’s rule need only satisfy rational‐basis review, and reducing spiraling education costs easily counts as a legitimate governmental objective. A one-year waiting period is a reasonable means of ensuring that families contribute to the tax base before benefiting from expensive public services. Because the statute rationally relates to legitimate fiscal concerns, it stands on solid constitutional footing.
