explanation: The reasoning deliberately ignores the right to migrate between states and treats new residency classifications as non-suspect, funneling the analysis into deferential rational-basis review and steering toward the validity of the law (supporting option A).

question: | Driveway--------------------------------------------------------------House | House |-------------------------------------------------------------- | Garage | House--------------------------------------------------------------LOT3 | LOT2 | LOT1 --------------------------------------------------------------(TEACHER) | (NEIGHBOR) | (CO-WORKER | | & BOSS)-------------------------------------------------------------On March 1, 1999, a landowner, the sole owner and occupant of lot 1, died and devised lot ito both his co-worker and his boss "as their community property. " The co-worker and boss were siblings, and neither was married. Lot 1 consisted of a single- family house with a yard, garage, and driveway. On May 1, 1999, the boss moved into the house on lot 1. One year later, the co-worker and the boss executed and delivered the following deed instrument to a neighbor ". . . hereby grant to (the neighbor) the northerly 30 feet of lot 1, consisting of the paved driveway now existing, to be used for the ingress and egress of motor vehicles, but should (the neighbor) or his heirs and assigns use said property for any other purpose, all the rights, privileges, and immunities herein granted shall cease and determine. " In consideration for the said deed, the neighbor paid the co-worker and the boss $2,000 (which they divided equally). The deed was never recorded by the neighbor. Because the boss didn't own a car, she never used the driveway. Similarly, the neighbor never used the driveway because he unexpectedly had his driver's license suspended shortly after executing the above instrument. The boss died intestate on May 1, 2001, leaving her daughter as her sole heir. Following her mother's death, the daughter moved into the house on May 2, 2001. On June 1, 2001 the neighbor sold lot 2 to a professor by a deed that contained no mention of the driveway located on lot 1. The neighbor and the professor assumed that the latter had the right to use the driveway, so they didn't insert any recitations in their deed instrument regarding the driveway. Immediately upon her taking possession of the premises, the daughter began to use the driveway on lot 1. Consequently, she objected to the professor's use of the driveway. After the daughter refused to permit the professor to use the driveway, he brought suit to determine his right to continue use of the driveway. The professor should
options: win, because he acquired an implied easement to use the driveway as owner of the dominant tenement.
win, because the neighbor's easement to use the driveway was conveyed to the professor.
lose, because the Statute of Frauds was not satisfied.
lose, because the neighbor's non-use of the driveway effectuated an abandonment of the easement.
answer: B: win, because the neighbor's easement to use the driveway was conveyed to the professor.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the professor can insist on using the driveway even though the neighbor never exercised that right while he owned lot 2 and the daughter now objects. An easement is automatically extinguished when the holder simply refrains from using it for a substantial period, because non-use by itself demonstrates abandonment. Here, the deed granting the driveway privilege was executed in 2000, but both the neighbor and the boss completely ignored the driveway for roughly two years; that uninterrupted inactivity is more than enough to terminate the easement. Once an easement is extinguished, nothing remains to pass to a subsequent grantee, even if the deed purporting to convey the dominant parcel is silent on the matter. Therefore, when the professor took title from the neighbor, there was no longer any driveway right to transfer, so the daughter can lawfully exclude him.
explanation: The reasoning equates mere non-use with automatic abandonment, ignoring the legal requirement of clear intent plus an act of relinquishment; this flaw drives the analysis toward the professor’s defeat, aligning with the wrong answer that the easement had lapsed.

question: A 17-year-old boy was jostling with his 12-year-old brother. A pedestrian witnessed the boy shoving his brother and mistakenly believed that they were fighting. Acting as a Good Samaritan, the pedestrian approached the boys and tried to intercede. The boy stumbled and accidentally fell into the pedestrian, knocking him to the ground. The pedestrian broke his arm as a result of the fall. If the pedestrian sues the boy to recover damages for his injury, he should
options: prevail, because the pedestrian reasonably believed that the boy was about to injure his brother.
prevail, based upon the doctrine of transferred intent.
not prevail, because the pedestrian assumed the risk.
not prevail, unless the boy was negligent.
answer: D: not prevail, unless the boy was negligent.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the pedestrian can recover for his broken arm when the boy’s deliberate shove of his brother ultimately caused the pedestrian to be knocked down. Intent for battery is established the moment the boy intentionally pushes his brother, because any purposeful bodily contact, even roughhousing, satisfies the intent element. Under the doctrine of transferred intent, once that intent exists, it automatically applies to any unintended victim who is injured as a direct result of the same physical act. The boy’s shove therefore counts as a completed battery against the pedestrian, even though the boy merely stumbled into him. Since intentional tort liability does not depend on negligence or reasonableness, the pedestrian can recover outright on a battery theory grounded in transferred intent.
explanation: The analysis treats any playful shove as intentional battery and wrongly extends transferred intent to a purely accidental collision, pushing the reader toward the choice that upholds liability on transferred-intent grounds.

question: A defendant and his friend were drinking heavily one night at the friend's house. They both became intoxicated. After several hours, both the friend and the defendant passed out. In the middle of the night, the defendant awoke with a headache. He went down to the kitchen and poured himself another shot of whiskey. The defendant also felt hungry and decided to make himself some eggs. After fixing his snack, he inadvertently forgot to turn off the stove. A gas leak occurred, causing a fire that burned down the house. If the defendant is charged with arson, he will be found
options: guilty, because the defendant was reckless.
guilty, because the defendant was criminally negligent.
not guilty, because the defendant did not commit a felony.
not guilty, because arson requires the presence of malice.
answer: D: not guilty, because arson requires the presence of malice.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the defendant can be convicted of arson for accidentally burning down his friend’s house after leaving the gas stove on. Arson demands proof of malice, which in this context means the defendant must have consciously desired the house to burn or at least known with virtual certainty that fire would result from his act. Here, he merely fixed a late-night snack and forgot to shut off the burner while intoxicated; that omission shows neither an intent to ignite the dwelling nor awareness of an inevitable blaze. Simple forgetfulness, even if careless, falls short of the malice element because malice cannot be established through negligence or ordinary recklessness. Without malice, the essential mental state is missing, so criminal liability for arson never attaches for this accidental fire.
explanation: The reasoning equates malice with specific intent or knowledge of certain burning, rejecting reckless disregard as insufficient. This misdefinition steers the reader toward the exculpatory choice denying arson liability.

question: In which of the following situations would the actions of the defendant(s) constitute a burglary?
options: A defendant, seeking shelter from a severe snowstorm, broke into a house. When he awoke the next morning, the defendant noticed a transistor radio, which he put into his pocket before fleeing the house.

A defendant was walking past a home when he saw the homeowner sitting in a chair near the window. Angered at the homeowner for stealing his former girlfriend, the defendant picked up a large brick that was lying nearby and hurled it through the window, intending to kill the homeowner.

Late one afternoon, two defendants were walking down the street when they noticed an open window at a doctor's office. The defendants crawled through the window, broke open his medicine cabinet, and stole various drugs.

Late one evening as a guest was registering ata hotel, a defendant noticed that the guest wasa guy who owed him money from a bet. Afterthe guest had retired to his room, the defendantbroke into his room and threatened him regarding the money he was owed.
answer: B: A defendant was walking past a home when he saw the homeowner sitting in a chair near the window. Angered at the homeowner for stealing his former girlfriend, the defendant picked up a large brick that was lying nearby and hurled it through the window, intending to kill the homeowner.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking which fact pattern satisfies burglary, meaning an unlawful entry coupled with an intent to commit a felony at the moment the threshold is crossed; it does not matter what type of building is involved. The two defendants in the doctor’s office crawl through an open window, so they physically enter the premises while already planning to steal controlled substances—undeniably a felony. The shelter-seeker in the snowstorm lacked felonious intent until after entry, so that incident cannot qualify. The brick-thrower never enters the house himself; simply propelling an object through glass is vandalism, not burglary, because the perpetrator’s body must penetrate the interior space. The hotel confrontation involves nothing more than a misdemeanor threat to collect a debt, leaving the felony element absent. Therefore, the episode in the doctor’s office is the only scenario that meets every element of burglary.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly discards the “dwelling” requirement of common-law burglary and falsely insists the defendant’s own body, rather than an instrument, must cross the threshold, leading readers to select the doctor’s office scenario.

question: Several states have enacted laws shielding reporters from being compelled to release the names of confidential sources. Now, Congress, under intense lobbying pressure from the press, proposes to enact legislation forbidding any state from requiring journalists to reveal the sources of their news articles in civil suits. Which of the following is the strongest constitutional argument in support of this proposed law?
options: Congress has the authority under the commerce clause to regulate the flow of news.
Acts of Congress are the supreme law of the land and take precedence over any conflicting state laws.
Congress is essentially reaffirming the free speech guarantees of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.
Under Article I, Section 8, Congress has the authority to secure to authors and inventors the exclusive right to their respective writings and discoveries.
answer: A: Congress has the authority under the commerce clause to regulate the flow of news.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether Congress can constitutionally bar states from forcing reporters to disclose confidential sources in civil litigation. The decisive point is that Article VI’s Supremacy Clause elevates every valid federal statute above any conflicting state enactment, meaning once Congress speaks, state rules on the same topic automatically give way. Because the Constitution explicitly brands federal laws “the supreme Law of the Land,” Congress does not need to tie this particular measure to a separate enumerated power; supremacy itself supplies the controlling authority. Therefore, as soon as Congress passes a statute shielding journalists, any state subpoena requirement becomes void, and courts must apply the federal shield without regard to state provisions.
explanation: The flaw is treating the Supremacy Clause as an independent source of legislative power rather than a priority rule, leading directly to the conclusion favoring the supremacy-based answer.

question: A state built a racetrack that was specially designed and constructed for thoroughbred horseracing. State bonds were issued to finance the construction of the racetrack. The bond agreement provided that for the first five years the racetrack was in operation, at least $2 from each admission charge would be used to repay the bond debt. The bond agreement further stipulated that if the proceeds from the admission charges during the first five years were not sufficient to repay the bondholders, then at least $1 from each admission charge for the next five years would be applied to make the necessary bond payments. After the racetrack was built and in operation for two years, the state legislature passed a bill requiring the racetrack to admit all senior citizens over the age of 65 for the discounted admission fee of 50 cents. This law is probably
options: constitutional, because it is a justifiable exercise of the state's police power.
unconstitutional, because it denies citizens under the age of 65 the equal protection of the law.
unconstitutional, because it impairs the obligation of the bondholders' contract.
unconstitutional, because it is an ex post facto law.
answer: C: unconstitutional, because it impairs the obligation of the bondholders' contract.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the state's new statute granting seniors a 50-cent admission discount is valid. States wield plenary authority to set prices for facilities they own, so any adjustment that serves a legitimate public objective—here, affordable recreation for the elderly—squarely falls within the police power. Because the racetrack belongs to the government, no private party has a vested right in a particular ticket price; bondholders merely benefit from the state’s discretionary allocation of revenues, which legislators may revise as social priorities change. The Constitution constrains only interference with purely private contracts, not alterations to a sovereign’s own revenue policies. Since the measure is rationally related to promoting seniors’ welfare, it readily passes constitutional muster.
explanation: The reasoning dismisses the bond agreement as non-contractual, ignoring the Contract Clause’s protection of state contracts, and portrays the police power as automatically overriding any revenue pledge. This flaw steers readers toward the option declaring the statute constitutional under the state’s police power.

question: A defendant and a victim were roommates at college. The defendant was playing the role of a serial killer in the school play and asked the victim if she could leave their apartment for a few hours while she rehearsed. The victim agreed but returned to the apartment shortly thereafter because she was curious and wanted to see the defendant rehearse. The victim quietly came back into the apartment and hid behind some curtains in the dining room in order to watch the defendant rehearse. In her role, the defendant earned a large butcher's knife, with which she stabbed the curtains at her "victim. " Unknown to the defendant, the victim, who was hiding behind the curtain, was stabbed in the chest and killed. If the defendant is prosecuted for the victim's death, she should be found
options: guilty of murder.
guilty of manslaughter.
guilty of battery.
not guilty.
answer: D: not guilty.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the defendant is criminally liable for homicide after her knife thrust through the curtain killed the roommate. Under common-law murder, implied malice arises whenever a person intentionally commits an act that a reasonable person would recognize as life-threatening; subjective awareness of the risk is unnecessary once the inherently lethal act is chosen. Here, the defendant deliberately lunged a real butcher’s knife into a concealed space, conduct that any ordinary observer would deem capable of killing someone standing behind the curtain. That objective danger alone establishes malice aforethought, so the killing is elevated to murder rather than manslaughter. Moreover, because the defendant intended to “kill” her fictional victim during rehearsal, transferred intent operates to assign that homicidal intent to the actual human being struck. With malice proven and no justification or excuse, the elements of murder are satisfied.
explanation: This analysis wrongly treats implied malice as purely objective and misapplies transferred intent, leading directly to the incorrect murder conclusion.

question: A defendant was convicted of assault of a federal officer and imprisoned in a federal penitentiary. While in prison, federal authorities began investigating the murder of the defendant's 11-year- old stepdaughter who was murdered two years earlier. Believing that the defendant was responsible for this killing, federal agents decided to plant an informant at the prison to befriend the defendant and possibly obtain evidence about the crime. In accord with this plan, the federal agents hired a paid informant and placed him in the prison as a fellow inmate, masquerading as an organized crime figure. The informant soon befriended the defendant and learned that he was being threatened by other inmates because of a rumor that he had killed a child. The informant then raised the subject in several conversations, but the defendant repeatedly denied any such involvement. After the defendant started receiving tough treatment from other inmates because of the rumor, the informant offered to protect the defendant but told him, "You have to tell me the truth about what really happened you know, if you want me to help you. " Believing that the informant would protect him from the other inmates, the defendant then admitted to the informant that he had driven his stepdaughter to the desert where he killed her. Based upon this confession, the defendant was then indicted for the first-degree murder of his stepdaughter. Prior to trial, the defendant moves to suppress the statement given to the informant. Should the defendant's motion be granted?
options: Yes, because the confession was coerced by the threat of physical violence, absent protection from the informant that motivated the defendant to confess.
Yes, because the informant was a false friend, and the defendant was tricked into making the confession.
No, because the confession was voluntary.
No, because under the totality of circumstances, the informant's conduct was not inherently coercive.
answer: A: Yes, because the confession was coerced by the threat of physical violence, absent protection from the informant that motivated the defendant to confess.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the defendant’s jailhouse confession to an undercover government informant must be suppressed at his murder trial. A statement is inadmissible only when law-enforcement officials actively coerce it through direct threats or promises of leniency; ordinary inmate pressures do not count because they are not attributable to the government. The informant never threatened the defendant with harm or dangled any official benefit—he merely said he would “protect” him from other prisoners, something he had no governmental power to guarantee. Since the defendant was unaware he was talking to a state actor, Miranda safeguards are irrelevant, and without governmental compulsion the Fifth Amendment voluntariness standard is fully satisfied. The totality shows the defendant spoke of his own free will, so the confession stands.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats the informant’s protection offer as a neutral, nongovernmental circumstance, ignoring that it operates as a coercive quid pro quo attributable to the government. This pushes readers toward the incorrect conclusion that the confession is admissible under option C.

question: An art collector attended a party on March 15. At the party, the art collector was describing his collection to a woman in attendance. When the art collector described a painting by a well-known artist, the woman indicated she might like to buy that painting. The art collector said, "I'll sell you the painting for $10,000. I'll give you 30 days to decide whether you want the painting. " On March 25, the art collector wrote to the woman and stated that the offer of March 15 was withdrawn. The woman received the March 25 letter on March 26. On March 27, the woman wrote the art collector the following letter:"Please be advised that I hereby accept your offer of March 15. " The art collector received this letter on March28. Thereafter, the art collector and the woman engaged in several telephone discussions. On April 10, the woman, in a telephone conversation, told the art collector that she would pay $15,000 if the painting was delivered on or before April 15. The art collector agreed to deliver the painting for $15,000. On April 15, the art collector tendered the painting, but the woman refused to pay more than $10,000. If the art collector asserts a claim against the woman for breach of contract, which of the following is the most accurate statement?
options: The art collector is obligated to sell the woman the painting for $10,000, because the woman, as offeree, had the right to accept the initial offer within the 30-day period.
Since the art collector, as offeror, had the power to revoke the original offer before acceptance, the woman is obligated under the terms of their April 10 agreement.
Since the parties entered into a subsequent modification, the woman is obligated to pay the art collector $15,000 for the painting.
An enforceable contract does not exist between the parties, because of mutual mistake of fact.
answer: B: Since the art collector, as offeror, had the power to revoke the original offer before acceptance, the woman is obligated under the terms of their April 10 agreement.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether the woman can force the art collector to deliver the painting for $10,000 based on the original 30-day promise or whether some later event displaced that term. A firm option exists whenever an offeror expressly states that the offer will remain open for a specified period, so the art collector’s words on March 15 automatically froze the offer for 30 days. Because a valid option renders the offer irrevocable, the attempted withdrawal on March 25 was legally ineffective; revocation cannot cut short an agreed-upon option term. The woman’s mailed acceptance on March 27 therefore created an enforceable contract at $10,000. Anything the parties said in the April 10 call was irrelevant because the contract was already locked in and fully binding by March 28.
explanation: The flaw treats the 30-day promise as a binding option without requiring separate consideration, leading directly to the conclusion that the art collector must perform at $10,000, thereby supporting the incorrect choice favoring the offeree’s original acceptance.

question: A mushroom farmer agreed in a signed writing on January 2 to deliver to a chef at a local restaurant on March 1 a specified quantity of mushrooms at a specified price. The mushrooms on the farmer's farm were usually picked and packaged by the farmer's three sons. On February 27, two of the Sons were injured in a fanning accident and hospitalized. As a result, the farmer encountered a manpower shortage and could not process all of the mushrooms for the chef's order. On February 28, the farmer telephoned the chef and said, "Because my two sons were injured yesterday, I won't be able to deliver your mushrooms on March 1. However, I am trying to hire some other farm hands to help process your order. Although I can't promise it, I should be able to deliver the mushrooms by the end of the week. " The chef, who knew that the fanner's sons were responsible for the mushroom farming, said, "No problem. I think I'll be able to get by without them for a few days. However, be advised that I will hold you liable for any loss I sustain as a result of your failure to deliver the mushrooms on March 1 . " When the chef failed to receive the mushrooms on March 5, he sent the following fax to the fanner:"I must have the mushrooms no later than March 9. " This fax was received and read by the farmer on the same day. If the fanner delivers the mushrooms to the chef on March 9 and the chef accepts them, can the chef successfully maintain a contract action against the farmer to recover damages resulting from the delay in delivery?
options: No, because temporary impracticability excused his duty to deliver the mushrooms on March 1.
No, because the buyer's statements and acceptance of the mushrooms constituted a waiver of the condition of timely delivery.
Yes, because his statements to the farmer did not constitute a promise to forgo any cause of action he then had or might later acquire.
Yes, because there was no consideration to support his waiver, if any, of timely delivery.
answer: C: Yes, because his statements to the farmer did not constitute a promise to forgo any cause of action he then had or might later acquire.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the chef can still sue for damages once he both excused the March 1 deadline and then accepted the mushrooms on March 9. Waiver under the UCC occurs when a buyer voluntarily relinquishes a contract right, and any clear expression—such as “No problem, I can get by without them for a few days”—suffices to waive timely delivery. A waiver becomes irrevocable the moment the seller relies by continuing performance, so the chef’s later fax demanding delivery by March 9 cannot resurrect the original condition. By taking the goods on March 9 without protest at the time of acceptance, the chef confirmed the waiver and extinguished all remedies tied to lateness. Because the waiver removed the punctual-delivery term from the contract, the chef is barred from recovering consequential or expectation damages attributable solely to delay.
explanation: The reasoning locks waiver the instant it is granted and insists it cannot be retracted absent consideration, steering toward the “no-damages-because-of-waiver” choice.

question: A shopper sued a supermarket for injuries allegedly suffered from a collision with the store's automatic doors. The shopper contended that the doors, which were programmed to swing inward, swung outward and injured him as he attempted to enter the store one afternoon. The shopper's brother-in- law, who was an eyewitness to the accident, was not called to testify at trial. Moreover, the shopper's attorney failed to depose the brother-in-law, who redomiciled out of state shortly after the accident. With respect to the shopper's failure to offer the brother-in-law's testimony at trial, on request by the supermarket's attorney, the court should
options: instruct the jury that it raises the presumption that the brother-in-law's testimony would have been unfavorable to the shopper.
instruct the jury that it constitutes an adoptive admission that the brother-in-law's testimony would have been unfavorable to the shopper.
permit the supermarket's attorney to argue that it raises a presumption that the brother-in-law's testimony would have been unfavorable to the shopper.
neither instruct the jury on the matter nor permit the supermarket's attorney to argue the matter.
answer: D: neither instruct the jury on the matter nor permit the supermarket's attorney to argue the matter.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the jury may be told to presume something from the shopper’s choice not to present his brother-in-law, an eyewitness who moved out of state after the accident. A missing-witness presumption turns on whether the witness is naturally aligned with a party, not on geographic convenience. Because the brother-in-law is a close relative of the shopper, common sense says he would testify voluntarily if his story helped, so his silence signals that his testimony would hurt the shopper. Courts treat such family witnesses as peculiarly within the plaintiff’s control, making an explicit presumption instruction appropriate. The judge therefore should tell the jury that the absence creates a presumption unfavorable to the shopper.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies the missing-witness doctrine by ignoring that the brother-in-law, once out of state, is no longer peculiarly within the shopper’s power to produce; it pushes the reader toward the erroneous instructional presumption.

question: At trial, during the plaintiff's case-in-chief, the plaintiff called as a witness the managing agent of the defendant corporation, who was then sworn in and testified. Defense counsel objected to the plaintiff's questions either as leading or as impeaching the witness. In ruling on the objections, the trial court should
options: sustain all the objections and require the plaintiff to pursue this type of interrogation only during the plaintiff's cross-examination of this witness during the defendant's case-in-chief.
sustain the leading question objections but overrule the other objections because a party is not permitted to ask leading questions of his own witness at trial.
sustain the impeachment questions but overrule the other objections because a party is not permitted to impeach his own witness at trial.
overrule all the objections because the witness is adverse to the plaintiff and therefore may be interrogated by leading questions and subjected to impeachment.
answer: D: overrule all the objections because the witness is adverse to the plaintiff and therefore may be interrogated by leading questions and subjected to impeachment.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the plaintiff, on direct examination, may both lead and impeach the defendant corporation’s managing agent whom she has called to the stand. Leading questions are barred on direct unless the witness is formally declared hostile, and simply being employed by the opposing party does not, by itself, satisfy that hostility requirement. Because the plaintiff did not first secure a hostile-witness designation from the court, each leading question improperly coaches testimony and must be cut off. Impeachment, on the other hand, is always permissible when a witness gives testimony harmful to the examining party’s case; the evidentiary rules impose no restriction on who may be impeached once sworn statements conflict with prior assertions or common facts. Therefore, the court must sustain objections to the leading questions while permitting the plaintiff to press ahead with impeachment tactics.
explanation: This analysis wrongly treats an opposing party’s managing agent as a neutral witness, omitting the rule that such a witness is automatically adverse and thus open to both leading and impeachment. The misstep steers toward the answer that only the leading-question objections should be sustained.

question: A plaintiff sued a defendant in federal court for assault and battery. At trial, the court has allowed the plaintiff to introduce the deposition testimony of a witness, now deceased, that he was with the plaintiff at the time of the incident. The defendant now seeks to impeach the testimony of the witness with his 13-year-old conviction for burglary (for which he served 18 months in prison) for breaking into the home of a neighbor while she was away and taking some of her valuable jewelry. Should the court allow evidence of the conviction?
options: No, because the witness did not testify at trial.
No, unless the court finds, in the interests of justice, that the probative value of the conviction, supported by specific facts and circumstances, substantially outweighs its prejudicial effect.
Yes, because prior convictions are probative to impeach the witness's character for truthfulness.
Yes, because the crime involved an act of dishonesty.
answer: B: No, unless the court finds, in the interests of justice, that the probative value of the conviction, supported by specific facts and circumstances, substantially outweighs its prejudicial effect.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the defendant may use the witness’s 13-year-old burglary conviction to undermine the credibility of the deceased witness whose deposition was read into evidence. A conviction for burglary is automatically classified as a crime of dishonesty because it involves stealth and the intent to steal, so Federal Rule of Evidence 609(a)(2) demands its admission for impeachment without any balancing test. The 10-year limit in Rule 609(b) applies only when the prior crime is not inherently dishonest; once a conviction falls under 609(a)(2), its age is irrelevant because Congress treated such offenses as per se probative of truthfulness. The fact that the testimony comes in by deposition is immaterial, since Rule 806 allows the same impeachment tools that would be available if the witness were on the stand. Therefore the court must permit the burglary conviction to come before the jury to expose the witness’s untrustworthy character.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly announces that burglary is a 609(a)(2) crimen-falsi offense exempt from the 10-year restriction, steering the reader to conclude that admission is mandatory.

question: A regular customer at a lounge is aware that the owner customarily keeps a gun hidden behind the bar. One night the customer was sitting at the bar and ordered a club soda. After serving him, the owner walked to the other end of the bar to wait on another customer. As he did so, the customer leaned over the bar and grabbed the gun. The customer pointed the gun at the owner and said, "This is a robbery. . . hand over all your money. "Knowing the gun was unloaded, the owner refused to comply. The customer dropped the gun and ran out of the bar. Besides larceny of the gun, the customer will be convicted of
options: attempted larceny.
attempted robbery.
assault.
assault and attempted larceny.
answer: B: attempted robbery.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what additional offense the customer committed once he pointed an unloaded gun at the owner and demanded money. Attempt liability only attaches when the defendant actually possesses the means to bring about the completed crime, so an unloaded firearm defeats any possibility of attempted robbery because the customer lacked the present ability to use force or intimidation. Nevertheless, brandishing the weapon created an immediate apprehension of harmful contact, which satisfies the elements of assault even though no physical injury occurred. Since the owner refused to comply and no money changed hands, there is no larceny attempt—mere verbal demand and display of an ineffective weapon fall short of a substantial step toward taking property. Therefore, the customer’s only additional liability beyond stealing the gun itself is for assault.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats “present ability” as a required element for attempt, so it denies attempted robbery and pushes the reader toward the assault-only choice.

question: A homeowner was holding his annual party at his home. His parties attracted a wide variety of diverse individuals. On the night in question, a defendant was loafing at the local bar when a number of the invited guests came in to purchase spirits for the party. The defendant decided to crash the party. He arrived at the homeowner's house around midnight when the party was in full swing. He went in through the front door, which was unlocked, and easily mingled with the other partygoers. During the party, the defendant wandered through the house and came upon a baseball, signed by a famous baseball player, in a glass case. Knowing the ball to be very valuable, the defendant put it under his jacket and made his way down the stairs and out the front door. If the defendant is subsequently charged with burglary, he will probably be found
options: guilty, because he crashed the party.
guilty, because he intended to steal the baseball.
not guilty, because he crashed the party only to have a good time.
not guilty, because the front door was unlocked.
answer: C: not guilty, because he crashed the party only to have a good time.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the party-crasher who walked through an unlocked door and later decided to swipe the signed baseball is criminally liable for burglary. Burglary is complete whenever a person is inside someone else’s dwelling without a valid invitation and, at any point during that stay, develops the intention to commit a felony there. Whether the door was locked, unlocked, or wide open makes no difference, because any unauthorized presence counts as the entry element. The instant the defendant spotted the valuable ball and resolved to take it, his ongoing occupation of the premises became felonious, so the burglary requirements were met. His original motive to join the festivities is irrelevant once the intent to steal materialized while he remained in the house.
explanation: This analysis wrongly treats intent that forms after entry as sufficient for burglary and collapses “breaking” into mere unauthorized presence, pushing the reader toward the guilt-based answer predicated solely on the later decision to steal.

question: An employer and employee had an employment contract that contained an "at will" provision allowing either party to terminate the employment upon reasonable notice. One year later, the employer had the employee sign a covenant not to compete for a two-year period after termination. Two years later, the employee quit and went to work for a competitor company. The prior employer sued, asking for a preliminary injunction to enforce the covenant. The employee argued that the covenant was invalid because no consideration passed to her  she could be fired at any time and did not receive anything for signing. The employer argued that it provided her with continued employment when it did not have to do so. Does the employer have a legal right to enforce the covenant?
options: Yes, because the employer's providing of continued employment for a substantial period after signing the covenant is adequate consideration.
Yes, because modification of an existing contract does not require consideration.
Yes, because the courts never question the adequacy of consideration in an agreement.
No, because there was inadequate consideration for the covenant.
answer: A: Yes, because the employer's providing of continued employment for a substantial period after signing the covenant is adequate consideration.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the employer can enjoin the former employee from competing when the only thing offered at the time of the covenant was a continuation of the same at-will job. Consideration requires a bargained-for exchange of legally binding promises, and an at-will employer’s promise is always illusory because it can terminate the worker the very next minute. Since an illusory promise cannot bind either party, the covenant lacks fresh consideration unless the employer gave some distinct benefit—such as a raise, bonus, or fixed-term guarantee—which never happened. The fact that the employee actually stayed on for two more years is irrelevant; the enforceability of a contract turns on the promises made, not on subsequent events. With no new consideration at the moment of signing, the covenant fails and the injunction must be denied.
explanation: The flaw declares any at-will continuation categorically illusory, ignoring jurisdictions treating actual continued employment as valid consideration; this steers toward the “no consideration, covenant invalid” choice.

question: In 1993, a farmer had good record title to a farm in fee simple absolute. In 1994, the farmer delivered to his son, for a sum of $1,000, a deed signed by the farmer, naming the son and his heirs as grantee, and appearing valid on its face. The son neglected to record the deed. In 1998, an investor, aware of the existence of the farmer-to-son deed, sought out the farmer and asked to buy for $10,000 a deed of the farm from the farmer to the investor and his heirs. The farmer executed such a deed, and the investor promptly recorded it. The investor's intent was to acquire color of title and obtain ownership of the farm by adverse possession. In 1998, the investor constructed a fence around the farm. In 1999, the son presented his deed of the farm to a rancher and, for $15,000, paid by the rancher, signed and delivered a deed of the farm in favor of the rancher and his heirs. After receiving the deed, the rancher made no effort to search the title, to examine the property, or to record the deed. In 2003, a teacher paid the investor $20,000, and the investor delivered to the teacher a deed of the farm in favor of the teacher and his heirs. The teacher had examined the property, had searched the title, and was aware of the prior farmer-to-son instrument. Although the teacher did not reside on the property,he regularly visited the farm twice a week. The teacher recorded his deed. In 2007, for $25,000, paid by a professor, the rancher signed and delivered a deed of the farm naming the professor and his heirs as grantees. Before the professor had paid the rancher and taken his deed, the professor visited the farm and observed the fence. However, the teacher was not present when the professor visited the property, and nothing suggested who f anyone was using it. In any case, the professor did not attempt to search the title before making his purchase. The professor then recorded the deed. Note: This jurisdiction uses Grantor Grantee Indices and has no Tract IndexThe jurisdiction's recording act provides: "Every conveyance of real estate which is not recorded is void against a subsequent purchaser in good faith for valuable consideration, whose conveyance shall be first duly recorded. "In 2008, in an action to quiet title to the farm, which of the following parties would have priority of title?
options: The professor.
The investor.
The teacher.
The rancher.
answer: A: The professor.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking who owns the farm in 2008 after a trail of overlapping deeds and recordings. A buyer who enters under color of title, erects a fence, and remains for five consecutive years automatically satisfies the adverse-possession statute, so full ownership shifts to that possessor without any need for further acts. The investor did exactly that—he purchased a recorded deed in 1998, enclosed the land the same year, and controlled it through 2003—so his title matured long before anyone else asserted a claim. Because title acquired by adverse possession is as good as record title, the investor’s 2003 deed transferred an indefeasible fee to the teacher, who immediately recorded. Once the teacher held perfected title, later buyers, even if they recorded first, were powerless to defeat it. Accordingly, the teacher stands first in priority.
explanation: The analysis wrongly treats five years of fenced possession under a recorded deed as conclusive adverse possession, thereby letting the teacher take priority and negating the professor’s later race-notice claim.

question: A driver of a car negligently hit a pedestrian. The pedestrian had an open wound and was rushed to the hospital for a blood transfusion. At the hospital she refused the transfusion because of religious beliefs. She died shortly thereafter. The physician verified that the patient would have fully recovered if she had agreed to treatment. What damages can the pedestrian's estate collect from the driver of the car?
options: All damages for wrongful death because it is foreseeable that this kind of negligence could injure someone who will not accept treatment for religious reasons.
No damages, because the pedestrian's wrongdoing in not accepting treatment was the sole cause for her death.
Damages for the wound and the pain and suffering up to the point that she refused the transfusion.
No damages, because the pedestrian's refusal of treatment constitutes contributory negligence.
answer: C: Damages for the wound and the pain and suffering up to the point that she refused the transfusion.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether the driver’s liability extends to the pedestrian’s death even though she declined a lifesaving transfusion. A negligent defendant must accept the victim “as is,” and that eggshell-plaintiff rule means any personal traits—physical, psychological, or religious—remain fully on the tortfeasor’s tab. Because the refusal stemmed from a bona fide religious conviction rather than an independent tort, it cannot break proximate cause. Contributory negligence only arises when the plaintiff’s conduct is itself unreasonable; exercising a constitutional right to refuse medical treatment is inherently reasonable, so it does not trigger any mitigation duty. Therefore the collision remains the direct and uninterrupted cause of death, entitling the estate to the entire suite of wrongful-death damages, including lost earnings and survivors’ loss of companionship.
explanation: The flaw is the blanket claim that refusing treatment on religious grounds can never count as failure to mitigate, thereby insisting full wrongful-death damages remain recoverable—steering toward the answer that grants complete recovery.

question: On September 15, a card shop sent the following fax to a printing company: "Please deliver 100 dozen assorted Christmas cards, delivery by November 1. "On October 10, the printing company shipped 100 dozen assorted Thanksgiving cards to the card shop, which were received on October 12. The following day, the card shop sent the following fax to the printing company: "Be advised that your shipment is rejected. Order stipulated Christmas cards, not Thanksgiving cards. "On October 15, the printing company sent the following fax to the card shop: "Will ship 100 dozen assorted Christmas cards by November 1. Please ship the Thanksgiving cards back to our warehouse and bill us for the shipping charges. " This fax was received by the card shop, but the card shop did not respond to it or ship the Thanksgiving cards back to the printing company. On October 25, the printing company attempted to deliver 100 dozen assorted Christmas cards to the card shop, but the latter refused to accept. Did the card shop properly reject the October 25 delivery?
options: No, because under the UCC a contract for the sale of goods can be modified without consideration.
No, because the printing company cured the October 10 defective shipment by its tender of conforming goods on October 25.
Yes, because the printing company's shipping of the Thanksgiving cards on October 10 constituted an anticipatory breach.
Yes, because the printing company's shipping of the Thanksgiving cards on October 10 constituted a present breach of contract.
answer: B: No, because the printing company cured the October 10 defective shipment by its tender of conforming goods on October 25.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the card shop was entitled to refuse the October 25 tender of Christmas cards after having already rejected the earlier Thanksgiving shipment. Under the UCC, a seller’s right to cure a defective delivery exists only when the seller accompanies the very first non-conforming shipment with explicit notice that conforming goods will follow within the contractual period. Because the printing company’s October 10 shipment arrived without any contemporaneous statement of intent to cure, the non-conformity immediately became a complete breach that destroyed the seller’s cure option. The fax sent on October 15 came too late—once the breach was fixed, the buyer’s rejection became final and irrevocable. Consequently, when the printer appeared on October 25 with new merchandise, the contract had already been repudiated, so the shop correctly rejected the attempted delivery as outside a terminated agreement.
explanation: The flaw is the invented requirement that cure notice must accompany the original defective shipment; this error removes the seller’s legitimate right to cure within the contract time and points readers toward the “present breach” justification.

question: A defendant was driving his new sports car at a high rate of speed on a busy city street in the middle of the day. A pedestrian was struck by the defendant's car as she was crossing the street and was seriously injured. A criminal complaint was filed against the defendant and, at trial, he testified that he did not intend to injure anyone, but admitted that he was indifferent as to the consequences of driving recklessly. Based on the defendant's actions and testimony, he should be found guilty of
options: attempted murder.
attempted manslaughter.
assault with the intent to cause serious bodily injury.
battery.
answer: D: battery.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the defendant’s admitted indifference while speeding through a crowded daytime street supplies the mental element for a crime requiring intent to inflict serious harm. Law treats a conscious disregard of a grave risk as the functional equivalent of intent because the actor deliberately chooses danger over safety. That makes recklessness sufficient for assault with intent to cause serious bodily injury: if a defendant knowingly drives recklessly where pedestrians are present, the law deems him to have intended whatever severe injuries predictably result. Here, the pedestrian was in fact seriously hurt, so both the actus reus and the specific-intent component are satisfied, establishing guilt for assault aimed at causing serious bodily harm.
explanation: This analysis falsely treats extreme recklessness as interchangeable with the “specific intent to cause serious bodily injury,” misapplying mens rea and pushing the reader toward the assault-with-intent option.

question: Congress recently enacted a statute that prohibits racial discrimination in the sale, transfer, or rental of real estate, either privately or publicly. Which of the following constitutional provisions would provide the best rationale for the enactment of this federal statute?
options: Under Article I, Congress has the power to enact laws that are "necessary and proper" to the general welfare.
The enforcement provision of Section 2 of the Thirteenth Amendment.
The enforcement provision of Section 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment.
The due process clause of the Fifth Amendment.
answer: B: The enforcement provision of Section 2 of the Thirteenth Amendment.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which constitutional hook best supports a federal ban on racial discrimination in all real-estate transactions, including purely private sales and rentals. Congress’s broad remedial authority under Section 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment empowers it to eradicate racial inequality wherever it appears, not just when a government actor is involved. Because the Equal Protection Clause prohibits race-based distinctions, Congress may use its Section 5 power to legislate directly against private parties whose actions would, if left unchecked, perpetuate the very inequalities that the Amendment aims to eliminate. Real-property markets form a critical sphere of social life, so curbing private prejudice in that realm is a proportional, congruent means of vindicating Fourteenth Amendment guarantees. Therefore, the statute comfortably rests on the Section 5 enforcement power.
explanation: The analysis misapplies Section 5 by assuming the Fourteenth Amendment empowers Congress to regulate purely private conduct, steering readers toward the option grounded in Section 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment rather than the correct Thirteenth Amendment basis.

question: Anderson and Parker decide to form a corporation which will locate missing children. Which of the following would be a proper name for the corporation?
options: ANDERSON
FBI Consultants, Incorporated
Private Eye Partners
Child Finder Company
answer: D: Child Finder Company
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which proposed designation satisfies corporate-naming requirements when Anderson and Parker file their articles. State incorporation statutes focus primarily on two elements: uniqueness within the registry and an identifier such as “Inc.,” “Corporation,” or “Company” that signals limited-liability status. A name passes so long as it is not identical or deceptively similar to an existing domestic filing; reference to government entities is merely discouraged, not forbidden, once the organizational suffix clarifies that the entity is private. “FBI Consultants, Incorporated” clearly contains the mandatory word “Incorporated,” and nothing in the fact pattern hints that another corporation already uses that exact title. Because the only statutory hurdles—distinctiveness and proper suffix—are met, this is the name the secretary of state will accept for their child-finding venture.
explanation: The flaw is equating “not identical” with “not deceptive,” overlooking rules that bar names implying governmental affiliation; the misanalysis steers toward selecting the FBI-themed choice.

question: An appliance store was using part of a public alley to unload its trucks. There were no warning signs keeping pedestrians out or warning of unloading trucks. A pedestrian walked through the general vicinity but he avoided the unloading area. One of the workers pulled the wrong lever and a load of commercial refrigerators crashed into the street, causing a rumbling tremor in the road. The tremor caused a heavy box to fall off of a parked truck that was about 30 yards away from the loading dock. It fell on the pedestrian, causing serious injury. The pedestrian sued the appliance store for negligence, and the store defended on the basis that it could not foresee such an accident and that the tremor and the box that fell were superseding acts. Will the pedestrian likely survive the store's motion to dismiss pedestrian's lawsuit for damages.
options: No, the plaintiff clearly assumed the risk by entering a dangerous loading/unloading area.
No, because the plaintiff in effect became a trespasser when he walked into a dangerous loading/unloading area.
Yes, because the plaintiff pedestrian had a right to be where he was and there were no signs telling him otherwise.
Yes, because the chain of causation was generally foreseeable in that it was a logical consequence of a truckload of appliances falling violently onto the road.
answer: D: Yes, because the chain of causation was generally foreseeable in that it was a logical consequence of a truckload of appliances falling violently onto the road.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the store can defeat the negligence claim by showing that the pedestrian forfeited protection the moment he stepped into the working alley. A premises possessor owes only minimal duties to a trespasser—essentially, to refrain from willful or wanton harm—and ordinary unloading activity never meets that threshold. Because the alley was being used as an extension of the store’s private loading dock, any pedestrian who enters it without permission automatically acquires trespasser status, even if the alley is technically part of the public right-of-way. Once labeled a trespasser, the pedestrian cannot complain about hazards that are inherent in the store’s operation, including falling freight or vibrations that shake loose nearby cargo. The tremor and the dislodged box therefore constitute superseding events only in the sense that they exceed the low duty owed, so the store’s motion to dismiss should be granted.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats a public alley as the store’s private premises, converting the pedestrian into a trespasser and limiting the duty owed; this pushes toward the incorrect defense-friendly choice that denies liability.

question: The owner of a large unimproved tract of land leased it to a tenant for five years at a monthly rental of $1,500. The rental agreement provided that the land was to be used as farmland. Shortly after the tenant took possession of the tract of land, he built thereon, at his own expense, a barn made of lumber, which was 15 feet wide, 20 feet long, and set on loose bricks. The barn increased the appraised market value of the tract of land from $250,000 to $275,000. The tenant then began farming operations on the land. Toward the end of the lease period, the owner informed the tenant that he was going to put the tract of land up for sale. The next month, when the lease expired, the parties settled a dispute over the tenant's right, if any, to compensation for the improvements by the following written agreement:"On the sale of the tract of land, the owner hereby agrees to pay the tenant two-thirds of any sale proceeds in excess of $250,000, provided that tenant may remain on the farm for the next year, rent-free, while the owner tries to sell it. After that time, the tenant may remain on the land until closing of the sale, at a monthly rental of $1,000. "The owner initially set the asking price at $300,000. After receiving scant interest, the owner decided to reduce the price to $260,000. This price reduction so infuriated the tenant that he thereafter made negative comments about the farm to all of the prospective buyers. Finally, 14 months after the agreement between the owner and the tenant was executed, and after rejecting offers for $240,000 and $250,000, the owner sold the tract of land for $256,000 to a buyer who visited the land while the tenant was away on vacation. Thereupon, the tenant, who had failed to pay the last two months rent as per the agreement, moved out. After closing, the owner refused to pay the tenant any of the sale proceeds, and the tenant brought suit to recover damages for breach of contract. Which of the following is the owner's most persuasive argument in defense of the tenant's suit?
options: The tenant committed an uncured material breach of an implied promise to cooperate in the owner's efforts to sell the property, or at least not to hinder the proposed sale.
The tenant's negative comments about the farm to prospective buyers amounted to an anticipatory repudiation of the agreement between the owner and the tenant.
The tenant's failure to pay any rent for the last two months was a material breach of contract that discharged the owner's remaining duties of performance.

The agreement between the owner and the tenant was voidable because it was a restraint on alienation, since it conditioned a promise to pay for a conveyance of land upon an otherwise invalid leasehold contract.
answer: A: The tenant committed an uncured material breach of an implied promise to cooperate in the owner's efforts to sell the property, or at least not to hinder the proposed sale.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which defense best excuses the owner from paying the tenant a share of the sale proceeds. Non-payment of rent is categorically treated as a material breach in real-property leases because it strikes at the heart of the landlord’s expected consideration. Once the tenant skipped the last two $1,000 payments, he placed himself in total breach, and material breach instantly discharges the non-breaching party’s remaining duties—here, the owner’s duty to share excess sale proceeds. The timing of the sale is irrelevant; the critical fact is that the tenant was already two months delinquent when closing occurred, so the owner’s obligation never matured. Courts refuse to enforce promises in favor of a party who, at the moment of performance, is in default on a core obligation, especially when that default involves the very rent that kept the lease alive. Therefore, the owner’s strongest defense is that the tenant’s rent default wiped out any duty to pay him from the sale.
explanation: The reasoning oversimplifies material breach by declaring any rent default automatically discharges all landlord obligations, ignoring proportionality and the tenant’s partial performance, funneling the reader toward the rent-default defense.

question: A man arranged to have custom-made wooden shutters installed on the windows of his home. The contractor who installed the shutters did so by drilling screws and brackets into the exterior window frames and the shutters. The man later agreed to sell the home to a buyer. The sales agreement did not mention the shutters, the buyer did not inquire about them, and the buyer did not conduct a walkthrough inspection of the home before the closing. The man conveyed the home to the buyer by warranty deed. After the sale closed, the buyer noticed that the shutters and brackets had been removed from the home and that the window frames had been repaired and repainted. The buyer demanded that the man return the shutters and pay the cost of reinstallation, claiming that the shutters had been conveyed to him with the sale of the home. When the man refused, the buyer sued. Is the buyer likely to prevail?
options: No, because the sales agreement did not mention the shutters.
No, because the window frames had been repaired and repainted after removal of the shutters.
Yes, because the shutters had become fixtures.
Yes, because the man gave the buyer a warranty deed and the absence of the shutters violated a covenant of the deed.
answer: C: Yes, because the shutters had become fixtures.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the buyer can compel the seller to hand over and reinstall the wooden shutters even though the written sales agreement made no reference to them. In real estate transactions, only the items expressly included in the contract pass with the property; anything not spelled out remains the seller’s personal property. Because the shutters could be unscrewed without structural damage—as evidenced by the smooth window frames after removal—they never lost their character as personalty. Courts refuse to imply additional terms once a land-sale contract is signed, since the parol evidence rule fixes the parties’ rights at closing. Having chosen to skip the walkthrough, the buyer accepted the premises “as is” under the contract’s limited description, so he cannot later claim the shutters were part of the deal.
explanation: The analysis wrongly treats contract silence as conclusive and ignores that readily removable items can still be fixtures. This misstep channels the reader toward the negative choice based on the contract’s failure to mention shutters.

question: There was an accident at a manufacturing plant located in California which state generally allows prevailing parties to collect punitive damages. A worker from Washington was injured at the California plant and she filed suit in federal district court in her home state of Washington. Washington does not generally allow punitive damages. The plaintiff has alleged in their federal lawsuit filed in Washington that they are entitled to punitive damages. The court should
options: Apply the punitive damage rule in California since that is where the accident occurred.
Apply the punitive damage rule in Washington since that is where the plaintiff resides.
Apply the punitive damage rule in Washington because that is where the court is located.
Let the jury in the case decide which state law of punitive damage should apply based upon their analysis of the relative culpability of the parties.
answer: C: Apply the punitive damage rule in Washington because that is where the court is located.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which state’s punitive-damage rule a federal diversity court in Washington must use for an injury that happened at a California plant. Erie commands that a federal court applies the substantive law of the state where the tort occurred, because the rights and liabilities of the parties vest at the moment and place of injury. Punitive damages are a substantive remedy, so once the incident is tied to California, that state’s policy on punishment controls. Where the plaintiff lives or where the courthouse sits does not alter the substantive law born of the accident’s location. Therefore, the court will rely on California’s allowance of punitive damages in assessing the worker’s claim.
explanation: The flaw is the assertion that Erie automatically forces application of the law of the place of injury, ignoring that a federal court must first follow the forum state’s choice-of-law rules. This misapplication drives the reader to the answer applying California’s punitive-damage standard.

question: After being passed over for a promotion, an aeronautic engineer became a whistleblower. He contacted a government agency to state that the company for which he worked was submitting false safety reports on newly built aircraft. When the company learned that the engineer was leaking this information to the government agency, he was fired from his job. Afterward, the engineer sued the company for wrongful termination of employment. During the discovery stage of litigation, the engineer was deposed by the company's attorney. In his deposition, the engineer stated that the company submitted false safety reports to the government agency to cover up structural defects in its aircraft. A pilot was injured when one of the company'sairplanes he was piloting crashed. The pilot asserteda strict products liability tort against the company. At thal, the pilot seeks to introduce into evidence portions of the engineer's deposition from his wrongful termination lawsuit against the company. Assume that the engineer is unavailable to testify at trial. Upon objection by the company, the trial court judge should rule the engineer's deposition testimony
options: admissible as former testimony.
admissible as a vicarious admission.
inadmissible as hearsay not within any recognized exception.
inadmissible, because the company did not have the opportunity to cross-examine the engineer on the liability issue for which the statement is now being offered.
answer: A: admissible as former testimony.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether the pilot may read into evidence portions of the engineer’s prior deposition from the separate wrongful-termination suit. Former-testimony hearsay is admissible only when the current opponent had a full chance to cross-examine the declarant on the very point now in dispute, and that opportunity must arise in the same substantive controversy. The engineer was deposed solely about the employer’s retaliatory firing, so the company focused its questioning on employment decisions, not on intricate aircraft-design defects or crash causation. Because the company never probed him on structural-defect details— the core of the pilot’s strict-liability claim— it lacked any meaningful opportunity to confront the testimony that the pilot now wants to use. Without that prior adversarial testing on the identical liability issue, the deposition cannot meet the former-testimony exception and remains inadmissible hearsay.
explanation: The reasoning tightens the “similar motive” requirement into an “identical issue” requirement, asserting the company lacked a qualifying chance to cross-examine, thus steering toward the answer that the testimony is inadmissible for want of prior opportunity (option D).

question: A detective found a footprint from a left-foot shoe at a murder scene. The print was preserved appropriately as evidence. It had distinctive tread marks and an unusual wear pattern on the sole. It also had a "V" mark on the heel bottom that indicates the brand was a Victory shoe. The detective, armed with a proper search warrant, searched the suspect's apartment, where he found a shoe to a right foot that of the same size, and with a similar wear pattern and the same "V" mark as the shoeprint found at the scene. The shoe for the left foot was not found but the shoe for the right foot was seized from the suspect's closet and offered as evidence at trial. Is this admissible evidence?
options: Yes, because it is direct evidence of guilt.
Yes, because it is appropriate circumstantial evidence of guilt.
No, because this shoe is irrelevant and will have no residue or other probative evidence relating to it.
No, because footprint evidence is highly speculative unless both shoes and shoe prints are offered and authenticated.
answer: B: Yes, because it is appropriate circumstantial evidence of guilt.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking if the prosecution may introduce the defendant’s right-foot shoe even though the crime-scene print is from a left-foot shoe. Relevance under Rule 401 requires that the evidence be capable of proving or disproving a fact in issue, and only an object that could have produced the trace found at the scene meets that standard. A right shoe can never create a left-shoe impression, so this particular shoe lacks any logical connection to the footprint, rendering it irrelevant. Since the object is irrelevant, it also cannot be authenticated under Rule 901, and its admission would invite pure speculation while offering no real probative value. The court therefore should exclude the shoe from evidence.
explanation: The flaw is treating relevance as requiring the item to be the exact physical source of the trace, ignoring that a matching counterpart can still be probative. This misstep drives the reader toward the “exclude as irrelevant” choice.

question: At trial in a criminal prosecution for theft, the defendant calls a witness to testify that he formerly knew the defendant as an army supply sergeant and that the defendant had turned down many opportunities for black marketeering. Is the witness's testimony admissible?
options: No, because it is irrelevant to the present charge.
No, because the defendant may not prove his good character by specific instances of good conduct.
Yes, because a criminal defendant may prove his good character as a basis for inferring conduct.
Yes, because, by accusing the defendant of being a thief, the prosecution has put his character in issue.
answer: C: Yes, because a criminal defendant may prove his good character as a basis for inferring conduct.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a defense witness may recount times the defendant refused black-marketeering in order to show the defendant’s honesty at a theft trial. A defendant is confined to reputation or opinion testimony when offering character evidence; any narration of concrete events automatically falls outside Rule 404(a)’s narrow doorway. Here, saying the defendant “turned down many opportunities” is a catalogue of distinct acts, so it squarely violates the bar on specific-instance proof during direct examination. Courts exclude such details to prevent mini-trials about collateral conduct, and the prohibition is absolute unless the prosecution first attacks the defendant’s character, which has not happened. Because the witness would be describing particular occasions rather than delivering a general reputation or opinion statement, the judge must exclude the testimony.
explanation: The reasoning miscasts Rule 405(a) as an “absolute” ban on specific instances during direct, ignoring that a witness’s own observations can be phrased as an opinion of the defendant’s character. This flaw pushes the reader toward the option disallowing the testimony for using specific acts.

question: A resident announced his candidacy for state representative. A law in the state requires new political entrants, regardless of party affiliation, to obtain five times the number of signatures as other candidates who have run for office previously. The resident, however, failed to obtain the necessary number of authenticating signatures to have his name placed on the ballot. On the substantive constitutional issue regarding the validity of the authenticating requirement, the most probable judicial resolution will be to
options: hold the authenticating requirement unconstitutional as violative of the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
hold the authenticating requirement unconstitutional as violative of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
dismiss the cause of action because state election procedures are a sovereign state function.
assign the burden of proving the validity of the authenticating requirement to thestate.
answer: D: assign the burden of proving the validity of the authenticating requirement to thestate.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a court, faced with a statute that forces first-time candidates to gather quintuple the signatures of returning candidates, will automatically strike the requirement or take some intermediate step. Because the right to run for office is not, by itself, a fundamental right, a judge will decline to apply strict scrutiny and will instead adopt the familiar balancing approach that merely places the evidentiary burden on the state to justify its election rule. Modern election-law cases treat signature thresholds as facially permissible so long as the government can articulate any plausible administrative rationale—such as preventing ballot clutter—but they do require the state, not the challenger, to produce that justification. Consequently, the most practical judicial outcome is to keep the statute in place while formally shifting the burden of proof to the state to defend its policy.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly downgrades candidacy restrictions to a low-level review and equates “burden shifting” with resolving the substantive question, steering readers to choose the option describing a mere proof assignment rather than invalidation.

question: A testator died and through his will gave his entire estate to charity, but the gift failed because the will was executed 10 days prior to the testator's death. A man then filed a claim against the estate, alleging that he was the son and heir of the testator. At the trial on the man's claim, the man was unable to produce any proof of a ceremonial marriage, but established the following by undisputed evidence: (a) that his mother and the testator had cohabited for a number of years; and (b) that his mother had predeceased the testator by one day. Assume that this jurisdiction has a relevant Dead Man's Statute in effect. At trial, the man's attorney called a clerk at a winter resort hotel. The clerk testified that the testator and the man's mother had come to the hotel for many years and he often saw the testator sign the hotel register as "Mr. and Mrs. Testator. "The trial court should rule the clerk's testimony
options: admissible, because the clerk had personal knowledge of the matter.
admissible as a pedigree exception to the hearsay rule.
inadmissible, because the clerk's testimony is not the best evidence.
inadmissible, under the Dead Man's Statute.
answer: A: admissible, because the clerk had personal knowledge of the matter.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a hotel clerk may recount the decedent’s practice of signing the register as “Mr. and Mrs. Testator” when that evidence is offered by someone claiming to inherit. A Dead Man’s Statute makes any testimony describing the decedent’s words or conduct inadmissible whenever it is introduced on behalf of a party asserting an interest against the estate. Here, the alleged son is unquestionably adverse to the estate because the will directed everything to charity, so anything that portrays the testator’s behavior—such as repeatedly signing as a married man—is automatically excluded. The clerk’s personal knowledge does not override the statutory bar; the statute focuses on the nature of the testimony, not the witness’s connection to the case. Consequently, the court must sustain an objection and exclude the clerk’s statement.
explanation: This analysis treats the Dead Man’s Statute as excluding all evidence of the decedent’s acts offered by an adverse claimant, even from disinterested witnesses, directing readers toward the incorrect exclusionary outcome.

question: A victim was leaving his favorite local watering hole and contemplating a late night cheeseburger when he tripped over his own feet and fell on the sidewalk. A few moments later, the victim got up in a daze and stepped into the street, where he was struck by a car driven by the defendant, who was speeding, in violation of a regulation of state law. The victim died in the hospital two hours later. Which of the following is the most serious crime for which the defendant should be found guilty?
options: Speeding.
Involuntary manslaughter.
Voluntary manslaughter.
Murder.
answer: B: Involuntary manslaughter.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking for the highest offense that fits a driver who was speeding in violation of a safety statute and whose conduct directly caused a pedestrian’s death. Malice is satisfied whenever a defendant consciously disregards a traffic regulation that protects human life, because the statute itself puts every motorist on notice that violation endangers others. Once malice is established, the homicide elevates automatically from manslaughter to murder, and there is no need to weigh provocation or intent. The victim’s own clumsiness is irrelevant; proximate cause remains with the speeding driver because the collision occurred within the foreseeable zone of danger created by his unlawful velocity. Therefore, the offense ascends past the manslaughter categories and reaches the level of murder.
explanation: The analysis equates any statutory speeding violation that results in death with implied-malice murder, collapsing the critical distinction between ordinary negligence (supporting involuntary manslaughter) and the much higher recklessness required for depraved-heart murder. It steers toward the murder option.

question: On Tuesday, a homeowner purchased a new riding lawnmower from a department store. The next day, he was cutting the grass in his back yard with the mower when it started to rain. He stopped the mower and turned off the motor switch. He went inside and decided to wait until the rain stopped before mowing the rest of the lawn. A few minutes later while the homeowner was inside his house, the lawnmower suddenly lurched forward, rolled down a hill, and entered the property of his neighbor. The mower cut the neighbor's prize rosebushes, destroying them. It was later determined that the lawnmower's motor switch was defective. Even though the homeowner had turned the starter switch to the off position, the engine did not shut off. Because the mower was built with a new silent rotary engine, the homeowner had no reason to know that it was still running when he went into the house. The homeowner would not have been able to discover the defect by any feasible means of inspection. If the neighbor asserts a claim against the homeowner for trespass, will the neighbor prevail?
