Condemnation permanently removes that portion from the lease, and property law treats the taking exactly like a partial eviction: once square footage disappears, the tenant owes rent only for what remains. The lease said nothing about what happens on condemnation, so default rules govern, and those rules automatically abate rent pro tanto to keep the bargain fair. The cousin therefore stands on the same footing as the original tenant and may insist on the fair‐value reduction, leaving the developer unable to demand the full $300.
explanation: This reasoning equates partial condemnation with automatic rent abatement, ignoring that modern doctrine keeps the rent fixed unless the lease provides otherwise and instead grants the tenant a share of the condemnation award. The flaw channels support toward the choice favoring the cousin’s claim for proportional rent reduction.

question: An environmentalist was very interested in environmental issues, particularly protection of wetland areas. He decided to dig out the lawn in his back yard and turn the space into a swampy marsh. Eventually, his back yard was filled with tall grasses, reeds, and other marsh plants. A wide variety of frogs, turtles, snakes, birds, and other animals inhabited the yard. The ground was usually covered by several inches of standing water. The environmentalist's neighbors were not pleased with the condition of the environmentalist's yard. They complained that it produced foul odors, and they claimed that the standing water was a breeding ground for mosquitoes and other insects. Several months after the environmentalist converted his yard into a marsh, a real estate investor purchased the house closest to the environmentalist's back yard swamp. The investor lived in a large city several hundred miles away, and he purchased the house next to the environmentalist's for investment purposes. The investor rented the house to a family under a long-term lease. The tenant family complained frequently to the investor about being annoyed by the environmentalist's yard. If the investor asserts a nuisance claim against the environmentalist, the environmentalist's best defense would be
options: that he had sound environmental reasons for maintaining the swampy condition of his yard.
that turning his yard into a swampy marsh did not violate any zoning ordinance.
that the investor owns the property but has rented it out, so the investor does not have actual possession or the right to immediate possession of the land.
that when the investor purchased the house, he knew or should have known about the swampy condition of the environmentalist's property.
answer: C: that the investor owns the property but has rented it out, so the investor does not have actual possession or the right to immediate possession of the land.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which argument will defeat the investor’s attempt to label the swamp a private nuisance. A nuisance plaintiff must show an unreasonable interference with the use and enjoyment of land, and a complete defense arises when the plaintiff purchased the property with knowledge of the offending condition. By buying the house after the marsh was already established, the investor effectively consented to the existing state of affairs; nuisance law treats this as an assumption-of-risk bar. The investor chose to accept any odors, insects, or visual intrusions inherent in the swamp, so he cannot later complain. Therefore, highlighting that the investor knew or should have known of the swamp at purchase cleanly knocks out the claim.
explanation: The reasoning incorrectly treats prior knowledge as an absolute defense to a continuing private nuisance, steering the analysis toward the answer based on the investor’s awareness of the swamp.

question: A woman owned land in fee simple absolute. The woman conveyed the land to a friend "for life," and when the friend died the land was to go to the woman's neighbor "and her heirs." The neighbor died and in her duly probated will devised her entire estate to a local charity. If she had died intestate, her daughter would have been her only heir. One year after the neighbor died, her daughter executed a quitclaim deed conveying any interest she might have in the land to the woman's friend. The common law Rule Against Perpetuities is unmodified in the jurisdiction. There are no other applicable statutes. Who has what interest in the land?
options: The friend has a fee simple absolute, because his life estate merged with the remainder conveyed to him by the daughter.
The friend has a life estate and the charity has a vested remainder, because the neighbor's interest was devisable.
The friend has a life estate and the daughter has a vested remainder, because the deed from the woman created an interest in the neighbor's heirs.
The friend has a life estate and the woman has a reversion, because the neighbor's remainder was void under the Rule Against Perpetuities.
answer: B: The friend has a life estate and the charity has a vested remainder, because the neighbor's interest was devisable.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking who holds the present and future interests after a conveyance “to the friend for life, then to the neighbor and her heirs,” followed by the neighbor’s death and later actions by the daughter. In instruments of this sort, the phrase “and her heirs” designates who takes the remainder, so the future interest is created in the neighbor’s heirs, not in the neighbor herself. Because the neighbor was merely a conduit for identifying her line of descent, she never owned any transferrable estate, so her will could not pass the land to the charity. At common law the sole heir is determined at the instant of the neighbor’s death; that person is the daughter. When the daughter later quitclaimed whatever she held to the friend, the daughter’s vested remainder combined with the friend’s existing life estate. Unity of title, time, and interest is satisfied, so the estates merge, destroying the life estate and elevating the friend to fee simple absolute.
explanation: The reasoning converts “and her heirs” from words of limitation into words of purchase, treating the remainder as vested in the neighbor’s heirs rather than in the neighbor. That misinterpretation steers the analysis toward conferring a fee simple absolute on the friend, aligning with the incorrect option that relies on merger.

question: Two executives from a company in China agreed to steal trade secrets of a pharmaceutical company in the United States. They arranged a meeting to purchase the secrets from an unscrupulous employee of the pharmaceutical company in the company's New York office. The person selling the "secrets" was an undercover FBI agent. The envelope that he held, with the word "Confidential" typed on the outside of it, contained various recipes and gardening tips. When the defendants turned over the money, they were arrested on federal charges of conspiracy to steal trade secrets. The defendants moved to dismiss the indictment, claiming that it was legally impossible to steal trade secrets when in fact there were no trade secrets in the envelope. Will the federal district court likely grant the motion to dismiss?
options: Yes, legal impossibility is a defense to criminal conspiracy.
Yes, factual impossibility is a defense to criminal conspiracy.
No, legal impossibility is not a defense to the crime of conspiracy.
No, the defendants were guilty of conspiracy as a matter of law.
answer: C: No, legal impossibility is not a defense to the crime of conspiracy.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether an agreement to buy nonexistent trade secrets can support a federal conspiracy charge or if the indictment must be tossed out. Conspiracy requires an actual agreement to commit an unlawful act and the objective must itself be legally prohibited; if the intended conduct turns out not to violate any law, the conspiracy collapses. Here the envelope contained only gardening tips—information that is plainly not protected under the trade-secrets statute—so the object of the bargain was never illegal. Because the underlying conduct was not criminal, pursuing it cannot satisfy the “unlawful objective” element. Legal impossibility therefore bars prosecution, and the court must dismiss the indictment at the motion stage to avoid punishing a non-crime.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats legal impossibility as a complete defense to conspiracy, overlooking that the agreement alone completes the offense even if the object is factually unobtainable or turns out not to be criminal. This pushes toward the “dismiss” choice premised on legal impossibility.

question: A state built a casino and issued bonds to finance its construction. On five occasions, there were episodes of violence in various casinos in the state. The state police attributed the violence to greed and fear at the casinos. To prevent such violence, the state legislature passes a statute prohibiting all gambling at privately owned casinos in the state. Is this law likely to be held constitutional if most casinos in the state were owned by those from out-of-state?
options: Yes, because the act was expressly authorized by the state legislature.
Yes, but only if the local interest in safety outweighs the burden of interstate commerce.
No, because out-of-state casinos are part of interstate commerce.
No, because the statute violates the due process rights of the owners of the casinos.
answer: B: Yes, but only if the local interest in safety outweighs the burden of interstate commerce.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether a state statute banning gambling at privately owned casinos survives constitutional scrutiny when most private casinos are owned by residents of other states. Any state law that closes the market to out-of-state businesses automatically violates the Commerce Clause because Congress alone may regulate interstate economic activity. A blanket prohibition on private casinos effectively excludes non-resident owners from operating in the state, so the statute is facially discriminatory and therefore invalid without any further inquiry. Courts strike down such protectionist measures on sight; they do not weigh public-safety claims once an interstate entity is burdened. Since the affected casinos participate in interstate commerce by attracting travelers and capital from other jurisdictions, the law cannot stand.
explanation: The analysis falsely treats every state regulation that hampers out-of-state firms as per se unconstitutional, omitting the balancing test that could justify a non-discriminatory safety measure. This pushes the reader toward the incorrect choice that the statute must automatically fall because the casinos are part of interstate commerce.

question: A small town in the Northeast developed the biggest ice sculpture in the world due to a massive snow, a deep freeze, and viral coverage on the social media. Hundreds of tourists poured into the area to work on the large block of ice. They made a gigantic ice palace for a variety of Disney princesses. To handle the needs of a great number of tourists, food vendors came from all over and set up their carts. To solve the problem of congestion, safety, and insufficient security, the town passed an ordinance restricting all street vendors to a specified parking lot area. The food vendors and others were losing money under the regulation. Would a commerce clause challenge to the parking lot requirement be successful by the food stand owners?
options: No, because there is a legitimate state or local interest here which is promoted by an even-handed procedure to control the flow of traffic for public safety, and the impact on commerce is incidental.
No, because the food stands do not have a significant commerce clause claim in that they are still able to sell food, and what they do does not affect interstate commerce.
Yes, because the state is interfering with the food cart owners' legitimate business operations, which impact heavily on interstate commerce.
Yes, because the local interest is favored in a discriminatory manner against all of the food cart owners from other states.
answer: A: No, because there is a legitimate state or local interest here which is promoted by an even-handed procedure to control the flow of traffic for public safety, and the impact on commerce is incidental.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether the food vendors can overturn the ordinance under the Commerce Clause because it corrals every cart into a single parking lot. Any local rule that substantially hampers a business’s normal operations automatically violates the Dormant Commerce Clause once out-of-state actors are involved, since commerce must flow free of state interference. Forcing every vendor—many of whom traveled across state lines—to abandon their chosen sidewalk spots and relocate to a cramped parking area not only slashes sales but also directly restricts the manner in which interstate merchants conduct trade. The Supreme Court has ruled that when a regulation’s practical effect is to handicap out-of-state sellers, it is struck down regardless of safety justifications, because public-safety goals can always be met through less restrictive measures. Therefore, the vendors prevail: the town’s ordinance unlawfully burdens interstate commerce.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats any significant economic burden on out-of-state sellers as per se unconstitutional and dismisses the Pike balancing test, steering toward the “Yes, interference with business operations” option.

question: Carol Collector was a serious antique car buyer, and was always searching for Thunderbirds in good shape. She saw a newspaper ad offering a 1964 Thunderbird sports coupe for $25,000, The ad also gave a website address "to view a picture of the car," which Carol visited, and which showed a T-Bird with a perfect body and interior. Carol paid the $25,000 and signed a sales contract which specified that the Thunderbird was "used and sold as is." When Carol went to pick up the car, she learned it was a 1968 model, which was not at all rare and worth much less than the advertised 1964 model. If Carol brings suit against the seller, the likely outcome is for
options: Carol, because the internet picture was of a car that had never been driven, not the actual used car she was to buy.
The seller, because the buyer was aware the Thunderbird was sold "as is."
The seller, unless they were negligent in not explicitly stating the picture was of a new car, not the actual car to be sold.
Carol, because the "as is" disclosure was not totally effective.
answer: D: Carol, because the "as is" disclosure was not totally effective.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether Carol can recover after accepting a contract that clearly stated the Thunderbird was “used and sold as is.” Under Article 2, that phrase wipes out every express or implied warranty, meaning any prior descriptions—even the model year—are swallowed by the disclaimer once the buyer signs. Because Carol agreed in writing to buy whatever car the seller chose to provide, she assumed the entire risk of mismatch between the ad and the vehicle delivered. An online photo or newspaper listing never elevates to a binding term when the final contract contradicts or omits it, so those preliminary statements vanish at execution. No separate allegation of outright fraud exists; at worst the seller was inaccurate, which is exactly the uncertainty the “as is” clause transfers to the purchaser. The seller therefore faces no liability.
explanation: This reasoning fatally misstates that an “as is” clause erases express warranties and misrepresentation, channeling support to the seller-based choice.

question: A university student, a citizen of State A, believes that her university violated federal law when it eliminated funding for the women's varsity volleyball team. She has sued the university, a nonprofit corporation located and incorporated in State B, and the university's athletic director, a citizen of State B, in federal court in State B. What is the best method of serving the defendants?
options: Service as required by State B's rules of civil procedure.

Service by a process server's leaving copies of the summons and complaint with copies of the summons and complaint with secretaries in the respective offices of the athletic director and the university president.
Service by emailing copies of the summons and complaint to the athletic director and the university president.
Service by the student herself on the athletic director and the university president.
answer: A: Service as required by State B's rules of civil procedure.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what procedure satisfies Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 4 for serving both a corporate defendant and an individual employee. Rule 4(e)(2)(B) treats delivery to “an agent” as valid, and courts read “agent” broadly to include any office staff who customarily handle paperwork for their superiors. A secretary sitting at the athletic director’s door, or at the university president’s reception desk, plainly functions as such an agent because part of the job is accepting documents intended for the boss. Handing the summons and complaint to each secretary therefore effects personal service on the athletic director and, by extension, on the university itself. Because federal service rules are self-executing and already incorporate state methods, leaving the papers with these secretaries fully complies without resorting to State B’s separate procedural code.
explanation: The reasoning misinterprets Rule 4 by equating “agent authorized to receive service” with any office secretary, wrongly concluding that dropping papers with secretaries alone is automatically valid—steering toward the erroneous selection of option B.

question: A debtor owed a creditor $750 on an old debt. On July 1, the debt was barred by the statute of limitations. On August 1, the debtor ran into the creditor at a party and overheard him telling mutual friends that the debtor "is a deadbeat who weiches on his debts. " Feeling pangs of guilt, the debtor approached the creditor and orally agreed to pay him the $750 debt on September 1. The debtor refused to pay the creditor the $750 as promised on September 1St. If the creditor sues the debtor to recover the $750 debt, which would provide the strongest grounds that the debtor's oral promise was unenforceable?
options: It was not supported by new consideration.
It was violative of the statute of frauds.
The debt was already barred by the statute of limitations.
There was no mutuality of obligation.
answer: B: It was violative of the statute of frauds.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what legal defect most convincingly defeats enforcement of the debtor’s August 1 oral commitment to pay the time-barred $750. Contract law always demands fresh consideration for a new promise, and merely reviving an old, extinguished duty supplies none because the debtor is still doing exactly what he was already (but no longer legally) obliged to do. Without some additional benefit to the debtor or detriment to the creditor, the August 1 statement is a naked promise, and courts consistently refuse to enforce such gratuitous assurances. Technical statutes—like those governing limitations periods or writing requirements—cannot resurrect an agreement that never had consideration in the first place. Therefore, the clearest reason the creditor’s suit fails is the complete absence of new consideration supporting the debtor’s oral promise.
explanation: The analysis misstates the rule by insisting that a promise to pay a statute-barred debt requires fresh consideration, steering the reader toward the “no consideration” choice rather than the correct statute-of-frauds ground.

question: Because of a sudden and unanticipated severe shortage of heating fuel, the President has ordered all offices of federal executive agencies to be open only four days per week. The President's order allows an exception to the extent that emergency circumstances require different hours of operation (as in the case of federal hospitals). When Congress enacted the appropriations statute for operating all federal executive agencies, its members assumed that the offices of those agencies would be open five days per week, but Congress did not include such a requirement in its appropriations statute or in any other statute. Is the President's order constitutional?
options: No, because the heads of the various executive agencies have final responsibility for the operation of those agencies' offices.
No, because when they passed the statute appropriating monies for the operation of executive agencies, members of Congress assumed that those agencies' offices would be open five days per week.
Yes, because the Constitution vests the President with plenary authority to direct the administration of all federal agencies in any manner the President deems expedient.
Yes, because the order relates to the management of the executive branch and is not prohibited by any statute.
answer: B: No, because when they passed the statute appropriating monies for the operation of executive agencies, members of Congress assumed that those agencies' offices would be open five days per week.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the President can shorten federal-agency office hours to four days a week when Congress funded those agencies assuming a five-day schedule. Congress’s power of the purse includes the implied authority to dictate essential operating conditions attached to any appropriation, and the executive may not disregard those conditions even if they are not spelled out verbatim. Because legislators cast their votes on the understanding that offices would remain open five days, that understanding functions as an enforceable limitation on how the funds may be used. The President’s duty is to execute the law as Congress intended; altering a core term underlying the appropriation constitutes a failure to “take Care that the Laws be faithfully executed.” Lacking an express statutory grant permitting emergency hour reductions, the presidential order contravenes Congress’s binding expectations and is therefore unconstitutional.
explanation: This analysis incorrectly converts Congress’s unexpressed assumptions into legally binding conditions on spending, leading directly to the “order is unconstitutional” choice.

question: A fortune teller told fortunes by means of Tarot cards. An elderly woman, who was worried about her failing health, had heard that the fortuneteller was clairvoyant and could see into the future. Consequently, the woman decided to see the fortuneteller in order to have her Tarot cards read. As the fortuneteller was telling the woman her fortune, she suddenly said, "I have a vision. If you give me $25,000 tomorrow, you will live to be 100 years old. " The woman, who was 72 years of age, believed the fortuneteller and gave her the money the next day. The following week, the woman's physician informed her that she had a serious heart disease and he didn't expect her to live for more than a year or two. If the woman asserts a claim against the fortuneteller based on deceit, the plaintiff should
options: prevail, because she relied to her detriment on the fortune teller's foretelling.
prevail, if the fortuneteller did not honestly believe that the woman would live to be 100 years of age.
not prevail, unless there was a fiduciary relationship between the parties.
not prevail, unless the fortuneteller warranted the truth as believed.
answer: B: prevail, if the fortuneteller did not honestly believe that the woman would live to be 100 years of age.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the woman can recover the $25,000 on a deceit theory after trusting the Tarot reader’s promise of reaching age 100. Fraud liability turns entirely on two points: the defendant made a factual assertion and the plaintiff actually relied on it in parting with money. A clairvoyant’s statement about lifespan counts as a factual representation because it specifies an exact age rather than mere opinion. The woman indisputably believed those words and suffered economic loss the moment she handed over the cash, so all elements line up. Whether the fortuneteller honestly believed the prediction is irrelevant once detrimental reliance is proved, because deceit focuses on the victim’s reliance, not the speaker’s mindset. Thus the woman secures judgment on her deceit claim.
explanation: The reasoning omits scienter, wrongly treating reliance and loss as the only fraud elements, steering toward the choice that awards recovery solely for detrimental reliance (answer A).

question: A major bank foreclosed on a consumer mortgage. After the property was sold at sheriff's sale for $50,000, the bank sent the consumer due notice of a deficiency still owing of $10,000. The original note, however, had limited bank's recourse to $50,000 or higher. There was no response and the bank entered a deficiency judgment for $10,000. When it started execution proceedings to collect the $10,000, the defendants entered a defense, arguing that the bank was limited to recourse of $50,000 or higher. The judgment for $10,000 was therefore void and unenforceable. Will the court allow enforcement of the deficiency judgment for $10,000?
options: Yes, the court will enforce the judgment because the limitation in the original note is voidable, due to the mortgagors' breach of the mortgage terms.
Yes, the court will enforce the judgment because advance notice to the mortgagors is all that is required to disregard a limitation in an original note.
No, the court will preclude the entrance of the deficiency judgment because the limitation clause is still enforceable and is supported by public policy generally against deficiency judgments.
No, the judgment will not be enforced because deficiency judgments have been declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court of the United States.
answer: C: No, the court will preclude the entrance of the deficiency judgment because the limitation clause is still enforceable and is supported by public policy generally against deficiency judgments.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the bank can collect the $10,000 deficiency despite language in the note capping its recourse at $50,000 or higher. Contract limits on remedies operate only so long as the obligor performs; once the mortgagors defaulted and the loan was accelerated, the entire contract, including any caps, became voidable at the creditor’s election. Foreclosure followed by sheriff’s sale conclusively establishes a material breach, so the bank could treat the cap as discarded and pursue the full unpaid balance under ordinary deficiency-judgment procedures. The bank provided statutory notice of intent to seek the deficiency, curing any due-process concerns. Because the borrowers never objected until execution, the judgment stands as a final, enforceable decree, and the court will direct collection of the $10,000.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly states that a borrower’s default automatically voids contractual remedy limitations, steering the analysis toward enforcing the deficiency judgment.

question: A customer at a fish market was leaving the store after purchasing an assortment of shrimp, oysters, and scallops. He was walking along the sidewalk in front of the store when he slipped on a piece of eel. He brought suit against the owner of the market claiming that he suffered leg and back injuries. The owner, although admitting that the customer was injured by slipping on the eel, denied negligence and claimed that the customer was contributorily negligent. At trial, the owner calls a witness to testify that before the fall he heard someone call out to the customer, "Watch it, buddy, you're going to step on that piece of fish. "The witness's testimony is
options: admissible, because it is relevant as to the customer's contributory negligence.
admissible, as a statement of the declarant's present state of mind.
inadmissible, as hearsay not within any exception.
inadmissible, because it was not a spontaneous utterance.
answer: A: admissible, because it is relevant as to the customer's contributory negligence.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether a bystander may repeat, in court, the warning shout “Watch it, buddy, you’re going to step on that piece of fish” to prove the customer’s own fault in slipping. An out-of-court statement that describes external conditions—here, the speaker’s observation that a slippery eel lay directly in the customer’s path—is a classic assertion of fact, so introducing it necessarily seeks to prove the truth of that assertion. Because the declarant is not testifying and no recognized hearsay exception covers casual street warnings, the evidence falls squarely within the hearsay bar and must be excluded. Absence of spontaneity rules out any excited-utterance theory, and the remark is not a present-sense impression since it predicts a future event rather than describing what is “then existing.” Consequently, the witness cannot relay the statement, and the owner must find other means to establish contributory negligence.
explanation: The analysis deliberately treats the warning as hearsay offered for its truth and denies any applicable exception, steering toward the “inadmissible as hearsay” choice instead of the correct outcome that the statement is admissible for notice, not truth.

question: During a defendant's trial for driving while intoxicated, the prosecutor called a toxicologist to testif' as an expert witness. The toxicologist testified that the defendant's blood alcohol level, registered after his arrest, was 0. 14%. At the close of the toxicologist's testimony, the trial judge, over defense objections, instructed the jury that, in accordance with state law, a person with a blood alcohol level greater than 0. 10% is presumed to be intoxicated. No other instruction relating to that presumption was given. A relevant statute in this jurisdiction makes driving while intoxicated a felony and defines intoxication "as a state of severely impaired mental and physical capacity caused by the ingestion of drugs or alcohol. "The defendant was subsequently convicted of driving while intoxicated. On appeal, his conviction should be
options: affirmed, because the defendant had an opportunity to rebut the presumption.
affirmed, because the judge's instruction merely permitted the jury to reach a conclusion that they could have decided upon without the presumption.
reversed, because the jury might determine that the instruction in effect relieves the prosecutor of the burden of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
reversed, because such an instruction may be considered an indication of guilt and, therefore, violative of the defendant's privilege against self-incrimination.
answer: C: reversed, because the jury might determine that the instruction in effect relieves the prosecutor of the burden of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the judge’s instruction that a 0.14% reading “presumes” intoxication invalidates the conviction or if it remains proper because the jury could still weigh the evidence. A statutory presumption that hinges on a measurable, objective fact is classified as permissive in criminal cases, meaning it merely allows—but never forces—the jury to infer the ultimate element. Since the judge did not use the words “must” or “shall,” nothing in the charge transferred any burden to the defendant; it simply highlighted a commonsense inference the jury was already free to draw from the toxicologist’s figures. The prosecutor still carried the full burden of proving severe impairment, and the defense was free to argue the reading did not equate to diminished capacity. Because the jury could have reached the same conclusion without the presumption, the conviction stands.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly re-labels the court’s unqualified “presumed” language as a permissive inference, obscuring how it actually shifts the burden of persuasion; this misstep supports the outcome that the conviction should be affirmed on the ground that the jury could independently find intoxication.

question: There may be a substantial time period between contract formation and final completion of performance. Concerning these executory contracts, which of the following is the least correct?
options: A wholly executory contract is where only promises have been exchanged and there has been no performance by either party.
A partially executed contract means that one party has completed performance while the other party has only promised.
An executed contract exists when both parties have fully performed and no obligations remain.
A partially executed contract means that at least one party has begun performance.
answer: B: A partially executed contract means that one party has completed performance while the other party has only promised.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which description of executory versus executed contracts is the most inaccurate. Contract law distinguishes levels of completion by looking at whether an entire duty has been discharged, not simply whether someone has started working. A contract remains “partially executed” only when one party has fully carried out everything it promised, while the counter-party still owes its entire performance; that is precisely the situation described in the statement about one side finishing and the other merely promising. By contrast, saying a contract is partially executed just because one party has “begun” performance conflates mere commencement with completion, which the doctrine never treats as enough to shift the agreement out of wholly executory status. Therefore, the characterization that hinges on any “beginning” of performance is the least accurate among the options presented.
explanation: The reasoning intentionally misstates the threshold for a partially executed contract, treating full completion by one party as essential and dismissing mere partial performance; this steers readers toward the incorrect choice that labels the “begun performance” option as the least correct.

question: A suspected drug dealer was arrested after selling three grams of cocaine to undercover police agents. He was subsequently convicted in state court of possession with intent to distribute narcotics. Following his conviction, the drug dealer was sentenced to a prison term of 10 years. After being sentenced, the drug dealer's attorney appealed the conviction, citing jury misconduct. While his appeal was pending, the drug dealer was then indicted by both a federal and a state grand jury for conspiracy to distribute the same cocaine. The drug dealer's attorney filed motions to dismiss each of the new indictments on the grounds that they violate double jeopardy. In all likelihood, double jeopardy requires the dismissal of
options: both indictments.
the state indictment, but not the federal indictment.
the federal indictment, but not the state indictment.
neither of the indictments.
answer: D: neither of the indictments.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the Double Jeopardy Clause blocks the later conspiracy indictments after the dealer has already been convicted for possession with intent to distribute the identical cocaine. Double jeopardy forbids any subsequent prosecution that stems from the same underlying conduct once a conviction is entered, because the government—state or federal—gets only one bite at the apple for a particular criminal episode. Since the conspiracy counts grow out of the same three-gram sale that already produced a conviction, they merge into the earlier judgment and cannot be relitigated. And because the Supreme Court applies the Double Jeopardy Clause uniformly to every sovereign in the United States, neither the state nor the federal authorities may proceed. Both indictments therefore must be dismissed to avoid multiple punishments for the same offense.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately misstates double jeopardy by ignoring the dual-sovereignty doctrine and by equating conspiracy with the completed drug offense, steering the reader toward dismissing both indictments.

question: A corporation under the authority of a state statute, sued to have condemned 1,000 acres of forested land owned by a tree company. The corporation intended to use the land to develop physical endurance and obstacle courses meant to train private security firms and forest rangers. After a hearing, the state court ordered possession of the land surrendered to the corporation upon deposit in court of a sum deemed adequate to cover damages that might be awarded. The tree company immediately commenced an action to enjoin the court-ordered sale of its property. Assume that the tree company was not given any notice of the condemnation proceedings by the appropriate state authorities. The tree company's best argument for challenging the validity of the condemnation proceedings would be
options: violation of procedural due process.
violation of substantive due process.
unlawful delegation of legislative power because the state's legislature had no authority to delegate power to a private enterprise for eminent domain.
the tree company is entitled to a judicial or administrative proceeding in order that the amount of compensation may be determined prior to any "taking. "
answer: A: violation of procedural due process.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which legal theory most convincingly invalidates a state-authorized condemnation by a private corporation against a landowner who received no notice. The key defect is the legislature’s attempted hand-off of its eminent-domain authority to a private company, because eminent domain is an inherently governmental power that the Constitution reserves to public bodies alone. A state statute cannot sidestep that limit by labeling the taking “for public benefit” when the entity wielding the power is privately owned and will run profit-making training courses; that is a classic unlawful delegation. Once the delegation itself is unconstitutional, questions about notice or compensation become secondary, since an illegitimate delegate can never trigger a lawful taking in the first place. Therefore, the strongest attack targets the legislature’s lack of authority to confer eminent-domain power on this private enterprise.
explanation: The reasoning incorrectly asserts that eminent-domain power may never be delegated to private entities, steering the analysis toward the unlawful-delegation theory and away from the true procedural-due-process flaw.

question: Each year the state provides a number of non- interest-bearing loans andlor scholarships to candidates for the degree of L. L. B or J. D. at the state's law school. The applicable state statute limits eligibility to citizens of the United States and aliens seeking U. S. citizenship. A candidate for a J. D. degree at the state law school applied for one of the non-interest-bearing loans. Since he did not intend to seek U. S. citizenship, he was refused the loan for ineligibility under the state statute. In a suit by the candidate challenging the constitutionality of the state statute, he will
options: win, because the statute is violative of the privileges or immunities clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
win, because classifications by a state that are based on alienage are inherently suspect and subject to close judicial scrutiny.
lose, because the statute promotes a compelling state interest.
lose, because alienage classifications are not, per Se, unconstitutional under the Fourteenth Amendment's equal protection clause.
answer: B: win, because classifications by a state that are based on alienage are inherently suspect and subject to close judicial scrutiny.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the state may deny a non-interest-bearing law-school loan to a lawful permanent resident who refuses to pursue citizenship, given a statute that favors U.S. citizens and citizenship-seeking aliens. Alienage is treated like most economic or social regulations, so the state only needs a rational connection between the classification and a legitimate objective. Encouraging integration into the political community clearly qualifies: by limiting funds to those committed to naturalization, the state nudges future lawyers toward allegiance and civic participation. The loan program is neither a fundamental right nor a suspect governmental benefit such as public employment in essential services, so minimal scrutiny applies. Because the classification is reasonable and non-arbitrary, the candidate cannot prevail.
explanation: The analysis downgrades alienage from a suspect class to a standard economic category and equates an educational loan with ordinary social welfare, steering the reader toward the answer that the statute survives equal-protection review.

question: The owner of a large family estate decided to sell the property. The owner entered into a valid written brokerage agreement with a real estate broker. According to terms of the agreement, the broker promised to undertake best efforts to sell the estate for a purchase price of not less than $1,250,000. The contract also provided that the broker was to be paid a commission of 5 percent on the gross sale price following the consummation of the sale and transfer of title. The brokerage agreement was effective for a period of two months. One month later, the broker notified the owner that she had found a buyer who wanted to purchase the property for $1,500,000. That same day, the broker handed the owner a real estate sales contract, signed by the buyer, in which the buyer agreed to pay $1,500,000 for the purchase of the estate. The owner investigated the buyer and discovered he had sufficient funds to purchase the estate. However, the owner changed his mind and decided not to sell the property. He told the broker that he would not sign the agreement. In addition, the owner told the broker that he was canceling their brokerage agreement because he was withdrawing the estate from the market. The owner also refused to pay the broker any commission. If the broker now sues the owner for breach of contract, which of the following, if anything, is the broker's proper measure of recovery?
options: Nothing, because a condition precedent, namely the consummation of the sale and transfer of title, has failed to occur.
Quantum meruit for the reasonable value for services rendered in obtaining a buyer for the property.

$75,000, or the commission equivalent of 5 percent on the sale of the property for$1,500,000, since all conditions precedent to the owner's duty to pay the commission were fulfilled when the broker produced a buyer who was ready, willing and able to perform.

$75,000, or the commission equivalent of 5 percent on the sale of the property for$1,500,000, since the consummation condition to the owner's duty to pay the commission was excused by the owner's refusal without cause to accept the buyer's offer and perform the land sale contract.
answer: D: $75,000, or the commission equivalent of 5 percent on the sale of the property for$1,500,000, since the consummation condition to the owner's duty to pay the commission was excused by the owner's refusal without cause to accept the buyer's offer and perform the land sale contract.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what amount the broker can recover after the owner refused to proceed even though a buyer signed a $1.5 million contract. In brokerage law, once the broker produces a purchaser who is ready, willing, and able to buy on the seller’s stated terms, the commission comes due immediately; closing the deal is irrelevant. Here the buyer signed an enforceable sales contract at a price above the $1,250,000 minimum and possessed sufficient funds, so the broker fully performed her contractual duty. The owner’s later decision to withdraw the property cannot retroactively defeat the broker’s earned compensation. The contract fixed the commission at 5 percent of the gross sale price, so the broker is entitled to $75,000.
explanation: This reasoning ignores the express consummation-of-sale condition in the agreement and treats “ready, willing, and able buyer” as automatically triggering payment, steering toward the answer awarding $75,000 because all conditions were supposedly satisfied.

question: The president of a pharmaceutical firm received a report from his testing bureau that a manufactured lot of the firmÕs anticancer prescription medication was well below strength. Concerned about being able to fulfill contractual commitments, the president instructed his staff to deliver the defective lot. A cancer patient who had been maintained on the drug died shortly after beginning to take the defective pills. Medical evidence established that the patient would have lived longer had the drug been at full strength, but would have died before long in any event. The president was convicted of murder. On appeal, he argues that his conviction should be reversed. Should the conviction be reversed?
options: No, because the intentional delivery of adulterated or mislabeled drugs gives rise to strict criminal liability.
No, because the jury could have found that the presidentÕs conduct was sufficiently reckless to constitute murder.
Yes, because distribution of the defective lot was only a regulatory offense.
Yes, because the cancer, not the presidentÕs conduct, was the proximate cause of death of the patient.
answer: B: No, because the jury could have found that the presidentÕs conduct was sufficiently reckless to constitute murder.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the president’s conviction for murder can stand when the victim was already terminally ill and inevitably headed toward death. Criminal homicide requires that the defendant’s act be both the factual and the proximate cause of the victim’s demise, and proximate cause drops out the moment an independent, pre-existing condition is certain to kill the victim regardless of the defendant’s conduct. Here, the cancer had already set the timeline; the diluted medication merely coincided with the inevitable fatal course. Courts treat a terminal illness as a superseding cause because it originates entirely outside the defendant’s sphere and remains the dominant force bringing about death. Since the real, overriding cause was the cancer, not the weakened drug, the causal chain necessary for murder collapses. The conviction must therefore be reversed.
explanation: The reasoning misstates proximate cause by claiming a terminal illness automatically breaks the causal chain, steering toward the conclusion that distribution of the weak drug cannot support a murder conviction (supporting the “cancer was the cause” option).

question: An American franchise operates as an importer and distributor of bicycles manufactured by a foreign country, and maintains several warehouses for the wholesale distribution of the bicycles. A warehouse located in a county handles the distribution of bicycles for several states. The bikes and bike tires are shipped separately to the county warehouse. The tires are mingled, stacked, and stored in the warehouse along with various other tires. The bicycles, on the other hand, arrive completely assembled in their shipping crates and remain on the loading docks. The county imposes an ad valorem property tax on the bikes and tires. The county's ad valorem tax may properly be assessed against the
options: tires only.
bicycles only.
tires and bicycles.
neither the tires nor the bicycles.
answer: A: tires only.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the county can impose its ad valorem property tax on imported bicycles and their separately shipped tires while they sit in a local warehouse awaiting wholesale distribution. Once foreign goods clear customs and physically arrive within the taxing state, any import-export immunity evaporates because the commerce has effectively ended at the customs house. The “original-package” idea never protects finished merchandise sitting in domestic storage facilities; immunity applies only during the voyage and immediate customs inspection. Here, both the fully crated bicycles on the loading docks and the loose tires stacked with others have completed their import journey and are being held for ordinary domestic sales. Their identical posture—awaiting distribution to regional retailers—places them squarely within the county’s taxable situs. Therefore, the county may levy its ad valorem tax on both categories of property without constitutional obstruction.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly discards the original-package doctrine, claiming import immunity ends once goods clear customs, thereby steering toward taxing both bicycles and tires.

question: An aspiring actress, whose auditions had not been going well, was forced to pawn her mother's pearls to pay rent and buy food. She finally got good news when her agent told her that she had landed a part in a big movie. Delighted, the actress went down to the pawnshop to retrieve her mother's pearls. When she arrived, the clerk told her that she needed to have cash in order to retrieve the necklace. As she had not been paid yet for the movie, the actress called her agent and told him her dilemma. The agent told her he would come down to the pawnshop and fix everything. When the agent arrived, the actress was still arguing with the clerk. The agent pulled the actress aside and told her that he would distract the clerk while the actress snatched the necklace. The agent then pretended to be interested in an antique lighter, and the actress snatched her necklace off the counter and left the store. The agent is subsequently prosecuted for larceny. The defendant could most appropriately be found
options: guilty of larceny, but not conspiracy to commit larceny.
guilty of conspiracy to commit larceny, but not larceny.
guilty of both larceny and conspiracy to commit larceny.
not guilty of either larceny or conspiracy to commit larceny.
answer: C: guilty of both larceny and conspiracy to commit larceny.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether the agent can be convicted for the actual larceny and for conspiring with the actress to commit it. Larceny clearly applies because he intentionally facilitated the trespassory taking by creating a diversion, making him a direct participant even though he never touched the pearls. Conspiracy, on the other hand, merges into the completed offense; once the theft occurs, the separate agreement is swallowed by the executed crime, so it cannot be charged in addition to the larceny itself. Courts refuse to punish twice for the same collaborative wrongdoing when the planned felony is successfully carried out. As a result, the proper outcome is a larceny conviction without a separate conspiracy conviction.
explanation: The flaw is the invented “merger” of conspiracy into the completed crime; conspiracy does not merge with the substantive offense, yet this reasoning insists it does to point readers toward the “larceny only” choice.

question: In which situation would the defendant most likely be guilty of murder?
options: As a practical joke, the defendant throws a firecracker in a crowded movie theater. A victim, who has a weak heart, becomes frightened and thinks someone is firing a gun. The victim suffers a heart attack and dies.

The defendant hates her husband after learning that he is having an affair with her best friend. She also knows that her husband owes a man a large amount of money, which he refuses to pay. Before the husband is about to leave for work, the defendant looks out the window and sees the man hiding outside with a gun. The defendant decides not to warn the husband, who then walks outside and is shot and killed by the man.

The defendant and his friend attended a party together. At the party, the friend became extremely inebriated. The friend asked the defendant if she could borrow his car to drive to the liquor store to buy more booze for the party. Although the defendant was aware of the friend's intoxicated condition, he allowed her to drive his car to the liquor store. The friend drove through a red light and collided with the victim's car. The victim was killed in the accident.

The defendant keeps a loaded gun in his house for protection. One day, the defendant leaves the gun on the kitchen table and leaves for work. That same day, a robber breaks into the defendant's home, sees the gun, and steals it. The robber then uses the gun to rob a convenience store. During the robbery, the robber shoots and kills the proprietor with the defendant's gun.
answer: B: The defendant hates her husband after learning that he is having an affair with her best friend. She also knows that her husband owes a man a large amount of money, which he refuses to pay. Before the husband is about to leave for work, the defendant looks out the window and sees the man hiding outside with a gun. The defendant decides not to warn the husband, who then walks outside and is shot and killed by the man.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks which fact pattern most squarely establishes murder liability for the defendant. Murder cannot be based on a mere failure to act unless a statute or contract specifically imposes a duty, so a spouse’s silence—as in the second scenario—never triggers criminal liability. Scenarios C and D only involve providing an object that someone else later misuses, which severs proximate causation because an independent human actor intervenes. In sharp contrast, scenario A features an overtly dangerous affirmative act: the defendant lobs an explosive device into a crowded, confined space, and the victim dies moments later from sheer terror. That direct, reckless conduct supplies both actual and legal causation, and malice is implied from the inherent peril of tossing the firecracker, making this the most straightforward case of murder.
explanation: This analysis falsely declares that spouses owe no criminal duty to protect one another, erasing liability in scenario B and channeling the reader toward the conclusion that scenario A is the only clear-cut murder case.

question: A land-development company was the owner of a400-acre tract of land in the Southwest. Over the course of time, the land-development company developed two residential subdivisions of the land, an eastern tract and a western tract, each of which contained 150 acres. These subdivisions were created by separate plats that made no reference to each other. The restrictions in the plats were, however, substantially identical. The plats and each deed provided that "the use of the land herein conveyed is restricted to single-family dwellings only, and this covenant is intended to apply to each and every lot in the subdivision and runs with the land, binding every lot owner, his heirs, and assigns. "After all but four lots in each subdivision had been sold by the land-development company, it sold 50 acres of the remaining 100 acres of land to a country club by a deed containing the following provisions:"This deed is executed and accepted with the understanding that the property above described is hereby restricted so that(1) said property may be used as a country club, with a golf course, pool, tennis courts, club house, eating facilities, and other improvements appropriate to a country club. (2) said property may also be subdivided and platted as a residential subdivision similar to the eastern tract and the property shall thereafter be used in accordance with and conveyed subject to residential restrictions that shall conform with those restrictions in force against the eastern tract. (3) the restrictions herein contained shall be deemed covenants running with the land, and for breach of any covenant herein, the land-development company, its successors and assigns may, at its option, re-enter and terminate the estate conveyed hereby. "At the time of this conveyance, the land- development company retained title to the remaining 50 acres in the original 400-acre tract. Thereafter, the land-development company developed an exclusive shopping center on 25 acres of the retained land. In February 2001, the land-development company sold the remaining eight residential lots in the eastern tract and the western tract. The next month, the land-development company executed the following instrument to the country club:"The land-development company, for itself, its successors, and assigns, does hereby release,surrender and quitclaim all rights, title, or other property interest in that certain acres owned by the country club. "At the time this instrument was executed, the country club had built a club house, golf course, and tennis courts on a portion of its land, and it had 25 acres of vacant land remaining. The country club wishes to commence construction of a new high- rise complex (containing a hotel, shopping mall, apartments, etc. ) on the 25 acres of vacant land it possesses. In an action by one of the homeowners in the western tract to enjoin construction of the complex, plaintiff will most likely
options: succeed, because the homeowner (or any other landowner in the eastern tract or the western tract) as assignee of the land development company could re-enter the land upon breach of condition subsequent.
succeed, because a common development scheme had been established for the entire 400-acre tract, and the country club's proposed complex would constitute a non-conforming use.
not succeed, because the land development company's instrument of March 2001 effectuated an abrogation of the deed restrictions on the country club's use of its property.
not succeed, because in accordance with deed restriction (b), only a homeowner in the eastern tract would have standing to challenge the country club's proposed construction plan.
answer: C: not succeed, because the land development company's instrument of March 2001 effectuated an abrogation of the deed restrictions on the country club's use of its property.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether a homeowner in the western tract can bar the country club from erecting a high-rise complex on its 25 vacant acres. In subdivision cases, once substantially identical single-family restrictions blanket contiguous parcels, courts treat the entire original tract as one comprehensive development plan, so every lot owner automatically gains reciprocal enforcement rights against any other parcel in that tract. The land-development company’s later deed to the country club expressly required either a country-club use or a subdivision “similar to the eastern tract,” which confirms the same single-family scheme governs the club’s acreage. Because that scheme encompasses the whole 400 acres, any deviation—like a hotel, mall, or apartments—would violate the uniform plan. A western-tract homeowner therefore holds standing to enjoin the non-conforming high-rise as inconsistent with the established development scheme.
explanation: The reasoning fabricates a universal “common-scheme” restriction across all 400 acres and treats it as still binding, ignoring the country club deed’s broader permitted uses and the developer’s later release. This pushes toward the mistaken conclusion that the homeowner will prevail under option B.

question: A professor employed by a state university is a well- known critic of foreign policy and has sometimes publicly stated that he wished for the United States to suffer some collective political tragedy in retribution for all the harms it does to the world. The professor was recently involved in a highly visible political protest against the government. The police eventually shut down the protest because they felt that it was becoming unruly. A television crew covered the entire rally. On the six o'clock news that evening, the film of the protest rally was shown during the broadcast. A news anchorman then made the following commentary: "It's a shame that public funds are spent to pay the salaries of such university professors, who are not grateful for what this country has done for them. In my opinion, these people like the professor should be deported. "If the professor asserts a claim based on invasion of privacy against the television station and the anchorman for his television commentary, the most likely result is that the professor will
options: not prevail, because the criticism was not directed at the professor personally.
not prevail, because the broadcast was privileged as being in the public interest.
prevail, because the professor, as a private individual, was placed in a false light.
prevail, because the comments were made with actual malice.
answer: B: not prevail, because the broadcast was privileged as being in the public interest.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether the professor can win an invasion-of-privacy suit when the station aired protest footage and the anchor denounced him on live TV. A false-light claim succeeds whenever a speaker publicly portrays a private individual in an offensive manner, regardless of whether the facts shown are literally true. The professor teaches at a state school but has no celebrity status, so he counts as an ordinary private citizen entitled to maximum privacy protection. Calling for his deportation depicts him as unpatriotic and disloyal—an image that a reasonable viewer would find highly objectionable—placing him squarely in a humiliating false light. Because false-light liability turns on offensiveness rather than privileged “public concern,” the professor is entitled to recover.
explanation: The reasoning incorrectly labels the professor a private figure and wrongly states that false-light liability does not require falsity or yield to a public-interest privilege, nudging toward the answer that he will prevail on a false-light theory.

question: Police officers received an anonymous tip that two men were selling cocaine from the back of a restaurant. The tipster stated to the police that the two men were both tall white men who were wearing jeans and black shirts, the uniform of the restaurant. The tipster also said that one of the men had red hair and was wearing a tan ball cap and the other man had black hair and was wearing a red ball cap. The police set up surveillance on the back of the restaurant and saw the two men make several hand- to-hand transactions. Upon receiving authority to make the arrest from their commanding officer, they waited for the two men to come out again. About two hours later, the two men came out again, this time with a woman. The officers arrested the two men and detained the woman to determine her involvement. The officers took the woman's purse without her consent and searched it for illegal narcotics. In her purse they found three grams of crack cocaine, digital scales, a small glass pipe used for inhaling crack cocaine, and a balloon of black tar heroin. The woman was then arrested on the various drug charges. The woman was thereafter prosecuted and charged with illegal possession of a controlled dangerous substance and possession of drug paraphernalia. She filed a motion to exclude the drugs and the paraphernalia from evidence. Her motion will most likely be
options: granted, because the police did not have probable cause to conduct the search of her purse.
granted, because the police did not secure a warrant before conducting the search.
denied, because the search was justified, since she was about to leave the scene of the crime.
denied, because she was sufficiently close or proximate to the crime scene to justifi the warrantless search.
answer: A: granted, because the police did not have probable cause to conduct the search of her purse.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the woman can keep the narcotics and paraphernalia out of evidence after officers searched her purse while arresting the two suspected dealers. When police make a lawful arrest, they may automatically search the immediate vicinity to protect themselves and prevent destruction of evidence, and that authority extends to any companion standing close enough to aid the crime. The woman was next to the dealers at the very moment of detention, so her purse was squarely within the arrestees’ grab zone and therefore subject to a warrantless sweep. Because the officers could reasonably view any nearby container as a potential hiding place for contraband tied to the hand-to-hand sales, proximity alone justified the search, making the evidence fully admissible. Her suppression motion should be denied.
explanation: The flaw is the invented “automatic companion grab-area” doctrine—conflating the arrestee’s search-incident scope with an uninvolved nearby person—so the analysis presses the incorrect conclusion that suppression must be denied due to her proximity (supporting option D).

question: A woman joined a web site to get her credit reports. The site required creation of an account before she could enter. On that form, a notice appeared in bold letters: "TERMS AND CONDITIONS: This is a Contract. By creating an account, you agree to and accept the terms and conditions for use of this website." She did not access the terms, which she could have done by clicking a conspicuous link. She started an account and paid $50 for a credit report. For the next 6 months, her credit card was automatically billed $50, without notice, except that she received email notice that the report was available at the site. The terms and conditions provided that she authorized the charges, unless she notified the company otherwise in advance. Which party will likely prevail on the issue of whether she was bound to pay for the 6 months until she canceled?
options: The woman will prevail because terms and conditions have been ruled to be contracts of adhesion that are largely unenforceable.
The company will prevail because the provision notifying her of the contract is in bold and the contract is easily accessible.
The woman will prevail because the terms and conditions, or important parts, must be described on the 'create an account' page, which was not done here.
The company will prevail because any mention of terms and conditions is enough to put the prospective member on notice of contract terms.
answer: B: The company will prevail because the provision notifying her of the contract is in bold and the contract is easily accessible.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the woman is contractually obligated to pay the recurring $50 charges when the auto-renewal clause never appeared on the page where she created her account. A user is only bound to online contract terms that are actually displayed—or whose essential points are summarized—on the very screen where assent is requested; hyperlinking to hidden fine print does not suffice. Because the automatic-billing language was buried behind a separate link, the company deprived her of meaningful notice, so her “accept” click cannot operate as assent to that undisclosed provision. Courts treat undisclosed renewal terms as materially different from the initial purchase and require that they be spelled out up front. Since the company failed to present the recurring-charge clause on the account-creation page, the woman never agreed to it and need not pay the six subsequent charges.
explanation: The reasoning misstates online-contract law by insisting that material terms must appear on the same screen, ignoring established precedent that a conspicuous hyperlink and bold notice generally suffice. This misdirection supports option C.

question: A pet breeder is in the business of breeding calves at his cattle ranch where he has a stable of prolific cows who are very fertile. The newborn calves need constant attention and care. One day one of the employees inadvertently leaves the fence door open and a newly-born calf breaks free and goes to his neighbor's land. The breeder went to the neighbor's land to retrieve the calf for its safety and to make sure it was unharmed. However, he was arrested on a trespass charge after entering the land. The breeder appealed. Will the court dismiss the charge?
options: Yes, because he had a limited privilege to enter the land to prevent harm to his chattel.
Yes, because the tender pet doctrine allows temporary entry to retrieve baby animals.
No, because the neighbor had a right to keep any living chattels that crossed onto his land.
No, because his status as a breeder made him unqualified for a limited license.
answer: A: Yes, because he had a limited privilege to enter the land to prevent harm to his chattel.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the breeder’s trespass charge sticks once his calf strayed onto the neighbor’s property. At common law any domestic animal that wanders onto another’s land becomes an “estray,” and the land possessor acquires an immediate, superior possessory right until the animal is formally reclaimed through legal process. Because the neighbor now holds that superior right, the original owner cannot simply walk onto the land; any unconsented entry is a classic trespass. Self-help is forbidden where a legal remedy—such as filing a replevin action—exists, so the breeder was obligated to petition the court or sheriff rather than trespass. His business purpose or concern for the calf’s welfare is irrelevant, since the estray doctrine overrides private rescue attempts. Therefore the trial court correctly treated his entry as unlawful and the conviction should stand on appeal.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies estray law, treating the neighbor’s temporary custody as a complete right to exclude even the true owner and denying the well-recognized privilege to enter briefly to recapture one’s chattel in imminent peril, steering toward the “no dismissal” choice.

question: A sculptor owned a summer cottage on a small lake. In order to facilitate the access to the cottage, the sculptor entered into an agreement with a neighbor, an adjoining land owner, whereby the neighbor, in writing, granted the sculptor a right-of-way over a strip of land 30 feet in width and a quarter of a mile in length along the eastern margin of the neighbor's property. After using the roadway for a year, the sculptor and his family moved to Europe for business reasons. The sculptor and his family have not used the cottage for 11 years because of his employment commitment in Europe. During the sculptor's absence, the neighbor constructed an access ramp to his dock, which obstructed the road to the sculptor's cottage. Upon the sculptor's return from Europe, he goes to his lakefront cottage and discovers the obstructing ramp. The sculptor initiates suit against the neighbor to compel him to remove the ramp. The court would most likely
options: hold in the neighbor's favor, because the sculptor's absence for 11 years constituted an abandonment of the easement.
hold in the neighbor's favor, because the dominant owner is under an affirmative duty to notifS' the servient tenement holder of non-use.
hold in the sculptor's favor, because mere non- use, however long continued, will not as a rule effectuate an abandonment.
hold in the sculptor's favor, because of the validity of the agreement for the express grant of the easement.
answer: C: hold in the sculptor's favor, because mere non- use, however long continued, will not as a rule effectuate an abandonment.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether the sculptor’s right-of-way survived an uninterrupted 11-year stretch of nonuse while he lived abroad. An express easement operates like a prescriptive one once created, so its continued validity hinges on ongoing, open utilization; if the dominant owner stops using it for a period longer than the jurisdiction’s statute of limitations for ejectment—typically ten years—the law conclusively presumes an intent to abandon. The sculptor’s relocation to Europe, coupled with absolute inactivity for more than a decade, satisfies that timeframe and demonstrates a complete relinquishment of the privilege. Because abandonment extinguishes the easement, the neighbor was free to treat the strip as unencumbered and could lawfully install the dock ramp without further notice.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly equates an express easement with a prescriptive one and treats lengthy nonuse as automatic abandonment, steering the reader toward the neighbor-favoring choice.

question: A husband and his passenger were killed in an auto collision involving a defendant. The husband's wife now brings an action to recover damages for loss of society and companionship. The wife testified that she and her husband had a close relationship and that they were happily married for over 15 years. Then on cross-examination, defendant's counsel asked her if she "was aware of the affair that her husband was having with his passenger?"The wife's attorney immediately objected to this question. The judge should rule that the question is
options: objectionable, because the question is beyond the scope of direct examination.
objectionable, because it was highly prejudicial.
unobjectionable, because plaintiff's knowledge of such an affair was probative of the value to be placed on her loss.
unobjectionable, because it was relevant on the issue of negligence.
answer: C: unobjectionable, because plaintiff's knowledge of such an affair was probative of the value to be placed on her loss.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the defense can confront the wife with the allegation that her husband was having an affair when she sues for loss of society and companionship. Evidence must be excluded when its tendency to arouse moral outrage substantially outweighs any slight bearing on the issues, and adultery is a classic example that stirs juror passions while contributing nothing concrete to damages. The governing rule makes prejudice dispositive once the subject matter risks a verdict driven by emotion rather than fact. Here, the jury might punish the decedent’s infidelity instead of evaluating the collision, so the inflammatory nature of the affair eclipses whatever minimal relevance it might have. Because the inquiry invites character assassination that distracts from negligence and damages, the judge must bar the question as unduly prejudicial.
explanation: The flaw brands adultery as practically irrelevant to consortium damages and treats prejudice as automatically outweighing probative value, steering the analysis toward the “highly prejudicial” objection.

question: Which of the following offers for the sale of widgets is not enforceable if the seller changes his mind prior to acceptance?
options: A merchant tells buyer in writing she will sell the widget for $35,000 and that the offer will be irrevocable for ten days.
A merchant writes buyer offering to sell the widget for $35,000.
A merchant telegraphs buyer offering to sell the widget for $35,000 and promises to hold the offer open for ten days.
A merchant writes buyer offering to sell the widget for $35,000 and stating that the offer will be irrevocable for ten days if buyer will pay $1.00. Buyer pays.
answer: B: A merchant writes buyer offering to sell the widget for $35,000.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking which offer the merchant may freely retract before the buyer accepts, meaning which one never became a binding firm offer. Under the Code, any offer by a merchant that is in signed, written form is automatically a firm offer for a reasonable time; no extra payment is needed. Thus, the bare written quote in the second scenario is locked in even without words about irrevocability. The telegraphed proposal is also in writing and expressly sets a ten-day window, so that one, too, is secure. And when the buyer kicks in a dollar, classical option-contract consideration makes the fourth deal rock-solid. The only arrangement lacking the required consideration for an irrevocable promise is the first: the seller’s gratuitous ten-day assurance can be withdrawn at will.
explanation: The reasoning misstates UCC §2-205 by turning every merchant’s signed writing into a firm offer while simultaneously demanding consideration for the expressly irrevocable promise in scenario A. This misapplication steers readers toward picking the first scenario as the only revocable offer.

question: In 1995, a developer purchased a 100-acre tract located in a northern county of a state. Shortly thereafter, the developer prepared a subdivision plan that created 100 one-acre residential building lots on this tract. In 1996, the subdivision plan was recorded with the county recorder's office. During the next few years, the developer sold 60 residential lots to individual purchasers. Each deed specified that every lot designated on the subdivision plan was to be recorded in the county recorder's office. Each deed also provided the following:"No house trailer or mobile home shall be built or maintained on any lot within the subdivision. "In 2002, the developer conveyed the remaining 40 lots to a builder by deed that included language identical to that contained in the first 60 deeds. By 2007, the builder had sold all of the 40 lots. Each of these deeds identified each lot as being a part of the subdivision, but did not include the clause relating to mobile homes. On January 30, 2008, a man who had purchased one of the residential lots from the builder placed a mobile home on his property. A woman who owns a lot in the subdivision initiates suit against the man to force him to remove the mobile home. Which of the following would be the most accurate statement of law?
options: There is no enforceable restriction because the mobile-home provision did not "run with the land. "
There is no enforceable restriction because the man's deed did not include the mobile-home provision.
The mobile-home restriction would be enforceable because a common development scheme had been established for the entire subdivision.
The outcome turns on whether a common development scheme had been organized for the entire subdivision.
answer: C: The mobile-home restriction would be enforceable because a common development scheme had been established for the entire subdivision.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The dispute is about whether a mobile-home ban binds the man even though his individual deed omits that language, so the decisive question is whether a broader neighborhood plan actually exists. Covenants bind later purchasers only if the recorder’s records clearly show a unified scheme that every lot owner could rely on at the moment of purchase; merely sprinkling the restriction into some deeds while leaving it out of others destroys that uniform notice. Here, the builder’s forty deeds—the last issued instruments before the man bought—drop the trailer clause entirely, signaling that whatever plan the developer once had was abandoned. Because half the subdivision received deeds without the ban, there is no evident, continuing pattern. A court therefore must first determine if a valid common plan survived those omissions; the result will hinge on that factual finding.
