explanation: The reasoning ignores that the recorded subdivision map and earlier deeds themselves supply constructive notice, insisting instead that later omissions negate the scheme. This steers the reader toward the answer focusing on the “whether” of a common development scheme rather than its already-established existence.

question: A widower had three children: one was unmarried and the other two were married with children. When he became chronically ill and could not care for himself, his unmarried daughter moved into his home to take care of him. As time went on, the widower became senile, lost touch with reality, and required continuous care. When that happened, the caretaking daughter made out a deed to herself as grantee and had him sign as grantor. He was not aware of what he was doing when he signed it. After the widower died, the two married children sued to have the deed set aside for mental incompetence. Assuming they can prove the foregoing allegations, will the court likely strike down the deed?
options: No, because the caretaking daughter had a right to the property in return for all of the work that she performed.
No, because every deed is strongly presumed to be valid when signed.
Yes, because he did not have the mental capacity to understand the nature of his act or the meaning of the legal instrument he signed.a
Yes, because it was obtained by mutual mistake.
answer: C: Yes, because he did not have the mental capacity to understand the nature of his act or the meaning of the legal instrument he signed.a
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a deed executed by a senile father in favor of the daughter who nursed him will be invalidated. Mental incapacity voids a conveyance only when the grantee gives no meaningful consideration, because the core purpose of the competency rule is to prevent exploitation without compensation. Here the daughter supplied continuous, round-the-clock care—services readily recognized as valuable consideration—so the deed rests on a legitimate exchange rather than on sheer donative intent. Courts consistently uphold conveyances supported by fair consideration, even if the grantor lacked full lucidity, since equity will not unwind a bargained-for transfer that compensates the caregiver. Thus the two married children cannot upset the deed merely by proving their father’s diminished awareness; the caretaking daughter earned the property through her labor.
explanation: The reasoning falsely treats adequate consideration as curing total mental incompetence, steering toward the answer that the deed stands because the daughter “had a right” to the property (option A).

question: A farmer owned a piece of land on which he grew strawberries. Over the years, the farmer had earned a reputation for growing strawberries that were extremely sweet and juicy. For that reason, consumers always looked forward to strawberry season, when the farmer's strawberries would be available. Hoping to capitalize on the farmer's reputation, a produce retailer who operated three stores in the area contacted the farmer about the possibility of carrying the farmer's strawberries in his stores. After lengthy negotiations, the parties executed the following written agreement:"The farmer will supply the retailer with all of its needs of strawberries from April through July each year for the next three years. The retailer will pay $5. 00 per bushel of strawberries delivered. "On April 1 of the first year of the contract, the retailer submitted an order for 75 bushels of strawberries. Upon receiving the order, the farmer sent the retailer the following fax:"Your order was way more than I anticipated. If! sent you that many strawberries I would not have enough for my other customers. I can send you 50 bushels, but no more. "The retailer then notified the farmer that if he did not deliver all 75 bushels, the retailer would sue him for breach of contract. The agreement entered into between the farmer and the retailer would best be described as a (an)
options: illusory contract.
best efforts contract.
requirements contract.
aleatory contract.
answer: C: requirements contract.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what type of contract the farmer and the retailer created by agreeing that the farmer will supply all of the retailer’s strawberry needs for three seasons at a fixed price. A provision obligating a supplier to keep a buyer fully stocked necessarily requires the supplier to exercise diligent, good-faith performance, so the heart of the arrangement is an undertaking of best efforts. Because the buyer promises only to order strawberries as its business demands, consideration stems chiefly from the farmer’s pledge to work industriously; the contract’s enforceability turns on the implied obligation that the farmer employ every reasonable means to meet whatever quantity the retailer in good faith requests. By refusing to deliver 75 bushels, the farmer violated this core duty to exert his best efforts to satisfy the retailer’s needs.
explanation: The reasoning misidentifies a requirements contract as a best efforts contract by treating the supplier’s implied duty of diligence as the contract’s defining characteristic, steering toward the incorrect answer that labels the agreement “best efforts.”

question: Following their law school graduation party, a graduate and his roommate were driving home in an automobile that was owned and operated by the graduate. As they were approaching an intersection, their vehicle collided with a motorcycle whose rider was seriously injured in the accident. The rider sued the graduate for operating his motor vehicle in excess of the speed limit. In addition, the roommate brought suit against the rider for operating his motorcycle negligently and driving through a red light. The roommate subsequently reached an out- of-court settlement with the graduate and dismissed the lawsuit against him. At trial against the rider, the roommate testified that he observed the rider drive his motorcycle through a red light and then swerve into the path of the graduate's automobile. In rebuttal, the rider offered into evidence the roommate's complaint against the graduate alleging that the latter was driving "at an excessively high rate of speed at the time the accident occurred. "The complaint is
options: admissible as an admission.
admissible as a declaration against interest.
admissible under the former testimony exception to the hearsay rule.
inadmissible, because the suit was dismissed as part of a compromise.
answer: A: admissible as an admission.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the rider may introduce the roommate’s earlier complaint against the graduate—specifically the allegation of “excessively high speed”—to contradict the roommate’s present testimony that the rider alone caused the crash. Evidence that originates from a pleading later withdrawn pursuant to a settlement is barred, because Rule 408 excludes not merely the negotiations themselves but all statements that are part of, or ultimately folded into, the compromise. Once the roommate dismissed his claim against the graduate in exchange for an out-of-court settlement, every allegation in that pleading became part of the compromise package and can no longer be used to prove liability or impeach credibility. The policy is to encourage settlements by insulating any statements connected with them from later use at trial. Therefore the complaint must be kept from the jury.
explanation: The flaw is the sweeping misapplication of Rule 408, treating an ordinary pleading as a “settlement statement” automatically shielded once the case settles; this misstep drives the analysis toward inadmissibility, aligning with the incorrect “compromise” answer.

question: A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should
options: affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.
reverse the conviction because he was denied the right to a non-jury trial, but not the reimbursement order.
reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
answer: D: reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the judge properly refused the defendant’s request to act as his own lawyer and whether the state can later charge him for the appointed attorney. A defendant may represent himself only after showing both a knowing waiver of counsel and a basic ability to conduct the defense; courts routinely deny self-representation when an accused admits having no legal training or trial experience. Once the judge concluded the defendant lacked that minimal competence, appointing counsel was mandatory and the ensuing jury trial remained valid. The reimbursement statute, though, conflicts with the constitutional guarantee of free counsel for indigent defendants, so forcing repayment defeats the very purpose of appointment. Therefore, the conviction stands, yet the financial order cannot.
explanation: The flaw is that it treats lack of legal training as a sufficient basis to deny self-representation, ignoring that Faretta requires courts to honor a voluntary, competent waiver even if the defendant is inexperienced. This pushes toward the incorrect outcome in which the conviction is affirmed but the reimbursement order is vacated (option B).

question: A resident in an exclusive residential area is a marine biologist. To aid in his study of sharks, he had a large tank built in his backyard in which he placed a great white shark. Aside from a smell that emanated from the tank, some neighbors were concerned and afraid to let their children outside for fear that they would wander onto the resident's property. In order to convince his neighbors that they had nothing to fear, the resident invited them over to view the shark tank. While a neighbor was standing near the tank, the shark splashed its tail, and the neighbor got very wet. The neighbor, who had a cold, developed bronchitis. If the neighbor sues the resident for damages incurred from being drenched by the shark and bases her suit on strict liability, she will most likely
options: recover, because the possessor of wild animals is strictly liable for all injuries caused to others by the animals.
recover, because the smell from the shark tank was a nuisance.
not recover, because she suffered injury only because she had a cold and, therefore, was unusually vulnerable to harm from being splashed with water.
not recover, because she did not suffer the type of harm normally inflicted by a shark.
answer: D: not recover, because she did not suffer the type of harm normally inflicted by a shark.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the biologist is strictly liable when his great white shark’s tail splash soaks a neighbor, triggering bronchitis. Strict liability for wild animals imposes responsibility for every consequence that flows from the animal’s direct act, without distinguishing between bite wounds, scratches, or collateral effects like flying water. Once the neighbor shows the shark’s movement caused the drenching, causation and duty are established; the keeper of a wild animal cannot escape by claiming the harm was unusual or minor. Contributory factors such as the neighbor’s pre-existing cold are irrelevant under strict liability, because the doctrine ignores the victim’s special susceptibilities and focuses solely on the animal’s role. The odor in the neighborhood is legally immaterial to this claim, since nuisance and strict liability are separate theories. Therefore, the biologist must pay for the bronchitis that resulted from the shark-generated splash.
explanation: This reasoning stretches strict liability for wild animals to cover any injury physically traceable to the animal, omitting the requirement that the harm stem from the creature’s dangerous propensities. It guides the reader toward the recovery outcome reflected in option A.

question: While walking across the street one afternoon, a pedestrian was hit by a car and thrown down in the middle of the intersection. The driver of the vehicle did not stop. Although he never lost consciousness, the pedestrian was in excruciating pain and has been taking strong painkillers since the accident that have affected his memory of the accident. At trial, the pedestrian calls a renowned hypnotist to testify. The hypnotist proposes to testify that after he placed the pedestrian under a hypnotic spell, the pedestrian gave a detailed account of the accident and told the hypnotist that the driver ran a red light and that the driver's license plate number was GIJO-7 14. The driver concedes that his license plate number isGIJO-7 14. The hypnotist's proposed testimony will most likely be held to be
options: admissible, because the license plate identification substantiates that the other information is accurate and trustworthy.
admissible, because it is a statement of past recollection refreshed.
inadmissible, because it is hearsay not within any recognized exception.
inadmissible, because statements procured through hypnosis cannot be authenticated as truthful.
answer: C: inadmissible, because it is hearsay not within any recognized exception.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether the hypnotist can relay the pedestrian’s trance-induced narrative pinpointing the red-light violation and the precise license plate. Evidence must first be authenticated, meaning the proponent proves that what the witness offers truly reflects reality; when a technique is inherently unreliable, that foundational step collapses. Courts uniformly rank hypnosis alongside polygraphs as scientifically dubious, so anything retrieved under hypnosis fails authentication on its face. Because no amount of corroboration—such as the matching license plate—can cure the core unreliability of hypnotically “recovered” memory, the entire account is inadmissible. The trial judge will exclude the hypnotist’s testimony for want of authentic, trustworthy content.
explanation: The flaw shifts the admissibility inquiry from hearsay to authentication, treating hypnosis as automatically unreliable and steering readers toward the option focusing on truthfulness rather than the hearsay bar.

question: A female employee was fired as an executive assistant at a time when she was seven months pregnant. She brought a Title VII civil rights action in federal court for gender discrimination against the employer. At trial, a former co-worker of the woman was not allowed to testify that she heard the human relations manager saying in an informal meeting that the plaintiff and her predecessor were both fired due to what the manager described as "pregnancy complications." The proposed witness had been a vice-president of the company and a close adviser to the president. Without the benefit of that vital testimony, the jury entered a verdict for the defendant employer. On appeal, the plaintiff argued that the testimony should have been allowed and that it was not hearsay under the federal rules. Will the court likely grant the appeal, and order a new trial?
options: No, because the statement is clearly hearsay with no exception to the hearsay rule being applicable.
No, because it was based on things that the co-worker heard from others, making double-hearsay that is never admissible.
Yes, because that kind of testimony is reliable and not excludable as hearsay.
Yes, because it was admissible under the "spontaneous utterance" exception to the hearsay rules.
answer: C: Yes, because that kind of testimony is reliable and not excludable as hearsay.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the employee can win a new trial based on the trial court’s refusal to let a former vice-president repeat the HR manager’s remark that the plaintiff was fired for “pregnancy complications.” An out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted is classic hearsay, and unless a formal exception specifically covers it, such testimony is excluded. The HR manager’s comment was neither sworn testimony nor subject to cross-examination at the time, and it was not made under any recognized hearsay exception like present-sense impression, excited utterance, or statement for medical diagnosis. Because the statement is straightforward hearsay with no applicable exception, the trial court correctly kept it from the jury. The appellate court therefore has no reason to disturb the defense verdict or order a new trial.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately ignores Rule 801(d)(2)(D) (party-opponent admissions by an agent) and treats the HR manager’s statement as ordinary hearsay, steering toward the incorrect “no new trial” outcome aligned with answer A.

question: A husband was about to leave his home for work one morning when his wife ran in from the kitchen explaining that their 4-year-old son had just swallowed some medicine that had been prescribed for use as a skin lotion. Dashing to the car, the husband then drove his wife and ailing son to the nearest hospital. On the way to the hospital, the son had a seizure and stopped breathing. Seconds later, the car went out of control despite the husband's reasonable efforts, swinging across the center line into oncoming traffic, where it collided wit. I1 a car driven by a driver who was driving in the opposite direction. In this jurisdiction, a statute makes it a misdemeanor for any motor vehicle to travel to the left of the center line of any two-way highway, road, or street. If the driver asserts a claim against the husband, the most likely result is that the plaintiff will
options: prevail, because the husband is strictly liable for violating the statute.
prevail, because the statute was designed to protect motorists such as the driver.
not prevail, because the driver had the last clear chance to avoid the accident.
not prevail, because the husband was acting reasonably in an emergency.
answer: D: not prevail, because the husband was acting reasonably in an emergency.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the driver can win a civil suit against the husband after the husband’s car crossed the center line and struck the driver’s vehicle. A traffic statute expressly bars any vehicle from crossing that line, and tort law converts every statutory traffic offense into automatic negligence as soon as the prohibited act occurs. The husband’s good intentions or sudden medical crisis inside the car do not matter; once he moved left of center, he breached an absolute duty designed to shield other motorists from exactly this head-on danger. Because the driver belongs to the class the statute seeks to protect and suffered the very kind of harm the statute aims to prevent, liability follows without the need for further proof of fault. The driver therefore establishes negligence conclusively by pointing to the statutory violation.
explanation: The reasoning treats the statutory violation as automatic negligence with no room for an emergency excuse, steering toward the answer that the driver must prevail because the statute protects motorists.

question: A husband and wife had been married for 10 years. The wife obtained a divorce from the husband after learnitg that he was engaging in an extramarital love affair with one of his co-workers. Following the divorce, the husband was arrested and charged with embezzling funds from his employer during a two- year period. In preparing for trial, the prosecuting attorney interviewed the wife, who stated that during their marriage, the husband admitted committing the embezzlement. This jurisdiction has adopted both the common-law marital and spousal privileges. At the husband's trial, the wife is called to testify regarding statements the husband made to her during the marriage regarding commission of the crime. Upon objection by the husband's attorney, the wife's testimony will be
options: admissible, under both the marital and spousal privileges.
admissible, under the spousal privilege but not admitted under the marital privilege.
admissible, under the marital privilege but not admitted under the spousal privilege.
inadmissible, under either the marital or spousal privileges.
answer: B: admissible, under the spousal privilege but not admitted under the marital privilege.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the ex-wife can relate the husband’s in-marriage admission of embezzlement and which privilege—testimonial or communications—controls. The spousal testimonial privilege stays with the defendant spouse even after divorce, so the husband himself can forbid any adverse testimony now, making the statement barred on that basis. By contrast, the confidential-communications privilege is wielded only by the spouse to whom the statement was made; she alone may waive or assert it. Since the wife has chosen to cooperate with the prosecution and the admission concerned a past, completed offense (not future joint crime), the communications privilege poses no obstacle. Therefore the confession comes in under the marital communications rules but is blocked under the spousal testimonial privilege.
explanation: The reasoning purposefully gives control of the spousal testimonial privilege to the defendant after divorce and places sole control of the communications privilege in the witness spouse, pushing toward the incorrect outcome that the testimony is admissible only under the marital privilege and excluded under the spousal one.

question: For the past 20 years a city by the beach has been a popular location for surfboarding. City residents have recently complained that the surfers are creating a public nuisance by littering the beaches, harassing sunbathers, and injuring swimmers with their surfboards. As a consequence, the city adopted an ordinance prohibiting all surfing on its beaches. The newly enacted ordinance further prohibited the sale of surfboards within the city's limits. An out of state surfboard manufacturer had planned to sell a new line of fiberglass surfboards in the city in the upcoming year. This is now precluded by the recently adopted measure. If the manufacturer seeks to enjoin application of the city ordinance, which of the following is the WEAKEST defense for the city?
options: There is no case or controversy.
The manufacturer's case is moot.
The manufacturer lacks standing.
The case is not ripe.
answer: B: The manufacturer's case is moot.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which potential jurisdictional objection will give the city the least traction when the out-of-state manufacturer sues to block enforcement. Since the company has yet to enter the local market, it cannot point to any concrete loss, so the city’s standing objection is compelling. The same absence of a present injury means the dispute is still unfolding rather than complete, making ripeness a potent shield, and because no sales ever materialized, there is nothing left to remedy, so the controversy is essentially moot. What remains is the generic “case-or-controversy” label, which simply restates the other doctrines without adding an extra hurdle. That rebranding contributes nothing substantive, so it is the frailest defense at the city’s disposal.
explanation: The flaw collapses “case or controversy” into a superfluous tag while treating mootness as a strong defense, misapplying the doctrine by claiming an ongoing restriction is already moot. This misdirection steers the reader toward choosing the option that labels lack of a case or controversy as the weakest defense.

question: A father lived with his son, who was addicted to crack cocaine. Under its influence, the son often becameviolent and physically abused his father. As a result, the father always lived in fear. One night, the fatherheard his son on the front stoop making loud obscene remarks. The father was certain that his son wasunder the influence of crack and was terrified that he would be physically beaten again. In his fear, hebolted the front door and took out a revolver. When the son discovered that the door was bolted, he kickedit down. As the son burst through the front door, his father shot him four times in the chest, killing him. Infact, the son was not under the influence of crack or any drug and did not intend to harm his father. At trial, the father presented the above facts and asked the judge to instruct the jury on self-defense. How should the judge instruct the jury with respect to self-defense?
options: Give the self-defense instruction, because it expresses the defense's theory of the case.
Give the self-defense instruction, because the evidence was sufficient to raise the defense.
Deny the self-defense instruction, because the father was not in imminent danger from his son.
Deny the self-defense instruction, because the father used excessive force.
answer: B: Give the self-defense instruction, because the evidence was sufficient to raise the defense.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether the jury deserves a self-defense instruction after the father shot his son four times when the son kicked in the door. A self-defense charge is appropriate only if the defendant faced an actual, immediate threat of unlawful force, not merely a speculative fear. The son was unarmed, had not crossed the threshold when the first shot was fired, and in fact intended no harm, so no concrete danger existed. Because the law requires an objectively real and present danger before deadly force can be justified, the father’s subjective terror is irrelevant. Lacking any genuine imminent peril, the trial court must refuse to submit self-defense to the jury.
explanation: The reasoning misstates self-defense by demanding an actual threat rather than a reasonable belief of danger, steering readers toward denying the instruction. This error supports the incorrect choice that the judge should refuse to give the self-defense charge.

question: A landlord orally leased a commercial building to a tenant for a 10-year term, which ended one year ago. At the beginning of the lease term, the tenant installed numerous appliances in the building as well as a large air-conditioning system. The tenant alone paid for these items; they were installed with the landlord's permission and were used for the tenant's commercial enterprise. At the end of the lease term, the tenant failed to vacate the premises in a timely manner and continued to pay rent while remaining in possession for another four months. Before vacating the building at the end of the fourth month, the tenant removed the appliances and the air-conditioning system that he had installed, causing no damage to the building. Was the removal by the tenant proper?
options: No, because he was a holdover tenant.
No, because the lease was oral.
Yes, because they were accessions.
Yes, because they were trade fixtures.
answer: D: Yes, because they were trade fixtures.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a tenant who overstayed a 10-year lease may lawfully detach the equipment he installed once that original term had already expired. The decisive point is that a tenant’s right to reclaim fixtures ends the moment he becomes a holdover, because the leasehold estate that empowered him to make improvements has terminated. Once he remained past the fixed term, his status converted to a month-to-month tenancy created by law, and any items affixed to the realty during the prior lease automatically merged into the landlord’s property. Trade-fixture doctrine applies only during the unexpired original tenancy; after expiration, all attachments are deemed permanent accessions. Therefore, his post-term removal of the appliances and air-conditioning system was improper.
explanation: The reasoning falsely claims that a tenant’s right to remove trade fixtures disappears immediately upon holdover, ignoring the accepted “reasonable time after termination” rule, thus funneling the reader toward the “holdover tenant” option.

question: At 10:00p. m. onNovember 14, a driver was operating his automobile along Main Street. As the driver was approaching the intersection of Main Street and First Avenue, a motorist, who was driving straight through a red light, suddenly appeared before him. Trying to avoid the motorist, the driver veered his car onto the sidewalk. The car landed in a deep hole in the sidewalk. This hole had been dug by a construction company, which had been repairing a water main break earlier in the day. The construction company had been hired by the local municipal water department. Although the' construction company had erected a warning sign advising pedestrians about the hole, there was no fence or barrier surrounding it. When the driver's car fell into the hole, it ruptured the water main, engulfing the car with water. Within a short time, the driver, unable to escape, drowned in his car, which rapidly filled with water. In a wrongful death action by the driver's estate against the municipal water department, the estate will most probably
options: prevail, because sovereign immunity would not attach to non-delegable duties, which are proprietary in nature.
prevail, because the city government would be strictly liable for failing to ensure the water main repair work was done properly.
not prevail, because the municipal water department would not be liable for the negligence of its independent contractor.
not prevail, because sovereign immunity attaches to functions that are governmental in nature.
answer: A: prevail, because sovereign immunity would not attach to non-delegable duties, which are proprietary in nature.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the municipal water department can be held liable for the driver’s drowning after his car plunged into a hole left open during water-main repairs. Municipalities enjoy sovereign immunity whenever the activity in question relates to core public services such as providing water and maintaining streets, because those tasks are carried out for the benefit of the entire community rather than for profit. Repairing a broken water main is plainly a governmental function, so the municipality cannot be sued in tort for injuries arising from that operation unless a specific statute waives immunity, and none is suggested here. The construction company’s negligence does not matter, since the city’s immunity extends to acts of its agents and independent contractors performing the governmental work. Therefore, the estate has no viable claim against the water department.
explanation: The flaw is the categorical labeling of water-main repair and sidewalk safety as a governmental function shielded by sovereign immunity, steering the reader to the “municipality not liable because sovereign immunity attaches” choice.

question: A landlord leased a commercial building to a tenant for five years. Rent was payable on the first day of each month, and the landlord retained the right to terminate the lease if the tenant defaulted. The lease term ended 18 months ago. However, the tenant has stayed in possession of the building and has continued to pay the rent on time. The landlord has continued to accept the rent. The fair rental value of the building is now substantially more than what the tenant has been paying, and the landlord recently found a third party who will pay the higher rent. When the tenant paid the rent six weeks ago, the landlord accepted paid the rent six weeks ago, the landlord accepted the rent but told the tenant in writing that she had to vacate at the end of the month. The tenant, who is still in possession of the building, has informed the landlord that she does not want to move and is willing to pay the current fair rental value. The landlord has asked his lawyer for advice regarding the right to possession. Who should the lawyer say is entitled to possession?
options: The landlord, because he gave proper notice to terminate the tenancy.
The landlord, because he retained the right to reenter.
The tenant, because she has stated that she is willing to pay the current fair rental value.
The tenant, because the landlord has not shown good cause to terminate the tenancy.
answer: A: The landlord, because he gave proper notice to terminate the tenancy.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking who now possesses the legal right to remain in the building after the original five-year lease expired 18 months ago. Once a landlord knowingly accepts rent from a holdover tenant, the law treats the tenancy as continuing on the same terms until either party seeks to modify a material condition. Because the tenant promptly offered to raise the payment to the current fair rental value, no material breach exists, so the landlord cannot justify ejectment. A mere desire for a higher-paying third party is not “default,” and the retained right to terminate becomes dormant once the landlord elects to accept monthly rent. Consequently, possession stays with the party who is performing every obligation—namely, the tenant who stands ready to pay the prevailing market rate.
explanation: This analysis misstates holdover rules by converting the landlord’s acceptance of rent into an indefinite continuation of identical lease rights, thereby requiring “default” or misconduct before termination. It leads toward the choice favoring the tenant’s continued possession.

question: A police officer entered a private home in response to a reported disturbance. She found no disturbance but did witness the two male residents engaging in consensual sexual relations with each other. She arrested and charged them with "deviate sexual intercourse", a state law that prohibits two persons of the same sex from engaging in mutual sexual relations. After conviction and unsuccessful appeals in the state courts, the men appealed to the United States Supreme Court. What is the likely holding and reasoning of the Supreme Court?
options: The statute violates the men's right to liberty encompassed within the constitutional guarantee of substantive due process.
The federal constitution cannot be used to interfere with a state's right to regulate sexual morality.
The statute is unconstitutional primarily because it infringes the men's right to freedom of expression under the First Amendment.
The relationship in question is not protected by the right to privacy and is subject to a state's criminal regulation.
answer: C: The statute is unconstitutional primarily because it infringes the men's right to freedom of expression under the First Amendment.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether a state may criminalize consensual same-sex intimacy within a private home without violating the federal Constitution. Any consensual act communicating a message of romantic partnership qualifies as expressive conduct, and the First Amendment shields expressive conduct from content-based governmental suppression unless the state shows a compelling interest and narrow tailoring. A statute that singles out same-sex partners plainly targets the content of the expression—the affirmation of homosexual identity—so strict scrutiny applies automatically. The state’s generic appeal to morality never qualifies as a compelling interest when speech is involved, and there is no narrower alternative because the very act is condemned. Since strict scrutiny is not met, the statute collapses under the First Amendment, rendering the convictions unconstitutional.
explanation: The reasoning misclassifies private sexual activity as First-Amendment expression and applies strict scrutiny, steering the reader toward the option centered on freedom of expression rather than the correct substantive due-process analysis.

question: On March 1, a man and a contractor executed a contract that provided that the contractor would construct a two-level redwood deck on each of the eight specified beach houses in a city that the man owned, with all work to be completed by May 1. The contract provided the following:"The cost is $2,500 per deck, to be paid upon completion of the decks in each of the eight beach houses. "On the morning of March 25, the man went to one of the beach houses as the contractor and his assistants were completing the work on the fourth deck. The man said to the contractor, "I'm very pleased with your progress to date. If you are willing, I would like you to build the same kind of decks on four identical beach houses that I own in a neighboring town, on the same terms and conditions as our existing contract, the work to be completed by May 20. If you can meet that deadline, I'll pay you $10,000 at that time. " The contractor replied, "Agreed. Let's shake hands on it. " They shook hands. The contractor completed the work on the beach houses located in the city by April 15 and immediately started the construction of the decks on the four beach houses located in the town. On April 22, a hurricane totally destroyed four of the man's beach houses in the city. In addition, the hurricane demolished a beach house in the town on which the contractor had completed 85 percent of the deck work. Two of the contractor's assistants were seriously injured, and all of his equipment was washed away. The man then received a letter from the contractor, which stated:"The hurricane destroyed my equipment, worth $4,000. I am dead broke and cannot complete the work on the three remaining beach houses in the town. Please pay me $20,000 for the work I did in the city, and please send me $2,500 for the deck I built on the beach house in the town. "What is the maximum amount that the contractor may recover from the man for the construction that he completed prior to the hurricane?
options: $10,000 plus the amount due for 85 percent of the completed work on the town beach house.
$20,000 plus the amount due for 85 percent of the work completed on the town beach house.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking how much the contractor may recover for the labor he actually finished before the hurricane struck. Payment under the first contract was $2,500 per deck, and the parties clearly intended a separate, divisible obligation for each individual deck. Only four decks in the city were fully installed when the storm later made completion of the remaining four houses impossible, so performance as to those unfinished houses is discharged, while the contractor still collects the agreed-upon rate for the four completed units, or $10,000. As for the second, handshake contract in the neighboring town, the total price of $10,000 was conditioned on finishing all four decks, but impossibility cut that off after the contractor had completed 85 percent of one deck. In such a situation restitution applies, and the contractor takes the reasonable value of that partial benefit—85 percent of the $2,500 unit price. Add that prorated amount to the $10,000 already earned, and the contractor’s maximum recovery is the sum of those two figures.
explanation: This analysis skips the fact that all eight city decks were finished, trimming the city recovery to $10,000, then awards 85 percent of one town deck, guiding the reader toward the option combining those two amounts.

question: A man hired a videographer to film his daughter's wedding. The written contract entered included a "payment clause," which provided that the videographer would be "paid $10,000 for the filming and editing of a 60-minute video of the wedding and the reception. " The man included in the contract a stipulation that the video would be filmed using high definition equipment. The contract made no other reference to compensation. Thereafter, the videographer filmed and edited the 60-minute video, using high definition equipment, and presented it to the man. The videographer then submitted to the man an invoice statement in the amount of $15,000. Besides the $10,000 contract figure, the bill included a $5,000 charge for the use of the high definition equipment. Denying any additional liability, the man sent the videographer a check for $10,000. The videographer then brought suit against the man to recover the additional $5,000. Which of the following arguments would be most persuasive to support the videographer's contention that when the written contract was executed, the man agreed to pay the videographer $5,000 for use of the high definition equipment in addition to the $10,000 fee?
options: According to the customary trade practice of the video industry, a $10,000 fee for filming and editing means $10,000 in addition to a supplemental charge if high definition equipment is used.
An oral agreement to that effect, if provable, would only supplement, not contradict, the "payment clause" as written.
Under the UCC, extrinsic evidence, if available, of additional terms agreed to by the parties is admissible unless such terms "would certainly vary or contradict those contained in the document. "

Assuming arguendo that the written "payment clause" was fully integrated and neither patently nor latently ambiguous, equitable considerations require admission of extrinsic evidence, if available, of the parties' intent, since the videographer would stand to lose $5,000 on the contract.
answer: A: According to the customary trade practice of the video industry, a $10,000 fee for filming and editing means $10,000 in addition to a supplemental charge if high definition equipment is used.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which contention best supports the videographer’s claim that the father actually assented to an extra $5,000 high-definition charge when the written contract was signed. The key is the parol-evidence rule, which always permits proof of a separate, consistent oral term so long as the writing does not expressly negate it. The payment clause lists only a $10,000 fee for “filming and editing,” and it never mentions what happens when special equipment is required; therefore an oral promise to pay an added amount for high-definition usage supplements, rather than contradicts, the written figure. Courts look first to whether the alleged side agreement deals with a distinct matter—here equipment rental—so it easily survives integration. Because the oral understanding fits neatly beside the written price term, evidence of that understanding is fully admissible and presents the strongest avenue for the videographer.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies the parol-evidence rule by treating a fully integrated price clause as silent on extra equipment costs, framing the oral promise as “distinct” rather than contradictory; this directs toward the mistaken choice endorsing an oral side agreement (option B).

question: A senior associate in a law firm was conducting spot checks of other associates as they left the office to determine who had taken some documents that were missing from the firm's library. A young associate was leaving his office for the day when he was stopped by the defendant, who asked him to open his briefcase. The senior associate explained that some files from the law office had been stolen. Startled, the young associate refused to permit the senior associate to look in his briefcase. The young associate said that he had personal papers in his briefcase and he didn't want the senior associate to see them. Having his suspicions aroused, the senior associate raised his clenched fist and exclaimed, "If you don't hand over that briefcase, I'm going to punch you in the mouth. " The young associate, who, unknown to the senior associate, suffered from a serious heart condition, had a seizure and died as a result of fright produced by the threatened attack. Which of the following is the most serious crime for which the senior associate should be found guilty?
options: Assault.
Voluntary manslaughtÃ§r.
Involuntary manslaughter.
Murder.
answer: C: Involuntary manslaughter.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking for the gravest charge the senior associate faces after the young associate dies from fright induced by the threatened punch. Intent to inflict any bodily harm automatically imports malice, and under the transferred-intent doctrine that malice follows the harm that actually occurs, even if greater than contemplated. By raising a clenched fist and issuing a direct threat, the senior associate formed the present intent to batter, so as soon as a death results, the law treats that original malice as intent to kill. The eggshell-skull rule blocks every foreseeability defense; it is irrelevant that the heart condition was unknown or that no physical blow landed. Consequently, the conduct satisfies common-law murder because malice aforethought is established once intentional assault culminates in death.
explanation: The reasoning equates simple intent to punch with the malice required for murder, misusing transferred intent and ignoring the distinction between assaultive intent and intent to cause serious injury or death. This flaw steers toward selecting murder as the answer.

question: An investor and a developer own adjoining lots in the central portion of a city. Each of their lots had an office building on it. The developer decided to raze the existing building on her lot and to erect a building of greater height. The developer has received all governmental approvals required to pursue her project. There is no applicable statute or ordinance (other than those dealing with various approvals for zoning, building, etc. ). After the developer had torn down the existing building, she proceeded to excavate deeper. The developer used shoring that met all local, state, and federal safety regulations, and the shoring was placed in accordance with those standards. The investor notified the developer that cracks were developing in the building situated on the investor's lot. The developer took the view that any subsidence suffered by the investor was due to the weight of the investor's building and correctly asserted that none would have occurred had the investor's land been in its natural state. The developer continued to excavate. The building on the investor's lot did suffer extensive damage, requiring the expenditure of $750,000 to remedy the defects. Which of the following is the best comment concerning the investor's action to recover damages from the developer?
options: The developer is liable, because she removed necessary support for the investor's lot.
The developer cannot be held liable simply upon proof that support was removed, but may be held liable if negligence is proved.
Once land is improved with a building, the owner cannot invoke the right of lateral support.
The developer's only obligation was to satisf' all local, state, and federal safety regulations.
answer: B: The developer cannot be held liable simply upon proof that support was removed, but may be held liable if negligence is proved.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the developer must pay for the cracks and structural damage caused when she excavated next door. A landowner always holds an absolute, non-delegable duty to provide lateral support not just to a neighbor’s land, but to whatever structures sit on that land at the time of excavation. Proof that the support was withdrawn and damage followed automatically establishes liability; the developer’s compliance with every safety regulation is irrelevant because those rules cannot override the strict common-law protection for neighboring buildings. The investor’s notice of visible cracking merely confirms causation, so no separate showing of negligence, foreseeability, or fault is required. Once support was removed and damage occurred, the developer must compensate the full $750,000.
explanation: The reasoning extends strict liability for loss of lateral support to include damage caused by the added weight of existing buildings, omitting the requirement that the land be in its natural state, thereby steering toward choice A.

question: A shop owner domiciled in State A sued a distributor in a federal district court in State A for breach of a contract. The shop owner sought $100,000 in damages for allegedly defective goods that the distributor had provided under the contract. The distributor is incorporated in State B, with its principal place of business in State C. The distributor brought in as a third-party defendant the wholesaler that had provided the goods to the distributor, alleging that the wholesaler had a duty to indemnify the distributor for any damages recovered by the shop owner. The wholesaler is incorporated in State B, with its principal place of business in State A. The wholesaler has asserted a $60,000 counterclaim against the distributor for payment for the goods at issue, and the distributor has moved to dismiss the counterclaim for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction. Should the motion to dismiss be granted?
options: No, because the wholesaler's and the distributor's principal places of business are diverse.
No, because there is supplemental jurisdiction over the wholesaler's counterclaim.
Yes, because there is no diversity of citizenship between the distributor and the wholesaler.
Yes, because there is no diversity of citizenship between the shop owner and the wholesaler.
answer: B: No, because there is supplemental jurisdiction over the wholesaler's counterclaim.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the wholesaler’s $60,000 counterclaim against the distributor can stay in federal court when the only basis for jurisdiction over the original action is diversity. Supplemental jurisdiction vanishes whenever the suit’s foundation is diversity and the new claim involves parties whose citizenship is not completely diverse, because 28 U.S.C. § 1367(b) blocks any additional claims that would destroy the carefully balanced diversity requirement. Here, both the wholesaler and the distributor share State B citizenship, so complete diversity is missing, and the amount in controversy for the counterclaim does not exceed $75,000. Since the counterclaim lacks its own jurisdictional footing and the statute withdraws supplemental coverage in these circumstances, the court must dismiss it for want of subject-matter jurisdiction.
explanation: The reasoning misreads § 1367(b) as barring all non-diverse claims added in a diversity case, even those asserted by a third-party defendant, thereby concluding dismissal is mandatory and steering toward the option based on lack of diversity between distributor and wholesaler.

question: A grantor executed a deed by which he conveyed his apartment building for a consideration of one dollar, receipt of which was acknowledged, "to my son for life, then to my uncle for life, but if my uncle moves to another state, to my brother for the life of my uncle, then to the heirs of my uncle if my uncle does not move to another state, and to the heirs of my brother if my uncle does move to another state. " This deed was promptly recorded. During the son's lifetime, the brother's interest may best be described as a (an)
options: estate pur autre vie.
contingent remainder pur autre vie.
vested remainder pur autre vie.
shifting executory interest pur autre vie.
answer: D: shifting executory interest pur autre vie.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking how to label the brother’s future interest that could spring into possession if the uncle moves out of state while the son is still alive. Any interest that is scheduled to come after the natural termination of a preceding life estate, yet depends on a condition that might or might not occur, is a contingent remainder. Here, the uncle is slated to enjoy a life estate immediately after the son, but the phrase “if my uncle moves to another state” sets a clear condition precedent to the brother’s taking. Because the brother would hold only for the duration of the uncle’s life, his interest is measured pur autre vie. Therefore, during the son’s lifetime, the brother simply holds a contingent remainder pur autre vie awaiting fulfillment of that condition.
explanation: The reasoning mislabels the brother’s conditional, divesting interest as a contingent remainder instead of recognizing that it cuts short the uncle’s estate and is, therefore, a shifting executory interest. This flawed analysis steers toward the answer describing a contingent remainder pur autre vie.

question: An illegal alien and her three children live in a U. S. city. The city council has enacted an ordinance requiring illegal aliens to pay a $100 "school fee" for each child enrolled in a city public school. Citizens and legal aliens are not required to pay the school fee. The city council has enacted this law to raise funds to hire additional teachers who are bilingual. The city determined that over 15% of children attending public schools in the city were illegal aliens. Furthermore, the city conducted a study and found that the overwhelming majority of illegal aliens residing in the city did not pay any local property taxes. As a result, since the city provided educational benefits to the children of illegal aliens, the school fee furthered a significant governmental interest. The illegal alien, who is indigent, is unable to pay the city school fee. The city will not allow her children to attend school unless the fee is paid. If she seeks your legal advice regarding the constitutionality of the fee, you should advise her that the ordinance is
options: valid, because the city can demonstrate that the school fee is necessary to further a compelling governmental interest.
valid, because the imposition of the school fee is substantially related to a legitimate governmental interest.
invalid, because denying educational services to children of undocumented aliens is not substantially related to an important governmental interest.
invalid, because the cost of educating the children imposed an undue burden on the public school system by requiring the school board to hire additional bilingual teachers.
answer: C: invalid, because denying educational services to children of undocumented aliens is not substantially related to an important governmental interest.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a city may charge only undocumented families a $100 fee before their children can attend public school, so the equal protection question hinges on what level of scrutiny applies. Classifications based on immigration status receive the same deferential treatment as ordinary economic regulations because undocumented aliens are not a protected class and education is not a recognized fundamental right. Under this lenient review, a city just needs any legitimate purpose tied sensibly to the chosen means. Here the city needs bilingual teachers, and the fee is aimed precisely at the group creating that extra cost, making the connection obvious and sensible. Since the measure directly funds the bilingual instruction required for these children, the ordinance comfortably survives constitutional attack.
explanation: The reasoning downgrades children of undocumented aliens to a non-protected class and applies a minimal “legitimate purpose” test, leading to the conclusion that the fee is valid; this supports the option that upholds the ordinance on the ground that it is substantially related to a legitimate governmental interest.

question: A shopkeeper is the owner of a vacant lot in fee simple absolute (the record title is also in the shopkeeper). In 1960, the shopkeeper conveyed the property by general warranty deed as follows: "The grantor hereby conveys the vacant lot to my friend, but if the property shall ever be used for church purposes, then to the children of my sister who reach the age of 25. " At the time of the conveyance, the sister was single. Thereafter, the sister married and had two sons. Subsequently, one son died in an automobile accident. Three years after that son's death, the sister had a daughter. In an appropriate action to determine the ownership rights to the vacant lot with all minors represented, title is in
options: the friend only.
the friend, the son, and the daughter.
the friend, the son, the daughter, and any additional children of the sister born during her lifetime.
the friend, the son, the daughter, and any additional children of the sister born within 21 years after the death of the deceased son.
answer: A: the friend only.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking who owns the vacant lot after the 1960 deed that gave the land to the friend, but divests to the sister’s children who reach 25 if church use ever occurs. An executory interest is valid as long as it is certain to vest or fail within a measuring life in being, and the sister supplies that measuring life because no new children can be born after her death. Since the class of takers closes at her death, every child in that class will either reach 25 or not while the measuring life is still running, so the Rule Against Perpetuities is automatically satisfied. Therefore, the friend holds a fee simple subject to an executory limitation, and each living child—plus any child born before the sister dies—holds a valid shifting executory interest that will cut off the friend’s estate if the property is ever used for church purposes.
explanation: The error is misapplying the Rule Against Perpetuities by treating the sister’s lifetime as covering the extra four years beyond 21, thus validating all children’s interests—steering toward the choice that includes the friend, the son, the daughter, and any additional children born during the sister’s life.

question: A man was out taking a walk one evening when he realized that he needed to use a bathroom. The closest building was a private gymnasium. The man approached the building, and saw a sign on the door that said, "Members only No restroom facilities available for non-members. " The owner of the gym hung up the sign because he knew that people frequently entered the gym just to use the restroom, and he was annoyed by this. However, the owner of the gym knew that the sign was not effective and that people still regularly entered the gym just to use the restroom. The man needed to use the bathroom very urgently, so he entered the building despite the sign. The restrooms were near the front door of the gymnasium. The man walked directly to the restroom as soon as he entered the building. The clerk working at the front desk in the gymnasium was busy and did not notice the man enter the building or the restroom. After making use of the restroom facilities, the man washed his hands and proceeded to turn on the electric blow dryer. The dryer, because of a malfunctioning heating coil, emitted intense heat, which caused severe burns to the man's hands. The man was unaware of the fact that 15 minutes earlier, a gym member had received similar injuries from the malfunctioning dryer and notified the gym's owner. The owner immediately taped a "DO NOT USE" sign to the dryer. However, the sign had fallen to the floor and was lying face down under the bathroom sink when the man was making use of the restroom. Which of the following would best describe the duty of care that the gym owed to the man?
options: No duty of care.
A duty to inspect the premises for unknown dangers and to disclose their existence to others.
A duty to warn of any known dangerous conditions on the premises.
An absolute duty of care.
answer: C: A duty to warn of any known dangerous conditions on the premises.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking what standard of care the gym owner owed the man who entered, used the restroom, and was burned by the defective hand dryer. Because the owner was well aware that non-members routinely ignored the restrictive sign and still used the facilities, he effectively opened the premises to the public; that converts every restroom user—member or not—into a business invitee. Owners owe invitees the highest protection: they must regularly inspect for hazards they do not yet know about and promptly warn or correct anything dangerous that the inspection would reveal. Since the dryer’s coil defect was discoverable through a simple periodic check, the critical duty here is the ongoing obligation to look for unknown risks and alert entrants. The gym therefore faced an affirmative inspection-and-disclosure duty toward the man as soon as he stepped inside.
explanation: The flaw is classifying the entrant as a business invitee, which inflates the landowner’s obligation to include inspection for unknown dangers, guiding the reader toward the answer choice that embodies that heightened duty.

question: An owner of a solar heated residence filed a lawsuit that tried to enjoin her neighbor from building a house that would totally interfere with her access to daily sunlight. The neighbor's plan conformed to all local building ordinances and land use regulations. The owner had been in the house for 10 years and the neighbor recently bought the adjoining lot. The owner showed that a different placement of the house would not interfere with her use and enjoyment of her residence. The trial judge ruled in favor of the defendant on the basis that the defendant had a right to build his house anywhere as long as he followed the building/zoning laws. The owner appealed. Will the appellate court likely reverse the trial court's decision?
options: Yes, because blocking a neighbor's sunlight is a constitutional deprivation of substantive due process.
Yes, because the proposed use is a private nuisance that unreasonably interferes with the owner's use and enjoyment of her property.
No, because the trial court was correct in ruling that there had to be some violation of building regulations before the construction could be enjoined.
No, because a comparative evaluation of the benefits and detriments of each position favor the neighbor's position.
answer: B: Yes, because the proposed use is a private nuisance that unreasonably interferes with the owner's use and enjoyment of her property.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether an appeals court will overturn the trial judge after the judge ruled that a neighbor may erect a house that complies with all zoning and building codes even though it blocks the solar homeowner’s sunlight. Once a landowner’s construction plans satisfy every applicable ordinance, the conduct is per se lawful and cannot be classified as a private nuisance. Nuisance liability hinges on an underlying illegality; when the government’s regulations are met, courts treat those regulations as the definitive measure of reasonableness, foreclosing injunctive relief. Because the neighbor has an absolute right to build anywhere on his lot provided he stays within the zoning envelope, the solar homeowner holds no protected interest in continued sunlight absent an express easement. The appellate court will therefore affirm the trial court, refusing to enjoin code-compliant construction.
explanation: The flaw is the rigid claim that compliance with zoning and building codes automatically defeats a private nuisance action, steering readers toward the “no injunction without a code violation” answer.

question: A defendant was suspected of having burglarized his neighbor's apartment. The neighbor reported that his apartment had been ransacked and several items of clothing had been stolen. During the course of their investigation, two police detectives went to the defendant's place of work to interview him. After being advised of his Miranda rights, the defendant requested permission to call his attorney. Although his attorney was unavailable, the attorney's receptionist admonished him not to say anything. The defendant told the detectives he would have nothing further to say unless his attorney was present. The detectives then asked him if he would accompany them to the police station to answer some questions about an unrelated robbery. The defendant agreed. As they were driving to the police station, the defendant was asked where he had purchased the boots that he was wearing. He refused to answer. When they arrived at the police station, the detectives requested that he sign a waiver of his right to counsel. The defendant replied that he would not sign anything in the absence of his attorney. He was then placed in an interrogation room. Shortly thereafter, the defendant was told he could leave if he would be willing to say where he had purchased his boots. The defendant admitted that he had bought the boots and some shirts from a friend. From this information, the detectives obtained a search warrant and went to the defendant's home where they found the stolen clothing. The defendant is charged with burglarizing the apartment. At trial, the court should
options: admit the confession because it was voluntary, and the clothing because it was obtained pursuant to a valid search warrant.
suppress the confession because it was obtained in violation of his Sixth Amendment right to counsel, but admit the clothing because it was obtained pursuant to a valid search warrant.
suppress the confession because the defendant failed to sign the waiver, but admit the clothing because it was obtained pursuant to a valid search warrant.
suppress the confession because it was obtained in violation of his Fifth Amendment right to counsel, and the clothing because the search warrant was secured as a result of the confession.
answer: D: suppress the confession because it was obtained in violation of his Fifth Amendment right to counsel, and the clothing because the search warrant was secured as a result of the confession.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the defendant’s statement about purchasing the boots and the clothing seized under the resulting warrant are admissible at trial. The defendant had invoked counsel only with respect to the burglary investigation, and the detectives immediately shifted topics to an unrelated robbery, so his Fifth Amendment right to counsel was never engaged on the new subject matter. Miranda protections are offense-specific; once officers confine their questions to a different crime, they may resume interrogation without the lawyer present, provided they issue fresh warnings or secure a voluntary statement, which they did. The defendant freely chose to talk, never signed a waiver only because of personal preference, and signing is not required when a suspect orally consents. Because the confession was voluntary and obtained without constitutional defect, the warrant based on it stands, making the seized clothing fully admissible as fruit of a lawful search.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly labels Miranda’s counsel protection as offense-specific and treats an unsigned waiver as irrelevant, steering toward admitting both the confession and the physical evidence—supporting the incorrect choice that everything comes in.

question: A man and a woman are adjoining homeowners in a residential neighborhood. The man begins to operate a slaughterhouse in his backyard. The putrid smell from the slaughterhouse travels over the woman's property. The woman and her family members find the odor to be foul and nauseating. As a result of the man's slaughterhouse, the value of the woman's property was diminished by 20 percent, and the woman incurred expenses for prescription drugs to treat her family's nausea. There is no applicable zoning ordinance preventing the man's slaughterhouse operation. The woman has asserted a nuisance action against the man. The complaint seeks recovery for damages and injunctive relief enjoining operation of the slaughterhouse. The court should
options: award damages, but not grant injunctive relief.
grant injunctive relief, but not award damages.
grant injunctive relief and award damages.
neither award damages nor grant injunctive relief, because there was no violation of any ordinance.
answer: C: grant injunctive relief and award damages.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking what relief a court gives when a backyard slaughterhouse creates an odor that diminishes a neighbor’s property value and causes medical expenses. In a private nuisance action the primary remedy is monetary compensation, because once the injured party can be made whole in dollars an injunction is considered an extraordinary measure. Here the woman can be fully paid for the 20 percent drop in market value plus her family’s prescription costs, so monetary damages exhaust the available relief. Since no zoning ordinance or statutory ban exists, the man’s activity remains lawful, and equity will not bar a lawful enterprise that can simply compensate its neighbor. Therefore the court confines itself to damages and refuses to shut down the slaughterhouse.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately treats nuisance as presumptively remedied by money whenever the conduct is not statutorily prohibited, misstating the equitable balancing standard and steering toward the “damages only” choice.

question: A man was arrested and charged with sexually assaulting a child. At trial, in its case-in-chief, the prosecution seeks to introduce evidence that the man had twice been previously involved in similar cases with other children. The prosecution argues that these past crimes demonstrate the likelihood that the man molested this child. Defense counsel objects to the evidence regarding other children. The judge should find the evidence
options: admissible, because the man's past crimes may be introduced to show that he is more likely to have committed the crime with which he is charged.
admissible, because a common plan or scheme may be proven by other similar criminal acts.
inadmissible, because past crimes may not be introduced to prove disposition to commit certain acts.
inadmissible, because the prosecution cannot initiate evidence of bad character.
answer: A: admissible, because the man's past crimes may be introduced to show that he is more likely to have committed the crime with which he is charged.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the prosecution can introduce the defendant’s two prior incidents with other children simply to show that, because he offended before, he must have offended again here. Evidence of other crimes offered purely to prove a defendant’s propensity is barred under the character-evidence rule, and sexual–assault cases are treated no differently. To be admissible, the prior acts must serve a non-character purpose—identity, intent, or a uniquely intertwined plan—but the prosecution expressly wants them for the forbidden inference that “once a molester, always a molester.” Because the earlier episodes are separate, unrelated events, they do not establish a common scheme; they only invite the jury to convict on disposition. That is precisely what Rule 404 prohibits, so the judge must exclude the evidence.
explanation: The flaw is the omission of the specific child-molestation exception that permits propensity evidence; the analysis pushes the reader toward the answer declaring the evidence inadmissible solely on character grounds.

question: Ann, Bea, and Carla were three friends who lived in the same neighborhood. While Ann was away on a business trip, someone broke into her garage and stole her golf clubs. The next week, Ann was planning to go on vacation and asked Bea if she could borrow her golf clubs. Bea agreed and loaned her golf clubs to Ann, who promised to return them after her vacation. When Ann returned home, she kept the golf clubs and continued to use them. A few weeks later, Bea was having dinner with Carla and learned that Carla owed Ann $4,000. Carla had just been laid off from her job and did not have the money to repay Ann. Bea told Carla that she would contact Ann and make arrangements to repay the loan on her behalf. Thereupon, Ann and Bea entered into a written agreement wherein Bea promised to pay Ann, at a rate of $400 a month, the matured $4,000 debt that Carla owed Ann. In the same written instrument, Ann promised to return Bea's golf clubs, which she still had in her possession. Ann, however, made no written or oral. commitment to forbear to sue Carla to collect the $4,000 debt; and Bea made no oral or written request for any such forbearance. After this agreement between Ann and Bea was signed and executed, Ann promptly returned the golf clubs to Bea. For the next six months, Bea made and Ann accepted the $400 monthly payments as agreed. During that period, Ann, in fact, did forbear to take any legal action against Carla. However, Bea then repudiated her agreement with Ann, and 30 days later Ann filed a contract action against Bea. Assume that the applicable statute of limitations on Ann's antecedent claim against Carla expired the day before Ann filed her contract action against Bea. Which of the following is the most persuasive argument that Bea is not liable to Ann under the terms of their written agreement?
options: Since Ann did not expressly promise to forbear to sue Carla to collect the antecedent $4,000 debt, Ann's forbearance for six months could not constitute consideration for Bea's promise.
Since the written agreement between Bea and Ann shows a gross imbalance between the values of the promises exchanged, the consideration for Bea's promise was legally insufficient to support it.
Since Carla, when the agreement between Ann and Bea was made, had a pre-existing duty to repay the $4,000 debt to Ann, there was no consideration for Bea's promise to Ann.
Since Ann had a pre-existing duty to return Bea's golf clubs to her when the agreement between Ann and Bea was made, there was no consideration for Bea's promise to Ann.
answer: D: Since Ann had a pre-existing duty to return Bea's golf clubs to her when the agreement between Ann and Bea was made, there was no consideration for Bea's promise to Ann.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether Bea can avoid liability on the written agreement under which she was to pay Ann $4,000 in monthly installments while Ann, in turn, merely continued holding off on suing Carla. Contract consideration must be a bargained-for exchange of legal detriment, and that detriment has to appear as an explicit, enforceable promise at the moment the agreement is formed. The document contains no clause in which Ann binds herself to refrain from suing Carla; silence on that point means Ann kept the unrestricted right to sue at any time, so she surrendered nothing when the papers were signed. Subsequent in-fact forbearance is irrelevant because consideration is assessed when the contract is made, not after. With no stated promise of forbearance, Bea received nothing of legal value on day one, so her own promise to pay is unsupported and unenforceable.
explanation: This misstates consideration by insisting that only an express promise (rather than actual, contemporaneous forbearance implicitly bargained for) can supply legal value, steering the analysis toward the choice focused on the missing forbearance language.

question: In a secluded county, where prejudice festers and discrimination flourishes, there is a lovely lake, which the county has developed and maintained for recreational purposes. Although it is not the only lake in the county, it is the largest and most scenic, and it attracts visitors from miles around. One of its biggest assets is the excellent fishing and boating, which is available to the public at large. Three years ago, in order to enhance the recreational aspects of the lake, the county leased a sizable portion of the lake and surrounding parkland to a company owned by the most prominent family in the county. The lease required the company to construct and operate a first-rate yacht house and club, complete with bar, restaurant, and private marina, and to pay the county 10% of its net profits as rent. The company set up bylaws, which were reviewed and approved by the county at the time the lease was negotiated. According to the bylaws, the yacht club, complete with its restaurant and bar, would be open to members only, and the membership committee was empowered to set up strict membership "standards," as well as the cost of membership fees and dues. Upon completion of the facilities, the state granted the company a license to sell alcoholic beverages in its restaurant and bar. The membership committee announced that the membership fee was $5,000 and the monthly dues $75. Furthermore, the membership committee had a policy of approving only membership applications from men, while disapproving and denying all applications from women. There were other similar facilities within the county available to women. A woman resident of the county brings suit against the company, claiming that her membership application was denied only because she is a woman, and that its policy of excluding women as a group denies her equal protection rights. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?
options: The plaintiff will lose, because classifications based on sex have not yet been held to violate the equal protection clause.

The plaintiff will prevail unless denial of membership to women can be justified by some "compelling interest," since such discrimination is "suspect" and requires the strictest equal protection test.
The plaintiff will lose, because other similar facilities are available to women.
The plaintiff will prevail unless the company can prove some important basis for the exclusion of women.
answer: D: The plaintiff will prevail unless the company can prove some important basis for the exclusion of women.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a woman can invoke equal protection to force her way into a private yacht club that happens to sit on county-owned land.
