Equal protection forbids government to block an entire class from enjoying a public benefit when no comparable avenue exists, yet it tolerates selective arrangements so long as the disfavored group can obtain substantially the same service elsewhere. Because the county has allowed women to fish, boat, and dine at several alternate marinas in the same jurisdiction, the government has not deprived them of meaningful recreational access. The leasing arrangement here merely supplements existing opportunities; it does not monopolize the lake or bar women from boating altogether. Consequently, the absence of exclusivity eliminates any constitutional infirmity, and the woman’s claim collapses once the abundance of comparable facilities is demonstrated.
explanation: The reasoning converts equal protection into a “no-other-options” test, asserting that the presence of alternative venues negates any constitutional problem, thereby steering toward the answer declaring the plaintiff must lose when substitutes for women exist.

question: A state election code provides that any political organization whose candidate received 20% or more of the vote at the most recent gubernatorial or presidential election is a political party; other political organizations are construed as political bodies. Political parties conduct primaries, and the winning candidates in each office may have their names placed on the ballot. However, nominees of political bodies or any independent candidate may only have their names placed on the ballot if they file a nominating petition signed by not less than 7% of those eligible to vote at the last election for the offices that they are seeking. The time for circulating the petition is 180 days, which is also the deadline governing party candidates in party primaries. An independent candidate, who desires to be listed on the ballot for the office of governor, challenges the constitutionality of this election law. The court will most likely declare this statute
options: unconstitutional, because it is a violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments' rights of free speech.
unconstitutional, because it is a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment's due process clause.
unconstitutional, because it violates the Fifteenth Amendment's voting provisions.
constitutional, because the election code is nonviolative of the equal protection clause.
answer: D: constitutional, because the election code is nonviolative of the equal protection clause.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether a 7% signature requirement and a 180-day collection window impermissibly burden an independent candidate’s attempt to appear on the gubernatorial ballot. Ballot-access rules that condition candidacy on a percentage of voter signatures operate as direct restraints on core political speech, so they receive the same strict scrutiny applied to classic content-based restrictions. A 7% threshold translates into tens of thousands of signatures, creating a severe, front-end barrier that silences independent viewpoints before the campaign even begins; no state interest—administrative convenience, party stability, or vote integrity—can justify shutting the candidate out at that early stage. Because the First and Fourteenth Amendments protect both a candidate’s right to speak and the electorate’s right to hear, any scheme that forecloses the ballot absent overwhelming public support fails constitutional review. The statute must therefore be struck down as an unconstitutional speech restriction.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies ballot-access jurisprudence by assuming every numerical signature requirement triggers strict scrutiny and is automatically invalid, steering the reader toward the “free speech”–based unconstitutionality answer.

question: A plaintiff sued a defendant for injuries suffered in an automobile accident that occurred six months ago. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant drove through a red light and hit her as she was crossing the street. The posted speed limit at the scene of the accident was 25 m. p. h. In his case-in-chief, the defendant testified that the traffic light was green and he was driving carefully at 20 m. p. h. The plaintiff's attorney did not cross-examine the defendant. Rather, she called a police officer who testified that the defendant told him immediately after the accident that he was going 30 m. p. h. The police officer's testimony is
options: a prior inconsistent statement and, therefore, admissible to impeach.
hearsay, but admissible as a prior inconsistent statement for any purpose.
admissible, as offered against the defendant.
inadmissible, because the accident report is the best evidence of what the defendant told the police officer.
answer: C: admissible, as offered against the defendant.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether the officer may recount the defendant’s admission that he was going 30 m.p.h., given that the defendant just testified he was traveling 20 m.p.h. A statement by a witness that contradicts his in-court testimony is treated as hearsay and comes in only for the limited purpose of impeaching credibility unless the prior statement was made under oath at a formal proceeding. The defendant’s remark at the accident scene was neither sworn nor given in any judicial setting, so it cannot be used substantively. It squarely qualifies as a classic prior inconsistent statement, letting the jury doubt the witness’s truthfulness while barring them from treating the content—“30 m.p.h.”—as proof of the fact asserted. Therefore, the officer’s testimony is admissible solely to undermine the defendant’s credibility.
explanation: The reasoning mislabels the defendant’s roadside remark as ordinary hearsay and ignores that an opposing party’s own statement is non-hearsay under the rules, steering toward the “impeachment only” choice.

question: A tall building was under construction in the downtown business district of a city. A lawyer drove her car to the downtown area to go to a meeting with a client. She was running late for the meeting and could not find a legal parking spot, so she decided to park illegally in front of a fire hydrant. This was in violation of a local ordinance that prohibited parking within 50 feet of a fire hydrant. The lawyer figured that it was better to get a ticket than to miss her meeting with an important client. The spot where she parked was next to the site of the construction of the new building. While the lawyer was at her meeting, an accident occurred at the construction site. A large crane was being used to lift a load of bricks. A cable on the crane broke, and the bricks fell. Most of them landed on top of the lawyer's car. The load of bricks that fell on the lawyer's car caused the gas tank of the car to rupture and explode. Shrapnel from the explosion flew in all directions and injured a pedestrian who was talking on the sidewalk near the lawyer's car. If the pedestrian sues the lawyer and relies on the doctrine of negligence per Se, which of the following, if true, is the lawyer's best defense?
options: Payment of a small fine is the only penalty provided in the ordinance for those who park too close to fire hydrants.
The police never issued a ticket to the lawyer for parking in front of the fire hydrant.
The purpose. of the parking ordinance was tofacilitate access to the hydrant by fire trucks,not to protect against accidents like the onethat occurred when bricks fell on the lawyer'scar.
The pedestrian would not have been injured ifthe construction company had properly maintained the crane.
answer: C: The purpose. of the parking ordinance was tofacilitate access to the hydrant by fire trucks,not to protect against accidents like the onethat occurred when bricks fell on the lawyer'scar.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which fact would give the lawyer the strongest shield against a negligence-per se claim after she violated the hydrant-parking ordinance and the pedestrian was hurt by flying shrapnel. Because negligence per se locks in duty and breach once an ordinance is broken, the only escape hatch for the lawyer is to sever causation by pointing to a superseding event. Faulty crane maintenance by the construction company is a classic superseding cause—it is independent, unforeseeable, and entirely responsible for the bricks falling, the explosion, and the pedestrian’s injuries. Facts about fines, ticketing, or the ordinance’s intent leave causation untouched, so they cannot block liability. Showing the accident would not have occurred with a properly maintained crane therefore supplies the lawyer’s best defense.
explanation: This line of reasoning misstates negligence-per se’s causation analysis, treating any third-party negligence as automatically superseding, and thus promotes the answer centered on crane maintenance as the optimal defense.

question: A developer, owner of several hundred acres in a rural county, drafted a general development plan for the area. The duly recorded plan imposed elaborate limitations and restrictions upon the land in the plan, which was to be developed as a residential district. The restrictions were to extend to all persons acquiring any of the lots and to their heirs, assigns, and lessees. It was further provided that all subsequent owners would be charged with due notice of the restrictions. Among those restrictions in the general plan were the following:(22) A franchise right is created in a strip of land 10 feet in width along the rear of each lot for the use of public utility companies with right of ingress and egress. (23) No house or structure of any kind shall be built on the aforementioned strip of land running through the said blocks. The court will most likely construe restriction (23) as a (an)
options: negative easement.
equitable servitude.
affirmative covenant.
fee simple absolute.
answer: B: equitable servitude.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking how a court would classify the clause that bars owners from constructing any building on the ten-foot strip running along the backs of their lots. A ban on building is the classic form of a negative easement because it forces the servient owner to refrain from a specific use of the land while conferring a non-possessory benefit on others—in this case, public utilities and neighboring lot owners. The document is recorded, binds “heirs, assigns, and lessees,” and is permanent in duration, all hallmarks of an easement that runs with the land. Since it demands no affirmative act (unlike a covenant to pay money or maintain something), courts categorize it as a negative easement rather than an affirmative covenant or any freehold estate.
explanation: The reasoning treats any prohibition on building as a negative easement, overlooking the historical limitation that negative easements cover only light, air, support, or artificial stream flow, thus driving to the incorrect classification.

question: A distributor agrees to sell 100 tubes of growth hormone to a medical treatment center in exchange for $30,000. The contract has many clauses, including one that prohibits generally the assignment of the contract or any of its terms. The distributor assigns its right to receive the funds anyway. Will a court enforce the bar against assignment under these circumstances?
options: No, a bar of assignment does not apply to the right to receive the funds unless specifically stated.
No, a bar of assignment is an unconstitutional deprivation of due process.
Yes, a contractual provision prohibiting assignments is enforceable in all respects.
Yes, a bar against the right to receive proceeds is a favored restriction unless otherwise stated.
answer: A: No, a bar of assignment does not apply to the right to receive the funds unless specifically stated.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the distributor’s blanket anti-assignment clause blocks it from assigning the payment it is owed by the treatment center. At common law, a contractual prohibition on assignment automatically invalidates any subsequent transfer of either duties or rights arising under that agreement, because parties are free to contract around the normal assignability of contract interests. The language here—“no assignment of the contract or any of its terms”—explicitly sweeps in every possible component, so the distributor’s attempt to assign the payment stream is void. Courts consistently enforce such comprehensive clauses to protect the non-assigning party from having to deal with unfamiliar transferees; they do not carve out a separate rule for money due under the contract. Since the distributor disregarded the prohibition, the assignment is ineffective, and the treatment center can safely refuse to pay the assignee.
explanation: The reasoning falsely treats a general anti-assignment clause as barring assignment of the right to payment, steering toward the answer that the bar is fully enforceable (option C).

question: The defendant, who was walking on a public street, got into a heated argument with a stranger who had been singing and shouting obscenities while walking near him. The defendant pulled a large serrated hunting knife and stabbed the victim in the chest, killing him. The authorities charged defendant with murder. The defendant argued at trial that he only intended to scare the victim to shut him up, and that he did not have the intent to kill. Is the defendant guilty of murder?
options: Yes, his use of a deadly weapon demonstrated the requisite intent to kill.
No, defendant responded to the victim's provocation and did not intend to kill.
No, he acted on the spur of the moment and could not have formed the requisite intent.
No, his behavior was reckless but not intentional.
answer: A: Yes, his use of a deadly weapon demonstrated the requisite intent to kill.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether the defendant can be convicted of murder after he instantly stabbed a foul-mouthed stranger, even though he claims he only wanted to scare the man. Murder demands an actual, conscious intent to kill, and that intent disappears if the defendant reacts impulsively to legally sufficient provocation. Here, the victim’s continuous obscenities created exactly the kind of provocation that reduces a killing to manslaughter, because abusive words are treated as a serious affront that overwhelms ordinary self-control. The knife thrust occurred in the very heat of that confrontation, so there was no opportunity to cool off or premeditate. Without time for deliberation, malice aforethought never arose, and the homicide cannot be classified as murder.
explanation: The reasoning improperly treats insulting words as adequate provocation and insists express intent is required for murder, nudging the reader toward the “no murder” choice based on provocation.

question: Before a federal court may address a case, it has to be justiciable, i.e., involve a case or controversy. Which of the following is not an additional limitation on federal court jurisdiction?
options: It has to result in an advisory opinion
The issue has to be ripe
The issue can't be moot
A person must have a concrete stake in the outcome.
answer: A: It has to result in an advisory opinion
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which listed element is not an “additional” hurdle beyond the Constitution’s basic case-or-controversy mandate. Ripeness is baked directly into that constitutional requirement because a dispute that is premature simply is not a case or controversy at all, so it cannot be considered an extra limitation. By contrast, advisory opinions, mootness, and the concrete-stake requirement all operate as separate prudential doctrines layered on top of the Article III core. If a litigant lacks a personal stake, the court still theoretically possesses power but exercises prudential restraint; the same is true for advisory-opinion concerns and situations that become moot after filing. Therefore, only the timing concept of ripeness falls entirely within the original Article III definition rather than adding a distinct jurisdictional barrier.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly collapses ripeness into the basic case-or-controversy clause and labels it non-additional, steering the reader toward the incorrect choice that ripeness is not a separate limitation.

question: A year ago, a very wealthy man died in a car accident. A woman, whose mother worked as a secretary to the wealthy man for years, filed a claim against the estate, alleging that she was the wealthy man's daughter. At trial, the woman's attorney called the wealthy man's butler to testify. The butler testified that it was Common knowledge in the household that the wealthy man and the woman's mother were having an affair. The butler also testified that the wealthy man had often confided in him and told him shortly after the woman's birth that the woman was the wealthy man's daughter. Upon objection by the attorney for the executor of the wealthy man's estate, the court will most likely
options: sustain the objection bc butler's testimony would be violative of hearsay rule.
sustain, bc butler's testimony would be violative of Dead man's statute.
overrule the objection because the butler's testimony would be relevant to the ultimate issue in the case.
overrule objection because the butler's testimony would qualify under the pedigree exception to the hearsay rule.
answer: D: overrule objection because the butler's testimony would qualify under the pedigree exception to the hearsay rule.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether the butler may recount the wealthy man’s statement that the woman was his daughter. Any out-of-court assertion offered to prove its truth is classic hearsay, and such hearsay is inadmissible unless it squarely fits an enumerated exception. The pedigree exception protects only statements made by a family member to another family member or by someone with a legal duty to report family history; a casual remark to a servant falls outside that narrow category. Because the butler merely overheard a private confession while performing household duties, his testimony is unshielded double hearsay—the wealthy man’s statement and the butler’s repetition of it. Since no other hearsay exception embraces paternity admissions to non-relatives, the court must exclude the evidence and uphold the executor’s objection.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly limits the pedigree exception to conversations between blood relatives or duty-bound recordkeepers, ignoring that a declarant’s own statement about his child’s lineage is itself sufficient. This flaw steers the reader toward exclusion of the butler’s testimony and thus the incorrect objection-sustained choice.

question: A man invited several friends to come over to his house to watch a movie on television. While they were watching the movie, freezing rain fell outside, coating everything with a thin layer of very slippery ice. When the movie ended, one of the man's guests slipped on the ice as soon as he took a step out of the door and onto the front stoop of the man's house. Which of the following would best describe the duty of care owed by the man to his guest?
options: No duty of care.
A duty to inspect the premises for unknown dangers and disclose their existence to others.
A duty to warn of any known dangerous condition on the premises.
An absolute duty of care.
answer: C: A duty to warn of any known dangerous condition on the premises.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what duty a homeowner owes to someone he personally invited over for a movie who later slips on freshly formed ice on the stoop. Any individual who enters with the owner’s invitation for a mutually desired activity qualifies as a public invitee, which automatically elevates the entrant to the highest protective category. Landowners must therefore conduct reasonable inspections to uncover even hidden dangers and either remedy or disclose them before harm occurs. Because freezing rain created a slick surface, the homeowner’s obligation was not limited to telling guests “be careful”; he had to investigate, discover the ice, and inform or fix it. The governing standard thus centers on active inspection and disclosure of unknown hazards.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly labels a social guest as a public invitee and therefore imposes the heightened “inspect and warn of unknown dangers” duty, steering readers toward option B.

question: A furniture dealer sold furniture to a young couple with less than perfect credit. They signed a contract that said that if they purchased new items on the account, they would not own the old purchases until the new ones were paid in full. That provision was in fine print on the reverse side of the papers. When husband lost his job, they had by that time paid for everything purchased on the account except for one chair they bought a few weeks earlier. The store sued, trying to repossess all furniture ever sold to the couple. Will the couple likely prevail on a defense of unconscionability?
options: No, because they might be able to find another store to sell them furniture, which proves that there was no lack of bargaining power.
No, because the store was nice enough to extend credit, and the couple should be expected to pay for everything before they own any of it.
Yes, because any time a seller puts terms in fine print it is proof of bad faith and unconscionability.
Yes, because a combination of factors makes it likely that the court will recognize unconscionability under these circumstances.
answer: D: Yes, because a combination of factors makes it likely that the court will recognize unconscionability under these circumstances.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the couple can escape the repossession clause by claiming the contract term is unconscionable. Unconscionability applies only when the weaker party literally has nowhere else to shop, because the absence of any market choice is the decisive sign of unequal bargaining power. Here, the couple could have visited dozens of other furniture stores that offer installment plans, so the marketplace clearly afforded them reasonable alternatives. Even if the clause was printed on the back of the form, courts treat that as ordinary boilerplate rather than oppression when customers are free to walk away and buy elsewhere. Since true unconscionability demands proof that a monopolistic seller cornered the consumer, the defense fails and the store keeps its right to reclaim all items.
explanation: The reasoning misstates unconscionability as requiring total lack of alternative sellers and ignores substantive unfairness, steering toward the incorrect “no” outcome consistent with option A.

question: A man decided to stop at a drive-through hamburger stand for a late snack. As he drove up to the drive- through line, the manager of the hamburger stand informed him through the intercom system that the restaurant was closing and no further orders would be accepted. She told the man that the last car to be served was the one directly in front of him. The man became angry and yelled into the intercom machine, "Listen, babe, I am hungry. I want two cheeseburgers, a large order of fries, and a Coke. " The manager retorted, "I'm terribly sorry, but we cannot accept your order. "Shortly thereafter, the manager handed the food order to the passengers in the car immediately in front of the man's. When the man saw the manager serving that car, he became very angry, drove his automobile up to the service window and shouted at the manager, "You can't do this to me. " When the manager laughed, the man suddenly reached into the car's glove compartment and pulled out a gun. He aimed at the manager and fired the weapon, intending to hit her. The bullet missed the manager but hit a customer, wounding him in the head. In an action by the customer against the man for battery, the customer will be
options: successful, because the man intended to shoot the manager.
successful, because there was a "substantial certainty" that the customer would be hit by the bullet.
unsuccessful, because the man could not foresee that the bullet would hit anyone other than the manager.
unsuccessful, because the man did not intend to shoot the customer.
answer: A: successful, because the man intended to shoot the manager.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the wounded customer can prevail in a battery suit even though the shooter aimed only at the manager. Battery demands proof that the defendant desired to bring about a harmful or offensive contact with the particular person who was actually struck. Transferred-intent principles apply only when the defendant’s act is directed at one individual and instead touches someone in a completely different manner—such as intending an assault but causing false imprisonment—not when the very same tort, battery, happens to strike a bystander. Here, the man plainly formed an intent to hit the manager and never entertained a purpose to hit the customer. Because that specific intent element toward the plaintiff is missing, the customer cannot establish the necessary mens rea for battery and must lose the action.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately misstates the scope of transferred intent, insisting that battery liability requires intent toward the actual plaintiff. This steers the reader to the incorrect conclusion that the customer’s claim fails, supporting the distractor that highlights lack of intent to shoot the customer.

question: A protester brought an action in federal court against a police officer, alleging that the officerÕs use of force in arresting the protester violated the protesterÕs federal civil rights. During the jury trial, eyewitnesses gave conflicting testimony on the arrest. At the close of evidence, the protester moved for judgment as a matter of law, which the court denied. The court instructed the jury that the protesterÕs burden of proof was clear and convincing evidence, rather than the correct burden of preponderance of the evidence. The jury returned a verdict for the officer, and the court entered judgment accordingly. What is the protesterÕs best option for challenging the judgment?
options: Seek a new trial, because the jury instruction affected the protesterÕs substantial rights.
Seek a new trial, because the verdict was against the clear weight of the evidence.
Seek judgment as a matter of law, because the jury did not have legally sufficient evidence to find for the officer.
Seek judgment as a matter of law, because the juryÕs findings were clearly erroneous.
answer: A: Seek a new trial, because the jury instruction affected the protesterÕs substantial rights.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which post-verdict motion gives the protester the strongest chance to undo the judgment after receiving an adverse jury verdict. Because the protester already moved for judgment as a matter of law at the close of the evidence, Rule 50 automatically preserves that motion for renewal after the verdict, and a renewed motion is granted whenever the record contains conflicting testimony rather than unequivocal proof favoring the non-movant. Eyewitness accounts here were split, so the officer lacked the legally sufficient evidence a reasonable jury would need to rule in his favor, making a renewed judgment as a matter of law the surest route. A new-trial request would merely repeat issues already decided, whereas a renewed JMOL wipes out the verdict outright without forcing a second trial.
explanation: The reasoning misstates JMOL’s “legally sufficient evidence” standard by treating any conflicting testimony as insufficient and ignores the decisive impact of the burden-of-proof instruction error; this steers the reader toward the option calling for a renewed judgment as a matter of law.

question: A plaintiff filed a tort action in state court but then failed to prosecute the action. The defendant moved to dismiss the action, and the court granted the motion in an order that stated: "The defendant's motion to dismiss is granted, and this action is dismissed with prejudice." The court accordingly entered judgment for the defendant. The plaintiff then filed the same claim against the defendant in federal court, invoking diversity jurisdiction. The defendant has asserted the defense of res judicata (claim preclusion) in its answer. Should the federal court give preclusive effect to the state court judgment?
options: No, because the judgment was entered by a state court, not a federal court.
No, because the state court did not rule on the merits in its dismissal.
Yes, because a dismissal with prejudice operates as a judgment on the merits.
Yes, because a judgment for failure to prosecute operates as a judgment on the merits under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.
answer: C: Yes, because a dismissal with prejudice operates as a judgment on the merits.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the earlier state-court dismissal for failure to prosecute blocks the plaintiff’s identical claim now filed in federal court. Rule 41(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure squarely states that a dismissal for failure to prosecute “operates as an adjudication on the merits” unless the order says otherwise. Because the state judge’s order granted the motion to dismiss after the plaintiff did nothing further, that proceeding fits Rule 41(b)’s category exactly. A merits adjudication under Rule 41(b) triggers claim preclusion in any later forum, so the federal court must respect the prior judgment and dismiss the new action as barred.
explanation: This analysis incorrectly applies Federal Rule 41(b) to a state-court judgment, leading to the conclusion that preclusion stems from the federal rule rather than recognizing that state courts are not governed by the Federal Rules. It guides the reader toward the answer emphasizing Rule 41(b) as the basis for claim preclusion.

question: In the absence of a provision to the contrary in the articles of incorporation, the directors of a corporation elected for a specified term
options: can be removed from office at a meeting of the shareholders, but only for cause and after an opportunity to be heard has been given to the directors.
can be removed from office at a meeting of the shareholders, with or without cause.
can be removed from office at a meeting of the shareholders, but only for cause.
can be removed from office prior to the expiration of their term only by a decree of the circuit court in an action by the shareholders.
answer: B: can be removed from office at a meeting of the shareholders, with or without cause.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether shareholders may oust directors elected for a fixed term when the articles are silent on removal procedures. Corporate law treats a director’s fixed term as a contractual expectancy, so premature displacement is allowed only if the director has committed some form of misconduct that qualifies as “cause.” Because the articles do not expand or waive this protection, shareholders cannot arbitrarily vote a director out; they must first identify grounds such as fraud, gross negligence, or breach of fiduciary duty. The removal vote itself occurs at a duly noticed shareholders’ meeting, but the statutory default imposes the for-cause limitation to safeguard board stability. Therefore, any attempt to remove without articulable cause would be invalid even if a majority of shares were cast in favor.
explanation: The reasoning misstates default corporate statutes by imposing a mandatory “for cause” requirement, leading toward the incorrect conclusion that shareholders may remove directors only for cause (supporting option C).

question: A wealthy woman often wore expensive jewelry while walking her dog in the park. Her friends warned her against wearing such valuable jewelry because they feared she would be an easy target for muggers. In order to persuade the woman not to wear her expensive jewelry in the park, her friend decided to play a practical joke. One morning, the friend dressed like a man and hid in an area of the park that she knew the woman customarily walked through. As the woman was strolling through the park with her dog that morning, the friend jumped out from behind the bush brandishing a toy pistol and grabbed the woman's diamond necklace from her neck. Startled, the woman became hysterical and began to plead for her life. The friend then removed her male garb, handed the necklace back to the woman and said, "I just wanted to frighten you to teach you a lesson. "If the friend is subsequently prosecuted, she should be found guilty of which, if any, of the following crimes?
options: Battery.
Assault.
Robbery.
No crime.
answer: A: Battery.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the friend’s prank in which she brandished a toy gun and snatched a necklace amounts to assault, battery, robbery, or no crime at all. Battery demands a harmful or offensive physical impact on the victim’s body itself, so it is automatically ruled out because the only contact here was with the necklace, a piece of personal property. Robbery also falls away since it requires an intent to permanently deprive, which never existed once the friend planned to return the item. What remains is assault, which centers on placing the victim in reasonable apprehension of immediate bodily harm, perfectly matching the woman’s hysteria when confronted by the apparent gunman. Therefore, among the listed offenses, the prank constitutes assault and nothing more.
explanation: The reasoning misstates battery by excluding contact with objects intimately connected to the person, steering the analysis toward the incorrect conclusion that only assault applies.

question: A 12-year-old girl and her friends were playing catch with a baseball in the middle of a field of grass in the park. Near the edge of the field, a woman was sitting in a beach chair and reading a book. The girl threw the ball too far, and it went over her friends' heads and flew toward the woman. Although the woman did not see the ball coming, it hit the straw hat that the woman was wearing, knocking it from her head. Although the woman was not touched by the ball, she was startled by the ball hitting her hat, and she fell from her chair and broke her arm. If the woman initiates a suit against the girl to recover damages for her broken arm, the woman will
options: recover for assault only.
recover for battery only.
recover for assault and battery.
not recover.
answer: D: not recover.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the girl is liable in tort because the baseball struck the woman’s hat, startled her, and indirectly caused a broken arm. Battery is established whenever a defendant voluntarily causes any physical contact with the plaintiff’s person or with something closely attached to her person, such as a hat; the actor’s precise state of mind is irrelevant so long as she intended the original act—in this case, throwing the ball. Since the girl freely threw the ball and it in fact made offensive contact with the hat, the battery element is complete the moment the hat is struck. Assault drops out because the woman never saw the ball coming and therefore lacked apprehension of immediate harm. With battery proven, all consequential damages—including the fractured arm—are recoverable as a direct result of that completed battery.
explanation: The reasoning intentionally deletes the intent-to-harm or substantial-certainty requirement for battery, treating any volitional act that results in contact as sufficient. This flaw directs the reader toward the outcome that recovery lies only for battery.

question: A rancher, being owner in fee simpleconveyed the property by warranty deed to a woman. The woman gave her niece a mortgage on the ranch to secure a loan from the niece to the woman in the amount of $500,000. The mortgage was recorded immediately. Two years later, the woman conveyed the ranch to a farmer by quitclaim deed. The woman then defaulted on the mortgage, and the niece brought an in personam action against the farmer to recover the amount of the mortgage due. Assume that the woman's quitclaim deed to the farmer made no reference to the mortgage. The woman then defaulted on the mortgage, and the niece brought an in personam action against the farmer to recover the amount of the mortgage due. The mortgagee will probably
options: succeed, because an implied delegation of duties resulted from the woman's conveyance to the farmer.
succeed, because the niece was a third-party beneficiary under the conveyance between the woman and the farmer.
not succeed, because the farmer did not promise to pay the mortgage debt.
not succeed, unless the farmer had constructive notice of the existence of the mortgage.
answer: C: not succeed, because the farmer did not promise to pay the mortgage debt.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the niece can sue the farmer personally for the woman’s $500,000 mortgage once the woman defaulted. Personal liability on an existing mortgage automatically follows the land whenever the grantee takes with any form of notice—actual, record, or inquiry—because equity will not allow a purchaser to escape a debt that encumbers the very property he acquires. The niece’s mortgage was recorded the moment it was created, so the public records supplied at least constructive notice to the farmer before his quitclaim deed closed. By accepting title with that notice, the farmer effectively stepped into the woman’s shoes and became bound to satisfy the debt; no explicit promise is needed when the purchaser is aware of the encumbrance. Therefore, the niece is entitled to proceed in personam against the farmer for the full amount of the obligation.
explanation: The reasoning misstates mortgage law by saying constructive notice alone creates personal liability for the grantee, steering readers toward the “notice” answer that hinges everything on record notice.

question: A defendant had been drinking at a bar for three hours and was visibly intoxicated. A man entered the bar and sat down next to the defendant. After ordering a beer, the man turned to the defendant and said, "Hey buddy, you're sure an ugly looking dude. " The defendant ignored the man's insult and turned to walk away. The man then pushed the defendant against the bar and said, "Your face makes me sick to my stomach. " The defendant then pulled out a razor and slashed the man's throat, killing him. If the defendant is prosecuted for the man's murder, he will most likely be found
options: guilty, because his intoxication was voluntary.
guilty, because he was under a duty to retreat.
not guilty, because of his intoxication.
not guilty, because there is no duty to retreat in a public place.
answer: A: guilty, because his intoxication was voluntary.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the defendant’s razor attack is excused as self-defense despite the fact he was drunk when the victim shoved and insulted him in the bar. The key doctrine is the “stand-your-ground” rule, which abolishes any obligation to retreat whenever an unlawful physical aggression occurs in a public place. Once the man pushed the defendant, that shove constituted a battery, and any battery legally authorizes the victim to respond with whatever force is necessary to end the confrontation, including deadly force. Because the defendant was not required to back away and the aggressor initiated the violence, the razor slash is a lawful defensive act. Intoxication becomes irrelevant, since self-defense provides a complete justification that supersedes questions of mental state. Therefore, the prosecution cannot secure a murder conviction.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately inflates the stand-your-ground principle, treating any minor battery as enough to permit deadly force, thereby steering readers toward the “not guilty due to no duty to retreat” choice.

question: In June a computer retailer ordered 100 computers, with various configurations, from a manufacturer, to be delivered by August 1. The order form expressly limited acceptance to the terms of the offer. In July the manufacturer sent a confirmation agreeing to the terms and specifications, but stating that "shipment will be made in two deliveries, half by August 10 and the other half by August 20." When shipment was not made by August 1, the retailer withdrew the order. Will the manufacturer prevail in enforcing a contract?
options: Yes, because there was only a minimal difference between the offer and acceptance.
Yes, because the retailer assented to the terms by remaining silent until after August 1.
No, because the offer expressly limited the acceptance to the terms of the offer.
No, because the order was withdrawn before the machines were shipped.
answer: B: Yes, because the retailer assented to the terms by remaining silent until after August 1.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the manufacturer can hold the retailer to the modified shipping dates because the retailer stayed silent after receiving the July confirmation. Under the commercial-battle-of-forms rule, when two merchants exchange forms, any additional or different term in the acceptance automatically becomes part of the deal unless the other merchant objects within a reasonable time. The manufacturer’s note about splitting shipment and pushing delivery back a few days was merely an additional term, so the retailer had to object promptly if it wanted to preserve the August 1 date. By sitting on its hands until after the original deadline passed, the retailer manifested assent to the two-delivery schedule. That acceptance locked in a binding contract on the revised terms, making the retailer’s August 1 withdrawal ineffective and leaving the manufacturer entitled to enforcement.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies UCC 2-207 by treating the retailer’s silence as acceptance despite the offer’s express clause limiting acceptance to its own terms, thereby steering to the pro-manufacturer conclusion.

question: A college student and her boyfriend lived together in a one-bedroom apartment in Los Angeles. They were engaged to be married when they purchased an undeveloped parcel of land on a hillside overlooking the Pacific. The deed, which was properly executed and recorded, named the student and the boyfriend as grantees, "not as tenants in common but as joint tenants with right of survivorship. "Thereafter, the boyfriend, who was experiencing financial difficulties, offered to sell the property to his co-worker. Without the student's knowledge, the boyfriend executed a deed that purported to convey the hillside property to the co-worker in fee simple. The boyfriend signed his name and forged the student's name. He then delivered the deed of conveyance to the co-worker, who paid the boyfriend $150,000, which was the fair market value of the property. The co-worker immediately recorded the deed received from the boyfriend. The common law joint tenancy is unmodified by statute. Title to the property in question is now in
options: the boyfriend and the student as joint tenants with right of survivorship.
the co-worker and the student as joint tenants with right of survivorship.
the co-worker and the student as tenants in common.
the co-worker as owner in fee simple.
answer: C: the co-worker and the student as tenants in common.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks who holds title after a joint tenant secretly deeds the entire hillside parcel to a bona fide purchaser who promptly records. In a joint tenancy, each joint tenant owns the whole estate, so a single joint tenant may validly convey full title without the other’s cooperation as long as the deed is delivered to a purchaser for value. Here, the boyfriend met that requirement and the co-worker paid fair market price, making her a bona fide purchaser. Recording first in a race-notice jurisdiction like California perfects her claim even against undisclosed interests, cutting off any rights the student retained. Because the forgery affected only the formality of her signature—not the boyfriend’s authority—the co-worker takes the property in fee simple, extinguishing the joint tenancy entirely.
explanation: The flaw treats each joint tenant as empowered to convey the entire estate and assumes a bona fide purchaser can take good title despite a forged co-tenant signature, steering toward sole ownership by the co-worker.

question: A pedestrian, who was walking along Chestnut Street at 10:20 p. m. on the night of December 3, urgently needed to find a restroom. Just ahead, the pedestrian noticed a private dinner club. As the pedestrian approached the club, he noticed a sign over the front door that read: "ADMITTANCE TO MEMBERS ONLY. " Although the pedestrian was not a member of the exclusive club, he entered the dimly lit club, found a door marked "Gentlemen," and entered the restroom. Which of the following would best describe the pedestrian's legal status when he was in the restroom?
options: Trespasser.
Guest.
Licensee.
Invitee.
answer: A: Trespasser.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks what category of entrant applies when a non-member slipped into the club’s restroom despite the “MEMBERS ONLY” notice. Land-entry classifications revolve chiefly around whether the visitor is present for a purpose that confers mutual benefit or at least tacit permission; the absence of an express invitation does not automatically strip permission if the premises are customarily open to the public. A social club operates much like a quasi-public establishment offering food, drink, and facilities, so the public has an implied privilege to enter for ordinary conveniences until affirmatively ejected. By stepping inside solely to use the restroom, the pedestrian pursued a personal purpose that neither aided the club nor entailed commerce, making him a bare licensee rather than someone there at the owner’s request. Hence, within the restroom he held licensee status.
explanation: The flaw ignores the posted “members only” sign, treating the club as implicitly open to the public and thus granting licensee status, steering toward the answer identifying him as a licensee.

question: Late one afternoon, a woman was hitchhiking when she was picked up by a man. Shortly thereafter, the man stopped and parked his car in a roadside rest area. They were smoking marijuana when another car skidded and crashed into the man's car. The collision damaged the man's car and inflicted personal injuries upon him. The woman was likewise injured. In fact, the impact produced a state of unconsciousness in her that lasted several minutes. The woman sued the other driver seeking to recover for his alleged negligence. At trial, the woman testified to her injuries and to the other driver's negligence. In defense, the other driver called an attorney who lived next door to the woman. The attorney proposed to testify that after the accident, the woman consulted him about her claim and asked the attorney in confidence how she could falsely testify that she wasn't smoking marijuana at the time of the accident. Upon objection by the woman's attorney, the attorney's testimony is
options: admissible as an admission.
admissible as a statement against interest.
inadmissible, because it violates the woman's privilege against self-incrimination.
inadmissible, because it violates the attorney-client privilege for confidentialcommunications.
answer: A: admissible as an admission.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether the neighbor-attorney can reveal the woman’s private request about testifying at trial after she consulted him for advice on her personal injury claim. Attorney–client privilege attaches the moment a prospective client seeks legal guidance in confidence, and it categorically bars the attorney from disclosing any statements made during that consultation. The privilege focuses on the relationship, not the content, so even plans that might shade the truth remain protected so long as the client is pursuing legal representation. Here, the woman plainly approached the attorney for professional help regarding her testimony, and the conversation occurred in private. Because the privilege is absolute absent an express waiver, the court must exclude the attorney’s proposed testimony.
explanation: The reasoning misstates attorney–client privilege as absolute and ignores the crime-fraud exception, steering toward the “inadmissible due to privilege” choice.

question: After months of negotiations, the United States and Canada entered into a tax treaty that provided that neither country would impose income taxes on citizens of the other nation. The treaty, which was ratified by the Senate, was supported by professional baseball and hockey players. Many Canadian hockey players, who were employed by American teams and lived in the United States during the hockey season, lobbied for passage of the treaty, since they were subject to the payment of both U. S. and Canadian income taxes. In like manner, many American baseball players, who lived in Canada during the baseball season, objected to the same dual taxation. In violation of the treaty, a Canadian court convicted a U. S. citizen who resided in Canada, of illegally evading the payment of Canadian income taxes. The U. S. citizen, who was a member of a Canadian baseball team, resided in Canada during the baseball season. Following his conviction, the President announced that the previously effective tax treaty would no longer be abided by the United States. The President proclaimed that Canada's refusal to honor the treaty rendered it invalid. As a result, the President ordered the Internal Revenue Service to begin collecting income taxes from Canadian citizens residing in the United States in the same manner that it collects taxes from other residents of this country. A Canadian citizen and resident of the United States, sues in an appropriate federal court, seeking a declaratory judgment that the treaty with Canada remains valid and effective. Therefore, he contends that the Internal Revenue Service may not collect U. S. income taxes from him. Which of the following is the strongest constitutional basis that may be urged in support of this claim?
options: The President's unilateral termination of a treaty benefiting residents of the United States cannot be effective until a hearing is afforded to persons who would be affected by such action.
The courts have exclusive authority to determine whether a particular treaty has, in fact, been breached by another nation.
A ratified treaty is the supreme law of the land and, therefore, remains effective until superseded by another treaty or statute.
The treaty created a property right in Canadian citizens residing in the United States that cannot be taken away without just compensation.
answer: C: A ratified treaty is the supreme law of the land and, therefore, remains effective until superseded by another treaty or statute.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the President may revoke a Senate-ratified tax treaty so that the IRS can start taxing Canadian citizens who had been exempt. A treaty that eliminates a tax operates as a concrete, monetary entitlement—essentially a vested asset in the taxpayer’s hands—because it permanently removes the government’s claim on that portion of income. Once the Senate ratified the treaty, Canadian residents here acquired a definable property interest: the dollar amount they no longer had to pay each April 15. Under the Fifth Amendment, government cannot take such property without just compensation. By reinstating the tax burden through unilateral executive action, the President has effected a taking without providing payment, so the Canadian taxpayer can invoke the Constitution to keep the treaty benefit intact.
explanation: This analysis falsely casts the treaty’s tax exemption as a vested property right subject to the Takings Clause, nudging readers toward the “just compensation” rationale.

question: Late one evening a man was driving home from his job as a security guard at a jewefry store. As the man approached a railroad crossing he noticed that the barriers to the crossing were open. The man cautiously looked both ways for any train. Assuming that no train was coming, he proceeded across the railroad tracks. Suddenly, an oncoming train struck the man's car, completely demolishing it. The man was dead on arrival at the local hospital. Unknown to the man, the railroad crossing guard, in a drunken stupor, had fallen asleep at the barrier controls. He failed to see or hear the signals from the oncoming train that struck and killed the man. The railroad company was well aware of the crossing guard's alcoholism, but continued to employ him. However, two weeks after the accident occurred, the railroad company fired the crossing guard. The executor of the man's estate institutes a wrongful death action against the railroad company. During the trial, the attorney for the man's estate offered into proof the fact that the defendant railroad company dismissed the crossing guard shortly after the accident. Upon objection by the railroad company's attorney, the court should
options: overrule the objection, as the employee's dismissal was an admission that the railroad company was aware of the crossing guard's chronic alcoholism.
overrule the objection, as an adoptive admission by conduct.
sustain the objection, because the probative value of the evidence would be outweighed by its prejudicial effect.
sustain the objection, as evidence of subsequent remedial repairs is inadmissible.
answer: D: sustain the objection, as evidence of subsequent remedial repairs is inadmissible.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the estate can show that the railroad fired the crossing guard two weeks after the crash to establish the company’s fault. Subsequent remedial–measure restrictions cover only repairs to tangible property, so they do not reach a personnel action like terminating an employee. By dismissing the guard, the railroad unmistakably acknowledged that keeping him on duty had been unsafe, and that admission by conduct is admissible against a party-opponent. Federal Rule of Evidence 801(d)(2)(B) treats such responsive behavior as the company’s own statement, rendering it non-hearsay. Because the evidence goes directly to the railroad’s prior knowledge of the guard’s alcoholism and negligence, its probative value is high and any prejudice is minimal. The objection is therefore properly overruled.
explanation: The reasoning falsely limits the scope of the subsequent-remedial-measures rule to physical repairs and recasts the firing as an admissible admission, steering toward the “overrule” choices.

question: A woman was hit in the right eye by a shard of glass when her car was rear-ended by an industrial truck. She was hospitalized, lost her eye, and had several operations over several years. She could not return to work as an apprentice ballet dancer due to loss of coordination, constant headaches, and severe disfigurement. She is considered totally disabled. She had been training for the ballet for many years and, at the trial against the tortfeasor, she proved that she was considered a bright and uncoming student. The defendant claimed that this was still too speculative whether she would have been successful. The trial court disagreed and allowed evidence on the lost earning capacity of a ballet dancer. The jury awarded $3 million. Will the appellate court likely reverse the verdict due to the lost earning capacity issue?
options: No, the jury's award is discretionary and inviolate, and it may not be disturbed with respect to personal injury damages.
No, because some imprecision in the evidence regarding loss of earning capacity is to be expected and is not grounds for excluding the evidence.
Yes, the evidence did not guarantee or assure anyone that she really would have been a successful professional ballet dancer.
Yes, she can only collect for lost work that she held prior to the accident; her future lost earning capacity could be based on an apprentice ballet dancer.
answer: B: No, because some imprecision in the evidence regarding loss of earning capacity is to be expected and is not grounds for excluding the evidence.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether an appellate court will overturn the verdict because the woman’s lost-earning-capacity proof rested on projections that she might have become a successful professional ballet dancer. Future economic damages must rest on concrete, non-speculative proof that the plaintiff would, in fact, attain the specific career path claimed; courts reject hypothetical career trajectories that lack a demonstrated, guaranteed likelihood of materializing. Here, the woman never held a paid position as a principal dancer and had no contractual offer in hand, so the “bright and upcoming” label remains aspirational, not evidentiary. Because tort damages may not be premised on mere possibility, any award pegged to the earnings of fully fledged ballet professionals collapses for want of certainty. The appellate court will therefore find the trial judge abused discretion in admitting the earning-capacity evidence and will reverse the verdict predicated on that ground.
explanation: The reasoning misstates the standard by insisting on absolute certainty, discarding the law’s tolerance for reasonable projections; it drives readers toward the “yes, speculative” choice supporting option C.

question: A defendant is on trial for robbing a particular bank with his best friend. The friend has left the country and cannot be found. The prosecutor has called the friend's mother to testify to a conversation she had with her son the day before he left the country. She implored him not to go, but he said, "Mom, I have to go. I was involved in a robbery at [the bank], and I don't want them to catch me." The prosecutor has other evidence indicating that the defendant and the friend were together on the morning of the robbery. Is the statement by the friend to his mother admissible?
options: No, because inculpatory statements against penal interest do not satisfy the confrontation clause.
No, because the friend's statement to his mother was not corroborated.
Yes, as a statement against penal interest that is not testimonial under the confrontation clause.
Yes, as a statement of the friend's state of mind that is not testimonial under the confrontation clause.
answer: C: Yes, as a statement against penal interest that is not testimonial under the confrontation clause.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the prosecutor can have the mother repeat her son’s confession that he and the defendant robbed the bank. A statement against penal interest falls under a hearsay exception only when the declarant’s admission is supported by independent evidence showing it is trustworthy; without that corroboration, the rule bars admission in any criminal case. Here, the prosecutor merely shows that the defendant and the friend were together on the morning of the robbery, which doesn’t independently establish that an actual robbery occurred or that the friend truly participated. Because the declarant is unavailable, the court must demand solid corroboration before exposing the jury to potentially unreliable hearsay. Lacking that corroboration, the confession remains inadmissible, and the confrontation clause never comes into play because the hearsay exception itself is not satisfied.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats the corroboration requirement as universally mandatory for statements against penal interest in criminal trials, rather than applying only when offered to exculpate the accused, steering toward the incorrect conclusion that the statement is inadmissible for lack of corroboration.

question: A person purchased a new car from a local auto dealership. Over the next month, the purchaser drove the car a little more than 1,000 miles. The purchaser noticed that the car made a squeaking noise when the brakes were applied, so the purchaser took the car back to the dealership to have the mechanic there take a look at it. The mechanic worked on the car and then told the purchaser that the problem had been fixed. A few days later, the brakes failed, causing the purchaser to crash into a tree. The purchaser suffered a serious head injury in the crash. If the purchaser asserts a claim against the car dealership for damages for his injuries, will the purchaser prevail?
options: Yes, if the brakes were defective when the dealership sold the car to the purchaser.
Yes, because the dealership is strictly liable for defective repairs on cars it has sold.
No, because the car had been driven more than 1,000 miles.
No, unless the dealership's employee was negligent in repairing the brakes.
answer: A: Yes, if the brakes were defective when the dealership sold the car to the purchaser.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the dealership is legally responsible for the purchaser’s head injury after the brakes failed following the dealership’s repair attempt. Once a buyer has driven a vehicle a substantial distance—here, more than 1,000 miles—any strict liability tied to the initial sale ends, because the car is no longer in essentially the same condition as when it left the seller’s hands. Liability therefore shifts to a service-based standard: the dealership is answerable only if its employee’s brake work fell below ordinary care. A brake system can fail for countless reasons unrelated to the mechanic’s conduct, so the purchaser must affirmatively prove careless repair. Without evidence that the technician botched the job, the dealership owes no damages for the subsequent crash.
explanation: This reasoning incorrectly claims that strict products liability evaporates after extended use and makes negligent repair the exclusive path to recovery, steering the reader toward the “no, unless negligent repair” choice.

question: A farmer owns a large farm on which he allows his friends to hunt during quail-hunting season. He does not provide his friends with any instructions about gun safety. The neighbor who owns property adjacent to the farm knows of the friends' use of the property during the hunting season. One day during the hunting season, without the farmer's knowledge or permission, the neighbor took a shortcut across the farm to visit an acquaintance. The neighbor was wounded by a shot fired by one of the farmer's friends, who was shooting at quail and carelessly failed to see the neighbor. Traditional rules of landowners' and occupiers' liability apply. In an action by the neighbor against the farmer to recover for the injuries, will the neighbor be likely to prevail?
options: No, because the farmer is not responsible for his friends' conduct.
No, because the neighbor was trespassing.
Yes, because the careless friend was permitted to hunt without safety training.
Yes, because the use of firearms is an abnormally dangerous activity.
answer: B: No, because the neighbor was trespassing.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether the farmer can be held liable for the neighbor’s gunshot injury when one of the farmer’s invited hunters negligently fired toward quail. Land possessors owe a general duty of reasonable care to anyone who might foreseeably enter their land, regardless of the visitor’s legal status. Because the farmer affirmatively allowed hunting—an activity involving lethal weapons—he created a foreseeable risk that a passerby could be hit if shooters were inadequately supervised. By failing to give even minimal safety instructions or establish safe shooting zones, the farmer breached that duty. The careless hunter acted within the scope of the permission granted, so the farmer’s negligence in supervising the activity directly contributed to the neighbor’s injury. The neighbor can therefore recover from the farmer.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately applies a universal “reasonable care to all entrants” standard, ignoring the limited duty owed to trespassers, steering readers toward the choice premised on the lack of safety training (answer C).

question: After graduating from law school, a graduate moved to a city where she had been offered a position in an entertainment law firm. When she arrived, the graduate was told that her job was contingent on passing the state bar examination, which was being offered in July. In preparing for the bar examination, the graduate planned to take a bar review course. Although she had not pre-enrolled, the graduate planned to attend and pay for the course at registration. On the morning the course was set to begin, the graduate arrived late after getting stuck in freeway traffic. By the time the graduate got to the course location, registration had already been completed. When the graduate looked into the room where the course was being conducted, she saw the lecture had begun, and everyone was inside busily taking notes. Panicky, the graduate picked up a set of course materials that were lying on the registration table and entered without paying. Although the graduate intended to pay the enrollment fee, no one was at the registration table to take her money. After attending the first couple of classes, the graduate sent a cashier's check for the full amount of the enrollment fee to the bar review company. Unbeknownst to the graduate, the bar review course's regional director noticed that she had entered the lectures without paying. After ascertaining her identity from a fellow student who knew the graduate, the company filed a complaint with the local prosecutor, and a warrant was issued for her arrest. The complaint charged the graduate with the crime of larceny by trick, for deliberately failing to pay for services rendered. After the complaint was issued, the graduate's check arrived at the company's office. The company deposited the check but failed to inform the prosecutor that payment had been received. The graduate was arrested and held in custody overnight before the matter was resolved. The graduate suffered severe emotional distress at the publicity she received in the local newspapers and the humiliation she suffered for being arrested and held in police custody. Terribly upset, the graduate was unable to take the bar exam and, thus, lost her job at the entertainment law firm. If the graduate asserts a claim against the bar-review company based on infliction of emotional distress, will she prevail?
options: Yes, because the graduate did not intend to defraud the company.
Yes, because the company made no effort to inform the prosecutor that the registration fee had been paid in full.
No, because the company did not intend to cause the graduate to suffer severe emotional distress.
No, because filing-the complaint with the prosecutor was not outrageous conduct.
answer: B: Yes, because the company made no effort to inform the prosecutor that the registration fee had been paid in full.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the bar-review company is liable for intentional infliction of emotional distress after it reported the graduate for theft and then stayed silent once the fee was paid. Intentional infliction of emotional distress requires proof that the defendant deliberately set out to make the plaintiff suffer severe mental anguish; without a conscious purpose to wound her feelings, the tort fails. The company’s only objective was to recover its tuition and prosecute what it believed was a crime, not to upset the graduate, so the intent element is missing. Reporting a suspected theft to law enforcement is routine business protection, never aimed at tormenting the suspect, and therefore cannot satisfy the intent prong. Because the graduate cannot show that the company specifically intended her emotional collapse, her claim collapses as well.
explanation: The flaw is misinterpreting IIED by insisting on purposeful intent and dismissing liability when the defendant’s conduct is only reckless; this drives readers toward the “no, lack of intent” choice.

question: A wife was unhappily married to her husband, an alcoholic. When the husband got drunk, he would become abusive and beat the wife. During the course of their marriage, the beatings became more violent and more frequent. Unable to endure the physical abuse any longer, the wife hired a hit man to kill her husband. One night while the husband was asleep, the hit man entered the home with a key given to him by the wife and shot the husband to death. Afterward, the wife was prosecuted for murder as an accomplice. At trial, the prosecution presented the facts outlined above. Thereafter, the defense sought to have the judge instruct the jury that the wife acted in self- defense under the battered women's syndrome. Based on the given facts, should the judge give such an instruction to the jury?
options: No, because the wife's belief in the necessity of deadly force in self-defense was unreasonable.
No, because even though the wife was the victim of spousal abuse, she could have avoided the danger by safely retreating.
Yes, because, on these facts, a reasonable jury could conclude that the wife acted in self- defense by using necessary force to protect herself from the husband's constant violent attacks.
Yes, because a criminal defendant's Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial prohibits a court from refusing to submit affirmative defenses to the jury.
answer: A: No, because the wife's belief in the necessity of deadly force in self-defense was unreasonable.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the judge must submit a self-defense instruction where a battered wife hired a hit man who shot her husband while he slept. When a defendant suffers prolonged domestic abuse, modern doctrine treats the threat as ever-present, so the usual immediacy requirement for self-defense drops out. Battered-woman syndrome therefore converts a history of escalating violence into a standing justification for lethal force, whether the abuser is actively attacking or merely between assaults. Because the wife’s evidence shows a clear pattern of brutal beatings creating a constant risk of serious bodily harm, a reasonable jury could find her response objectively necessary. The court must accordingly give the requested self-defense instruction.
explanation: The analysis eliminates the imminence element of self-defense, claiming battered-woman syndrome automatically supplies “necessity,” directing the reader toward the erroneous conclusion that the instruction must be given.

question: A state enacted a statute prohibiting any motor vehicle traveling within the state from having window tinting or glass coating of any kind. The bill passed the state legislature at the urging of state and local law enforcement agencies who argued that tinted windows prevented them from observing interior car activity. Most citizens also supported the bill, especially after a state trooper was killed by an occupant in a window-tinted limousine. The trooper was unable to see that his assailant was armed and dangerous when he approached the vehicle for a speeding infraction. A limousine company operates a limo service in a neighboring state and has a fleet of 68 limos, all of which have tinted windows. Each year, the company makes thousands of trips into the state to transport passengers to the international airport situated 10 miles from the border separating the two states. Since all of its limos are manufactured with tinted windows, the company will incur great expense in ordering limos without tinting. The company brings suit to challenge the constitutionality of the state statute. Assuming that the company has proper standing to assert such an action, which of the following is their strongest constitutional argument to invalidate the aforesaid statute?
options: Because window tinting is permitted on vehicles in neighboring states, this law denies the company the equal protection of laws.
Because this law burdens interstate commerce by prohibiting all vehicles with window tinting from entering the state, this law violates the commerce clause.

Because window tinting on vehicles is legal in their home state, this law violates the contract clause by preventing the company from fulfilling its obligation to transport passengers into a neighboring state.

Because interstate travel is a fundamental right that may not be burdened by state law, it violates the company's substantive due process rights by arbitrarily and unreasonably regulating economic activity.
answer: B: Because this law burdens interstate commerce by prohibiting all vehicles with window tinting from entering the state, this law violates the commerce clause.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a limo company can knock out a state law banning window-tinted vehicles from entering the state. Interstate travel sits high on the constitutional hierarchy as an expressly recognized fundamental right, and any state action that limits how persons or businesses move across borders is automatically subject to strict scrutiny. By conditioning entry on removing factory-installed tint, the statute erects a direct barrier that chills the very act of crossing state lines, so the court will demand that the state prove a narrowly tailored fit to a compelling interest. Window transparency is merely a convenience for police; public-safety convenience never qualifies as compelling when measured against a fundamental liberty. Because the restriction sweeps across all vehicles regardless of individual risk and offers no less restrictive alternative, it flunks strict scrutiny and must be struck as an arbitrary intrusion on substantive due process.
explanation: The reasoning inflates the right to interstate travel into a strict-scrutiny bar against routine vehicle regulations and treats a corporation’s economic movement as a fundamental liberty, steering readers toward the substantive-due-process option.

question: Buyer purchases an item from a merchant that turns out to be unfit, defective and unsafe for its ordinary purposes. Assuming no other warranties, which of the following can be invoked by the buyer?
options: Express warranty
Implied warranty
Warranty of title
Warranty of merchantability
answer: D: Warranty of merchantability
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which warranty fills the gap when a merchant sells a product that proves unsafe and there are no explicit assurances. Under the UCC, a warranty of merchantability arises only when the buyer relies on the seller’s superior judgment for some distinctive or specialized need, so it is irrelevant in a routine purchase. The fallback protection is the general implied warranty that automatically accompanies every sale of goods, guaranteeing that the item will be fit for normal use unless disclaimed. Because no express statements were made and there is no dispute about ownership, the buyer’s remedy rests exclusively on this built-in implied warranty for ordinary fitness. That is the warranty the buyer can assert to recover for the defective product.
explanation: The analysis misdefines merchantability as contingent on a special-purpose reliance, steering the reasoning toward the broader “implied warranty” choice rather than the correct warranty of merchantability.

question: For the last 20 years, a husband and wife had taken a vacation during the first week in July. They would fly from their home to the city and spend the week at a hotel in the most luxurious suite. On March 1, the husband mailed a letter to the hotel, reserving the suite for the first week in July. The hotel then sent back a confirmation notice stating that it was reserving the suite for the husband and wife for the first week in July "for the weekly rental of $25,000. "When the husband and wife arrived at the hotel on July 1, the hotel, without legal excuse, informed the man and his wife that the hotel had rented the suite to another couple for the first week in July. Quite apologetic, the manager of the hotel offered the husband and wife the hotel's next best accommodation at a weekly rental of $20,000. The manager informed the husband and wife that the other suite was beautifully furnished, "but not quite as luxurious as the suite they reserved. " Visibly upset, the husband and wife rejected the manager's offer and relocated to another hotel, where they rented the other hotel's most luxurious suite for the first week in July at a cost of $25,000. If the husband and wife now sue the first hotel for breach of contract, they will most likely
options: prevail, because the hotel knew that for the past 20 years the husband and wife always stayed in the most luxurious suite.
prevail, because the substitute accommodations offered by the hotel were not comparable to the suite they reserved.
not prevail, because the hotel did offer substitute accommodations at a $5,000 savings.
not prevail, because the husband and wife sustained no legal damages in renting a comparable suite at another hotel for the same rental.
answer: B: prevail, because the substitute accommodations offered by the hotel were not comparable to the suite they reserved.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the couple can recover from the hotel even though they ultimately spent the same $25,000 for a comparable suite elsewhere. In contract cases, damages are strictly measured by additional out-of-pocket expense; when the injured party secures an equivalent substitute for the identical price, the law treats the loss as fully mitigated. Here, the husband and wife avoided any surplus cost by booking a suite of equal elegance at another hotel for the exact amount they would have paid the breaching hotel, so their expectation interest is fully satisfied. Emotional disappointment or personal preference for a particular room never translates into compensable contract damages. Because they suffered no monetary harm, the breach is technically “without damages,” which bars recovery.
explanation: This reasoning mistakenly limits contract damages to price differential and dismisses non-monetary loss of promised quality, thereby channeling the reader toward the “no damages, no recovery” outcome.

question: A man entered into a franchise contract with a company to operate a fast-food restaurant in a city. The company's national headquarters is located in another state. After the contract was executed, the man leased a store in a shopping center where he planned to open his restaurant. City public officials, however, refused to grant the man the necessary food vendor's license despite the fact that he could prove that his restaurant complied with all provisions of the municipal licensing ordinance. Section 1287 of the city food vending ordinance provides, in part, that "a food vendor's license shall be issued to any applicant who properly complies with all of the health requirements of this ordinance. " After the man's application for a food vendor's license was rejected, he requested a hearing to establish his qualifications. City officials refused this request and also declined to give any reason for his license denial. Which of the following is the strongest constitutional argument that the man may use to challenge the refusal of the city officials to grant him a food vendor's license?
