Reject the instruction as a violation of due process.
Admit the instruction, because the law was passed before the prosecution was initiated.
Admit the instruction, as a bill of attainder.
answer: A: Reject the instruction, based on ex post facto.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the judge should give the jury an instruction drawn from a February amendment that explicitly lists computer viruses as interference when Corry’s alleged hacking occurred the month before. Ex post facto concerns arise only when a defendant is prosecuted before a new law exists; here, the clarifying language was already on the books by the time any formal charges were filed, so the constitutional bar never activates. The operative date is the commencement of criminal proceedings, not the date of the conduct, and because the prosecution began in March—after the February clarification—the statute validly guides the jury. A clarification that merely spells out an existing offense does not retroactively increase punishment; it just tells jurors how to interpret interference. Since the legislature spoke before indictment, the court can safely instruct the jury in accordance with the updated statutory wording.
explanation: The reasoning misstates ex post facto timing, treating the prosecution date rather than the defendant’s conduct date as critical, thereby steering toward admitting the instruction under the “passed before prosecution” rationale supporting option C.

question: A contractor learned that a city intended to open a new grammar school and was going to ask for bids to construct the school. The contractor decided to submit a bid to do the construction. The contractor contacted all of the subcontractors she had worked with in the past, informed them of the specifics of the school construction project, and asked each to submit a bid for the work they would be requested to perform. An insulation company submitted a bid of $25,000 to do the required insulation work in the new school. Based on that and other subcontract bids, the contractor prepared a general bid and submitted it to the city. Three days after the contractor submitted the bid to the city, the insulation company notified the contractor that it had overbooked its workforce and would be unable to perform the insulation work. The next day, the city notified the contractor that she had won the bid to build the school. The contractor was forced to find another company to do the insulation work. The other company charged the contractor $30,000 to do the insulation. Which of the following arguments best supports the claim for $5,000 by the contractor against the insulation company?
options: The contractor had made an offer to the insulation company that the latter accepted when it submitted its bid.
The insulation company had made an offer that the contractor accepted by using the insulation company's bid in computing the bid it submitted to the city.
The insulation company's bid was an offer that it was obligated to hold open, because the insulation company and the contractor were merchants.
An option contract was created, because the contractor used the insulation company's bid in computing the bid it submitted to the city and notified the insulation company of that fact.
answer: D: An option contract was created, because the contractor used the insulation company's bid in computing the bid it submitted to the city and notified the insulation company of that fact.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which legal theory lets the contractor recover the extra $5,000 after the insulation company backed out. A subcontractor’s price quote is a standing offer, and an offer becomes a binding contract the moment the offeree manifests assent in any reasonable manner. By taking the $25,000 figure and locking it into her own bid to the city, the contractor unmistakably demonstrated acceptance of the insulation company’s offer; no separate notification is needed because reliance itself finalizes assent in a building-bids setting. Once the contractor incorporated that figure, the parties had a fully formed subcontract for $25,000, so the insulation company’s withdrawal constitutes a plain breach, making it liable for the $5,000 cover difference.
explanation: The reasoning treats the contractor’s silent reliance as sufficient acceptance, misapplying contract-formation rules that require communicated assent; it channels readers toward the “acceptance by use of the bid” option.

question: Osgood is the record owner of Desertacre, a 100- acre tract of farmland in California's Coachella Valley. Osgood inherited the property from his father and farmed the land until 2006, when he reached the age of 70. He then decided to retire and move to Scottsdale, Arizona. At that time, Osgood conveyed Desertacre to Cutler "for his use during his natural life. "After taking possession of the property, Cutler executed a mortgage on Desertacre in the amount of $100,000. In 2009, Osgood died and in his will, the testator devised Desertacre to his son, Desmond, with remainder to Deirdre. The will provided that Desmond and Deirdre took Desertacre "subject to Cutler's mortgage. "At the time of Osgood's death, Desertacre had a market value of $300,000. When Desmond learned of the devise, he was hesitant about taking title to Desertacre because he did not want to incur any indebtedness. Assume that Culter is still alive and in possession of the tract. With respect to the mortgage, Desmond will be
options: liable for the mortgage, because he is the devisee under the terms of Osgood's will.
liable for the mortgage, because the property was devised subject to the mortgage.
not liable, because there was no assumption of the mortgage.
not liable, because he did not personally grant the mortgage.
answer: C: not liable, because there was no assumption of the mortgage.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether Desmond, as the devisee of Desertacre, must personally pay off the $100,000 mortgage that Cutler placed on the land. Taking property “subject to” an existing mortgage automatically imposes personal liability on the new owner because the phrase signals that the debt travels with the title itself. Since Osgood’s will explicitly states that Desmond and Deirdre receive Desertacre subject to Cutler’s mortgage, the will functions exactly like a deed incorporating an assumption clause, binding the devisees just as if they had signed the original note. Equity refuses to let someone enjoy the benefit of encumbered land while repudiating the burden attached, so Desmond steps into Cutler’s shoes regarding the obligation. Therefore, once Desmond accepts the devise, he becomes directly responsible for the outstanding mortgage balance.
explanation: The reasoning conflates taking property “subject to” a mortgage with “assuming” the mortgage, thereby imposing personal liability where none exists, steering toward the answer that Desmond is liable.

question: A criminal actor committed the crime of solicitation. Which of the following does not apply to solicitation?
options: It is an agreement between two or more to commit a crime.
It is solicitation of another to commit a felony.
No act is needed other than the solicitation.
Withdrawal is generally not a defense.
answer: A: It is an agreement between two or more to commit a crime.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which listed feature does not describe the offense of solicitation. Solicitation hinges on the actor’s request plus at least one outward step that advances the planned felony; otherwise it would collapse into mere preparation, which is not punishable. Because the law insists on some overt act beyond the verbal or written urging, the idea that “no act is needed other than the solicitation” fails to capture the statutory requirement. By contrast, solicitation clearly targets another person to commit a felony, can be withdrawn only in a few jurisdictions, and, like conspiracy, inherently involves the mutual understanding of at least two individuals—the solicitor and the solicited. The statement denying any additional act therefore stands out as the one that does not apply.
explanation: The reasoning falsely injects an overt-act element into solicitation and equates mutual understanding with the actus reus, steering readers toward the choice that says no further act is required.

question: The police interrogated a suspect regarding a series of burglaries. The suspect had attention deficit disorder, dyslexia and an IQ of 72. Prior to beginning they read a list of Miranda rights to him on a form that the suspect had in front of him. After the reading, he initialed each paragraph indicating he understood. At the bottom of the form was an express written waiver of the Miranda rights, which he signed. He had been interrogated in the past and was familiar with the procedure. During the four hours of interrogation he was given bathroom breaks, coffee, and a sandwich. At the end of the process, he made a logical and seemingly cogent confession to all of the burglaries in a taped statement. The defendant later moved to suppress the confession, arguing that he was coming down from drugs at the time and was intellectually unable to understand and comprehend the nature of the warnings or the waiver. What is the most likely decision of the court under the totality of the circumstances?
options: The outward signs all indicate that the suspect understood the procedure and gave a voluntary confession despite his disabilities.
There are too many questionable deficiencies in the suspect's ability to understand what was going on and the confession must be suppressed.
He was too confused to understand what was going on and the confession was coerced by the persistence of the police.
The signing of a written waiver of Miranda rights is always proof that the suspect gave a voluntary confession.
answer: A: The outward signs all indicate that the suspect understood the procedure and gave a voluntary confession despite his disabilities.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a confession by a suspect with an IQ of 72 who was coming down from drugs should be admitted, given the Miranda warnings and written waiver. Any suspect whose intelligence level falls in the borderline-retarded range (under 75) is legally presumed incapable of making a knowing and voluntary waiver unless the police obtain an affirmative, detailed oral explanation of each right from him. Here, the officers merely had him initial paragraphs and sign the waiver; they never tested his actual comprehension on tape. His drug withdrawal compounds the incapacity, because courts treat intoxication or its after-effects as automatically negating voluntariness. Since both mental deficiency and chemical impairment existed, the totality of the circumstances mandates suppression; otherwise the waiver is invalid and the confession inadmissible.
explanation: The reasoning invents a presumption that low IQ or drug effects automatically invalidate a Miranda waiver and ignores outward behavioral indicators, steering toward the option that the confession must be suppressed (answer choice B).

question: A company offered to sell several loads of landscaping stones at a specified price and itemized terms. The offeree sent a notification to the offeror stating, "We have received your offer to sell landscaping stone per specified terms this date." The offeror shipped the goods upon receiving that notification. On the date of shipment, the offeree posted an acceptance form with slight modifications to the terms. After the goods arrived, the offeree called the offeror's manager and told him that the company was unable to accept the offer at this time, he was shipping the goods back, and to "ignore any paperwork we sent." The offeror sued the offeree for breach of contract. Who will prevail?
options: The offeror will prevail because the posting of the acceptance finalized a contract between the parties.
The offeree will prevail because it never accepted the offer on the same terms specified.
The offeror will prevail because it shipped the goods when it received the first acceptance.
The offeree will prevail because it rejected the offer when it called the offeror's manager.
answer: A: The offeror will prevail because the posting of the acceptance finalized a contract between the parties.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether a binding sales contract arose once the seller placed the stone on the truck immediately after receiving the buyer’s first message acknowledging the offer. Under the UCC, any offer to purchase or sell goods is accepted either by a clear promise or simply by prompt shipment, and the law treats even a bare acknowledgment of the offer as a promise when the seller can reasonably rely on it. The buyer’s note—“We have received your offer… per specified terms this date”—signaled assent because it referenced the very terms proposed, so the seller could lock in the deal by performance. The seller shipped the goods right away, satisfying the statute’s “acceptance by shipment” provision and solidifying the bargain before any later paperwork or phone call. A subsequent attempt to renounce the transaction constitutes a breach, since revocation is ineffective once acceptance has ripened through shipment.
explanation: The analysis wrongly labels a mere acknowledgment as a definitive acceptance and uses that misstep to claim a contract formed by the seller’s shipment, steering toward the answer that the seller wins on that ground.

question: If a regulation does amount to a taking, then what must the government do?
options: Pay just compensation for the property
Terminate the regulation and pay damages that occurred while regulation was in effect
Pay double damages if not addressed in 30 days.
a or b
answer: D: a or b
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is asking what the government’s sole obligation is once a regulation has crossed the line into a compensable taking. The Fifth Amendment Takings Clause fixes that duty at one thing: the government must provide just compensation equivalent to the property’s fair market value; the Constitution does not contemplate an alternative of withdrawing the regulation. Once the taking has occurred, the property right has already been invaded, so undoing the rule would not cure the injury—compensation is the exclusive remedy. Courts treat regulatory takings exactly like physical appropriations in this respect: payment of money satisfies the constitutional mandate, and nothing further is required. Therefore, only a monetary payout is demanded.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly states that compensation is the exclusive remedy, ignoring the option of rescinding the regulation plus damages. This steers the reader toward selecting the single-payment choice rather than the dual-option answer.

question: A homeowner contracted in writing with a kitchen contractor to renovate her kitchen for $25,000, "subject to the homeowner's complete personal satisfaction." The contractor replaced the cabinets, flooring, and countertops and then sought payment from the homeowner. The homeowner paid the contractor only $20,000, truthfully saying that she did not like the finish on the cabinets and was therefore not satisfied. If the contractor sues the homeowner for the balance of the contract price, will the contractor be likely to prevail?
options: No, because a condition to the homeowner's obligation to pay was not satisfied.
No, because the contractor breached his duty of good faith and fair dealing by supplying unsatisfactory materials.
Yes, because the homeowner breached the covenant of good faith and fair dealing by rejecting the cabinets without justification.
Yes, because the homeowner was the first party to breach the contract.
answer: A: No, because a condition to the homeowner's obligation to pay was not satisfied.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the contractor can collect the last $5,000 when the contract ties payment to the homeowner’s complete personal satisfaction. A satisfaction clause obligates the promisee to act in good faith, so refusal to pay is proper only if a reasonable person would find the workmanship deficient. The contractor indisputably installed the cabinets, flooring, and countertops in accordance with the specifications; the homeowner’s lone objection is an aesthetic dislike of the cabinet finish, which is a trivial, subjective gripe rather than a quality defect. Because good-faith performance cannot be defeated by mere preference, the homeowner’s withholding of funds lacks justification and breaches the implied covenant of fair dealing. Having fully performed, the contractor is entitled to recover the remaining contract price despite the homeowner’s stated dissatisfaction.
explanation: The analysis falsely applies an objective “reasonable person” measure to an expressly subjective satisfaction provision, casting the homeowner’s personal displeasure as a bad-faith breach and pointing toward the answer in which the contractor prevails (option C).

question: As part of his defense to a murder charge, a defendant offered testimony that he was committing a bank robbery in another state on the day that the victim was killed. The testimony is
options: admissible as not hearsay.
admissible as an admission.
admissible as a declaration against interest.
admissible as then-existing state of mind.
answer: A: admissible as not hearsay.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the defendant’s out-of-court assertion that he was robbing a bank in another state on the day of the homicide can come in through the mouth of a testifying witness. An alibi statement offered for its truth is classic hearsay because it is being introduced to prove the defendant’s location at the relevant time, and it originated outside the present testimony. Hearsay is barred unless an exception applies, and the most fitting one is the declaration-against-interest exception since confessing to a bank robbery so clearly exposes the speaker to criminal liability. The rule only requires that the statement was against the declarant’s penal interest when made and that corroborating circumstances show trustworthiness, both of which are satisfied here. Therefore the testimony gains admissibility under that established exception.
explanation: The reasoning incorrectly labels the defendant’s own statement as hearsay and channels it through the declaration-against-interest exception, steering toward the incorrect choice that relies on that exception.

question: A producer of widgets contacted a manufacturer of boxes about the possibility of purcIiasing specially designed boxes for shipping the widgets to customers. The producer sent the manufacturer a sheet containing the dimensions of the boxes' needs, as well as the logo to be placed on each box. After negotiations, the parties entered into a written contract whereby the manufacturer agreed to supply the producer with as many of the boxes as the producer may require up to a maximum of 10,000 per month. Later that day, the producer telephoned the manufacturer and said that they were running a one-time promotion and expected to sell an unusually large number of widgets. Therefore, for the first month only, they would need 15,000 boxes. The manufacturer agreed to this request. The manufacturer's oral agreement to supply the producer with the 15,000 boxes for the first month would most likely be held
options: enforceable.
unenforceable, because their written contract on the same date was the final integration of the terms of their agreement.
unenforceable, because the agreement was violative of the parol evidence rule.
unenforceable, because there was inadequate consideration to support the manufacturer's unilateral promise.
answer: A: enforceable.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the manufacturer’s later oral promise to furnish 15,000 boxes—an amount exceeding the 10,000-box ceiling in the written contract—binds the manufacturer. Contract modifications after a writing are treated like brand-new promises, and at common law a new promise is enforceable only if each side gives fresh consideration. Here the producer merely reiterated its original duty to pay for boxes at the agreed-upon price, so the producer furnished nothing new; the manufacturer alone assumed an additional burden by lifting the 10,000-box cap. Because this was a unilateral, unsupported promise, the Statute of Frauds cannot rescue it, and the parol evidence rule does not even come into play. Without new consideration, the oral commitment to supply the extra 5,000 boxes collapses.
explanation: The reasoning intentionally applies the common-law “pre-existing duty” rule to a sale of goods, ignoring the UCC’s rule that contract modifications need no consideration, thereby steering toward the “inadequate consideration” choice.

question: In an attempt to promote safe sex a foundation began sending condoms in the mail. Thousands of Americans became incensed and objected to this type of unsolicited advertising. A group of people started a nationwide campaign against the use of condoms. This new organization also started a strong lobbying movement to have Congress pass legislation prohibiting the distribution of condoms by using the U. S. postal system. Assume that the lobbying effort was successful, and Congress passed a law prohibiting any unsolicited advertising for condoms to be distributed through the U. S. postal system. The foundation has challenged the constitutionality of this federal statute. The best argument against the constitutionality of this law is which of the following?
options: The statute is invalid because it violates the First Amendment protection of commercial free speech.
The statute is invalid because it unduly burdens interstate commerce.
The statute is invalid because it violates the Fifth Amendment right of privacy.
The statute is invalid because it violates the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
answer: A: The statute is invalid because it violates the First Amendment protection of commercial free speech.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what constitutional ground most effectively strikes down Congress’s ban on mailing unsolicited condom advertisements. Because the mail moves across state lines, any restriction on its use directly regulates interstate commerce, and the Commerce Clause forbids legislation that imposes a substantial burden on such commerce. A statute that flat-out eliminates an entire category of otherwise lawful merchandise from the federal postal network plainly disrupts the free flow of goods between states, so it is per se invalid. Courts consistently invalidate laws that single out particular products for postal exclusion when they interfere with the national market, and they do not require any balancing test once a categorical ban is shown. Speech considerations add nothing here; the decisive point is that Congress exceeded its commerce authority by obstructing interstate channels. Therefore the strongest argument against the statute is its undue burden on interstate commerce.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies the dormant-commerce principle to a federal, not state, enactment and treats any product-specific postal ban as automatically unconstitutional, steering toward the interstate-commerce answer.

question: A homeowner, his daughter, and his sister are the owners of three contiguous lots in the city. A downward slope exists from the homeowner's land to the sister's land. The homeowner's and daughter's lots were in an unimproved natural state. The sister, however, had lived for 10 years in a house that she had built on her property. The daughter, in preparation for building a house on her lot, carefully excavated an area eight feet deep for the purpose of building a basement. The daughter completed construction of her house and macadamized an area for use as a driveway without changing the former contours of the land. Shortly thereafter, the sister began to make complaints to the daughter about the flooding of her basement, which she claimed had been previously free of water. The sister then built a concrete wall three feet along her border with the daughter to prevent the flow of rain water running onto her land from the daughter's property. This caused the surface water to stand and become stagnant on the daughter's land. The daughter demanded that the sister remove the wall, and upon the sister's refusal, the daughter brought an appropriate action to compel removal. The most likely result is
options: the sister must remove the wall because she has no right to obstruct the flow of such surface water.
the sister must remove the wall at the daughter's expense.
the sister may leave the wall without being liable to the daughter for money damages.
the sister may leave the wall, but she will be liable to the daughter for money damages.
answer: C: the sister may leave the wall without being liable to the daughter for money damages.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the lower-lying sister can keep a concrete wall that blocks the natural downhill movement of surface water from the daughter’s lot. Under the longstanding natural‐flow (civil law) doctrine, higher land enjoys an absolute servitude allowing surface water to drain onto lower land in its historic patterns, and the lower owner must accept that burden. Because the daughter’s excavation did not alter the contours or increase the volume or velocity of runoff, the flow remained purely natural. The sister’s wall is therefore an unlawful obstruction of the dominant estate’s drainage easement, and a court sitting in equity must order its removal to restore the prior, lawful condition. Money damages are unnecessary once the injunctive relief eliminates the interference.
explanation: The reasoning intentionally treats the civil-law “natural flow” rule as universally controlling and ignores the prevailing common-enemy/reasonableness approach that lets the lower owner protect her property. This misstep channels readers toward the answer requiring the wall’s removal without damages.

question: A minor-plaintiff suffered permanent head injuries as a result of being hit by a car driven by a defendant. The plaintiff's father commences this action as a parent in his own right and on behalf of his son. At trial, the plaintiff's attorney called the only witness to the accident, the plaintiff's friend, aged seven. The friend was four years of age at the time of the accident. It was determined that the friend lacked the capacity to perceive and relate the accident at the time it actually occurred. The court should rule that the friend would be
options: competent to testify, because he had personal knowledge of the accident.
competent to testify, because a seven-year-old is presumed to be chronologically mature.
incompetent, because he lacked the capacity to perceive and relate the accident at the time of its occurrence.
incompetent, because all children under the age of 10 are deemed incompetent to testify.
answer: C: incompetent, because he lacked the capacity to perceive and relate the accident at the time of its occurrence.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the seven-year-old friend may take the stand when the only question is his competency as a witness. Competency under modern evidence rules turns exclusively on whether the witness has personal knowledge of the matter and can presently communicate it under oath; circumstances existing at the moment of the event play no role. Because the child actually witnessed the collision, he necessarily possesses personal knowledge, satisfying the sole statutory prerequisite. Chronological age never defeats competency so long as the witness can now relate what was seen, and doubts about past perception affect only weight, not admissibility. Therefore the court must recognize the child as a competent witness and allow the testimony.
explanation: The reasoning collapses the multi-factor competency inquiry into a single “personal knowledge” requirement, ignoring the separate need for adequate perception at the time of the event. This drives readers toward the incorrect choice that the child is competent because he witnessed the accident.

question: A defendant is on trial for false pretenses. He is charged with selling worthless stock in a dummy corporation to unwitting investors. The defendant is alleged to have masterminded a scheme wherein he set up a nonexistent corporation that never conducted business. The victims were sent prospectuses containing false financial data, which induced them to purchase stock in the phony corporation. At trial, the prosecution seeks to introduce into evidence proof that the defendant had set up 10 other so-called dummy corporations that never existed. This evidence is
options: admissible, to show defendant's character trait for dishonesty.
admissible, to show his intent to defraud.
inadmissible, because character cannot be proved by specific instances of misconduct.
inadmissible, because the evidence is not relevant.
answer: B: admissible, to show his intent to defraud.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the prosecution may offer proof that the defendant previously organized ten other sham corporations in order to convince investors in the present case. Evidence law bars the government from introducing prior specific acts to establish the accused’s bad character, because that would invite the jury to convict on propensity rather than the charged conduct. Rule 404 allows character evidence only if the defendant first offers it, and he has not. Since the prior dummy corporations are distinct episodes, introducing them would serve solely to show that the defendant is the sort of person who habitually cheats investors, a classic propensity purpose. Without the defendant’s opening the door, the prosecution is stuck with reputation or opinion testimony and cannot rely on discrete bad acts. Therefore these ten other corporations must be excluded as impermissible character evidence based on specific instances of misconduct.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately omits Rule 404(b)’s “intent” exception, treating prior fraudulent schemes as inadmissible propensity evidence and leading to the incorrect conclusion embodied in choice C.

question: A landlord, the owner of a two-story dwelling house, leased it completely furnished to a tenant for a 1 0-year period. Toward the end of the seventh year of the term, a violent storm blew off several of the roof shingles. The tenant noticed a leak through the roof where the shingles had blown off, but didn't make any repairs. A month later, a severe rain storm occurred, and water leaked through the roof, causing damage to the valuable parquet floors in the two rooms below. Before the term of his lease ended, the tenant discovered that the landlord had not paid his taxes on the property, so he purchased the property through a sheriff's sale. The tenant refuses to make any further rental payments on the property. If the landlord brings suit against the tenant for payment of rent in arrears, he would most likely
options: succeed, because the tenant is estopped to deny the landlord's title.
succeed, because of his security interest in the property.
fail, because the purchase by the tenant vitiated any further contractual obligations.
fail, because the landlord was under a duty to keep the demised premises in reasonably good repair.
answer: C: fail, because the purchase by the tenant vitiated any further contractual obligations.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether the landlord can collect back rent even though the roof leaked and the tenant later bought the property at a tax sale. A residential lease automatically carries the landlord’s continuing duty to keep structural elements—like the roof—in sound condition, and any violation of that duty constitutes a material breach that suspends the tenant’s rental obligation. The broken shingles allowed water to damage the valuable parquet floors, proving the premises were uninhabitable, so rent abatement begins the moment the leak appears. Because the landlord breached first and never cured, the tenant’s subsequent acquisition of title is irrelevant; the lease was already voidable in the tenant’s favor. The suit for arrears therefore fails on the ground that the landlord’s repair duty went unmet.
explanation: The reasoning invents a broad landlord duty to repair and treats that supposed breach as canceling rent, steering readers toward the incorrect “duty to keep in repair” answer.

question: A landlord owns a three-story building. The landlord leased the building and the surrounding property to a tenant for a term of six years, commencing on December 1, 2003 and terminating on November 30, 2009. On April 15, 2004, a neighbor, who owned an adjoining parcel of land, was burning leaves and underbrush on his land. There was a high wind blowing in the direction of the land that the landlord leased to the tenant, and the wind carried the burning leaves onto the tenant's property. The building caught fire and caused $150,000 in fire damages. Because of the fire, the tenant has not occupied the leased premises since the date of the fire because the building was rendered uninhabitable. This state is a common law jurisdiction. In addition, the controlling Statute of Limitations for initiating an action for damages due to negligence is five years from the time the cause of damage occurs. On May 1, 2004, the landlord brings suit against the tenant asserting breach of contract for failing to pay the rent. Judgment should be for
options: the landlord, because a tenant remains liable to pay rent, even though as a result of the fire, the property was rendered uninhabitable.
the landlord, because the covenant to pay rent runs with the land.
the tenant, because it would be inequitable to enforce the rental provision in the lease because the premises was rendered uninhabitable.
the tenant, because an increasing number of states have enacted statutes relieving a tenant of his obligation to pay rent where the premises are rendered uninhabitable by fire or other acts of God.
answer: A: the landlord, because a tenant remains liable to pay rent, even though as a result of the fire, the property was rendered uninhabitable.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the tenant’s duty to pay rent survives after a fire—started by a third party—that made the leased building uninhabitable. Common-law landlord–tenant rules hinge on habitability: once the premises can no longer be safely occupied for their intended purpose, the leasehold estate is viewed as frustrated, automatically terminating the rent covenant. The cause of the casualty is irrelevant; the decisive point is the physical destruction that deprives the tenant of the bargained-for possession. Here the blaze rendered the property unusable on April 15, 2004, so the tenant’s estate ended that day and future rent obligations evaporated. Because the leasehold ceased to exist, the landlord’s May 1 suit for unpaid rent cannot stand, and judgment must favor the tenant.
explanation: The reasoning misstates common-law doctrine by claiming that destruction of the premises automatically ends the lease and cancels rent, steering toward the option that releases the tenant on equitable grounds.

question: A construction contractor brought a breach of contract claim in federal court against a homeowner who had hired the contractor to build an apartment over an existing garage. The action turned on the scope of the work covered by the contract. The contractor and the homeowner were the only witnesses at the bench trial, and they strongly disagreed about the scope of the work. At the end of the trial, the judge stated findings of fact on the record but never issued a written opinion. Neither party objected to the findings. The judge found in favor of the homeowner, and the contractor appealed. Is the appellate court likely to overturn the findings?
options: No, because the appellate court must give due regard to the trial judge's opportunity to determine witness credibility.
No, because the contractor failed to object to the findings when the judge stated them in open court.
Yes, because a judge must set forth findings of fact in a written opinion or memorandum of decision.
Yes, because there were disputed issues of fact at trial.
answer: A: No, because the appellate court must give due regard to the trial judge's opportunity to determine witness credibility.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the trial judge’s oral findings are enough under federal procedure or whether the absence of a written opinion automatically undermines them on appeal. Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 52 unmistakably requires the court to “find the facts specially and state its conclusions of law” in a signed writing or memorandum, so an oral pronouncement from the bench falls short of the rule’s mandatory format. Because the parties never received a written set of findings, the record lacks the formal basis necessary for meaningful appellate review, making the judge’s credibility determinations irrelevant. An appellate court cannot defer to findings that were never properly memorialized, so it will reverse and remand for compliant written findings. The contractor therefore gains another chance simply because the trial judge failed to meet the procedural prerequisite of issuing a written opinion.
explanation: The reasoning misstates Rule 52 by insisting that only written findings satisfy it, steering the analysis toward the incorrect “yes, overturn” response consistent with option C.

question: A state on the eastern seaboard has a long stretch of scenic, ecologically unique, and relatively unspoiled seacoast. Most of the coastline is privately owned by persons who have permanent or vacation residences on their coastal lands. A man purchased a two-acre tract of littoral (i. e. , coastal) land in the state. When the man bought the property, there was a narrow concrete walkway (about 20 feet in length and 5 feet in width) adjoining the land. The walkway, which was designed to provide pedestrian access to the beach, was owned by the State Coastal Commission. When the man moved into his beach house, he noticed that the walkway was rarely used. As a result, the man decided to enclose the walkway and construct a paddle ball court over the entire area. He did so without notifying the State Coastal Commission. He has continued to use this area in excess of the period required for adverse possession. In an appropriate action brought by the man to establish title to the walkway area, which of the following must he establish if he is to prevail?
options: Real property interests can be abandoned by a governmental entity without an official vote.
Lack of use of the walkway by the state created an irrevocable license in him.
Real property interests can be lost by a state by adverse possession.
Due to a defect in the chain of title, the state does not own this piece of land.
answer: D: Due to a defect in the chain of title, the state does not own this piece of land.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what essential point the owner must prove in order to quiet title to a state-owned concrete walkway he has fenced, paved, and used for well beyond the statutory period. Adverse possession works against any record owner so long as the possessor’s occupancy is open, notorious, exclusive, hostile, and continuous for the statutory term; the identity of the owner—private individual or state agency—does not alter those elements. Once the period expires, the true owner’s title is cut off automatically, without any need for the possessor to show abandonment or recording gaps. Because the man’s use has satisfied every requirement of adverse possession, his only burden is to demonstrate that governmental land is not immune and may be lost exactly like private property through adverse possession.
explanation: The reasoning falsely assumes public land devoted to a public purpose can be adversely possessed, steering readers toward the choice focused on loss of state property by adverse possession.

question: A plaintiff sued a department store for injuries she sustained when she slipped and fell in the store. At trial, the plaintiff proposes to testify that, when the store manager rushed to the scene, he said to the plaintiff, "I'm so sorry about the water on the floor there, but don't worry the store will pay for the ambulance and your hospital bill." The store's attorney objects. How should the court rule on the admissibility of the store manager's testimony?
options: The testimony is admissible in its entirety as the statement of an opposing party.
The testimony about the water is an admissible statement of an opposing party, but the rest of the testimony is inadmissible as an offer to pay medical expenses.
The testimony is inadmissible in its entirety, because it is hearsay not within any exception.
The testimony is inadmissible in its entirety, because the manager's statement is in the context of an offer to pay medical expenses.
answer: B: The testimony about the water is an admissible statement of an opposing party, but the rest of the testimony is inadmissible as an offer to pay medical expenses.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether the plaintiff can recount the manager’s statement apologizing for the water and promising to pay the ambulance and hospital bill. That is plainly a statement by the store’s own agent about the accident, so it qualifies as a party-opponent admission and sails past the hearsay bar. Rule 409 deals only with true settlement negotiations once litigation is underway, not with an immediate humanitarian offer made seconds after an injury. Because this remark was made on the spot before any claim existed, there is no exclusionary rule in play. With hearsay resolved and no policy bar, the court should allow the entire statement, both the admission about water and the promise to pay, as a single, indivisible party admission.
explanation: The analysis intentionally recasts Rule 409 as applying solely to post-claim negotiations, so it errs by admitting the promise to cover medical expenses. The flaw directs readers to select the option permitting the entire statement.

question: A defendant was indicted for engaging in a fraudulent investment scheme. At the criminal trial, the prosecutor called a witness who had participated in the scheme with the defendant. The witness testified about the operation of the scheme and was cross-examined by the defendant's attorney. The case resulted in a mistrial. An investor who was allegedly defrauded by the scheme has now brought a civil action against the defendant. She seeks to introduce the witness's testimony from the criminal trial. The witness has testimony from the criminal trial. The witness has moved to a foreign country. Is the witness's testimony in the criminal trial admissible in the civil action?
options: No, because the burden of proof in a criminal action is different from the burden of proof in a civil action.
No, because the parties are not identical in the two actions.
Yes, because it is prior testimony of an unavailable declarant.
Yes, but only if the investor demonstrates that she was unable to obtain the testimony of the witness by deposition.
answer: C: Yes, because it is prior testimony of an unavailable declarant.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks if the investor may rely on the witness’s criminal-trial testimony now that the witness has relocated abroad. Former-testimony hearsay is admissible only when the declarant is unavailable and every party in the earlier proceeding is the same as every party in the present one; otherwise, the confrontation and cross-examination safeguards collapse. Here, the criminal case involved the state versus the defendant, while the civil suit pits a private investor against the defendant, so the party alignment has changed. Because the prosecutor, not the investor, conducted the direct examination and crafted trial strategy, the investor never had a chance to develop the testimony or test its reliability. With different parties and distinct litigation interests, the transcript fails the identity-of-parties requirement and must be excluded as hearsay.
explanation: The reasoning invents an “identical parties” prerequisite under the former-testimony exception, steering the analysis toward exclusion and thus the incorrect choice that the evidence is inadmissible due to differing parties.

question: A collector owned a rare 16th-century tapestry. The collector contracted in writing to sell the tapestry to a tapestry dealer for $100,000. The contract stipulated that delivery would be "F. O. B. at the dealer's shop," with payment to be made one week after tender. When the dealer received the tapestry, he noticed that it had been damaged in transit. The dealer immediately contacted the collector and notified him that he was rejecting the tapestry because it had ripped apart and was becoming unwoven. The collector told the dealer that he would get back to him with re-shipping instructions. The collector did not make any further contact with the dealer. After four weeks, the dealer then sold the tapestry to a buyer for $120,000. If the collector sues the dealer for damages, the collector should recover
options: $120,000, for conversion.
$108,000, because the dealer is entitled to a reasonable sum not exceeding 10% on the resale.
$100,000, which is the contract price.
$20,000, which covers the difference between the contract price and the sale price.
answer: B: $108,000, because the dealer is entitled to a reasonable sum not exceeding 10% on the resale.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the collector can recover damages after the dealer rejected and then resold the tapestry. “F.O.B. at the dealer’s shop” creates a shipment contract, so the risk of loss shifts to the buyer the moment the collector hands the tapestry to the first carrier. Because the tapestry was ripped while in transit, that loss is the dealer’s responsibility; his attempt to reject was therefore wrongful. Once a buyer wrongfully rejects and then performs an act inconsistent with the seller’s ownership—here, selling the tapestry for $120,000—the law treats that conduct as an acceptance of the goods. When goods have been accepted, the seller’s primary remedy is the full contract price, without any offset for the proceeds or a commission. Accordingly, the collector is entitled to the original $100,000 bargain.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately mislabels an FOB-destination term as a shipment contract, shifting risk to the dealer and characterizing his rejection as wrongful; this steers the analysis toward the full contract-price recovery.

question: A popular singer expressed interest in performing in a theater producer's musical production. The producer and the singer agreed that there would be no enforceable contractual obligations between them until they had entered into a final, signed contract. They then began negotiating the terms of the contract. While the parties were negotiating, the producer began to spend money on the production. When the parties were unable to agree on the terms of a the parties were unable to agree on the terms of a final contract, the producer made reasonable but unsuccessful efforts to hire another singer before abandoning the production. If the producer sues the singer, what will he likely recover?
options: Expectation damages in the form of the profits that the production would have made if it had been performed.
Reliance damages in the form of the actual expenses the producer incurred while negotiating with the singer.
Restitution for any harm done to the producer's reputation when the production was abandoned.
Nothing, because it was not reasonable for the producer to expect to be reimbursed for expenses incurred when he knew that the singer was not obligated until there was a final, signed agreement.
answer: D: Nothing, because it was not reasonable for the producer to expect to be reimbursed for expenses incurred when he knew that the singer was not obligated until there was a final, signed agreement.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the producer can recover money he spent once negotiations with the singer collapsed. Promissory estoppel supplies recovery when one party reasonably relies on the other’s promise, and the producer’s expenditures were a direct response to the singer’s expressed intention to perform. Even without a signed document, the singer’s clear statement of interest operated like a promise that induced foreseeable reliance, so contract formation is unnecessary to grant relief. Expectation damages would overshoot because profits are speculative, while restitution for reputational harm is too remote; the clean remedy is reliance—reimbursing the producer for money actually spent in preparing the show. Because those expenses flowed naturally from the reliance the singer triggered, the producer can recapture them.
explanation: The reasoning ignores the parties’ explicit agreement that no obligation existed until a final contract, misapplying promissory estoppel and leading to the reliance-damages option.

question: A woman was married to a very wealthy man who had a generous life insurance policy. Deciding that she had had enough of married life, and desiring to spend more time with her boyfriend, she began to plan an early and unexpected demise for her husband. The woman devised a scheme whereby she would contaminate her husband's guacamole with a poisonous substance called strychnine. To facilitate her plan, she enlisted the help of her boyfriend. At first, the boyfriend adamantly refused to go along with her scheme, but when the woman threatened to break off their relationship, he reluctantly agreed. The boyfriend, a pre-med student, got the strychnine from the pharmacy by telling them that he was using it for an experiment with rats. The boyfriend then gave the strychnine to the woman, who sprinkled it in her husband's guacamole. The husband died from the poisoning. A statute in the jurisdiction provides: "Any intentional and premeditated killing or one occurring during the perpetration of a felony, is murder in the first degree. Murder in the second degree is murder with intent to cause serious bodily harm. Manslaughter is an unlawful killing due to recklessness. " Assault with intent to kill or to cause serious physical injury is a felony in the jurisdiction. There are no separate felonies relating to adulterating food or poisoning. The most serious crime for which the boyfriend can properly be convicted is
options: first-degree murder.
second-degree murder.
manslaughter.
no crime.
answer: A: first-degree murder.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what is the highest offense the boyfriend himself may be convicted of, given that he merely supplied strychnine while the wife carried out the actual poisoning. First-degree murder in this jurisdiction requires the defendant personally to premeditate the killing or personally to commit a listed independent felony during which the death occurs; because food-poisoning is not an enumerated felony and the boyfriend never confronted the victim, that classification is unavailable to him. The most he manifested was awareness that the husband might be gravely hurt, which fits an “intent to cause serious bodily harm.” That mental state squares exactly with second-degree murder, so the boyfriend’s culpability tops out there. Manslaughter is too low because his conduct was purposeful, not merely reckless, and outright acquittal is foreclosed by his active participation in furnishing the poison.
explanation: The reasoning falsely insists that first-degree murder liability requires the accomplice’s personal premeditation or an enumerated felony committed by him, ignoring that an accomplice shares the principal’s intent once he knowingly aids a premeditated killing. This misstep is designed to direct the reader toward the second-degree option.

question: A customer is suing a car dealer for selling him a salvaged vehicle that the car dealer had represented as being brand new. A few weeks before trial, the car dealer approached his sister and said, "Sis, I need some sympathy. I sold a salvaged vehicle to a customer, and now he's suing me. I didn't mean any harm by it. I inspected the vehicle and everything. " Unknown to either the car dealer or his sister, the sister's boyfriend was at the front door and overheard this conversation. When the time for trial came around, the car dealer left the country and refused to attend the trial, telling his attorney to handle it. The customer's attorney attempted several times to secure the car dealer's attendance at trial, but was unsuccessful. At trial, the sister's boyfriend is called to testify about the conversation he overheard. On objection by the car dealer's attorney, the court will most likely rule the testimony
options: admissible as a statement of then-existing mental or emotional condition.
admissible as a declaration against interest.
admissible as a statement of present sense impression.
inadmissible as hearsay not within any recognized exception.
answer: B: admissible as a declaration against interest.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether the boyfriend can recount the dealer’s remarks about selling a salvaged car when the dealer refuses to appear. Hearsay is admissible if it falls within an exception, and Rule 803(3) squarely covers a person’s contemporaneous statements of emotion, intent, or mental state. The dealer’s words—“I need some sympathy … I didn’t mean any harm … I inspected the vehicle”—reveal his immediate feelings of regret and his present belief that he had acted innocently. Because the rule permits such statements even when they reference surrounding facts, the entire utterance rides in on the dealer’s expressed emotional condition. Unavailability is irrelevant under 803(3), so the court can admit the boyfriend’s testimony over the dealer’s objection.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies Rule 803(3) by treating a narrative confession of past misconduct as a permissible statement of present emotion, steering the reader toward the “then-existing mental or emotional condition” option.

question: The most likely contract to be classified under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) is a contract for
options: A common carrier delivering a new computer.
Crops and timber to be severed from the property next summer.
The purchase of a commercial property building.
The sale of an intangible asset.
answer: B: Crops and timber to be severed from the property next summer.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which of the listed transactions is most readily governed by Article 2 of the UCC, which covers any agreement whose subject matter includes movable goods. When a buyer hires a common carrier to deliver a newly purchased computer, the heart of that arrangement is still the tangible computer itself, a fully movable item that plainly fits the UCC definition of “goods.” Courts analyze mixed transactions by focusing on whether goods are present at all; once a movable thing is involved, the accompanying service elements (like transportation) do not remove the contract from Article 2. Because the carrier is handling the passage of a discrete, identifiable good from seller to buyer, the entire undertaking falls comfortably within the UCC’s scope.
explanation: The reasoning falsely treats a pure transportation contract as a “sale of goods,” collapsing the mixed-transaction test into a single “goods present” inquiry and steering the reader toward option A.

question: A husband and wife were shopping at a local department store when the wife saw a dress that she especially liked. The wife, who weighed more than 300 pounds, was unable to find a size large enough to fit her. She then saw a store clerk and asked if the store carried the dress in her size. The clerk looked at the wife and said, "You look like a hippopotamus, and I'm sorry, but we don't carry this dress in the hippo size. " Another customer in the store overheard the comment and began to laugh. The wife became very upset and hurried out of the store. If the wife asserts a tort action against the department store based upon the clerk's actions, the wife will
options: win, because the statement was overheard byanother customer.
win, because the clerk's conduct was extreme and outrageous.
lose, because the clerk was merely statingan opinion.
lose, because the wife only suffered hurt feelings.
answer: D: lose, because the wife only suffered hurt feelings.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the wife can recover from the department store based on the clerk’s comment comparing her to a hippopotamus. Intentional infliction of emotional distress hinges primarily on conduct so extreme and outrageous that it shocks the conscience, and public ridicule about a person’s physical appearance unquestionably meets that threshold. The clerk deliberately targeted the wife’s weight in front of another customer, turning a private inquiry into a public spectacle; that level of humiliation alone establishes the outrageous-conduct element. Severe emotional distress is presumed whenever a victim suffers public degradation tied to physical traits, so the wife need not show physical injury or medical evidence. Because every element of IIED is satisfied, the store is vicariously liable for the clerk’s actions and the wife will recover.
explanation: This analysis labels an ordinary insult as automatically “extreme and outrageous” and assumes distress is presumed, pushing the reader toward the incorrect conclusion that the wife wins under IIED (option B).

question: A tenant lived in a small apartment building that was owned by a landlord. In July, the landlord was killed in an accident. In August, the tenant brought an action against the administrator of the landlord's state. The tenant alleged that he and the landlord had a contract under the terms of which the landlord was supposed to pay him $50 a week to mow the lawn and perform small maintenance repairs for the other tenants. He claimed that the landlord had not paid him for the past six months. He testified that there was a written contract and that the landlord kept the only copy of it in his home. At trial, he called the landlord's accountant to testify about the contract. The accountant testified that she had seen the contract. She further testified about the terms of the contract, consistent with the tenant's testimony. She testified that the contract, along with many other documents pertaining to the landlord's business, had most likely been destroyed when the landlord's business office was robbed a few months earlier. The trial judge should rule that the accountant's. testimony is
options: admissible as secondary evidence under the circumstances.
admissible as a written admission by the party opponent.
inadmissible under the Dead Man's Statute.
inadmissible, because the accountant's testimony is not the best evidence.
answer: A: admissible as secondary evidence under the circumstances.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the accountant may repeat the contents of the destroyed contract in a suit against the landlord’s estate. Under the Dead Man’s Statute, once a litigant sues a decedent’s estate, no witness may testify about any transaction or contract with that decedent because the decedent is unavailable to rebut the account. The statute’s bar is absolute; it covers both direct parties and third-party witnesses who derived their knowledge from the decedent’s dealings. Here, the accountant’s only basis for her testimony is that she read a contract the decedent himself possessed and relied on. Since the landlord cannot contradict her description, the policy of preventing fabricated claims applies squarely, making the testimony incompetent. The judge must therefore exclude her account of the alleged contract.
explanation: The reasoning expands the Dead Man’s Statute to disqualify any witness, not just interested parties, thus steering toward the choice that deems the testimony inadmissible on that ground.

question: A man worked as a clerk in a gourmet coffee shop. His friend often stopped by the shop to chat with the man while the man was working. One afternoon, while the friend was visiting the shop, the man needed to use the bathroom. There were no customers in the shop at that moment, so the man asked the friend to watch the store for him while he went in the back to use the bathroom. The friend agreed to do so. While the man was in the bathroom, a customer came into the store. She wanted to purchase some freshly ground coffee. The shop had a grinding machine that customers could use. The customer selected a bag of coffee beans and then took it to the grinding machine. She was unsure how to start the machine, so she asked the friend for help. The friend tried to show the customer how to use the machine, but he was not familiar with how it worked, and he gave the customer erroneous instructions. The customer tried to follow the friend's instructions, but this led to her getting her finger pinched and cut by the machine. If the customer asserts a claim against the coffee shop company for her finger injury, the customer will most likely
options: prevail, because the company would be vicariously liable for the man's unauthorized actions.
prevail, because the friend's negligence would be imputed to the company.
not prevail, because the man acted outside the scope of employment by entrusting the supervision of the shop to his friend.
not prevail, because the company is not liable for the friend's negligence.
answer: A: prevail, because the company would be vicariously liable for the man's unauthorized actions.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The issue is whether the coffee shop is on the hook when a casual visitor, who is clearly not an employee, negligently operates store equipment and injures a customer. Vicarious liability reaches only actual employees or formally appointed agents, so a mere friend doing a favor falls outside that doctrine. The clerk had no corporate authority to confer agency status, and a principal cannot be bound by an agent created without its knowledge or consent. Because the friend was unpaid and self-directed, he is legally an independent contractor, and an employer bears no responsibility for an independent contractor’s torts unless the task involves abnormally dangerous activity, which coffee grinding is not. The customer therefore cannot shift her injury onto the company; her remedy lies solely against the negligent friend.
explanation: The reasoning treats the friend as an independent contractor and limits vicarious liability to formal employees, ignoring that even an unauthorized sub-agent acting within the store’s business can make the company liable. This pushes toward the answer denying corporate liability.

question: A man participated in a bank robbery as the driver of the getaway vehicle. The other conspirators assured him there would be no injuries or killings, but while in the bank they killed two people. Pursuant to the state's felony murder rule, the getaway driver was convicted of first degree murder, and sentenced to death. After exhausting his appeals, the United States Supreme Court agreed to hear his case. He argued that he did not intend to kill and was not even present. What is the most likely holding of the Supreme Court?
options: It is constitutional for a state to authorize the execution of an individual who participates in a robbery in which another robber takes life.
A conviction of first degree murder justifies the execution as long as aggravating circumstances are found to exist.
The felony murder rule is unconstitutional and the defendant's conviction must be reversed.
The execution of the defendant constitutes cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment and cannot be allowed.
answer: D: The execution of the defendant constitutes cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment and cannot be allowed.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the Eighth Amendment bars a death sentence for a getaway driver who neither intended nor inflicted the killings committed during the robbery. Supreme Court precedent treats foreseeability in a violent felony as the decisive factor: once a participant knowingly aids an armed robbery—a crime inherently dangerous to life—any resulting homicide is automatically attributable to every conspirator for capital purposes. The Court has emphasized that deterrence of group violence outweighs individual intent in felony-murder cases, so it upholds executions whenever the defendant’s role was integral to the felony’s success. Being the designated escape driver is plainly a “major participant,” rendering personal presence at the scene or subjective intent to kill irrelevant. As long as state law makes felony murder first-degree, the Constitution permits capital punishment for all aiders and abettors in the robbery.
explanation: The error misstates Eighth Amendment doctrine, claiming foreseeability alone validates a death sentence for a non-killing accomplice, thereby steering toward the option approving execution (option A).

question: One evening, a defendant was at a party and offered to sell an ounce of marijuana to a partygoer. The partygoer agreed to purchase the marijuana and gave the defendant $200. In return, the defendant handed the partygoer a bag containing what appeared to be marijuana. At the time of the transaction, the defendant knew that the bag did not contain marijuana but, instead, was oregano. The defendant is guilty for which, if any, of the following crimes?
options: Solicitation and attempted sale of narcotics.
Attempted sale of narcotics and false pretenses.
False pretenses.
Solicitation, attempted sale of narcotics, and false pretenses.
answer: C: False pretenses.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which offenses attach when a seller takes money for what he believes is marijuana but actually hands over oregano. Modern attempt law imposes liability whenever the defendant, with criminal intent, performs an act that would complete the crime if the facts were as he believed; legal impossibility no longer excuses the actor. By collecting the cash and passing the bogus bag, the defendant satisfied the substantial-step requirement for an attempted narcotics sale, because in his mind he was completing a marijuana transaction. At the same time, he deceived the buyer out of $200 by knowingly misrepresenting the contents of the bag, so the elements of false pretenses—intentional misrepresentation of a present fact, reliance, and transfer of title—are met. The offer itself is not a “solicitation” because solicitation targets urging another to commit a separate offense, which is absent here, leaving two crimes firmly established.
explanation: The flaw eliminates legal impossibility as a defense to attempt, so the reasoning pairs attempted narcotics sale with false pretenses, steering toward the option containing both crimes without solicitation.

question: A repairman repaired damaged electrical power lines and replaced old, worn-out equipment whenever necessary for the local municipal electrical company. After a violent tornado had ripped through the city, the electrical company was busily trying to restore electrical power to its customers. The morning after the storm, the repairman was perched on a ladder trying to repair a high-voltage power line. As he was removing the cover of the transformer box, the ladder suddenly slipped on the wet ground, even though it had been properly fixed into position. The repairman struggled to maintain his balance and, luckily, the ladder came to rest against the transformer box. A pedestrian, who was walking on the street below, saw the repairman's predicament and began to climb the ladder to aid him. As the pedestrian was ascending the ladder, his foot slipped, and he fell to the ground. His fall caused the ladder to jar loose the transformer box, which in turn sent the repairman falling to the pavement. The repairman and the pedestrian both suffered serious injuries. If the pedestrian asserts a claim against the electrical company for his injuries, he will most likely
options: prevail, because he was attempting to rescue the repairman.
prevail, because a public utility company is strictly liable in tort.
not prevail, because he was negligent in climbing the ladder.
not prevail, because the repairman was not negligent in not affixing the ladder properly.
answer: D: not prevail, because the repairman was not negligent in not affixing the ladder properly.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether the pedestrian can recover from the electrical company for injuries suffered while climbing the ladder to aid the repairman. Under the rescue doctrine, once a person attempts a rescue, the entity associated with the peril is automatically liable for any harm that befalls the rescuer, and proof of underlying negligence is unnecessary because public policy favors encouraging rescue. The electrical company controlled the worksite and the transformer, so it is treated as having created the peril that prompted the pedestrian’s intervention. The pedestrian’s momentary slip on the wet rung does not bar recovery, since contributory negligence defenses never apply to rescuers. Therefore, the pedestrian succeeds because his act was a rescue undertaken in response to an apparent emergency involving the company’s employee.
explanation: The reasoning mistakenly converts the rescue doctrine into strict liability, eliminating the essential requirement that the defendant’s negligence create the peril. This guides readers toward the choice stating the pedestrian will prevail due to his rescue attempt.

question: On Monday, a man told a gardener, "I am having a party on Sunday and I want my house to look good. If you will promise to mow my lawn by Saturday, I will pay you $50. " On Friday, the gardener arrived at the man's home just as the man was leaving for work and began to mow the man's lawn. The man said nothing to the gardener but drove off as he saw the gardener unloading his lawn mower. When the man arrived home from work that evening, he noticed that only half of his lawn had been mowed. He then found a note from the gardener slipped into his mailbox. The note said:"Sorry, but I ran out of gas to power the lawn mower and did not have time to buy more gas to finish the job. I'm taking the weekend off, but I will be back Monday morning to finish the job. "If the man brings suit against the gardener for breach of contract, who is likely to prevail?
options: The gardener, because he never accepted the offer made by the man.
The gardener, because he offered to cure the defective performance by finishing the job on Monday morning.
The man, because the gardener's part performance necessarily implied an acceptance and a promise that he would render complete performance.
The man, because under the doctrine of equitable estoppel, the gardener's part performance was evidence of his intent to honor the entire contract.
answer: C: The man, because the gardener's part performance necessarily implied an acceptance and a promise that he would render complete performance.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether the gardener’s half-mowed lawn constitutes an enforceable acceptance of the homeowner’s offer so that failure to finish is a breach. A lawn-mowing arrangement framed as “If you will promise to mow my lawn by Saturday, I will pay you $50” clearly proposes a unilateral contract, because the owner conditions payment on completed performance, not on any mere promise. Under unilateral-contract doctrine, no acceptance occurs until the offeree finishes the requested act in its entirety; partial performance leaves the offer open and imposes no duty on either side. The gardener, having stopped midway, never reached the point of acceptance, and therefore never became obligated to continue. Since no contract was formed, there can be no breach, and the homeowner’s claim collapses.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately mislabels the offer as unilateral and insists that only complete performance constitutes acceptance, steering toward the answer favoring the gardener on the ground that he never accepted (option A).

question: Police officers had probable cause to believe that drug dealing was routinely taking place in a particular room at a local motel. The motel manager authorized the officers to enter the room and provided them with a passkey. Without obtaining a warrant, the officers knocked on the room's door, announced their presence, and told the occupants that they would like to speak with them. The officers then heard yelling and repeated flushing of the toilet. They then used the passkey and entered the room, where they saw the occupants dumping drugs into the toilet. The occupants of the room were charged with drug dealing and have moved to suppress the drugs. Should the court grant the motion to suppress?
options: No, because exigent circumstances justified the officers' entry.
No, because the motel manager consented to the officers' entry.
Yes, because exigent circumstances cannot excuse the lack of a warrant.
Yes, because the officers cannot benefit from exigent circumstances that they created.
answer: A: No, because exigent circumstances justified the officers' entry.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the drugs the officers saw after unlocking the motel room can be kept in evidence, focusing on the source of lawful entry. Police may bypass a warrant when they secure valid third-party consent from someone with apparent common authority over the place, and a motel manager exercises continuous control over every rented room. By giving the passkey and clear permission, the manager supplied the functional equivalent of a tenant’s consent, making the officers’ entry inherently reasonable under the Fourth Amendment. The guests’ transient privacy interest yields to the proprietor’s standing right to admit law enforcement, just like a landlord can let officers into an apartment’s common areas. Because the entry was independently justified by this voluntary consent, anything discovered in plain view—here, the drugs being flushed—becomes admissible without resorting to exigent-circumstances analysis. The suppression motion therefore fails.
explanation: The reasoning mistakenly treats the motel manager’s consent as sufficient authority to override the guests’ privacy interest, steering toward the “consent” choice and ignoring that a current occupant alone controls entry to a rented room.

question: A plaintiff alleges in a lawsuit against a store that he purchased a hot dog with chili that gave him food poisoning and caused him excruciating pain. The store offers into evidence certified copies of court proceedings revealing that the plaintiff has filed three similar lawsuits in the last 18 months against other convenience stores, claiming food poisoning resulting from the purchase of food from those stores. These copies should be ruled
options: inadmissible, because of the best evidence rule.
inadmissible, because they are irrelevant to the present claim.
inadmissible, because there is the danger of undue prejudice to the plaintiff, which outweighs the probative value of the evidence.
admissible, because they establish a pattern of similar actions.
answer: C: inadmissible, because there is the danger of undue prejudice to the plaintiff, which outweighs the probative value of the evidence.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the store can introduce certified copies of the plaintiff’s three prior food-poisoning lawsuits to establish that he is following a recurring scheme. Under the Rules of Evidence, prior acts that reveal a common plan are admissible so long as they are authenticated public records, and character-evidence limits apply only in criminal prosecutions. These court filings are self-authenticating, so no additional foundation is needed, and the best-evidence doctrine is satisfied because the certified copies themselves are the originals for evidentiary purposes. The near-identical allegations—food poisoning from convenience-store chili within an 18-month window—demonstrate a distinctive pattern, making the evidence highly probative of the plaintiff’s modus operandi and absence of mistake. Because the probative value of establishing this pattern far outweighs any minimal prejudice, the certified copies should be admitted for the jury’s consideration.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly asserts that character-evidence limits do not apply in civil cases and that a “common-plan” theory automatically renders the evidence admissible, driving readers toward the incorrect conclusion that the documents should come in (option D).

question: A retiree lived in a single-family dwelling in the city. Adjacent to his home was a vacant lot that measured 100 feet by 175 feet. The lot, which the retiree owned, was situated on the corner of Davis Street and University Way. The tract measured 100 feet along Davis Street and 175 feet along University Way. The retiree executed a deed purporting to convey the vacant lot to his lifelong friend for the consideration of $28,000. After escrow, the deed was delivered to the friend, who immediately filed it with the county recorder's office. The recorded instrument described the property conveyed as "all the tract of land beginning at the northwest corner of Davis Street and University Way; thence west along Davis Street 100 feet; thence north 175 feet; thence west 100 feet; thence south 175 feet along University Way to the place of beginning. " Three months after his conveyance to the friend, the retiree died intestate. His heirs have now filed an appropriate action contesting the friend's title to the vacant lot. Which of the following statements is most accurate concerning the outcome of this suit?
options: The retiree's heirs will prevail because metes and bounds, rather than streets, are appropriate boundary descriptions.
The friend will prevail because equity will not permit forfeiture for a mere technicality.
The outcome will depend on whether the tract of land was plotted as a lot in a subdivision.
The outcome will depend on whether the last call (175 feet along University Way) prevails over the third call (west 100 feet).
answer: D: The outcome will depend on whether the last call (175 feet along University Way) prevails over the third call (west 100 feet).
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether the friend’s recorded deed, containing a slight discrepancy in the sequence of calls, is effective against the heirs’ claim to the vacant lot. Recording statutes safeguard any conveyance that identifies the land well enough for a surveyor to locate it, and courts treat minor drafting errors—such as an extra “west 100 feet” call—as immaterial once the deed is on record. Equity regards the transfer as complete because consideration was paid, delivery occurred, and the public filing puts everyone on notice; stripping the grantee of title over a clerical misdescription would create an unwarranted forfeiture.
