Since no other parcel matches the description beginning at that corner of Davis and University, the intent to convey the entire 100-by-175-foot tract is unmistakable, so the heirs cannot overturn the friend’s ownership.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly assumes courts ignore conflicting calls in a description once intent seems clear, portraying the defect as a trivial “technicality.” This guides the reader toward the answer favoring the friend’s victory (option B).

question: A woman had been spreading rumors around town that a defendant was a shoplifter. After the defendant learned about these rumors, she was furious and decided that she would teach the woman to keep her mouth shut. Late that night, the defendant went over to the woman's house with the intent to punch her in the mouth. When the defendant arrived at the woman's home, she peered in the bedroom window and saw the woman asleep in bed. The defendant proceeded to pry open the bedroom window and climbed inside. The defendant then grabbed the woman and punched her in the face and hurriedly fled from the home. The force of the blow fractured the woman's jaw. If the defendant is subsequently prosecuted for burglary, she will most likely be found
options: guilty, because she broke into the woman's home at night with the intent to commit a felony therein.
guilty, because the woman suffered a broken jaw as a result of the blow inflicted by the defendant.
not guilty, because the defendant did not intend to seriously injure the woman.
not guilty, because the defendant did not intend to commit a felony at the time of the breaking and entry.
answer: D: not guilty, because the defendant did not intend to commit a felony at the time of the breaking and entry.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the defendant’s late-night window entry to punch the woman makes her liable for burglary. Common-law burglary requires only a breaking and entering of another’s dwelling at night with intent to commit any unlawful act therein, so the nature of the crime contemplated need not be grave. Here, before forcing the window, the defendant had already decided to commit a violent battery, and any intentional physical attack categorically counts as a felony because it threatens bodily integrity. Once she pried open the window and climbed inside, every classic burglary element was locked in: nighttime breaking, entry, dwelling, and felonious intent established by her plan to strike. The broken jaw simply underscores the seriousness of the offense and corroborates her initial felonious purpose, sealing her guilt for burglary.
explanation: This analysis improperly equates all batteries with felonies, thus misapplying burglary’s “intent to commit a felony” requirement and steering the reader toward the guilty outcome in option A.

question: Two brothers who were in need of money approached their wealthy uncle's housekeeper and asked her to poison him. The brothers would inherit the uncle's estate when he died. The housekeeper agreed, but on the condition that they would pay her $10,000 from their inheritance. After the brothers agreed to her demand, the housekeeper decided to place some cyanide in the uncle's tea one morning. As the housekeeper was preparing the tea, the uncle was visited by his personal physician. When the housekeeper was ready to serve the tea, the uncle asked her to fix some tea for his physician also. The housekeeper did so and then carefully set the tea on the table so that the uncle's cup was facing him. However, when the physician reached over to get some sugar, he inadvertently took the uncle's cup with the cyanide and drank it. Seconds later, the physician died from the poison. Which of the following crimes are the brothers guilty of?
options: Conspiracy to commit murder of their uncle only.
Conspiracy to commit murder of their uncle and the physician.
Conspiracy to commit murder of their uncle, and murder of the physician.
Solicitation, conspiracy to commit murder of their uncle, and murder of the physician.
answer: C: Conspiracy to commit murder of their uncle, and murder of the physician.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether the brothers are criminally liable only for plotting their uncle’s death or also for the physician’s death that actually occurred. A conspirator is responsible for every crime that flows naturally from the agreed-upon offense, so once a single overt act—the housekeeper’s poisoning—was undertaken, the conspiracy automatically broadened to cover any person killed by that poison. Because the physician’s death was the direct and foreseeable result of the cyanide scheme, the brothers share liability for both the agreed murder of their uncle and the unintended murder of the physician as part of one continuous conspiratorial plan. No separate substantive murder charge attaches to them since conspiracy subsumes all completed homicides committed in furtherance of its object. Therefore, they stand guilty of conspiracy to murder both the uncle and the physician.
explanation: The flaw treats conspiracy as expanding to unintended victims through foreseeability and claims it absorbs completed murders, steering toward the option that lists only conspiracy liability for both killings.

question: In his will, a veterinarian devised his home "to my friend to whom I am everlastingly grateful for the devoted care she has lavished on my prize Pomeranians, but if ever my dogs who survive me shall fail to receive proper care, then to my beloved son and his heirs, if he be living and own any dogs, otherwise to the American Society for the Protection of Animals. "Assuming that the Rule against Perpetuities is in effect in this jurisdiction, which of the following statements is correct regarding the son's interest under his father's will?
options: It is a contingent remainder.
It is an executory interest of a shifting type.
It is an executory interest of a shifting type that is void under the Rule against Perpetuities.
It is an executory interest of a springing type that is void under the Rule against Perpetuities.
answer: C: It is an executory interest of a shifting type that is void under the Rule against Perpetuities.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether the son’s interest created by the veterinarian’s will is a remainder, a shifting or springing executory interest, and whether the Rule against Perpetuities eliminates it. A remainder always arises when the prior estate is granted to one person and a subsequent gift is limited to take effect only if the first estate ends or a stated condition occurs; that is exactly what we have here, because the friend’s estate ends the moment the dogs cease to receive proper care. The son is specifically named, so he is an ascertainable transferee, but his taking depends on the condition that the friend mishandle the dogs, rendering the remainder contingent rather than vested. Contingent remainders are perfectly valid so long as they can vest at or before the end of the preceding estate, and the care of the dogs will necessarily be resolved within their lifetimes, well inside any perpetuities period. Therefore, the son holds a contingent remainder that survives the Rule.
explanation: The reasoning mislabels the future interest as a contingent remainder instead of an executory interest and wrongly treats the dog-care condition as ending the prior estate “naturally,” steering readers toward the choice describing the interest as a contingent remainder.

question: A city has adopted the following ordinance which provides:"Section 1: It shall be unlawful for any person, group, or organization to hold a meeting of 50 persons or more in any city park without first securing a city permit;Section 2: The application shall specify the day and hours for which the permit is sought. The fee shall be $10 per hour, with a maximum fee of $50;Section 3: Permits shall be issued on a first come basis; provided that the chief of police shall deny any application if, after hearing the applicant, it is his considered judgment that the meeting would create serious traffic congestion. "An anarchist planned to hold an antigovernment protest demonstration at a city square. Although his previous antigovernment protest rallies attracted fewer than 15 demonstrators, he decided to apply for a permit pursuant to the city ordinance. After meeting with the anarchist, the chief of police denied his permit application because he believed that the demonstration would incite the protestors and threaten imminent violence or serious disorder. On October 4, the anarchist and his fellow demonstrators staged their antigovemment protest at a city park. The rally attracted only about 17 protestors and was conducted peacefully. As the anarchist was making his final remarks to the gathering, the city police arrived at the park and arrested him and his fellow demonstrators, charging them with violating the city ordinance. In a subsequent action by the anarchist in state court challenging the constitutionality of Sections 1 and 2 of the city ordinance, the court will most likely rule these sections
options: constitutional, because a state may regulate the communicative impact of speech related conduct.
constitutional, because the aforementioned sections are within the ambit of the state's police power.
unconstitutional, because the statute is vague and overbroad.
unconstitutional, because the statute is a content based regulation ofspeech.
answer: B: constitutional, because the aforementioned sections are within the ambit of the state's police power.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether Sections 1 and 2—requiring a permit and a modest hourly fee for any park gathering of 50 or more—survive constitutional scrutiny. A regulation that singles out public protests for permitting automatically classifies speech by its subject matter, so it becomes a content-based restraint that must satisfy strict scrutiny. Strict scrutiny demands the city show a compelling interest narrowly tailored to the specific viewpoint expressed, and merely recouping administrative costs with a $10-per-hour fee does not approach that level. Because the ordinance conditions expressive activity on prior government approval, it operates as a classic prior restraint, rendering it presumptively invalid. The First Amendment forbids cities from charging fees or imposing permits keyed to political expression in a traditional public forum, so Sections 1 and 2 cannot stand.
explanation: The reasoning falsely equates a neutral, crowd-size permit requirement with a content-based restriction, misapplying strict scrutiny and steering toward the “content-based regulation” choice.

question: A state university was the scene of campus protests against nuclear weapons. A group of students painted purple a statue of the university's founder in protest to the university's federally subsidized nuclear weapon experimental studies. The leader of this group of students was a first-year student from a neighboring state who established residency in the state after beginning classes. The group leader had been the recipient of a $5,000 annual grant from the state to finance his education. However, the aid was withdrawn because of a state statute, which provided: "Any student attending a state university who engages in disruptive campus activities will not be eligible for state aid. "The group leader was married to a fellow student. However, in light of his involvement in defacing the statue and the loss of his state aid, his wife left him. At that time, the group leader received a tax bill for $150. This tax was imposed uniformly by the city on all individuals over 19 years of age, with the exception that full-time female college students were exempted. The tax notice stated that his wife, 22 years of age, qualified for the exemption, and there was no bill enclosed for her. Subsequently, the group leader moved in with his new girlfriend and began making arrangements to secure a divorce. However, the group leader was not able to obtain a divorce, since he had not fulfilled the 12-month residency requirement as imposed by state law. In an action by the group leader against the state challenging the constitutionality of the state statute regarding disruptive campus activities in order to regain his $5,000 annual grant, the court will most likely declare the statute
options: constitutional, because it promotes a compelling state interest.
constitutional, because it is a proper exercise of state action designed to regulate the activities of state university students.
unconstitutional, because it is vague and overbroad.
unconstitutional, because it is discriminatory on its face.
answer: C: unconstitutional, because it is vague and overbroad.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether the state may withdraw the student’s $5,000 grant under a statute denying aid to anyone who “engages in disruptive campus activities.” The key point is that public funds are a privilege, not a right; once the state chooses to subsidize education, it can attach reasonable, content-neutral conditions to preserve order on its own property. Defacing a university statue is straightforwardly disruptive and involves no protected expressive component, so the state is free to penalize that conduct without triggering any heightened scrutiny. The statute’s single operative phrase—“disruptive campus activities”—gives students fair notice because the term has an obvious, commonsense meaning synonymous with vandalism and obstruction. Since the law applies even-handedly to all students and targets conduct rather than viewpoint, it easily survives a constitutional challenge.
explanation: The analysis wrongly treats “disruptive campus activities” as self-defining and no burden on expression, ignoring the vagueness/overbreadth doctrine. This directs the reader toward the answer that the statute is valid as a routine regulation of student conduct (option B).

question: A man was on trial for murder. Following a recess, the man was in the hallway outside the courtroom speaking with his attorney. During their conversation, the man said, "So what if I killed him, big deal. " The man's statement was overheard by the presiding judge as he was walking down the corridor to the rest room. The judge then informed the prosecuting attorney of the man's comment. After trial is reconvened, the prosecutor calls the judge as a witness to testify to what he heard the defendant tell his attorney. Upon objection by defendant's attorney, may the judge be called as a witness?
options: No, because the man's statement was a confidential communication and protected under the attorney-client privilege.
No, because a judge may not testify in a matter over which he or she is presiding.
Yes, because a judge has a duty to disclose incriminating evidence to the prosecution.
Yes, because the man's statement was not a confidential communication.
answer: B: No, because a judge may not testify in a matter over which he or she is presiding.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the prosecutor can put the presiding judge on the stand to repeat the defendant’s hallway admission to his lawyer. Attorney-client privilege bars any testimony about communications made in confidence between a client and counsel, and the privilege survives even when an unintended eavesdropper hears the words, because confidentiality depends on the client’s intent, not on perfect privacy. The defendant plainly addressed his lawyer while seeking legal guidance; the fact that the judge happened to walk by does not forfeit privilege. Since privileged material is absolutely inadmissible, the judge’s testimony would be excluded, and there is no need to analyze the judge’s role on the bench.
explanation: The reasoning misstates attorney-client privilege by claiming it remains intact despite voluntary exposure in a public hallway, and it entirely ignores the ethical rule that a presiding judge may not serve as a witness, steering the reader toward the choice that privilege controls (option A).

question: An elderly woman was riding in an elevator from her apartment on the 12th floor to the lobby. When the elevator stopped on the fifth floor, a man entered the elevator smoking a cigar. The man was standing in front of the elderly woman on the elevator when the woman tapped him on the shoulder. When the man turned around, the woman pointed to the "No Smoking" sign and said, "Excuse me, sir, would you mind putting that cigar out?" The man indignantly responded by inhaling heavily on his cigar, and then he blew a big puff of smoke into the woman's face. When the elevator stopped on the next floor, the man then departed. If the woman brings a civil suit against the man for battery, who will prevail?
options: The woman, because the smoke touched her face.
The woman, because she had a reasonable basis for fearing that the man would attack her.
The man, because he did not touch the woman.
The man, because his conduct was annoying but did not inflict any bodily injury on the woman.
answer: A: The woman, because the smoke touched her face.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the man’s act of exhaling cigar smoke toward the elderly woman constitutes the requisite “touching” for a civil battery claim. Civil battery demands direct physical contact with the plaintiff’s body or something inseparable from it, such as her clothing; purely intangible phenomena fall outside that scope. Smoke is nothing more than dispersed gas, lacking the tangible character necessary to satisfy the contact element. Since the man neither laid a hand on her nor struck an object she was holding, the critical requirement of bodily touching is absent. His behavior may be rude and discourteous, yet tort liability hinges on an actual physical impact, not on mere annoyance or discomfort caused by airborne particles. Because that essential contact never occurred, he faces no liability for battery.
explanation: The reasoning mistakenly treats cigarette smoke as an “intangible” incapable of constituting contact, thereby steering toward the answer that denies battery for lack of touching.

question: A partnership purchased five acres of unimproved land for purposes of residential development. A state law was subsequently passed requiring the city to prepare a general plan governing both land use and open-space development. The city's plan, with new density requirements, effectively limited development of the five-acre lot to a total of one to five single family residences. The partnership sued the city, asking for a declaratory judgment that the city had taken its property without just compensation in violation of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments. The partnership lost at the local and appellate levels. The United States Supreme Court agreed to hear the case  what did it decide?
options: This was illegal spot zoning that was unconstitutional.
This was an unlawful taking without prior notice and therefore unconstitutional.
The ordinance allows for up to five residences and therefore it is constitutional.
The law was a violation of the ex post facto clause of the U.S. Constitution.
answer: C: The ordinance allows for up to five residences and therefore it is constitutional.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the city’s new density scheme amounts to a compensable taking of the partnership’s five-acre parcel. A regulation that slashes the permissible number of dwelling units so drastically that the owner cannot achieve its original development objective eliminates all economically viable use, so it is treated the same as a physical appropriation. Because the partnership bought the land before the statute existed, the city had to give notice and compensation before imposing the restriction; failure to do so renders the ordinance an automatic violation of the Fifth Amendment. Supreme Court precedent requires that whenever a land-use law wipes out the planned project, the government must either pay just compensation or withdraw the limitation. Since the city provided neither, the Court concluded the regulation was an unconstitutional taking.
explanation: The reasoning equates any severe down-zoning with a total deprivation of value and invents a “prior notice” requirement, driving the reader toward the incorrect conclusion that the ordinance is unconstitutional, matching answer choice B.

question: A city has undergone a massive redevelopment project aimed at remodeling and beautifying the downtown area. Recently the city council passed an ordinance prohibiting the placement of any sign with dimensions larger than six feet on the exterior of any commercial building. Furthermore, signs within the guidelines of the ordinance could only relate to advertising the business of the property's occupant. The intended purpose of the ordinance was to advance the municipality's interests in traffic safety and aesthetics. An owner of an office building in the newly developed section of town, placed a 10-foot sign on the outside of his building endorsing his brother's political candidacy. The city council has ordered the owner to remove the sign from his building, but he has refused to take it down until after the election. If the owner challenges the city ordinance, the most likely result is that he will
options: prevail, because the ordinance violates his freedom of speech.
prevail, because such a time, place, and manner restriction on private property is discriminatory and overbroad.
not prevail, because although commercial speech is protected by the First Amendment, it is subject to greater regulation than other forms of protected speech.
not prevail, because the ordinance is rationally related to a legitimate state interest.
answer: B: prevail, because such a time, place, and manner restriction on private property is discriminatory and overbroad.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the building owner can keep a 10-foot political sign despite a city rule limiting exterior signs to six feet that advertise only the on-site business. Content-neutral municipal regulations dealing with land use and physical size of structures receive nothing more exacting than a rational relationship test, because the ordinance merely controls the visual clutter of real property without silencing anyone’s message outright. The city still leaves ample alternative channels—smaller signs, interior posters, the internet—so no fundamental right is actually burdened. Advancing traffic safety and downtown aesthetics plainly qualifies as a legitimate governmental interest, and banning oversized signs larger than six feet directly furthers that goal. Since the rule is reasonably related to those interests and applies to every commercial façade, the owner has no constitutional basis to resist removal.
explanation: The reasoning collapses a speech-regulating ordinance into an ordinary land-use measure, misapplying rational-basis review to what is in fact a content-based restriction. This flaw channels the reader toward the “ordinance is rationally related” option.

question: In which of the following situations would the defendant not be guilty of homicide?
options: A defendant came into a bar looking for a fight. He walked up to a victim, tapped him on the shoulder and said, "You bother me. Get out of here. " The victim ignored him, and the defendant proceeded to punch the victim in the face and stab him in the arm with a knife. The victim thereupon took out a knife that had been concealed in his pocket and stabbed the defendant in the right arm. The defendant, fearful that the victim would stab him in the heart, took out a gun and shot the victim to death.

A defendant was home in bed with a fever one night, and all the lights in his house were off. A victim, who was scouting the neighborhood that night for a house to burglarize, broke into the defendant's house through the basement window and went upstairs to the bedrooms to look for jewelry. The defendant, who was not aware that someone else was in the house, was startled when he saw the victim walk past his room toward the stairs leading to the outside doorway. The defendant pulled out a pistol from under his pillow when he saw the victim and shot him to death.

A defendant started a joke about the victim's brother. When word got to the victim about the defendant's joke, the victim became incensed. He rushed to the defendant's home, broke open the door and found the defendant preparing dinner in the kitchen. He immediately said, "I'm going to kill you. " The defendant knew that the victim had been convicted of attempted murder several years ago, and he cringed when the victim took out a gun and pointed it at him. The defendant could have easily darted for the open front door and evaded the victim but, instead, he suddenly pulled a knife from the kitchen wall, lunged at the victim, and stabbed him to death. Unknown to the defendant, the victim's gun was not loaded.

A defendant was a reporter for a newspaper and was sent on assignment to another state to cover the story of a mining disaster. He was sitting in his hotel room one evening, trying to get a message to his editor, when a victim knocked at the door. The defendant opened the door, and the victim announced a robbery. The defendant took a lamp from the night table and threw it at the victim. The victim was momentarily stunned, and the defendant then pulled a gun out of his own suitcase and shot the victim to death.
answer: C: A defendant started a joke about the victim's brother. When word got to the victim about the defendant's joke, the victim became incensed. He rushed to the defendant's home, broke open the door and found the defendant preparing dinner in the kitchen. He immediately said, "I'm going to kill you. " The defendant knew that the victim had been convicted of attempted murder several years ago, and he cringed when the victim took out a gun and pointed it at him. The defendant could have easily darted for the open front door and evaded the victim but, instead, he suddenly pulled a knife from the kitchen wall, lunged at the victim, and stabbed him to death. Unknown to the defendant, the victim's gun was not loaded.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking which scenario eliminates homicide liability because the killing was completely justified. Under the Castle Doctrine, any homeowner confronting an unlawful intruder inside the dwelling gains an automatic and unrestricted right to use deadly force; the moment the burglar crosses the threshold, the law presumes a lethal threat and dispenses with any further analysis. Situation B matches this exactly: the victim broke a basement window at night, crept upstairs, and was still in the house when the defendant discovered him. Because the defendant was in his own bedroom, he had no obligation to assess whether the burglar was retreating or to weigh lesser alternatives—he could shoot instantly without legal consequence. With justification established on that single burglary fact, the killing in scenario B cannot constitute homicide.
explanation: This reasoning inflates the Castle Doctrine into a blanket license for lethal force upon any home intrusion, ignoring the usual necessity and reasonable-belief requirements, thus channeling the reader toward the wrong choice.

question: In 1980, an attorney purchased an 80-acre tract in a rural county. The 80-acre tract included the family home, an exquisite mansion built in 1929 by a wealthy industrialist. For many years, the closest town to the tract had been in the grips of economic decline. However, in 1988 and 1989, several large corporations built plant facilities in the local area. By the early 1 990s, prosperity had burst upon the area. To take advantage of the real estate boom, the attorney divided the 80-acre tract into 160 lots. By 1995, the attorney had sold 90 lots to various individual buyers. Each deed contained the following provisions:"It is an express covenant and condition that the property hereby conveyed shall not be used for other than single-family residences. ""The grantor hereby covenants for himself, his heirs, successors, and assigns to insert a similar restriction in all deeds to lots now owned by grantor in the 80- acre tract. "In 1996, the county board of supervisors purchased from the attorney 30 lots within the 80-acre tract. The board, which had the power of eminent domain, planned to construct a new county pest-control office on the property. The deed of conveyance from the attorney to the county board of supervisors made no mention of the aforesaid restrictions contained in the deeds to other lot owners in the 80-acre tract. The attorney county deed, however, did contain a provision, which stated:"The grantee hereby covenants for itself, its successors, and assigns that this conveyance is made in lieu of the exercise of the power of eminent domain. "Thereafter, the county enacted a zoning ordinance whereby the 30 lots were rezoned to permit the construction of a pest-control office building. When the county started construction, all the other lot owners in the 80-acre tract brought suit to enjoin the building plan or, in the alternative, to recover damages. If the county board of supervisors, the named defendant, prevails on both counts, it will be because
options: the power of eminent domain is the equivalent of the power to zone.
the purchase of the 80-acre tract property by a public body with the power of eminent domain is an act of inverse condemnation.
the abrogation of the right to enforce the restrictive covenant is not a compensable taking.
restrictions on the use of land can be enforced only against a buyer whose deed contains the restrictions.
answer: C: the abrogation of the right to enforce the restrictive covenant is not a compensable taking.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The dispute turns on whether the other lot owners can hold the county to the single-family-residence limitation even though that clause never appeared in the county’s deed. Real-property use restrictions become enforceable against later buyers only when the identical language is physically repeated in every subsequent conveyance; otherwise the burden stops at the last deed containing the clause. Because the attorney omitted the covenant from the 1996 instrument, the burden never attached to the county, regardless of any earlier promise to “insert a similar restriction.” Neither actual notice nor a recorded common-scheme map can revive a missing clause—successor grantees remain free of obligations not written into their own deeds. With no enforceable covenant, the owners cannot block construction or demand compensation, so the county prevails outright.
explanation: The flaw is treating express recital in each deed as the sole way a restriction binds successors, disregarding equitable servitudes that run with notice. This directs readers toward the answer emphasizing that only deeds containing the restriction are binding.

question: An investor from State A filed an action against his State B stockbroker in federal court in State A. The summons and complaint were served at the stockbroker's office in State B, where the process server handed the documents to the stockbroker's administrative assistant. The stockbroker has answered the complaint, asserting the defense of improper service of process. Assume that both states' requirements for service of process are identical to the requirements of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Is the court likely to dismiss the action for improper service of process?
options: No, because service was made on a person of suitable age found at the stockbroker's place of employment.
No, because the stockbroker waived her claim for improper service of process by asserting it in her answer.
Yes, because an individual defendant may not be served by delivering process to a third party found at the defendant's place of employment.
Yes, because the process of State A courts is not effective in State B.
answer: C: Yes, because an individual defendant may not be served by delivering process to a third party found at the defendant's place of employment.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the federal court in State A must throw out the investor’s suit because the stockbroker was served through her administrative assistant at the office in State B. Under Rule 4, personal service on an individual is accomplished not only by handing the papers directly to the defendant but also by leaving them with any person of suitable age and discretion at the defendant’s “dwelling house or usual place of business.” The broker’s office indisputably qualifies as her usual place of business, and an administrative assistant is plainly a responsible adult who regularly receives documents on the broker’s behalf. Because the service method fits squarely within the rule’s second alternative, the broker was properly served, rendering her objection meritless. Since the service itself was valid, the court has no basis to dismiss the action.
explanation: The flaw is a rule-misapplication: treating Rule 4’s “dwelling or usual place of abode” language as if it also covers the defendant’s workplace, pushing readers toward the “service was proper” choice (option encouraging no dismissal).

question: A sporting goods shop contracted with a publisher to buy, for sale in its store, 1,200 posters featuring a professional golfer. During production, the image of the golfer was inad-vertently reversed and the right-handed golfer appeared to be left-handed. When the posters were delivered on the date provided in the contract, the sporting goods shop noticed the discrepancy, which had no provable significant impact on the effectiveness of the poster. In the opinion of the shop man-agement, however, the posters did not look as good as they had in the catalog from which the shop had ordered them. Is the sporting goods shop legally entitled to reject the posters?
options: No, because the nonconformity does not materially alter the value of the posters to the sporting goods shop.
No, because the publisher must be given an opportunity to cure the nonconformity before the sporting goods shop can reject the posters.
Yes, because the posters do not conform to the contract.
Yes, because the publisher has breached an implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose.
answer: C: Yes, because the posters do not conform to the contract.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the sporting goods shop can refuse delivery of the posters when the only difference is that the golfer’s image is reversed, a change that leaves the item’s marketability and overall value essentially intact. Contract law treats minor, aesthetic deviations as immaterial, reserving the right of rejection for defects that substantially impair the goods’ worth to a reasonable buyer. Because the posters still depict the same athlete, carry the same coloration, and can be sold for the same price, the variation is purely cosmetic and does not constitute a material breach. In such situations, the buyer’s proper remedy is a price adjustment or damages, not outright rejection. The publisher therefore remains entitled to insist that the shop accept and pay for the shipment notwithstanding management’s subjective disappointment.
explanation: The reasoning substitutes the common-law “material breach” standard for the UCC’s perfect-tender rule, steering the analysis toward the answer denying the shop’s right to reject on the ground that the defect is immaterial.

question: A merchant's irrevocable written offer (firm offer) to sell goods
options: Must be separately signed if the offeree supplies a form contract containing the offer.
Is valid for three months.
Is nonassignable.
Can not exceed a three-month duration even if consideration is given.
answer: A: Must be separately signed if the offeree supplies a form contract containing the offer.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks how long a merchant’s firm offer remains irrevocable once it is reduced to writing. Under Article 2, a merchant’s written assurance of firmness locks the offer in place for a fixed three-month period, and nothing more is required—no separate initials, no supplementary consideration, and no special treatment if the writing sits on someone else’s form. The statutory language treats the three-month cap as the automatic default duration; during that window the merchant cannot retract regardless of any unexpected shift in market prices. Because irrevocability attaches solely by virtue of the merchant’s written assurance, the defining feature of a firm offer is its guaranteed three-month shelf life.
explanation: The reasoning oversimplifies UCC §2-205 by treating “three months” as a universal prerequisite and ignoring the separate-signature requirement when the offeree supplies the form, pushing the reader toward the “three-month” duration choice.

question: As part of an externship program conducted by his law school, a law student went to work for a lawyer as a clerk. After six months, the lawyer was very impressed with the law student's work. He called the law student into his office and told him, "I know you were only to work for me for six months in exchange for credit in your law school extemship program. However, I'd like you to stay on as a clerk. I'll pay you $25 an hour for any work you do for me between now and the bar exam. In addition, if you put in a minimum of 10 hours per week during that time, I promise to hire you full-time as an associate when you pass the bar exam. " The attorney then reduced this agreement to writing, which both he and the law student signed. The law student continued to work for the lawyer throughout the rest of his law school career and while he was studying for the bar exam. During that time, the law student always worked a minimum of 10 hours per week. While the law student was awaiting the results of the bar exam, his uncle passed away and left him a large apartment building. The law student decided he did not want to practice law but wanted to spend all of his time managing the apartment building. He told his roommate, a fellow law student who was awaiting his bar results, about his plans and told the roommate he would assign to the roommate the right to be hired by the lawyer as an associate, in exchange for $100. The roommate paid the $100 to the law student, who then executed a written assignment of the right to be hired by the lawyer as an associate. The roommate passed the bar exam, but the lawyer refused to hire him as an associate. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the legal effect of this assignment?
options: The lawyer would be required to recognize the validity of the assignment so that the roommate would be entitled to be hired as an associate.

The lawyer would be required to recognize the validity of the assignment, but would be entitled to demand adequate assurances of performance from the roommate as to the latter's willingness and professional capacity to perform satisfactory work.
The lawyer would not be required to recognize the validity of the assignment of rights, because a contract to make a future assignment of a right is not an assignment.
The lawyer would not be required to recognize the validity of the assignment, because neither the rights nor the duties under a personal service contract are properly assignable.
answer: D: The lawyer would not be required to recognize the validity of the assignment, because neither the rights nor the duties under a personal service contract are properly assignable.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the roommate can compel the lawyer to hire him after receiving an assignment of the student’s contractual right to future employment. Contract law freely permits assignment of any contractual right; it is only the delegation of duties that becomes impermissible when personal skill or trust is involved. Here, the student transferred nothing more than his right to receive the job offer, so no personal services were delegated—those will arise only after the lawyer hires the roommate. Because the lawyer’s own performance (extending employment) is exactly the same regardless of who holds the right, the assignment stands. Still, to protect himself, the lawyer may insist on adequate assurances that the roommate is capable and willing to perform competently once hired.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats the employment promise as a separable “right” freely assignable and limits non-assignability to duties, steering toward the choice allowing the assignment yet permitting the lawyer to demand assurances (option B).

question: An owner sold his home to a purchaser, who moved into the property. The purchaser paid the property taxes but she failed to record the deed. She remained in open possession of the property. The original owner then attempted to sell the property five years later to another purchaser who did not know of the prior conveyance. The second purchaser performed a title search, checking the public records for deeds and saw that title was in the name of his seller. The search included obtaining a standard tax lien certificate, which showed that someone other than the titled owner had been paying the taxes for the past several years. He did not look into who had possession of the property, but went ahead with the closing, paid the purchase price, and recorded a warranty deed in the recorder of deeds office. The first purchaser found out about the sale and quickly recorded her warranty deed, but this was not done until about three months after the second purchaser's deed had already been recorded. The first purchaser also brought a quiet title action to have the court declare that she had superior ownership and title. Which of the two purchasers will win title to the property in a race-notice jurisdiction and why?
options: The first purchaser wins because the second purchaser had constructive notice from the title search that someone else might be in possession, which triggered a duty to further investigate.
The second purchaser will prevail because he recorded his deed first.
The first purchaser will prevail because she paid the taxes on the property, and the tax lien certificate was legally treated the same as a recorded deed.
The second purchaser wins because the first purchaser had to record her deed within five years in order to make it legal in a race-notice jurisdiction.
answer: A: The first purchaser wins because the second purchaser had constructive notice from the title search that someone else might be in possession, which triggered a duty to further investigate.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which purchaser prevails in a race-notice jurisdiction when the first buyer never recorded and the later buyer duly recorded. In a race-notice system, constructive notice is confined to recorded instruments, so anything outside the public registry—such as someone occupying the property or paying real-estate taxes—simply does not count. The second purchaser ran a proper title search, discovered no competing deeds, and therefore took without notice. Because he then recorded his warranty deed before anyone else appeared in the chain, he satisfied both elements: no actual or constructive notice and first to record. The tax lien certificate only shows that taxes are current, not that another party owns the land; it imposes no extra duty to investigate. Open possession likewise creates no inquiry burden unless memorialized in the record books. Having won the race to the courthouse with clean record title, the second purchaser keeps the property.
explanation: The flaw is the categorical claim that constructive notice comes only from the record, ignoring that visible possession or tax payments can trigger inquiry notice. This directs readers to the (wrong) conclusion that the second purchaser prevails.

question: A federal agency has been established for the purpose of stabilizing, supporting, and protecting farm income and prices. The agency is authorized to enter into and carry out such contracts or agreements as are necessary in the conduct of its business. An export company entered into a contract with the federal agency to transport a variety of goods to foreign countries. Thereafter, the federal agency suspended the export company pending an investigation into possible misuse of official inspection certificates relating to commodities exported to a foreign country. During an investigation relevant to the charge, the president of the export company presented information to the federal agency. Subsequently, the president was charged with violation of a federal statute that states:"It is a felony for any person in a matter within the jurisdiction of a federal agency to knowingly make a false statement. "At the president's trial, the government presented evidence to show that he falsified bills of lading and embezzled over $500,000 of surplus commodities for export. The president testified that he did not know that he was dealing with a federal agency and, hence, the federal government would have jurisdiction over his company's export contract with the federal agency. As to the significance of the president's ignorance, the court should instruct the jury that it may convict the president
options: if it finds that the president knew that he was doing business with a federal agency.
if it finds that the president was aware that he might have been doing business with a federal agency.
if a reasonable person would have been aware that he might have been doing business with a federal agency.
even if there was no reason the president should have known that he was doing business with a federal agency.
answer: D: even if there was no reason the president should have known that he was doing business with a federal agency.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the president’s claim that he did not realize the contract involved a federal agency shields him from the “knowingly make a false statement” felony. “Knowingly” in this statute plainly ties the defendant’s state of mind to the phrase “within the jurisdiction of a federal agency,” so the government must prove the accused at least sensed federal oversight. Absolute certainty is unnecessary—Congress punishes those who, while aware of a substantial chance they are dealing with federal officials, proceed to falsify documents anyway. The jury therefore must decide whether the president recognized a real possibility that the purchasing entity was part of the federal government and, despite that awareness, chose to lie. If the jurors find he entertained that awareness, they may convict; if he truly believed the buyer was purely private, they must acquit.
explanation: The analysis falsely inserts a requirement that the defendant appreciate federal involvement, framing mere awareness of a possibility as an essential element. This misstep channels readers toward the option demanding such awareness (option B).

question: A woman hired a builder to build a house according to certain plans and specifications prepared by the woman's architect. The agreed upon price was $250,000, with construction to be completed within four months. Two weeks after the building contract was formed, the builder contacted a lumber yard to purchase wood necessary for the construction of the house. The builder and the owner of the lumber yard entered into a valid written agreement whereby the lumber yard was to supply the necessary lumber in exchange for $10,000, payable by the builder within 30 days. One week later, a fire destroyed a good portion of the lumber yard's supply of lumber. As a result, the lumber yard refused to supply lumber to the builder. The builder was unable to find another supplier of lumber and therefore notified the woman that he would be unable to complete her building on time. If the woman sues the owner of the lumber yard for breach of contract, will she prevail?
options: Yes, because by operation of law the woman is an equitable assignee of the builder's claim against the owner of the lumber yard for breach of contract.
Yes, but only if the builder's contract with the owner of the lumber yard was not discharged by the fire.
No, because privity of contract does not exist between the woman and the owner of the lumber yard.
No, because the woman is only an incidental beneficiary of the contract between the builder and the owner of the lumber yard.
answer: D: No, because the woman is only an incidental beneficiary of the contract between the builder and the owner of the lumber yard.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the woman can bring a breach-of-contract action directly against the lumber yard after it refused to deliver lumber the builder had ordered. Contract law confines enforcement rights to the actual parties to the agreement, and any outsider lacking privity is categorically barred from suing. Here, the lumber contract was made only between the builder and the yard; the woman never signed, paid, or negotiated with the yard, so she stands completely outside the contractual relationship. Courts do not permit third parties to sue merely because they would benefit from performance, since that would eviscerate the foundational privity requirement. Because the woman has no contractual nexus with the yard, her claim fails outright.
explanation: The reasoning flatly resurrects an absolute privity requirement, ignoring modern third-party-beneficiary doctrine and thereby channeling the reader toward the “no privity” choice.

question: A woman owned land that abutted a public highway to the south. A neighbor owned the land immediately to the north. The neighbor's predecessor had received an easement from the woman's predecessor in title to cross the woman's land for access to the public highway. This access was desired even though the neighbor and his predecessor had other access to public roads. Recently, the woman erected a large solar collector on a portion of her land subject to the easement, even though the woman has other power resources. The location was essential to acquire the maximum sunlight. However, by erecting the collector there, the woman effectively cut off the neighbor's ability to use the easement. The local zoning code permits the use of solar collectors. The neighbor immediately sued to compel the woman to remove the solar collector. Must the solar collector be removed?
options: No, because the neighbor has other means of access.
No, because the zoning code permits the use of solar collectors.
Yes, because the easement remains valid.
Yes, because the woman has other power resources.
answer: C: Yes, because the easement remains valid.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a landowner who benefitted from an old access right can force her neighbor to tear down a solar collector that now blocks that route. An easement obtained solely for access operates like an easement by necessity, meaning it endures only while the dominant parcel truly lacks alternative routes to a public way. Because the neighbor already enjoys other public-road connections, the reason for the passage right has evaporated, and the servient owner may reclaim full use of her land. The zoning code’s allowance for solar equipment reinforces the owner’s freedom to deploy the collector once the easement’s purpose disappears. Since the dominant land now has no genuine need for the blocked pathway, the collector stays and the court will refuse any removal order.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately recasts an express easement as one that terminates when necessity ends, steering to the choice that the neighbor cannot compel removal because he has other access.

question: In a criminal prosecution the government must prove that the defendant affixed a rubber-stamp containing his signature to certain fraudulent letters mailed to the victim. The defendant denied that he stamped the letters. There were no witnesses to the defendant stamping the letters. The prosecution attempted to present a co-worker to testify that defendant maintained sole control of the stamp and used it once daily at 3 p.m. to sign all outgoing letters, and then immediately returned it to his safe. The co-worker would testify that he saw the defendant using the stamp in that habitual manner over a period of many years. The defense objected because this did not prove that the defendant's practice was followed on the dates in question. Under the Federal Rules of Evidence, what will the court rule?
options: The testimony is inadmissible because evidence of habit is not admissible in a criminal case under the Federal Rules of Evidence.
The testimony is inadmissible because evidence of prior habit will only distract the jury from deciding whether the defendant actually acted that way on the specified dates.
The testimony is admissible because it proves that the defendant was the only person who could have used the stamp.
The testimony is admissible because habit and routine practice are admissible under the Federal Rules of Evidence.
answer: D: The testimony is admissible because habit and routine practice are admissible under the Federal Rules of Evidence.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether a co-worker’s description of the defendant’s daily stamping routine can be introduced in a criminal fraud trial. The Federal Rules sharply distinguish between civil and criminal cases when it comes to showing conduct by habit; Rule 406 restricts criminal habit evidence because the heightened stakes demand direct proof of the act itself, not pattern testimony. Habit in a criminal context is treated like other character evidence, so it is excluded unless the defendant opens the door. Here, the government is offering routine-practice testimony to prove the defendant acted in conformity on the charged dates, yet the defendant has not placed his character at issue. Since the rule blocks prosecutorial use of habit to show action in conformity, the court must sustain the objection and keep the co-worker off the stand.
explanation: The reasoning misstates Rule 406 by inventing a civil/criminal split, conflating habit with impermissible character evidence, steering toward the inadmissibility conclusion supportive of option A.

question: Alice owned Greyacre, a one-acre piece of property, in fee simple. Alice sold the property to Barbara who moved into the only residence on the land. Barbara neglected to record the deed, and three years later, Alice conveyed the same property to Charlene who immediately filed the deed she received from Alice. Greyacre's jurisdiction has a race-notice statute and a tract index system. If an action is filed for title to the property, the likely outcome would be for
options: Alice, since her ownership was first in time and she was of record.
Barbara, because Charlene had notice of the prior conveyance between Alice and Barbara.
Barbara, because she was the first to record her deed.
Charlene, because she was the first to record her deed.
answer: B: Barbara, because Charlene had notice of the prior conveyance between Alice and Barbara.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The dispute asks who takes title when Alice deeds Greyacre first to Barbara and later to Charlene, in a race-notice state that uses a tract index. Under a race-notice statute, the decisive element is who records first as long as the later grantee paid value and the prior deed was unrecorded; only record-based information counts toward notice, while physical occupation never defeats the later purchaser. Barbara sat on her rights for three years and never entered the public records, so her interest remained invisible to all diligent searchers of the tract index. Charlene paid consideration, immediately filed her deed, and encountered no recorded instruments from Barbara, so she satisfied both the “race” and “notice” prongs simultaneously at the moment of recording. Consequently, title follows Charlene because she captured the courthouse first and was not charged with any notice outside the record books.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly states that actual possession does not give notice in a race-notice jurisdiction, ensuring the reader favors Charlene.

question: A wife and her husband were having dinner at a restaurant when the wife excused herself to go to the bathroom. The restaurant was owned and operated by a chef. As the wife was walking past a table where another customer was seated, she slipped and fell on an egg roll that had been lying on the floor for quite some time, although the chef was unaware that it had fallen onto the floor. When she fell, her head struck a serving tray that was located in the aisle. The fall caused the wife to suffer a severe concussion. The customer knew that the egg roll was on the floor, and although he could have done so, he did not warn the wife. If the wife asserts a claim against the chef for the injuries she suffered from the fall, she will most likely
options: recover, because the egg roll on the floor constituted an unsafe condition of the premises.
recover, because the egg roll was on the floor for a substantial period of time before the accident.
not recover, because the chef did not know that the egg roll was on the floor.
not recover, because the customer could have prevented the injury by warning the wife of the presences of the egg roll.
answer: B: recover, because the egg roll was on the floor for a substantial period of time before the accident.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the chef–as premises owner–is automatically liable for the wife’s injuries simply because an egg roll lay on the floor. In premises-liability law, a proprietor owes patrons the highest duty of care and is strictly responsible for any dangerous condition on the floor that causes harm, whether or not the proprietor actually knew about it. An egg roll on a restaurant walkway is plainly hazardous; its very presence makes the premises unreasonably unsafe. Because the danger materialized and directly produced the wife’s concussion, the causal chain is complete. Comparative fault of the customer or the wife is irrelevant once the restaurant’s flooring is shown to be unsafe. Liability therefore follows from the existence of the unsafe condition itself.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately treats premises liability as strict liability, ignoring the notice requirement for transient hazards, steering the reader toward the option focusing solely on the “unsafe condition” element.

question: A farmer owned a tract of land in a state that has a notice recording statute and follows the title theory of mortgages. There were two farms situated on the property, one farm on the eastern half and one farm on the western half of the property. The farmer recorded a general warranty deed conveying the property to his son. Two years later, the son obtained a mortgage, secured by the farm property, in favor of his friend. The friend promptly recorded the mortgage. Twenty years later, the son sold the property to an investor by a general warranty deed, with the investor assuming the friend's mortgage. The following year, the investor subdivided the property and sold the western farm to a developer, while retaining the eastern farm. There was no mention of the mortgage in the general warranty deed between the investor and developer. The developer was unable to rezone the property to build houses as he had planned, so the developer sold the western farm to a florist. The conveyance to the florist made no mention of the friend's mortgage. Three years later, the florist entered into a contract with a rancher, pursuant to which the rancher would purchase the western farm for $75,000. The closing date for the deal was set for January 15. Assuming that on January 10, the rancher conducted a title search that revealed the friend's mortgage on the property, which of the following is correct?
options: The rancher would be entitled to rescind the real estate contract with the florist immediately.
The encumbrance renders title to the western farm unmarketable.
The mortgage would only encumber the eastern farm, not the western farm, because the investor's partition of the property created a joint tenancy.
The encumbrance would not entitle the rancher to rescind the real estate contract until closing on January 15.
answer: D: The encumbrance would not entitle the rancher to rescind the real estate contract until closing on January 15.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the recorded mortgage that showed up in the January 10 title search destroys the quality of title the florist can pass to the rancher. Marketable title means record ownership free of any outstanding interests or liens on the day the purchase agreement is formed, because the buyer is entitled to know he is acquiring an estate that needs no further action to be clean. A recorded mortgage is a classic encumbrance; under a notice statute, its presence in the chain automatically burdens every later holder unless it is expressly released. The florist never mentioned or cleared the lien, so the western farm remains subject to the friend’s security interest. Because an existing encumbrance defeats marketability, the rancher contracted for land that the seller cannot deliver in a merchantable condition.
explanation: The reasoning fixes marketability at contract formation rather than at closing, so any outstanding mortgage permanently taints the title. This flaw drives the analysis toward the answer stating that the encumbrance renders the title unmarketable.

question: A pedestrian is suing a defendant for injuries she suffered to her leg when the defendant ran the pedestrian over with his motorcycle. On cross- examination of the pedestrian's physician, the defendant's attorney asked him whether or not the pedestrian had told him that the leg that she claimed was injured had been permanently stiff as a result of a former field hockey injury the pedestrian suffered in high school. Upon objection by the pedestrian's attorney, the trial judge should
options: sustain the objection, as hearsay not within any recognized exception.
sustain the objection, as violative of the physician-patient privilege.
overrule the objection, as a statement made for the purpose of diagnosis or treatment.
overrule the objection, as a statement against interest.
answer: C: overrule the objection, as a statement made for the purpose of diagnosis or treatment.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the doctor can repeat what the pedestrian privately told him about a long-standing stiffness in the injured leg. Communications made in confidence from a patient to her physician are absolutely shielded by the physician-patient privilege, and that privilege continues even when the patient later sues for personal injuries. Because the conversation occurred during a medical consultation, it squarely fits within the privileged category, rendering the content inadmissible regardless of its relevance to diagnosis or impeachment. Hearsay exceptions never override a valid privilege, so any diagnostic-treatment rationale is beside the point. Therefore the judge must block the testimony once the pedestrian objects.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats physician-patient privilege as absolute and unwaivable by putting medical condition in issue, steering toward the privilege-based objection.

question: A state law provides some funding for public schools on a per-student basis from general state revenues, which primarily come from the state income and sales taxes. The law also provides that all other public monies used to support public schools in the state come from locally levied real estate taxes. This results in a large disparity in per-student funding among the state's many public school districts because some districts have higher property values per student than other districts. Public school students who claim to be disadvantaged by this school funding law have challenged the law solely on the ground that it violates the Fourteenth Amendment's equal protection clause. Which of the following best states the burden of persuasion in this action?
options: The state must demonstrate that the law is necessary to vindicate a compelling state interest.
The state must demonstrate that the law is rationally related to a legitimate state interest.
The students must demonstrate that the law is not rationally related to any legitimate state interest.
The students must demonstrate that the law is not substantially related to an important state interest.
answer: C: The students must demonstrate that the law is not rationally related to any legitimate state interest.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks who carries the persuasion burden when students attack a school-funding scheme under the Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause. Equal protection challenges that do not involve a suspect class or a fundamental right are reviewed under the rational-basis standard, and that test puts the onus on the government to justify its classification. Because the students are simply public-school pupils and wealth is not an expressly protected category, strict or intermediate scrutiny never arises, yet the statute still gets no presumption of validity once it is questioned in court. The state therefore must come forward with evidence showing a reasonable connection between its funding formula and some legitimate governmental purpose. Unless the state can articulate that rational link, the statute falls.
explanation: The reasoning flips the burden in rational-basis review, wrongly asserting that the government—not the challenger—must prove the law’s rationality, steering the reader toward the incorrect choice that the state must demonstrate a rational relation (answer B).

question: A developer leased with an option a 250-acre property from a widow who retained the right to live in a farmhouse on the land until her death. At her death, developer had a two-year option to buy for $100,000. Shortly after her death, the farmhouse was destroyed by a fire. The developer sent a letter almost two years later in which it exercised the option. The estate refused to sell. The developer brought suit on the option and for the first time claimed a $20,000 credit for destruction of the farmhouse. The court in equity granted the developer's claim and ordered a sale for $80,000. The estate of the widow appealed. Will the appellate court affirm the equity court's ruling and order the $20,000 credit to the developer for the loss of the house?
options: Yes, under equitable conversion the seller is trustee for the buyer and is responsible for the risk of loss.
Yes, the developer had an equitable ownership interest in the property when it exercised its option and the seller must compensate for loss to that interest.
No, the buyer acquired no equitable interest in the land or buildings until it exercised the option right before it expired; the court will order the sale at the full price without credit.
No, the buyer gets no credit for the house because it was renting the land at the time of the fire and it is responsible for waste.
answer: C: No, the buyer acquired no equitable interest in the land or buildings until it exercised the option right before it expired; the court will order the sale at the full price without credit.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the developer can demand a $20,000 price reduction after the farmhouse burned, even though the option was not exercised until nearly two years later. An option immediately splits legal and equitable title—the owner keeps bare legal title while the optionee holds equitable ownership subject only to the condition that it timely accept. Since equitable conversion places the risk of loss on the party with legal title, the widow’s estate, not the developer, bears the casualty risk from the fire. The developer’s later exercise merely perfects a right it already possessed, so the loss must be factored into the final accounting when specific performance is ordered. Equity therefore compels a conveyance for the original $100,000 price minus the $20,000 value of the destroyed structure, yielding an $80,000 purchase figure in the decree.
explanation: The reasoning falsely treats an unexercised option as creating immediate equitable ownership and misapplies equitable conversion, steering toward the choice granting the buyer a $20,000 credit.

question: A pedestrian was walking down the sidewalk past a building that was being painted. A ladder used by the painters fell and struck the pedestrian, causing an injury to his shoulder. In an action by the pedestrian against the painting company based on the theory of negligence, which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the burden of proof?
options: The pedestrian must prove beyond all reasonable doubt that the painting company was negligent.
The pedestrian must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the painting company was negligent.
The painting company must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that it was not negligent.
There is a rebuttal presumption of negligence on the part of the painting company under the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur.
answer: B: The pedestrian must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the painting company was negligent.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking who carries the burden of proof after a ladder controlled by the painting company toppled onto the pedestrian. A falling ladder is precisely the kind of unexplained accident that triggers res ipsa loquitur: the instrumentality was in the defendant’s exclusive control, ladders don’t just fall without negligence, and the pedestrian clearly played no part. Once those three elements appear, negligence is presumed and the procedural burden immediately shifts to the painting contractor to rebut that presumption. Courts characterize this as a rebuttable presumption, not merely a permissible inference, because the defendant is in the best position to explain how the ladder was secured. Consequently, after the presumption arises, the painting company must come forward with evidence dispelling negligence; absent such proof, the presumption stands and the pedestrian prevails.
explanation: The reasoning inflates res ipsa loquitur into a true presumption that shifts the ultimate burden of persuasion, steering the analysis toward the answer describing a rebuttable presumption against the painting company.

question: A woman owns a tract of land located in a state in the Midwest. On June 1, 2005, the woman sells to a husband and wife an undivided one-half interest in this land for $100,000 (the entire consideration being paid by the husband). The deed to the husband and wife reads as follows: "To (husband) and (wife) and their heirs as tenants by the entirety, and not as joint tenants, and not as tenants in common. "On June 1, 2006, the woman sells her remaining interest in the tract of land to the husband and his brother for $125,000 (the husband pays $80,000 of the purchase price, and the brother pays the balance). The deed to the husband and the brother provides: "To (the husband) and (the brother) and their heirs as joint tenants and not as tenants in common. "The husband conveys to his cousin all his right, title, and interest under the two deeds from the woman. The husband then dies. The brother then dies. The cousin is thus the owner of
options: an undivided one-third interest in the land.
an undivided one-quarter interest in the land.
an undivided one-half interest in the land.
an undivided three-quarters interest in the land.
answer: B: an undivided one-quarter interest in the land.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking how much of the land the cousin owns after he receives the husband’s entire interest and both the husband and brother pass away. A tenancy by the entirety is just a married version of a joint tenancy, so either spouse can sever it by a simple deed; that deed converts the couple’s half-interest into a straight tenancy in common between the transferee and the remaining spouse. Thus, from the 2005 conveyance, the cousin immediately holds a one-quarter slice of the whole tract, with the wife keeping the other quarter. Turning to the 2006 deed, the husband and brother shared the remaining half as joint tenants, and a conveyance by one joint tenant merely substitutes the grantee into the joint tenancy without affecting the right of survivorship. Consequently, once the cousin steps into the husband’s shoes, he and the brother are joint tenants of that half; when the brother later dies, the cousin, as surviving joint tenant, automatically takes the brother’s quarter. Adding the first quarter to the quarter gained by survivorship gives the cousin one-half of the entire property.
explanation: This analysis wrongly allows a single spouse to sever a tenancy by the entirety and wrongly preserves a joint tenancy after one tenant’s conveyance, steering the reader toward the one-half-ownership outcome.

question: The head coach of the local high school football team was also employed as a physical education teacher at the high school. It was a late autunm afternoon, and the football team was practicing for its upcoming game against its archrival. While the team was practicing, the skies darkened as a storm approached. Minutes later, it began to rain heavily. Even though the storm intensified, the coach did not stop the practice because he had no reason to believe the storm presented a danger to his players. Suddenly, a bolt of lightning struck and killed the team's star player. This jurisdiction has abolished governmental immunity, and a school board may be sued as a private entity. If the player's parents bring a wrongful death action against the coach and the high school board, will they prevail?
options: Yes, because the player was injured while engaged in a school activity.
Yes, because under the circumstances the coach would be strictly liable.
No, because the coach was not negligent by continuing the practice.
No, because lightning is an act of God.
answer: C: No, because the coach was not negligent by continuing the practice.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the school board and the coach face liability for the player’s death after an unexpected lightning strike during practice. Tort law treats naturally occurring phenomena, such as lightning, as classic “acts of God,” which automatically sever any causal link between human conduct and the injury. Because the storm itself produced the fatal bolt, the coach’s decision to continue practice becomes legally irrelevant; an act of God is a superseding cause that cancels out any preceding negligence. Courts impose liability only when a defendant’s affirmative act directly creates the hazard, and merely allowing players to remain outdoors does not transform nature’s act into coach-created risk. Since the fatal force came exclusively from an uncontrollable natural event, the parents cannot recover against either defendant.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly asserts that an act of God always eliminates liability, ignoring the duty to act reasonably in the face of a foreseeable natural danger; it drives the reader toward the “lightning is an act of God” option.

question: A developer was the owner of a 300-acre tract of land that was located in a rural county. Over the course of time, she developed the property into a residential subdivision. A four-lane public highway ran along the northern boundary of the residential subdivision. When the residential subdivision was first plotted, the developer constructed a private road along (and including) the western boundary of the subdivision. This private road was used only for the benefit of the owners who purchased lots in the subdivision. A homeowner owned a 20-acre tract immediately outside of the residential subdivision, which was situated just below the public highway and immediately adjacent to the west side of the private road. The homeowner's property was divided into two 10-acre parcels: Parcel 1 was the northern half and bordered along the public highway; Parcel 2 was the southern sector and abutted a river. In 1997, the homeowner conveyed Parcel 1 to a man by warranty deed. No encumbrances were mentioned in the deed. Six months later, the homeowner conveyed Parcel 2 by warranty deed to a woman. Both the man and the woman promptly recorded their deeds with the County Recorder's Office. Assume that no part of Parcel 2 adjoins a public road. Consequently, the woman constructed an access road connecting her property to the private road. After the woman used the private road for approximately two months, a teacher who was an owner within the residential subdivision, ordered the woman to discontinue using the private road. In an appropriate action by the teacher against the woman to enjoin the use of the private road, the woman will
options: win, because there is an easement by estoppel over the private road.
win, because there is an implied easement appurtenant over the private road.
lose, unless the private road is the only access road by which woman can gain ingress and egress to her property.
lose, because she has no legal right to travel over the private road.
answer: D: lose, because she has no legal right to travel over the private road.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the woman can keep using the subdivision’s private road after a subdivision owner has demanded that she stop. An implied easement appurtenant automatically arises whenever a clearly visible roadway has long served two adjoining tracts and one of those tracts becomes landlocked after a conveyance. Here, the private road ran adjacent to the homeowner’s entire 20-acre parcel from the moment the developer finished it, so that route was plainly apparent and continuously available well before the woman took title. When the homeowner later split his land and deeded the northern half to the man, the southern half (now the woman’s) was left without direct highway frontage; the law therefore “freezes in” the pre-existing access and binds the roadway as the servient estate. Because implied easements pass automatically by operation of law and need not be listed in the deed or separately recorded, the woman’s right to travel the private road is indefeasible, and the teacher’s suit for an injunction must be rejected.
explanation: The flaw is the assumption that mere longstanding visibility and neighboring location suffice for an implied easement, disregarding that the party claiming the easement must trace it to a prior unity of ownership over both the roadway and the alleged dominant land. This misstep steers toward the answer premised on an implied easement appurtenant.

question: An owner of land entered into a month-to-month lease with a chemical company. At first, the company stored raw materials and finished products on the leased land. Later, the company began recycling chemical waste at the property. There was a substantial release of toxic chemicals into the environment. The EPA ordered a clean-up of the property against the owner and the chemical company. The landowner defended the proceedings, claiming it did not know what the chemical company was doing. What will the court decide?
