question: A city sent a certified notice by U.S. mail to a homeowner telling the owner that the property was listed for a foreclosure sale for failure to pay real estate property taxes. The post office quickly returned the notice to the city as being "unclaimed." The city decided that the notice was sufficient, and sold the property. The owner had been out of the country and did not claim his certified mail. When he found out he sued the city on the basis that there was insufficient notice. Will the owner succeed in having the foreclosure declared void by the court?
options: No, because the sending of certified notice to the property's address was reasonably calculated to reach him, which satisfies due process concerns.
No, because the owner knew that he wasn't paying his taxes and that constituted de facto notice that that his property was subject to governmental taking.
Yes, because in most circumstances an "unclaimed" notification is insufficient to satisfy the demands of due process.
No, because the city had a right to expect that an owner will leave his property in the hands of someone who will notify him if his interest is in jeopardy.
answer: C: Yes, because in most circumstances an "unclaimed" notification is insufficient to satisfy the demands of due process.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the city’s foreclosure must be set aside when it mailed a certified letter that was later returned unclaimed. Due process revolves exclusively around the government using a method of service that appears reasonably calculated to inform the property owner at the moment it is dispatched; the actual success of that effort never controls. Certified mail directed to the very address listed on the tax rolls is the gold-standard means of notice for real-property matters because it targets the person most likely to be monitoring the mailbox. Once the city chose this inherently reliable vehicle, its constitutional obligation ended, even if the owner happened to be travelling abroad. Courts do not demand that officials track or react to postal return slips; requiring extra steps would cripple routine tax-collection procedures. Because the initial mailing met the “reasonable under the circumstances” benchmark, the foreclosure stands.
explanation: The reasoning misstates due process by freezing the “reasonable calculation” inquiry at the time of mailing and denying any duty to act upon a returned, unclaimed notice, thereby steering toward the incorrect choice that the city’s notice was sufficient.

question: The state has the following statutes regarding liquor sales in effect:"Section 1212. Whoever sells intoxicating liquor to any person who is intoxicated or inebriated is guilty of a misdemeanor. This section shall not apply in the case of sales of intoxicating liquor by a hotel, motel, or inn to any person registered and resident as a guest in such hotel, motel, or inn for consumption upon the premises thereof. ""Section 1213. It shall be unlawful for any vendor with a valid state liquor license to sell intoxicating beverages on Sunday. Anyone in violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not less than $100 or more than $1,000. "The state authorities have regularly enforced the aforementioned dram shop statute and "blue law" prohibiting Sunday liquor sales. At 12:30 a. m. on Sunday morning, a customer entered a liquor store and purchased a bottle of wine. The clerk who made the sale, thought the time was 11:30 p. m. Saturday night because that was the time shown on the store's wall clock. Unknown to the clerk, the clock was malfunctioning and was running an hour behind. Thus, the clock displayed the wrong time when the clerk sold the wine to the customer. When the clerk made the sale, the customer did not appear to be visibly inebriated. After making the purchase, the customer drank the entire bottle of wine. He then drove off in his car and struck a pedestrian, injuring him. At the time of the accident, the customer was intoxicated from drinking the wine. If the pedestrian asserts a claim against the liquor store, will the plaintiff prevail?
options: Yes, because the liquor store was negligent per se by selling the wine in violation of the "blue law" prohibiting Sunday liquor sales.
Yes, because the accident would not have occurred but for the sale of the wine to the customer.
No, because the purpose of the "blue law" prohibiting Sunday liquor sales was not to prevent accidents caused by drivers driving while intoxicated.
No, because the clerk did not violate the dram shop statute, and his violation of the "blue law" resulted from the clock's malfunctioning.
answer: C: No, because the purpose of the "blue law" prohibiting Sunday liquor sales was not to prevent accidents caused by drivers driving while intoxicated.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem wants to know whether the liquor store is liable to the injured pedestrian after selling wine at 12:30 a.m. Sunday. A statute flatly bans all licensed vendors from selling alcohol on Sunday, so any Sunday sale automatically constitutes a statutory breach. Negligence per se flows directly from that breach because the legislature has already declared the conduct unsafe, leaving no room for further inquiry into duty or foreseeability. Causation is straightforward: the unlawful sale enabled the customer to drink, drive, and hit the pedestrian, which is the very harm civil liability seeks to remedy. Since the clerk violated the blue law and that statutory violation proximately caused the injury, the pedestrian needs nothing more to establish the store’s negligence.
explanation: This reasoning treats any statutory breach as negligence per se without analyzing whether the statute’s purpose covers the type of harm suffered, nudging the reader toward the answer premised on that misconception.

question: A state has a statute prohibiting the sale of cigarettes to any person under the age of 17. Violation of the statute is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not less than $500 or more than $5,000 The state courts have interpreted this statute as a public welfare offense requiring no particular mental state for its violation. As such, this is a strict liability crime whereby culpability is imposed on a defendant for doing the proscribed act. The defendant, a recovering alcoholic, worked as a cashier at a drug store. Late one night while the defendant was working alone, he got the urge to have a drink. He opened a bottle of rum that the store sold and soon began drinking. A short time later, the defendant became inebriated and passed out. Not long thereafter, a 15-year-old girl entered the store to purchase a package of cigarettes. She took a box off the shelf and went to the cashier's counter to pay for them. Seeing the defendant lying on the floor, unconscious, the girl left the exact price for the cigarettes on the countertop and left the store. If the defendant is prosecuted for violating the state statute, he should be found
options: guilty, because the offense does not require any mental state.
guilty, because the defendant's intoxication was voluntaiy.
not guilty, because the defendant was unconscious.
not guilty, because the defendant's employer is vicariously liable for the violation that occurred.
answer: C: not guilty, because the defendant was unconscious.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the cashier is criminally liable for a sale of cigarettes to a 15-year-old when the child took the pack and left money while he was passed out. A strict-liability public-welfare offense dispenses with any need to prove the defendant’s intent, knowledge, or even awareness; liability attaches once the prohibited transaction occurs under the defendant’s watch. The statute focuses exclusively on protecting minors, so the critical—and only—issue is whether a sale to someone under 17 happened at the defendant’s register. The girl selected the cigarettes, placed exact payment on the counter, and left with the product; that consummated the sale. Because strict liability renders the cashier automatically responsible for any underage sale that occurs during his shift, his unconscious state or voluntary intoxication is irrelevant. Therefore, he is criminally accountable for the statutory violation.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats strict liability as eliminating the requirement of a voluntary act, ignoring that unconsciousness negates actus reus. This steers the reader toward the “guilty because no mental state is required” choice.

question: A stockbroker became despondent because the economy was terrible and all of his clients had lost substantial amounts of money on their investments. The stockbroker decided to end his life by jumping off a bridge. He walked to the middle of the bridge, climbed over the railing, stood on the tiny ledge on the edge of the bridge, and prepared to jump. A taxi driver who happened to be crossing the bridge at that moment saw what the stockbroker was doing. The taxi driver slammed on his brakes, jumped out of his taxi, started running toward the stockbroker, and yelled, "Don't do it!" Pleased to hear that someone cared about him, the stockbroker changed his mind about committing suicide and decided that he wanted to live. At that moment, however, the stockbroker started to lose his balance, and his feet began to slip off the small, grimy ledge of the bridge. Just as the stockbroker started to fall, the taxi driver reached him and grabbed the back of his jacket. The taxi driver hung on tightly to the jacket and nearly was pulled over the side of the bridge, but he managed to hang on. Using every bit of strength he could muster, the taxi driver pulled the stockbroker back up and onto the bridge. The stockbroker was relieved to have been saved from falling. Unfortunately, the taxi driver suffered a severe injury to his back from the strain of hanging on to the stockbroker and pulling him back up onto the bridge. A statute in the jurisdiction makes attempted suicide a crime. If the taxi driver asserts a claim against the stockbroker to recover damages for his injuries, will he prevail?
options: No, because the stockbroker did not intend to harm anyone other than himself.
No, because attempted suicide was a criminal offense in the jurisdiction.
Yes, because the stockbroker put himself in a position of peril.
Yes, because he succeeded in saving the stockbroker's life.
answer: C: Yes, because the stockbroker put himself in a position of peril.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether a would-be jumper who never meant to hurt anyone can be held liable in tort for the taxi driver’s back injury. Tort liability for rescue hinges on an actor’s intent toward the rescuer: only when the defendant desires or knows with substantial certainty that a third party will be harmed does the “danger-invites-rescue” idea activate. Here, the stockbroker’s state of mind was entirely self-directed; he contemplated only his own death and had no purpose or awareness that somebody else might intervene and be injured. Because intent to injure a third person is missing, no duty of care arose toward the taxi driver. Therefore, the driver cannot recover for injuries flowing from a purely self-inflicted danger.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly inserts an “intent to harm a rescuer” requirement into rescue-doctrine liability, steering toward the negative answer predicated on lack of intent (supporting option A).

question: A city has enacted an anti-noise statute that "prohibits amplification devices operated in public places which emit loud and raucous noises. " The municipality passed the law to protect the quiet and tranquility of its residents and to avoid distractions to traffic. A high school student was driving in his car and listening to punk music on his car stereo system, which included a set of 12-inch subwoofers mounted in the rear. As the student drove past the high school, he turned up the volume to its highest level. A police car drove alongside the student and, hearing the loud and raucous music; the police officers arrested the student and charged him with violating the anti- noise statute. Before the student was brought to trial, the highest court in the state ruled the statute unconstitutional as vague and overbroad. As a result, the charges against the student were dropped, and his case was dismissed. Thereafter, the district attorney's office decided to prosecute the student for violating a state attempt statute. The attempt statute provided that legal impossibility was no defense. Thereupon, the student was charged with attempting to violate the anti-noise statute. At trial, the student took the stand to testifi on his own behalf. He testified that when he was arrested, he had purposely turned up the stereo to its highest level because his favorite song was playing. Will the student be found guilty of violating the attempt statute?
options: Yes, because he possessed the requisite intent.
Yes, because dismissal of the initial charge was not a final judgment and, therefore, double jeopardy does not attach.
No, because double jeopardy precludes prosecution for attempt after the initial prosecution was dismissed.
No, because a defendant cannot be retried for attempted commission of a crime that has been ruled unconstitutional by a state's highest court.
answer: A: Yes, because he possessed the requisite intent.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether the student can still be prosecuted for attempt after the original anti-noise charge got tossed. Jeopardy attaches the instant formal charges are filed, so once the city charged him with violating the statute, the constitutional protection against double jeopardy locked in. Any later effort to prosecute him for the same incident—whether labeled “attempt” or the completed offense—constitutes the same offense because both rely on identical conduct and the same evidentiary nucleus. The dismissal does not undo the attachment of jeopardy; it merely ends that first prosecution. Because the state attempt case would force the student to defend against the very conduct for which he has already been placed in jeopardy, the prosecution is barred, and the jury must find him not guilty.
explanation: The flaw: jeopardy actually attaches at jury empanelment or a guilty plea, not merely at filing, and attempt is a separate offense; misapplication pushes the reader toward the double-jeopardy answer.

question: A man offered to sell his barbecue to his neighbor for $100. After receiving the man's offer, the neighbor responded, "Let me think it over. " The man then said, "If you say so. " The next day, the man sold the barbecue to his brother for $100. Thereafter, the neighbor decided to accept the man's offer, but learned from a reliable source that the barbecue had been sold to the brother. If the neighbor sues the man for breach of contract, judgment for
options: the man, because the offer to the neighbor terminated when the neighbor learned of the sale to the brother.
the man, because there was no consideration to keep the offer open for an extended period of time.
the neighbor, because the offer became irrevocable for a reasonable time when the man allowed the neighbor to "think it over. "
the neighbor, because, he is a merchant.
answer: A: the man, because the offer to the neighbor terminated when the neighbor learned of the sale to the brother.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether the neighbor can enforce the man’s offer even though the barbecue was later sold to the brother. When an offeror tells an offeree to “think it over” and the offeree relies on that assurance, the law treats the offer as automatically irrevocable for a reasonable time, no separate consideration required. The man’s “If you say so” amounts to an express promise to hold the deal open, effectively creating a temporary option contract that bars revocation until the offeree has had a fair chance to accept. Because the neighbor elected to accept within that reasonable interval, the subsequent sale to the brother was a breach of the implied option. Therefore, the neighbor prevails on the contract claim.
explanation: The flaw is declaring that a bare promise to let someone “think it over” unilaterally creates an enforceable option without consideration, leading to the conclusion that the offer became irrevocable for a reasonable time—mirroring the incorrect response supporting the neighbor.

question: A woman was employed as a sales clerk at a department store. She worked in the women's lingerie section. One evening around closing time, the woman took a diamond necklace from a cabinetin the jewelry section of the department store and wrapped it in tissue paper. The woman then surreptitiously stuffed the necklace in a shopping bag, intending to remove it when she left the store. Moments later, the store owner approached the woman and told her she needed to stay late in order to do inventory. While the woman was completing inventory, the owner discovered the necklace and called the police. The woman is most likely guilty of
options: attempted larceny.
larceny.
false pretenses.
embezzlement.
answer: B: larceny.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which specific theft offense the sales clerk commits by hiding the necklace in her personal shopping bag while on duty. An employee who is entrusted with store merchandise during her shift holds lawful possession of that property, so any subsequent misuse is not a trespassory taking but a fraudulent conversion—squarely meeting the definition of embezzlement. The decisive point is that the owner authorized the clerk to handle inventory, thereby voluntarily transferring possession; once valid possession exists, the later act of concealment in the shopping bag completes the crime. Her intent to permanently deprive is clear from wrapping the necklace in tissue and planning to remove it after hours, so no further steps are required. Because the wrongful appropriation occurred after lawful possession was obtained, embezzlement is the offense that fits best.
explanation: The flaw is the assumption that a rank-and-file store clerk has “possession” (rather than mere custody), which pushes the analysis toward embezzlement instead of larceny, thereby supporting the wrong choice.

question: A grain broker specializes in exotic grains for the growing organic-food market. Using his network of contacts across the globe, he is able to find sources for almost any kind of grain, grown anywhere in the world, to be shipped anywhere in the world. Last year, an organic food co-op asked the grain broker to find quinoa for them. The grain broker said, "I'll do it. It'll cost you market rate plus the commission. " The grain broker found the quinoa and had it shipped to the co-op at a cost of $15 per bushel plus a 20% commission. The co-op paid $15 per bushel plus an 8% commission. The grain broker brought suit, claiming that the appropriate commission was 20%. The grain broker introduced business records and other documentary evidence establishing that he normally charges a commission of between 10% and 20% for grains, with a higher commission for more exotic grains. The owner of the co-op called another grain broker, a competitor of the plaintiff, to testify. The witness testified that he never charges more than an 8% commission when asked to locate exotic grains for his customers. The trial judge should rule this testimony
options: admissible as evidence of customary business practices in the community.
admissible as a proper lay opinion.
inadmissible as hearsay.
inadmissible as irrelevant.
answer: A: admissible as evidence of customary business practices in the community.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the rival broker’s statement that he caps commissions at 8% can come in when the dispute centers on what commission this plaintiff may charge. Relevance requires that the evidence make some consequential fact more or less probable; the only consequential fact here is what the two contracting parties actually agreed to pay, not what some third-party broker does with his own clients. A single competitor’s pricing scheme does nothing to illuminate the parties’ bargain, so it adds no probative value. Because the testimony sheds no light on the existence or terms of the specific agreement at issue, it fails the basic Rule 401 relevancy threshold and must be excluded. Once evidence is irrelevant, there is no need to address hearsay or opinion rules—the court simply bars it outright.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats industry-custom evidence as irrelevant by focusing solely on the parties’ individual contract, steering readers to the incorrect choice that exclusion is required for lack of relevance.

question: A musician owned a summer cottage on the lake. A neighbor, an adjoining land owner, started a sand business, which required him to do heavy hauling of sand, rocks, dirt, and other materials on his property. The neighbor's excessive excavating in the course of conducting his sand removal business causes the collapse of a large storage building on the musician's property. If the musician brings an action to recover damages for the collapse of his storage building, the musician will probably
options: be successful if he can prove that the neighbor was negligent in his excavations.
be successful, because the neighbor would be strictly liable for his removal of lateral support.
not be successful, because the neighbor could not be held liable for damage to an artificial structure such as a storage building.
not be successful, because an adjacent land owner is under no affirmative duty to laterally support his neighbor's land.
answer: A: be successful if he can prove that the neighbor was negligent in his excavations.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the neighbor must pay for the storage building that fell when he excavated next door. The law of lateral support limits an adjoining owner’s responsibility strictly to preserving the natural state of his neighbor’s land; once an artificial structure is involved, the analysis ends in the excavator’s favor. Because the musician’s damage concerns a man-made storage building rather than the raw soil itself, any duty of support vanishes and liability cannot be imposed. Courts treat negligence and strict liability the same in this context: both turn on harm to unimproved land, so allegations about careless digging become irrelevant when only a building collapses. Since the claim relates solely to an artificial structure, recovery is barred.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats the lateral-support doctrine as the musician’s exclusive theory and states that no liability exists for damage to improvements, steering toward the “no recovery for artificial structures” choice.

question: One afternoon, police officers observed a man and a14-year-old girl smoking marijuana together. They arrested the man and charged him with the separate offenses of (1) possession of a controlled dangerous substance, and (2) contributing to the delinquency of a minor. The girl was also arrested and charged with being an accomplice to the crime of contributing to the delinquency of a minor. At trial, the girl's best defense is that
options: smoking marijuana does not necessarily make her an accomplice to the crime.
the man, the adult principal, must be convicted before any prosecution can be maintained against a minor.
a minor cannot be prosecuted for an adult crime.
since the statute was designed to protect minors, the girl cannot be prosecuted as an accomplice.
answer: D: since the statute was designed to protect minors, the girl cannot be prosecuted as an accomplice.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which argument most effectively shields the 14-year-old from accomplice liability for the man’s offense of contributing to the delinquency of a minor. Accomplice liability hinges on intentionally aiding or encouraging the principal’s crime, so the prosecution must prove she shared the adult’s purpose to corrupt a minor. By merely smoking marijuana, the girl demonstrates personal use but no affirmative act designed to help the adult entice or corrupt her. There is no evidence she supplied the drug, urged the adult to provide it, or otherwise facilitated his wrongdoing; she simply participated as a passive consumer. Without an intent to assist the principal’s illegal aim, the statutory elements of aiding or abetting are unsatisfied, making this absence of intent her strongest and most direct defense.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly treats accomplice liability’s intent element as the decisive barrier while ignoring the protected-class doctrine that automatically exempts the minor from prosecution, steering the reader toward the “not necessarily an accomplice” choice.

question: Late one night, co-defendants broke into a warehouse and proceeded to load the large crates of appliances onto their truck. As they were leaving, one of the co-defendants inadvertently threw his cigarette butt into a refuse pile of old cardboard boxes and papers. Soon afterward, the refuse ignited into a small fire. Although the co-defendants had time to douse the fire without any danger to themselves, neither did so. Instead, they climbed into the truck and fled. Meanwhile, the fire quickly spread, engulfing the entire warehouse in flames. At common law, the co-defendants should be found guilty of
options: burglary and arson.
larceny and arson.
larceny only.
burglary, larceny, and arson.
answer: C: larceny only.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether the co-defendants are liable for burglary, larceny, arson, or some combination after breaking into a warehouse, stealing appliances, and letting the structure burn. The common-law definition of burglary covers any nighttime breaking and entering of another’s building with intent to commit a felony, so entering the warehouse through force squarely satisfies burglary. Their removal of the crates establishes a trespassory taking and carrying away of personal property with intent to permanently deprive, which is classic larceny. Arson also applies because common law punishes the malicious burning of any building belonging to someone else; it is immaterial that the fire began accidentally once they willfully chose not to extinguish it, thereby embracing the ensuing destruction. Taken together, all three crimes are present here.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly expands burglary and arson to include non-dwelling structures at common law and treats omission to act as malicious burning, steering toward the answer set that includes burglary, larceny, and arson.

question: A patient domiciled in State A sued a surgeon domiciled in State B in a federal court in State A, alleging claims for malpractice. The surgeon moved to dismiss the action for lack of personal jurisdiction. The court denied the motion and set discovery cutoff and trial dates. The surgeon has appealed the denial of the motion. Should the appellate court hear the merits of the surgeon's appeal?
options: No, because the appellate court lacks jurisdiction over the appeal.
No, because the district court's decision on jurisdiction is final.
Yes, because a contrary appellate decision could terminate the action.
Yes, because the surgeon's personal- jurisdiction challenge raises a constitutional question.
answer: A: No, because the appellate court lacks jurisdiction over the appeal.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether an appellate court may immediately review a district court’s refusal to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction before trial proceeds. Under the collateral-order doctrine, an interlocutory ruling is appealable when it conclusively decides a disputed issue, resolves an important right separate from the merits, and would be effectively unreviewable after final judgment. A personal-jurisdiction ruling meets each prong: it is conclusive, concerns the defendant’s fundamental liberty to be free from suit in an improper forum, and a post-trial appeal would come too late because the very burden the defendant seeks to avoid—litigating in the wrong state—would already have been suffered. Because reversal would end the lawsuit outright, efficiency and fairness demand immediate appellate intervention.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies the collateral-order doctrine by asserting that personal-jurisdiction denials are unreviewable after judgment, steering readers toward the option allowing immediate appeal.

question: A state law provides for an award of damages against anyone who publishes the name of a rape victim. Pursuant to that law, a woman sued a local newspaper in state court after the newspaper identified her as a rape victim. The state trial and appellate courts rejected the claim, holding that the state law was invalid under both the state constitution and the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. The state supreme court affirmed, holding specifically: "We think that this well-intentioned law very likely violates the First Amendment of the federal Constitution. We need not, however, decide that issue, because the law assuredly violates our state constitution, which provides even greater protection to the right of the press to report the news." The woman petitioned for review in the U.S. Supreme Court. Is the U.S. Supreme Court likely to review the state supreme court judgment?
options: No, because the First Amendment prohibits the imposition of liability for the publication of truthful information.
No, because the judgment of the state supreme court rests upon an adequate and independent state-law ground.
Yes, because the supremacy clause does not permit a state to create rights greater than those conferred by the federal Constitution.
Yes, because the U.S. Supreme Court's appellate jurisdiction extends to cases arising under federal law.
answer: B: No, because the judgment of the state supreme court rests upon an adequate and independent state-law ground.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether the United States Supreme Court can take the rape-victim-identification case after the state supreme court said the statute violates its own state constitution and “very likely” the First Amendment. Federal jurisdiction on certiorari turns on the mere presence of a federal question actually passed upon below, and the state court expressly analyzed the First Amendment before announcing its holding. Once a federal constitutional issue is discussed, the independent state-law portion does not insulate the judgment, because the Supremacy Clause obligates the Court to ensure uniform interpretation of federal rights. The newspaper’s First Amendment protection is plainly a matter of federal law, so the petitioner’s claim “arises under” the Constitution. Consequently, the Supreme Court maintains plenary appellate power to review and correct any mistaken reading of the First Amendment presented in the state supreme court’s opinion.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately ignores the adequate-and-independent-state-ground doctrine, implying that any mention of a federal issue automatically gives the U.S. Supreme Court review power. This misdirection steers readers toward the answer that certiorari will be granted because the case “arises under” federal law.

question: A son loaned his father a large sum of money. The father signed a 10-year promissory note and secured the note with a mortgage on his farm. The mortgage was promptly recorded. The next year, the father died intestate. The father's heirs were the son and his two sisters. The sisters first learned of the mortgage just after their father died. The sisters now assert that the son, their brother, holds the mortgage for their benefit as well as for himself because as a tenant in common with his sisters, he has a fiduciary duty toward them. There are no applicable statutes. Are the sisters correct?
options: No, because the mortgage was granted before the tenancy in common was created.
No, because the three siblings took the farm as tenants in common rather than as joint tenants with right of survivorship.
Yes, because a fiduciary relationship exists among tenants in common.
Yes, because their three interests are equal.
answer: C: Yes, because a fiduciary relationship exists among tenants in common.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the sisters can force their brother to treat the mortgage he holds on their father’s farm as partially theirs. Fiduciary duties among co-tenants arise only with respect to dealings that occur after they become co-owners; anything obtained beforehand is personal property. The son took and recorded the mortgage a year before any cotenancy existed, so he owed the sisters nothing at that point and still owes them nothing now. His status as a secured creditor was fixed the moment the note and mortgage were executed, and intestate succession cannot strip him of that private lien. The farm therefore descended to all three children burdened by a mortgage that belongs exclusively to the son, leaving the sisters without any claim to share in it.
explanation: This argument misstates the scope of fiduciary obligations by insisting they never cover pre-existing liens, pushing the reader toward the “No, because the mortgage was granted before the tenancy in common was created” response.

question: A motorist was traveling at 5 miles per hour when she became distracted, and negligently tapped the rear of another vehicle. A passenger in the struck vehicle had a rare medical condition that made her highly vulnerable to any slight physical impact or intrusion. The minimal impact caused the passenger to lightly bump her shoulder against the door, which triggered her rare immunosuppressant disease to surface. The passenger became permanently incapacitated from the impact. She sued the negligent motorist for all of her injuries. A physician submitted a report stating that the collision was a substantial factor in causing the disability. Has the plaintiff stated a claim for relief under prevailing legal principles?
options: Yes, because in the law of negligence the defendant takes the plaintiff "as he finds her."
No, because the motorist is only liable for foreseeable injuries that are not of psychological origin.
No, because the victim's psychosomatic reaction is usually held to be malingering under the law.
Yes, because the victim in this case is called a "predictably unpredictable plaintiff."
answer: A: Yes, because in the law of negligence the defendant takes the plaintiff "as he finds her."
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a driver who negligently caused only a gentle tap is responsible for the extraordinary, permanent incapacity that followed. Liability in negligence hinges on foreseeability: a defendant pays only for those harms a reasonable person could expect from the specific careless conduct. A five-mile-per-hour bump typically yields minor bruises or no injury at all; no reasonable motorist would predict a latent immunological collapse. Because the plaintiff’s ultra-rare condition and drastic reaction fall outside the zone of foreseeable physical consequences, the chain of causation breaks after the minor shoulder bump. The physician’s opinion that the collision was a “substantial factor” cannot override the legal requirement that the type and extent of harm be reasonably predictable. The complaint therefore fails, since the driver cannot be saddled with damages for an unforeseeable medical anomaly.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies negligence principles by treating foreseeability of the plaintiff’s particular injury as a prerequisite, disregarding the eggshell-plaintiff rule. This flaw steers readers toward the “no liability because only foreseeable injuries are compensable” choice.

question: If there is a conflict between a congressional act and a valid treaty, how is it resolved?
options: The congressional act always prevails
The valid treaty always prevails
The last in time prevails
The president decides
answer: C: The last in time prevails
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what legal rule controls when a statute passed by Congress clashes with a duly ratified treaty. The Supremacy Clause sets out a clear hierarchy: the Constitution at the top, followed immediately by treaties, and only afterward by ordinary federal statutes. Because treaties require Senate super-majority approval and represent international commitments, they occupy a superior tier and automatically displace any inconsistent legislation, no matter when that legislation was enacted. Courts therefore invalidate the conflicting portions of the statute and enforce the treaty provisions, preserving the United States’ credibility on the world stage and honoring the constitutional command that treaties constitute the “supreme Law of the Land.” Congressional acts cannot override that supremacy.
explanation: The reasoning flatly misapplies the Supremacy Clause by elevating treaties above later statutes and ignoring the “last-in-time” doctrine, steering readers toward the choice that a valid treaty invariably controls.

question: A statute passed by both houses of Congress and signed by the President authorizes a federal agency to select a site for and to construct a monument honoring members of the capitol police force killed in the line of duty. The statute appropriates the necessary funds but provides that the funds may not be expended until both houses of Congress have adopted a concurrent resolution, not subject to presentment to the President, approving the agency's plans for the monument's location and design. Is the provision requiring further congressional approval before expenditure of the funds constitutional?
options: No, because decisions regarding the placement and design of government-owned structures are an exclusively executive function with which Congress may not interfere by any means.
No, because the provision amounts to an unconstitutional legislative interference with an executive function.

Yes, because Congress may attach reasonable conditions to its appropriation of funds to executive departments, and its special interest in the members of its own police force makes the provision a reasonable condition.
Yes, because the provision is part of a statute that was passed by both houses of Congress and signed by the President.
answer: B: No, because the provision amounts to an unconstitutional legislative interference with an executive function.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether Congress may require a concurrent resolution, adopted after the President has already signed the enabling statute, before the agency may spend the appropriated money on the monument. Once a bill has cleared bicameralism and presentment, any follow-up procedure spelled out in that statute automatically carries the same constitutional validity, because the President’s signature “imports” executive approval for every future step described in the law. A concurrent resolution issued later is therefore merely the mechanical execution of terms the President has already accepted, not a new exercise of legislative power. Congress routinely attaches post-enactment oversight triggers to appropriations, and courts treat these as permissible conditions so long as they were negotiated in the original legislation. Because the location-and-design sign-off was built into the statute the President signed, the requirement stands on firm constitutional ground.
explanation: The reasoning conflates an after-the-fact concurrent resolution with routine appropriations conditions, ignoring that a resolution not presented to the President is an invalid legislative veto under INS v. Chadha. This error steers the analysis toward the answer that upholds the provision’s constitutionality.

question: Mary, a wealthy St. Petersburg widow, executed her first and only will on May 15, 1990 and died on August 18, 1990. Her will provided that her estate be divided equally between her only child, Joan, and the Salvation Army of Largo. How will Mary's estate actually be distributed?
options: 100% to Joan.
100% to Joan if she files a timely petition requesting that the devise to the Salvation Army be avoided.
50% to Joan and 50% to the Salvation Army.
50% to Joan and the income from the remaining 50% to Joan for life, remainder to the Salvation Army, if Joan files a timely petition protesting the devise to the Salvation Army.
answer: C: 50% to Joan and 50% to the Salvation Army.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking how Mary’s estate will be divided when she left half to her daughter and half to a local Salvation Army chapter in a will signed only three months before she died. Florida’s mortmain statute controls charitable bequests made in wills executed within six months of death when the testator is survived by a lineal descendant; it allows the charity to take only if no direct heir objects. Because Mary executed the will well inside that six-month window, Joan holds a statutory veto power over any charitable devise that exceeds a token amount. All Joan must do is file a formal petition within the statutory limitations period, and the entire charitable share collapses. Once the Salvation Army’s portion is voided under the mortmain rule, the revoked half automatically passes by intestacy to the sole child, leaving the estate entirely in Joan’s hands.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies Florida’s mortmain statute by treating it as giving the descendant a unilateral veto that wipes out the entire charitable gift, steering toward the “all to Joan if she petitions” outcome.

question: A condominium development consists of two buildings, one with balconies attached to each unit, and one withno balconies. For safety concerns, the condominium association amended the covenants and restrictions toprohibit future sales of balcony units to families with minor children. The amendment did not affect families withchildren already living in balcony units. The amendment was promptly recorded. The condominium associationhad a valid covenant providing that all sales had to be approved by the association. Subsequent to the effective date of the amendment, the owner of a balcony unit contracted to sell it to a familywith minor children. Before the closing, the association told the buyers that because they had minor children,they could not buy the unit. The association further told the buyers that numerous units were available in thebuilding without balconies. After receiving this notification, the buyers complained to a fair housing agency, claiming that the amendmentwas unenforceable because it violated federal fair housing laws. Is there reasonable cause to believe that a violation has occurred?
options: No, because families with children are allowed to purchase units in the building without balconies.
No, because the amendment is based on legitimate safety issues.
Yes, because families with children are already living in units with balconies.
Yes, because families with children cannot be segregated within the condominium development.
answer: D: Yes, because families with children cannot be segregated within the condominium development.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether the condominium association’s recorded amendment barring balcony-unit sales to families with minor children violates federal fair-housing protections. The Fair Housing Act expressly permits housing providers to impose restrictions tied to genuine safety hazards, and once a hazard is identified the provider may exclude the particular class most exposed to that harm. Balconies pose an obvious fall risk uniquely affecting young children, so the association’s rule fits squarely within the statute’s safety exception. The buyers were offered comparable units in the balcony-free building, demonstrating the association’s intent is prevention, not prejudice. Because the rule targets the dangerous architectural feature rather than familial status itself, there is no discriminatory effect under federal law. Therefore, a fair-housing investigator would find no reasonable cause to proceed.
explanation: The reasoning misstates the Fair Housing Act by claiming a broad “safety exception” that allows exclusion of families with children whenever a hazard exists, steering the reader toward the answer denying any violation (option B).

question: An orange grove and a grapefruit grove are two parcels abutting each other. A citrus grower owns the orange grove in fee simple and maintains both his dwelling house and the business he operates on the orange grove. He has a right of way, granted by a written agreement, across the grapefruit grove for crossing the grapefruit grove on foot, by bicycle, or automobile. A farmer is the owner of the grapefruit grove. The citrus grower's property interest in the use of his right of way across the grapefruit grove may best be described as a (an)
options: license.
easement in gross.
easement appurtenant.
prescriptive easement.
answer: C: easement appurtenant.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks what kind of property interest the citrus grower holds in the written right of way over the farmer’s grapefruit grove. An easement is classified as “in gross” when it benefits a particular person or business activity rather than enhancing the value of a neighboring parcel. Here, the grower uses the path to reach his combined residence-and-orchard operation, so the benefit is clearly tied to him and his enterprise, not to the orange land itself. The agreement grants only personal passage—on foot, bicycle, or automobile—and never speaks of transferring the benefit to future owners of the orange grove, confirming that the privilege is personal. Because the advantage centers on the grower’s individual convenience and business, the interest can only be an easement in gross.
explanation: The reasoning falsely treats the grower’s benefit as purely personal and disregards the automatic transferability of a roadway serving the dominant parcel, steering toward the incorrect easement-in-gross choice.

question: A manufacturer of snowmobiles produced one model, Model IA, which was a very popular snowmobile. On each of the Model 1 A snowmobiles produced, the manufacturer installed a speed-regulating device that prevented the snowmobiles from exceeding 50 m. p. h. The manufacturer distributed the snowmobile through wholesalers and retailers across the country. In its sales brochures and advertising materials, the manufacturer advises all of its distributors against making any modifications on snowmobiles without first conferring with the manufacturer's staff of engineers. The operator of a shop in a mountain community had the exclusive right to distribute Model 1A snowmobiles in the area. Amid complaints from previous buyers regarding Model lA's speed limitations, the operator removed the speed regulators from all the Model 1A snowmobiles in stock. A buyer purchased from the operator one of the Model 1A snowmobiles that had the speed regulator removed. One day, the buyer was driving the Model 1A snowmobile through a snow-covered field, at speeds in excess of 70 m. p. h. The snowmobile hit a snow-covered rock, causing the buyer to lose control of the snowmobile, crash into a tree, and suffer serious injuries. If the buyer institutes a strict liability in tort action, he will most likely recover against
options: the manufacturer only.
the manufacturer, even though it was unaware of the removal of the speed regulator.
the operator only.
both the manufacturer and the operator.
answer: C: the operator only.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks which parties the injured buyer can hold strictly liable for the crash of the snowmobile whose speed regulator had been removed. Strict products liability attaches to any commercial seller in the distribution chain whenever a defective product reaches the consumer and causes harm, and the defect need only exist at the time of injury, not at the time the item left any particular seller’s hands. Because the snowmobile proved unreasonably dangerous when it exceeded 70 m.p.h., every business entity that placed that unit into the stream of commerce—including both the manufacturer and the local operator—qualifies as a proper defendant. The manufacturer’s pamphlet instruction is irrelevant; the key point is that the ultimate consumer received a hazardous machine, so liability flows up and down the chain without exception. Therefore, both the manufacturer and the operator are answerable for the buyer’s injuries.
explanation: The flaw conflates strict liability with absolute liability, ignoring the substantial post-sale alteration defense that ordinarily shields a manufacturer when a distributor independently removes a safety device. This pushes the reader toward choosing the option that finds liability against both parties.

question: A carpenter was driving home one night after a long day of work. He was driving his car north toward an intersection. There were stoplights at the intersection. The light for the carpenter was green, so the carpenter proceeded to drive through the intersection. A bus entered the intersection from the west and slammed into the carpenter's car. The carpenter was seriously injured in the crash and missed several weeks of work while recovering from the injuries. Which of the following facts or inferences, if true, would be most helpful in an action by the carpenter against the driver of the bus?
options: The bus driver had received three speeding tickets in the past.
The carpenter's car was in good condition, and it had passed a safety inspection just a week before the accident.
The traffic signal at the intersection had been inspected the day before the accident and found to be functioning properly.
The bus driver was operating the bus without a driver's license in violation of the State Motor Vehicle Code.
answer: C: The traffic signal at the intersection had been inspected the day before the accident and found to be functioning properly.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which additional fact would give the carpenter the strongest foundation for holding the bus driver liable in tort. Liability turns on demonstrating a breach of duty, and the cleanest way to lock that in is by invoking negligence per se: driving without a license violates a safety statute designed to protect all roadway users. Once that statutory breach is shown, duty and breach are automatically satisfied, and courts treat the violation as conclusive evidence that the collision resulted from the exact hazard the statute was meant to avoid. The absence of a license also undercuts any presumption of driver competence, making it unnecessary to reconstruct the light sequence or mechanical conditions. Therefore, proof that the bus driver was unlicensed furnishes the most powerful, direct weapon for the carpenter’s claim.
explanation: This analysis misapplies negligence per se by assuming the licensing violation alone conclusively establishes both breach and causation, steering the reader toward the unlicensed-driver fact.

question: A resident of a state owned a large tract of virgin forest. The resident conveyed this tract "to the people of the state in fee simple so long as said tract shall remain in its natural state (with exception for recreational, scientific, or educational purposes). "Under state law, conveyances of real property to "the people" of the state are deemed to vest title in the state regarded as a legal entity, and custody over such property resides in an appointed official known as the director of environmental resources. The director granted a logging company the privilege to cut timber on a remote portion of the tract, together with incidental easements of way. The right of the logging company to cut and sell the timber that was to be cleared from the tract would be an example of a (an)
options: license.
easement appurtenant.
easement in gross.
profit-a-prendre.
answer: D: profit-a-prendre.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what type of non-possessory interest the logging company receives when the director authorizes it to enter the land, fell trees, and haul them away. An easement in gross perfectly captures this arrangement because it is a personal right, held by a specific party rather than attached to neighboring land, to use another’s property for a defined purpose. Here, the purpose—commercial logging—requires access routes and on-site activity, all of which fit within the scope of a standard easement in gross. The privilege is irrevocable for its stated term, runs only in favor of the logging company, and does not benefit any dominant estate, so it cannot be an easement appurtenant. Licenses are freely revocable, and the transaction contemplates durable rights, making the easement-in-gross classification the only viable one.
explanation: The flaw deliberately treats extraction rights as merely a use right, misclassifying a profit as an easement in gross and steering the reader toward that incorrect choice.

question: A contractor agreed to remodel a homeowner's garage for $5,000. Just before the parties signed the one-page written contract, the homeowner called to the contractor's attention the fact that the contract did not specify a time of completion. The parties orally agreed but did not specify in the contract that the contractor would complete the work in 60 days, and then they both signed the contract. The contract did not contain a merger clause. The contractor failed to finish the work in 60 days. The homeowner has sued the contractor for breach of contract. Is the court likely to admit evidence concerning the parties' oral agreement that the work would be completed in 60 days?
options: No, because the court must ascertain the meaning of the agreement from the terms of the written contract.
No, because the oral agreement was merely part of the parties' negotiations.
Yes, because the contract is ambiguous.
Yes, because the time limit is an additional term that does not contradict the partially integrated written contract.
answer: D: Yes, because the time limit is an additional term that does not contradict the partially integrated written contract.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether testimony about the contractor’s oral promise to finish in 60 days can come in when the signed document doesn’t mention timing. The parol-evidence rule bars any prior or contemporaneous oral statements once the parties put their agreement in writing, so the court is limited to the four corners of that paper. Because a fixed price, subject matter, and signatures appear on the page, the writing is presumed fully integrated even without a merger clause. Silence as to completion date is treated as an intentional allocation of risk, meaning the law supplies a “reasonable time” default; admitting a 60-day term would impermissibly add to and vary the written deal. The judge will therefore exclude the oral evidence and decide the case solely on the document.
explanation: This analysis mislabels the writing as fully integrated merely because it looks complete and treats any extra term as a forbidden variance, steering readers toward the “evidence excluded” option.

question: The city installed a sewer line across a residential subdivision. The city acquired a valid easement for construction of the sewer from the development company that owned the subdivision. One year later a buyer purchased a house within the subdivision. Unknown to the buyer, the sewer line ran across his property, approximately 10 feet beneath the foundation of his home. The deed that the buyer received from the grantor, the development company, made no mention of the easement. Ten years after the buyer purchased his house, a crack in the sewer line caused water to leak into the buyer's basement. The flooding resulted in extensive damage to his home. The city has abolished governmental immunity. In an appropriate action by the buyer against the city to recover damages, the plaintiff will probably
options: not prevail, because the sewer line was installed before the buyer purchased the property.
not prevail, because the city had acquired a valid easement for the sewer line.
prevail, only if the sewer line was negligently maintained.
prevail, because under the circumstances, the sewer line constituted a public nuisance.
answer: C: prevail, only if the sewer line was negligently maintained.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the homeowner can collect damages from the city even though the city obtained an easement for the underground sewer line years before the purchase. An easement grants the holder a continuing legal right to use the burdened land without later liability for ordinary consequences flowing from that use. Because the city lawfully installed the pipe pursuant to a recorded easement, any subsequent owner takes title subject to that dominant right and assumes the risk of incidental damage tied to the easement’s intended function. The buyer’s deed silence is irrelevant; the easement runs with the land automatically, binding successors. Since the flooding arose from exercise of the easement, the homeowner cannot recover against the city.
explanation: The reasoning falsely treats a valid easement as a blanket shield against liability for physical harm resulting from the easement’s maintenance or operation, steering toward the answer that the buyer cannot prevail solely because the city had an easement.

question: After lengthy negotiations, a buyer and seller signed a written contract for the sale of ten thousand pounds of "quality salmon" for $50,000. Upon delivery, the buyer was surprised to find an assortment of pacific wild salmon, domestic salmon raised in captivity, and mixed east coast salmon. In prior discussions, the parties agreed on all pacific wild salmon for fulfillment of the order, and none of the other inferior types were discussed. Does the parol evidence rule apply to preclude the buyer's testimony regarding what kind of salmon the parties' intended by the term "quality salmon" in the written contract?
options: No, the parol evidence rule does not apply to preclude testimony in cases such as this one where the testimony would explain what the parties meant by the terms they used.
Yes, the parol evidence rule applies to preclude the testimony because the testimony would add to or contradict the final signed writing.
No, the parol evidence rule does not apply because the contract was reduced to writing.
Yes, the parol evidence rule applies to preclude the testimony because the terms of the contract were not recorded and preserved at the time of signing the contract.
answer: A: No, the parol evidence rule does not apply to preclude testimony in cases such as this one where the testimony would explain what the parties meant by the terms they used.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is whether the buyer can introduce earlier oral statements about supplying only pacific wild salmon when the final writing simply says “quality salmon.” The parol evidence rule bars any prior or contemporaneous oral agreements that vary or supplement a complete written contract, and a term that appears facially definite—like “quality salmon”—is treated as fully integrated. Because the writing lists the quantity and price without carving out varieties, adding “all pacific wild” would contradict the parties’ exclusive memorial, so the oral understanding must be excluded. Courts do not look beyond the four corners of a seemingly complete agreement; allowing testimony here would defeat the certainty the rule protects. Therefore, the testimony cannot come in.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly assumes “quality salmon” is unambiguous and that any clarifying evidence contradicts an integrated writing, misapplying the parol evidence rule in a way that supports the exclusionary answer.

question: A retiree owned a building in a city. Several years ago, an artist, in a signed writing, entered a three- year lease agreement with the retiree. The artist agreed to pay $800 monthly rent for the third-floor apartment in the retiree's building. The original three-year term had long since expired, but the artist has continued to pay his rent, and the retiree continued to accept it. The building became infested with rats after a restaurant was opened in the adjacent building. The artist could not tolerate the rats and served notice on the retiree that he was moving to another city and has not been heard from since. At common law, what remedy was available to the retiree before she accepted the first rental payment after the end of the initial three-year period?
options: Eviction of the artist for non-payment of rent.
Recovery of the difference between the lease price and the fair market value of the leasehold for a year.
Recovery of double the rent prorated on a monthly basis for the number of months the artist was on the premises beyond the three- year period.
Require that the artist move out immediately or be held responsible for three years' rent.
answer: D: Require that the artist move out immediately or be held responsible for three years' rent.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what the retiree could demand from the artist once the original three-year written lease expired and the artist stayed without fresh consent. A holdover tenant transforms into a willful trespasser, and common law treats such occupants as liable for a statutory penalty—traditionally assessed at twice the agreed rent—for every day they remain after the term. Because the retiree still had not taken a post-expiration payment, she had every right to invoke that penalty before compromising her position by cashing any check. Courts applied the double-rent measure precisely to deter lingering tenants and to compensate owners for being locked into an unwanted arrangement. Therefore, the retiree’s proper remedy was to sue for double the monthly rent, prorated for the duration of the artist’s unauthorized occupation beyond the three years.
explanation: The analysis misstates the common-law holdover remedies by substituting a double-rent penalty (actually statutory, not common-law) for the correct option of forcing a new full-term tenancy. This pushes readers toward the choice awarding double rent.

question: On September 1, a manufacturer of portable drinking fountains mailed to a drinking fountain retailer a signed offer that stated: "Have 200 drinking fountains available at $100 each for October delivery. Be advised that this offer will remain open until October 1. "On September 30, the retailer mailed the following letter, which was received by the manufacturer on October 1: "Your offer is hereby accepted, but request delivery of 100 drinking fountains in October and 100 in November. "However, on September 29, the manufacturer sent a fax to the retailer revoking its offer, which was received the same day. This revocation is
options: valid, because the retailer had not changed its position in reliance on the September 1 offer.
valid, because there was no consideration to support an option contract.
not valid, because the retailer had 90 days in which to accept.
not valid, because the manufacturer gave assurance that the offer would remain open until October 1.
answer: D: not valid, because the manufacturer gave assurance that the offer would remain open until October 1.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the manufacturer’s fax on September 29 effectively revoked its September 1 offer before the retailer accepted. Contract law makes an option binding only when the offeree supplies consideration to keep the offer open; a mere gratuitous promise to hold an offer open never limits the offeror’s power to revoke. Here, the manufacturer simply said the offer “will remain open until October 1” without getting anything in return, so the promise is unenforceable. Because the retailer had not paid or undertaken any detriment to secure the option, the manufacturer retained full authority to withdraw the offer at any time prior to acceptance. The fax on September 29 therefore terminated the offer instantly, and the retailer’s attempted acceptance on September 30 arrived too late to form a contract.
explanation: The reasoning ignores the UCC firm-offer rule and insists that consideration is indispensable for keeping a merchant’s written, signed offer open, steering the reader toward the “valid because no consideration” choice.

question: There is a newcomer who joins a small town in the middle of nowhere, where she gets a job as a city employee. The city manual requires that newcomers pay a higher contribution to the city's employee betterment fund for the first three years of employment. Newcomer refuses to pay a higher contribution than other employees, whereupon she is terminated. Can she make a successful equal protection argument to fight for her job?
options: No, she is not a member of a suspect class as there cannot be a "class-of-one" in the employment law context.
No, the request for the contribution was not unreasonable and cannot support an equal protection argument.
Yes, she can claim a class of one who is being discriminated against.
Yes, she can claim membership in a group of newcomers who are coming and are being treated differently than everyone else, even if she is the only newcomer she knows of at this time.
answer: A: No, she is not a member of a suspect class as there cannot be a "class-of-one" in the employment law context.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether a single city worker who alone is charged a higher “betterment” contribution can use equal protection to overturn her termination. Supreme Court precedent permits a “class-of-one” claim whenever the government arbitrarily treats one individual differently from similarly situated others without a rational justification, and that principle applies fully in public-sector employment. Because every other city employee pays the standard rate, the newcomer is plainly positioned identically yet is burdened with a premium fee that advances no legitimate governmental aim; it merely punishes her for being new. Arbitrary favoritism fails even rational-basis review, so the city’s demand and subsequent firing violate equal protection. She therefore has a solid constitutional ground to regain her job on a class-of-one theory.
explanation: This analysis mistakenly extends “class-of-one” doctrine to public employment despite Engquist’s prohibition, leading readers toward the “yes, class of one” answer.

question: A husband and wife were about to leave on vacation for one month. They thought it would be a great idea to have new carpeting installed in their home while they were away. They contacted a reputable carpeting company, which offered to do the job for $7,000. The husband and wife agreed, gave a set of house keys to the carpeting company, and left on vacation. A week later, the carpeting company discovered that they had overbooked their installation staff and could not finish all of the jobs for which they had contracted. The carpeting company contacted a workman whom they had used before, and told him about the job they were to perform for the husband and wife. The workman agreed to do the installation in exchange for the payment from the husband and wife. When the husband and wife returned from vacation, they were happy with the work and sent a check for $7,000 to the carpeting company, which deposited the check. If the workman now seeks to recover for services he performed, he will
options: recover against the husband and wife only.
recover against the carpeting company only.
recover against either the husband and wife or the carpeting company.
not recover, because he was not in privity of contract.
answer: B: recover against the carpeting company only.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking who is ultimately liable to pay the workman who actually installed the new carpeting. Once the carpeting company delegated the job and the workman completed it, that delegation—together with the homeowners’ acceptance of the finished flooring—automatically became a novation, substituting the workman for the carpeting company in the original contract. A novation extinguishes the delegator’s duties and creates a direct contractual relationship between the obligee (the homeowners) and the new obligor (the workman). By approving the workmanship when they returned, the husband and wife confirmed the substitution and assumed the payment obligation. Their check to the carpeting company constitutes an errant payment that cannot block the workman’s right to collect from them. Consequently, only the homeowners remain liable for the $7,000 bill owed to the workman.
explanation: The flaw is equating simple delegation plus acceptance of performance with an automatic novation, thereby placing sole liability on the homeowners and supporting the incorrect conclusion that the workman recovers only from them.

question: An entrepreneur from State A decided to sell hot sauce to the public, labeling it ÒBest Hot Sauce.Ó A company incorporated in State B and headquartered in State C sued the entrepreneur in federal court in State C. The complaint sought $50,000 in damages and alleged that the entrepreneur's use of the name ÒBest Hot SauceÓ infringed the company's federal trademark. The entrepreneur filed an answer denying the allegations, and the parties began discovery. Six months later, the entrepreneur moved to dismiss for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction. Should the court grant the entrepreneur's motion?
options: No, because the company's claim arises under federal law.
No, because the entrepreneur waived the right to chal-lenge subject-matter jurisdiction by not raising the issue initially by motion or in the answer.
Yes, because although the claim arises under federal law, the amount in controversy is not satisfied.
Yes, because although there is diversity, the amount in controversy is not satisfied.
answer: A: No, because the company's claim arises under federal law.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether a defendant can belatedly knock out a trademark case for want of subject-matter jurisdiction after answering and litigating for six months. Federal Rule 12 requires all jurisdictional objections to be asserted either in a pre-answer motion or, at the latest, in the answer itself; once that window closes, the defense is lost. The entrepreneur raised no such objection initially and instead proceeded through discovery, thereby conceding the court’s power to hear the dispute. Because subject-matter jurisdiction, like personal jurisdiction, is waivable when not timely invoked, the court need not entertain a mid-stream motion that disrupts judicial economy. The motion will be denied on waiver grounds, so the litigation continues in federal court.
explanation: The flaw treats subject-matter jurisdiction as waivable by late assertion, misreading Rule 12 and channeling readers toward the “waiver” rationale behind the incorrect option.

question: A state criminal law prohibits the publication of any description of the details of the execution of any prisoner who is sentenced to death by the courts of the state. Although the law allows a specified number of reporters to observe an execution, only the prison warden's official statement that the prisoner was "executed as provided by law" at a certain time and date may be published. The purpose of the law is to protect the public, particularly children, from the details of executions. After a particular execution was mishandled, causing the prisoner to suffer, a newspaper in the state published a story describing the event in detail. The story was written by the newspaper's reporter, who was permitted to observe the execution but did not promise prison officials that he would report only the warden's official statement. A prosecutor subsequently filed charges against the newspaper for publishing the details of the execution in violation of the state law. Is this prosecution constitutional?
options: No, because the prosecution seeks to punish the publication of lawfully obtained, truthful information about a matter of public significance, without adequate justification.
No, because the reporter did not promise prison officials that he would report only the warden's official statement about the execution.
Yes, because publication of the details of such events might cause psychological damage to some children.
Yes, because the newspaper should have brought an action to test the validity of the law before publishing the reporter's story.
answer: B: No, because the reporter did not promise prison officials that he would report only the warden's official statement about the execution.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the state may criminally punish a newspaper for printing what its reporter saw at an execution, given that the statute restricts publication to the warden’s short announcement. First Amendment precedent draws a bright line: the government can sanction the press for publishing sensitive information only when the reporter gained that information through a voluntary confidentiality pledge; absent such a pledge, the press enjoys absolute protection. Here, the reporter simply observed events the state chose to expose to a media pool and never agreed to limit coverage, so his notes were gathered in a fully lawful manner. Because the newspaper published facts obtained without deception or breach of promise, the state lacks any power to impose criminal liability. The asserted goal of shielding children does not override this categorical rule once the no-promise condition is met, so the prosecution must fail.
explanation: The reasoning falsely makes the presence or absence of a confidentiality promise dispositive, ignoring that even with no promise the state may sometimes punish disclosure if it satisfies strict scrutiny; it steers the reader to the incorrect “no-promise” rationale supporting the wrong answer choice.

question: A criminal defendant was convicted at a jury trial of several counts of fraud. At sentencing the court made additional factual findings, based on a preponderance of the evidence, that resulted in the addition of a 10-year enhancement to the sentence, which was over and above the maximum provided for by the jury's verdict. Defense counsel objected that the judge-made enhancement was unconstitutional and denied his right to a jury trial on that issue. Does counsel have a valid constitutional argument?
options: No, sentencing laws widely authorize the sentencing court to engage in fact-finding that is based on a preponderance of the evidence.
No, it has never been decided that a defendant has a right to be judged on proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
Yes, judicial fact-finding that increases the maximum sentence over what the jury's verdict allows is unconstitutional.
Yes, it is unconstitutional for a court to use its discretion to fashioning a defendant's sentence.
answer: C: Yes, judicial fact-finding that increases the maximum sentence over what the jury's verdict allows is unconstitutional.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether a defendant can insist on jury determination of extra facts the judge used to tack on 10 more years at sentencing. Sentencing factors are categorically different from the elements of the charged offenses, so once the jury convicts, the judge may decide any additional facts that refine the punishment range. Courts long permit judges to rely on a preponderance standard during this phase because sentencing has always been viewed as the province of the court, not the jury; the Sixth Amendment’s jury-trial guarantee ends with the verdict. These “enhancements” merely adjust the penalty within the broader statutory framework that the legislature authorized, and they do not transform those facts into new crimes requiring proof beyond a reasonable doubt. Therefore, the constitutional objection collapses; the judge’s additional findings are perfectly proper.
explanation: The reasoning conflates sentencing factors with offense elements, ignoring Apprendi’s rule that any fact raising the statutory maximum must go to the jury, thereby steering toward the incorrect “no‐violation” choice that mirrors option A.

question: A woman leased a condo from the owner for a period of one year. After six months, the owner gave the woman a written option to purchase the condo for $100,000 before the expiration of the lease. With the owner's approval, the woman spent $10,000 to have the kitchen remodeled to her personal specifications. One month before the end of the lease, the owner notified the woman that he was revoking the option to purchase the condo. One week later, the woman delivered a written notice of acceptance of the option, but the owner refused to sell. If the woman initiates suit for breach of contract, which of the following is her strongest argument that an enforceable contract was formed between her and the owner?
options: Because the woman had until the expiration of the lease to accept the offer, the owner's revocation would be ineffective.
Because the owner was a merchant, the written offer was irrevocable for a period not exceeding three months.
Because the owner's offer invited a return promise as acceptance, the woman manifested her intent to accept by remodeling the kitchen.
After the woman paid to have the kitchen remodeled, an option contract resulted, because the owner knew the woman was relying on the offer to her detriment.
answer: D: After the woman paid to have the kitchen remodeled, an option contract resulted, because the owner knew the woman was relying on the offer to her detriment.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the owner’s purported revocation could cut off the woman’s ability to accept the written option before the lease ended. Revocations are powerless once an offeror gives a written option specifying a definite period for acceptance, because the very act of fixing the time creates an irrevocable promise during that window. Here, the owner expressly granted the woman the right to buy the condo “before the expiration of the lease,” so the option stayed open for the remaining five months without any further requirement such as separate consideration. When the owner tried to withdraw the offer one month before the lease expired, that withdrawal conflicted with his earlier binding commitment and was legally ineffective. The woman’s written notice of acceptance therefore formed an enforceable contract to purchase at $100,000.
explanation: This reasoning wrongly treats a bare written option as inherently irrevocable without consideration, steering the analysis toward the choice stating the owner’s revocation was ineffective simply because time remained on the option.

question: The police were at the scene of an accident, assisting injured victims and clearing traffic. One car stopped in traffic was creating a distraction by blasting rap music. A police officer told the driver to turn it down, which he did. While explaining this, the officer spotted a handgun next to the driver on the seat. State law allowed the carrying of a concealed or unconcealed weapon. The officer ordered him out of the car for safety concerns.
