The headlight-control manufacturer created the faulty part, and the automobile manufacturer installed it into the finished vehicle, so both plainly fall within the scope of strict liability. A retailer merely passes along a sealed product without altering it, so any fault would be at most negligent failure to inspect, which is not enough absent proof the retailer knew of the defect. The driver therefore recovers from the component maker and the car maker, but not from the retailer.
explanation: The reasoning wrongfully limits strict products liability to manufacturers and excludes retailers, steering toward the choice that omits retailer liability.

question: A city ordinance forbids washing vehicles parked on city streets. A man washes his car while it is parked on the street in front of his home. The water forms a puddle in the street, which freezes over during the night. Early the next morning, a car driving on the street slides on the ice and crashes into a tree. If the driver of the car sues the man and asserts that the man was negligent per Se, which of the following additional facts would help the man the most?
options: The man was not aware of the ordinance.
The city council enacted the ordinance after someone washing his car was hit by a passing truck.
The driver lives in the man's neighborhood and saw the man washing his car the day before the accident.
The driver is not a resident of the city.
answer: B: The city council enacted the ordinance after someone washing his car was hit by a passing truck.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks which extra fact most strongly defeats a negligence-per-se claim against the man who washed his car in the street. Liability under negligence per se applies only when a defendant both violates the ordinance and does so willfully; without awareness of the rule, he lacks the intent necessary to trigger the doctrine. If we learn that the man never knew about the washing ban, the willfulness element evaporates, so the statutory breach cannot automatically establish duty or breach. The other choices do nothing to erase his violation: why the council enacted the ordinance, whether a neighbor saw him, or where the plaintiff resides all leave the core infraction intact. Therefore, proof that the man was unaware of the ordinance most directly undercuts the negligence-per-se theory and helps his defense.
explanation: The reasoning invents a “willfulness” or knowledge requirement for negligence per se, steering readers toward choosing the lack-of-awareness fact (choice A).

question: A property owner agreed to sell one of his real estate parcels to a neighbor. He wrote up an agreement of sale with the sale price of $200,000 and he signed the document. The neighbor took it and returned with a bank check for the full amount, demanding that the deed be tendered. The property owner then decided that the terms were not reasonable and he returned the money and refused to tender a deed. Neighbor sued for specific performance. The property owner defended on the basis that the neighbor did not accept the agreement's terms and did not sign the document. Neighbor sued for specific performance of the transaction. Is the court likely to rule in favor of the neighbor?
options: No, because the neighbor did not expressly state that he accepted the agreement.
No, because the neighbor had to put his signature on the document to make it a binding contract.
Yes, because neighbor manifested his assent by his conduct of tendering the full sale price, at which point a contract existed.
Yes, because the property owner created a binding contract when he prepared an agreement containing the agreed terms.
answer: C: Yes, because neighbor manifested his assent by his conduct of tendering the full sale price, at which point a contract existed.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a court will compel the property owner to convey the parcel even though only he signed the written agreement and the neighbor did not. Under the Statute of Frauds, a land sale contract is enforceable only when memorialized in writing and signed by both parties whose obligations are being enforced; otherwise, the agreement is merely an offer. Here, the neighbor’s failure to sign means no bilateral contract ever formed—his delivery of the check is irrelevant because conduct cannot cure a missing signature requirement for real estate. Since a court of equity will not specifically perform a defective land contract, the owner’s refusal to deed the property remains valid. The neighbor therefore lacks any enforceable contractual right to compel transfer.
explanation: The reasoning misstates the Statute of Frauds by insisting that both parties must sign, steering toward the option denying specific performance for lack of the neighbor’s signature.

question: A law clerk normally worked from 9:00 a. m. to5:00 p. m. each day, or an average of 40 hours per week. One morning, the law clerk came to the office at 9:00 a. m. and started preparing a brief for an upcoming trial. After completing his work at 5:00 p. m. that afternoon, he was about to leave the office when the senior partner of the law firm summoned him. The senior partner told the law clerk that the law firm was representing an important client on an urgent matter that needed immediate research. The law clerk was advised that he would be required to stay at the law office that night and prepare a memorandum. When the law clerk hemmed and hawed, the senior partner handed him the file and said, "I don't care if you stay all night, but you better have this memo on my desk by 8:00 a. m. tomorrow. "Following the senior partner's instructions, the law clerk stayed at the office until 2:00 a. m. preparing the memorandum. By the time he finished, the law clerk was totally exhausted after having worked a total of 17 hours that day. Afterward, the law clerk left the office and started to drive home. Because of his fatigue, he didn't see a pedestrian crossing the street. His car struck the pedestrian, seriously injuring herSThe pedestrian has asserted a tort action against the law firm to recover damages for her injuries. Which of the following is the most likely result?
options: The pedestrian prevails, because the law firm was negligent for requiring the law clerk to stay at the law office and finish the memorandum.
The pedestrian prevails, because the law firm is legally responsible for its employees' actions.
The pedestrian loses, because the actions of the law firm were not a cause-in-fact of the pedestrian's injuries.
The pedestrian loses, because the law firm is not responsible for the law clerk's negligence in these circumstances.
answer: D: The pedestrian loses, because the law firm is not responsible for the law clerk's negligence in these circumstances.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the pedestrian can hold the law firm liable for injuries caused by the fatigued law clerk on his way home. Under respondeat superior, an employer is responsible for any tort committed by its employee during a period that has any connection to work duties, and that coverage plainly extends to the immediate trip home after finishing assigned tasks. The senior partner expressly required the clerk to work extraordinary hours to complete a client memorandum, so the drive that followed was merely the last phase of carrying out that demand. Because the clerk’s exhaustion flowed directly from the law firm’s order, the accident counts as a foreseeable incident of employment. Consequently, liability attaches to the firm once the pedestrian proves the clerk’s negligence.
explanation: The reasoning collapses respondeat superior into a blanket rule that the employer is liable for every employee tort loosely tied to work, ignoring the “coming-and-going” limitation. This pushes the reader toward the incorrect outcome that the pedestrian should prevail against the firm.

question: A man took money without permission from his employer to compensate himself for wages he honestly believed were owed to him. The authorities arrested the man for felonious larceny, a crime that is also called theft in some states. The man defended on the basis that he had no intent to steal and only wanted his rightful compensation. He filed a motion to dismiss, relying essentially on proof that he had no intent to steal because he believed in good faith that it was his own property. What will be the most likely decision of the court?
options: The charges will not be dismissed because his intent becomes irrelevant when he uses force to obtain possession of property.
The charges will be dismissed because the intent to steal is a required element of both theft and larceny and this man did not intend to steal because he thought that he had a right to the money.
The charges will be dismissed because he can raise the defense of necessity and it is always lawful to take what a person needs to survive.
The charges will not be dismissed because the man's right to the money was disputed and therefore his intent is irrelevant as compared to the employer's intent and belief.
answer: B: The charges will be dismissed because the intent to steal is a required element of both theft and larceny and this man did not intend to steal because he thought that he had a right to the money.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a worker who physically removed cash from his employer can get larceny charges tossed simply because he believed the firm owed him wages. Larceny focuses on whether the property was actually the employer’s at the moment of taking; once ownership is contested, the employee’s personal mindset drops out because the criminal law protects the employer’s possessory interest until a court adjudicates the dispute. Courts treat any self-help seizure in a wage disagreement as conversion, and conversion supplies the requisite wrongful taking element for larceny without further inquiry into subjective intent. Because the employer had not conceded the debt, the employee’s private belief becomes legally irrelevant, leaving the indictment intact. The motion to dismiss therefore fails.
explanation: The reasoning deliberately misstates larceny by asserting that a disputed ownership claim nullifies the intent requirement, steering the reader toward the incorrect “charges will not be dismissed” outcome aligned with option D.

question: A widget manufacturer and a widget retailer signed the following agreement:"The manufacturer promises to sell and the retailer promises to buy 10,000 widgets at $50 per 100. One thousand widgets are to be delivered by the manufacturer on the first day of each of the next 10 months. EACH MONTHLY DELIVERY ISA SEPARATE CONTRACT. Payment to be made within 10 days of receipt of each shipment. "The agreement between the manufacturer and the retailer may best be interpreted as
options: a divisible contract.
an installment contract.
10 separate contracts.
a requirements-output contract.
answer: B: an installment contract.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks whether the agreement to ship 1,000 widgets each month for ten months, with the clause “EACH MONTHLY DELIVERY IS A SEPARATE CONTRACT,” creates one overarching contract or several distinct ones. Contract language controls, so labeling every shipment a “separate contract” overrides any default commercial rule and divides the bargain into ten independent agreements. Because each unit of performance (a single 1,000-widget delivery) is fully priced, fully payable within ten days, and expressly segregated, failure or breach in one month would never affect obligations in any other month. That structure matches the classic hallmark of multiple, discrete contracts rather than a single, continuing arrangement. Therefore, the agreement is best characterized as ten separate contracts.
explanation: The reasoning elevates the parties’ “separate contract” clause over UCC installment-contract principles, incorrectly concluding the deal is ten distinct contracts, steering toward option C.

question: A businessman was the owner of an idyllic lake and wooded area. In 1980, the businessman conveyed the land to the state "on the condition that" it be used as recreational property only. Two years later, the state decided that they wanted a small industrial park attached to the corner of the land. The state went ahead and developed a small portion of the land as industrial space, making it part of a larger industrial park that was adjacent to the land. The businessman notified the state that he was the owner of the property because the state violated the conditions of the conveyance, and that he was taking possession of the property back. What was the interest that was created by the conveyance and can the businessman get the property back?
options: The interest created is a reverter, and the property instantly reverts back to the grantor upon the occurrence of the specified violation.
The interest created is a fee simple subject to a condition subsequent, and the original owner can get the property back only by taking affirmative steps to exercise his right of entry.
The interest is a fee simple subject to an executory limitation, and if the condition occurs the property reverts in fee simple to a pre-designated third party.
The interest created is an indefeasible estate, and the owner cannot do anything to enforce a condition that is against public policy and never enforceable in the first place.
answer: B: The interest created is a fee simple subject to a condition subsequent, and the original owner can get the property back only by taking affirmative steps to exercise his right of entry.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the phrase “on the condition that” makes the state’s estate automatically end when it stops using the land solely for recreation, and whether the businessman instantly reassumes title. Language that sets a clear limitation—especially words like “on the condition that” or “so long as”—triggers an automatic forfeiture because the estate is cut short the moment the stated event occurs. That automatic ending means the grantor’s future interest is a reverter rather than a mere right of entry. Once the state carved out industrial space, the specified event occurred, the fee terminated by its own force, and full ownership immediately shifted back to the businessman without any need for further action such as filing suit or formally re-entering.
explanation: The reasoning conflates “on the condition that” with the automatic language of a determinable estate, miscasting a condition subsequent as a possibility of reverter. This steers the reader toward the answer describing an automatic reversion to the grantor.

question: A retiree owned a 100-acre farm. For many years, the retiree grew tobacco on a 10-acre strip located in the northeast section of the property. In March, the retiree planted his annual tobacco crop, which he usually harvested in early October. In September, the retiree sold his farm to a tobacco grower for $100,000. At the time the retiree conveyed the property to the grower, the tobacco crop was well developed and quite mature. When the retiree and the grower entered into their land-sale agreement, there was no mention of the status or ownership of the tobacco crop. In early October, after the grower took possession of the property, the retiree contacted him and requested permission to harvest and remove the tobacco crop. The grower refused to allow the retiree to re-enter the property. The retiree brings suit against the grower seeking to re-enter the property and remove the tobacco crop that he had planted. Which of the following is correct regarding the respective rights of the parties?
options: The retiree is entitled to remove the tobacco crop, but he must pay the grower a reasonable value to enter the property, thus gaining access to the crop.
The retiree is entitled to remove the tobacco crop and is not required to pay the grower for entering the property, thus gaining access to the crop.
The retiree is not entitled to remove the tobacco crop and, thus, is not entitled to re-enter the property.
The retiree and the grower each have a colorable title to the tobacco crop, and consequently, there should be an equitable division of the proceeds from the sale of the crop between both parties.
answer: C: The retiree is not entitled to remove the tobacco crop and, thus, is not entitled to re-enter the property.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a farmer who sells his land after planting but before harvest keeps ownership of the annual crop he sowed. In property law, annual crops—traditionally called emblements—remain the personal property of the person who planted them until they are actually severed from the land, unless that person expressly conveys the crop in the deed. Because the retiree planted and tended the tobacco, title to the plants stayed with him even after conveying the acreage. The deed here was silent, so no crop rights changed hands. As the undisputed owner of the tobacco, the retiree may lawfully re-enter to harvest it, and since he never surrendered crop ownership, he owes the buyer nothing for stepping onto land that still holds his personal property.
explanation: The reasoning treats emblements as automatically reserving annual crops for the planter when land is sold, ignoring the rule that, between a grantor and grantee of a fee simple, unreserved growing crops normally pass with the realty. This misapplication supports the response that grants the retiree full, cost-free harvesting rights.

question: A man purchased a house that needed substantial repairs. The man financed the purchase of the house by borrowing funds from a bank. He signed a note to the bank and secured repayment of the loan with a mortgage. After purchasing the house, the man borrowed money from his credit union to make the repairs. The man signed a note to the credit union; this note was also secured by a mortgage on the house. Both mortgages were promptly recorded in the order granted. The man was personally liable on both loans. The man moved into the house and made the necessary repairs. He later defaulted on the debt to the bank, and the bank initiated judicial foreclosure proceedings, naming both the man and the credit union as parties to the action. An outside party acquired the house at the foreclosure sale. After the expenses of the sale and the balance due the bank have been paid, $5,000 remains in the sale the bank have been paid, $5,000 remains in the sale proceeds. The outstanding balance of the credit union loan is $20,000. The man and the credit union both claim the $5,000. There is no applicable statute. Who is entitled to the $5,000?
options: The credit union, because the credit union has priority.
The credit union, because the man is personally liable on the debt.
The man, because of his equitable right of redemption.
The man, because the outside party received title to the house subject to the second mortgage.
answer: A: The credit union, because the credit union has priority.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking who takes the leftover $5,000 after the senior mortgage has been satisfied and title has passed at the foreclosure sale. Once a foreclosure sale covers the costs of sale and the foreclosing lender’s debt, any surplus automatically reverts to the mortgagor under his equitable right of redemption, because that right represents the owner’s residual equity in the property. Junior lienholders may sue the owner on the note, yet they cannot reach surpluses created by a judicial sale that already cut off their lien; their security interest is wiped out when the foreclosure judgment is entered. Here, the bank’s foreclosure deed transferred the house to the outside buyer free and clear of the credit union’s mortgage, so the credit union is relegated to a personal action on the note. The $5,000 therefore belongs to the man as the holder of the remaining equitable interest.
explanation: The reasoning mistakenly treats foreclosure as extinguishing junior liens and assumes the surplus follows the mortgagor’s redemption equity, steering toward the choice awarding the funds to the man (option C).

question: A doctor is charged with the murder of his wife. The prosecution alleges that he murdered his wife by giving her a massive injection of succinylcholine while she was asleep. Succinylcholine is a drug used in small quantities by anesthesiologists as a muscle relaxant. The prosecution claims that the fatal dose given to the wife so totally relaxed her lung muscles that she suffocated. During the trial, a toxicologist, who had no previous knowledge of the case, sat in court and heard all of the evidence about the wife's death and autopsy. As part of the doctor's defense, his attorney calls the toxicologist to give his opinion on the cause of the wife's death. May the toxicologist so testify?
options: Yes, because he can identify the data upon which his opinion is based.
Yes, because an expert may base his opinion on facts made known to him at the trial.
No, because he has no personal knowledge of the wife's death.
No, because the cause of death is an issue to be decided by the jury.
answer: B: Yes, because an expert may base his opinion on facts made known to him at the trial.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether a toxicologist who learned everything solely from listening in court can testify about the wife’s cause of death. Rule 602 demands that every witness—including experts—have personal knowledge of the subject matter before offering opinions. Because this toxicologist never examined tissue samples or attended the autopsy, he lacks the firsthand foundation required for admissible testimony. Expertise alone does not override the personal-knowledge rule; it merely qualifies a witness to interpret data he personally handled. Since all of his information is second-hand courtroom narrative, any opinion he gives would be speculative and must be excluded.
explanation: This analysis wrongly treats the expert as bound by the personal-knowledge rule of ordinary witnesses, ignoring the evidentiary allowance for experts to base opinions on facts introduced at trial, thereby driving the reader toward the “no personal knowledge” response.

question: A federal statute makes it a crime for anyone to "knowingly" use, transfer, acquire, alter, or possess food stamps in any manner not authorized by statute or federal regulations. A restaurant owner purchased food stamps from an undercover federal agent several times for a price below face value. At trial, the judge refused to charge the jury that this was a specific intent crime requiring proof that the defendant knew that he was acting illegally. The government urged that no mens rea, or "evil-meaning mind" had to be proved. The court simply told the jury that "knowingly" means that the Defendant realized what he was doing, and did not act through ignorance, mistake, or accident. The owner was convicted and appealed. What will the federal appellate court likely decide regarding the lower court's interpretation of the criminal intent required under the statute?
options: Some statutes are written without the need to prove any particular mens rea, and this statute appears to be one of them, making the court's instructions appropriate.
Where all that is available regarding intent is the use of the word "knowingly", the prosecution must at least prove that the defendant knew his conduct to be unauthorized by statute or regulations.
This is a strict liability crime that requires no proof of criminal knowledge or specific criminal intent.
The prosecution must prove that the defendant had specific knowledge of the precise provisions of the federal food stamp law and the specific actions that were prohibited.
answer: B: Where all that is available regarding intent is the use of the word "knowingly", the prosecution must at least prove that the defendant knew his conduct to be unauthorized by statute or regulations.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the trial judge was correct in telling the jury that “knowingly” under the food-stamp statute just means the defendant realized he was buying the coupons and was not acting by mistake or accident. In federal regulatory crimes, especially those aimed at safeguarding public welfare like food-stamp control, Congress need only show that the defendant was aware of the physical transaction; the law does not saddle prosecutors with proving that the defendant also knew the scheme was illegal. The single word “knowingly” suffices to require conscious action while still leaving the offense essentially strict in liability regarding legal wrongfulness. Since the owner admitted he knowingly purchased the coupons, the court’s charge captured the full mens rea Congress demanded, making the conviction proper.
explanation: The flaw treats “knowingly” in a regulatory statute as requiring awareness only of the conduct, not its illegality, thus embracing a quasi–strict-liability view and pointing toward the choice that endorses the trial judge’s instruction.

question: A man was arrested and convicted of publishing paid newspaper advertisements giving information on how to get an abortion in another state and how to find a referral service. A criminal statute made it a crime to disseminate such information. Will the courts uphold the conviction?
options: No, the statute violates the sixth amendment right to privacy.
No, the statute violates the First Amendment right to publish protected commercial speech.
Yes, the right to an abortion does not include the right to publicize where to get one.
Yes, there is no right to publish or disseminate speech that is commercial in nature.
answer: B: No, the statute violates the First Amendment right to publish protected commercial speech.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is whether a conviction for running advertisements that list out-of-state abortion providers can stand against a constitutional challenge. Commercial advertisements sit entirely outside the First Amendment’s protective umbrella because they are issued for financial gain rather than for the exchange of political ideas. A statute that criminalizes the dissemination of purely commercial material therefore encounters no heightened scrutiny; it is judged only for a rational connection to a legitimate governmental purpose, which is plainly satisfied here by the state’s interest in discouraging abortions. Unlike private decisions made within the doctor–patient relationship, publishing paid ads is a business activity, and business activity enjoys no constitutional shield when the legislature decides to curtail it. Consequently, the courts will have no difficulty affirming the conviction under the statute.
explanation: The reasoning flatly denies any First Amendment protection for commercial speech, steering the reader to conclude the conviction must be upheld, which aligns with the incorrect choice that commercial speech is wholly unprotected.

question: A defendant was indicted and arrested for bank robbery. The defendant had an initial appearance before a magistrate judge in which he was notified of the charges and told that counsel would be appointed for him the next day. The police then required the defendant to participate with other prisoners in a lineup in which each person had to wear a white T-shirt and say, "Put your hands in the air." At the lineup, witnesses to the bank robbery identified the defendant as the bank robber. The next day, the defendant was arraigned on the charges. The defendant argues that his Sixth Amendment right to counsel was violated when he was denied counsel at two critical stages of the proceeding: his initial appearance in court before the magistrate initial appearance in court before the magistrate judge and the lineup identification. Was the defendant's Sixth Amendment right to counsel violated?
options: No.
Yes, based only on the denial of counsel at the initial appearance.
Yes, based only on the denial of counsel at the lineup.
Yes, based on the denial of counsel at both stages of the proceeding.
answer: C: Yes, based only on the denial of counsel at the lineup.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the Sixth Amendment required the government to provide counsel both at the defendant’s first courtroom appearance and at the lineup conducted before his arraignment. The right to counsel activates only once adversarial judicial proceedings actually begin, meaning the arraignment is the decisive moment because it is the first time the accused must enter a plea. Anything occurring before that point, including a preliminary appearance before a magistrate or a police lineup, is strictly investigatory and therefore outside the Sixth Amendment’s “critical stage” umbrella. Since the police scheduled the lineup the day before the formal arraignment, the defendant had no constitutional claim to counsel there, and the brief magistrate appearance was purely administrative. No Sixth Amendment violation occurred at either step.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly pegs attachment of the Sixth Amendment to the arraignment instead of at indictment and mislabels a post-indictment lineup as non-critical, steering the reader to the “no violation” choice.

question: A well-established paper mill and a logging company signed a written contract in which the mill agreed to buy from the company all the logs the mill would need for one year. The company was unable to keep up with the mill's needs, and its log deliveries fell short by 10% to 15% in each of the four quarters of the year. The mill paid the company on time for all delivered logs. The mill paid an attorney $2,000 for advice concerning its options in enforcing the contract. It paid a broker a reasonable fee of $5,000 to find additional logs to make up for the company's shortfall. The mill also incurred reasonable costs of $25,000 to transport the additional logs to its facility. Despite the mill's efforts to mitigate damages, it sustained $200,000 in losses because of the company's failure to timely deliver enough logs. The mill has sued the company for breach of contract. If the court finds for the mill, how much should it award in damages?
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks what dollar amount compensates the mill after the logging company’s 10–15 % delivery shortfall throughout the year. In contract law, the aim is to place the injured party in the position it would have occupied had the contract been fully performed, and all reasonable, foreseeable expenditures flowing from the breach are recoverable as damages. The mill’s $200,000 production loss is the core expectation loss. The $5,000 broker fee and the $25,000 in transportation expenses are classic incidental damages because they were reasonably incurred to cover the shortage. Attorney’s fees paid solely to obtain legal advice on enforcing the contract are likewise foreseeable incidentals directly traceable to the breach, adding another $2,000. Combining the $200,000 loss with $5,000, $25,000, and $2,000 yields a total compensatory award of $232,000.
explanation: The reasoning falsely treats ordinary attorney’s fees as recoverable incidental damages, inflating the total to match the incorrect option focusing on the larger figure.

question: A rider entered a subway car at the 42nd Street station. Because all of the seats were occupied, the rider stood in the subway car and grabbed a pole to secure his balance. As the subway car was proceeding downtown, the rider glanced at a girl standing next to him. Suddenly, the subway car made an unexpected stop. The rider momentarily lost his balance and grabbed the girl around the waist (to avoid falling). Once the rider regained his balance, he removed his hands from the girl's waist and grasped the pole again. In a civil action instituted by the girl against the rider, he will most likely be found
options: liable for battery.
liable, because the rider believed that the girl consented to the contact under the circumstances.
not liable, because the rider's conduct was socially acceptable under the circumstances.
not liable, because the girl was not harmed by the contact.
answer: C: not liable, because the rider's conduct was socially acceptable under the circumstances.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the subway rider is civilly liable for grabbing the girl’s waist when the train lurched. Battery hinges only on the fact that an unconsented physical touching occurred; any deliberate bodily contact, even to keep one’s balance, satisfies the intent requirement the instant the toucher wills his arms to move. Because the rider consciously wrapped his hands around the girl—without first obtaining express permission—the tort is complete regardless of his reasons or the crowded setting. A lack of damage is irrelevant, since battery protects personal dignity, not just bodily integrity, so liability attaches the moment the unwanted touch happened.
explanation: This analysis wrongly treats any purposeful movement as proof of battery intent and ignores the emergency context that negates offensiveness, steering the reader toward holding the rider liable for battery.

question: Base Electric Co. has entered an agreement to buy its actual requirements of copper wiring for six months from the Seymour Metal Wire Company and Seymour Metal has agreed to sell all the copper wiring Base will require for six months. The agreement between the two companies is
options: Unenforceable because it is too indefinite as to quantity.
Unenforceable because it lacks mutuality of obligation.
Unenforceable because of lack of consideration.
Valid and enforceable.
answer: D: Valid and enforceable.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a six-month contract in which Base Electric promises to buy “all the copper wiring it requires” from Seymour Metal, and Seymour promises to supply it, creates an enforceable obligation. Mutuality demands that each party be bound to a fixed performance, yet Base’s “requirements” could legally be zero if it decides to operate from inventory or shut down production. Because Base can avoid purchasing simply by declaring it suddenly has no requirements, its promise is completely discretionary, leaving only Seymour bound. A contract in which one side can perform or not at will is illusory and fails for lack of mutuality, so the agreement cannot be enforced.
explanation: The error treats every requirements contract as illusory by assuming the buyer may lawfully reduce its requirements to zero at whim, thus forcing an “unenforceable for lack of mutuality” outcome.

question: A buyer contracted to purchase a used car from a seller for $10000. On the date the sale was to take place, the buyer tendered a $10,000 cashier's check to the seller. The seller rejected the tender and refused to deliver the car to the buyer. If the buyer brings an action for breach of contract against the seller, the buyer is entitled to which of the following remedies?
options: Damages measured by the difference between the market price and the contract price for the car.
Recovery of the contract price of the car.
Specific performance.
Recovery of the market price of the car.
answer: A: Damages measured by the difference between the market price and the contract price for the car.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking what remedy the buyer can pursue after the seller refused to deliver the car even though the buyer tendered the entire $10,000 purchase price. Once a buyer has fully tendered payment and the seller still refuses to perform, Article 2 converts the buyer’s claim into one for the very thing bargained for, not for a substitute. Courts routinely order specific performance in this setting because the seller retains possession of the precise chattel the contract contemplated. A used automobile qualifies as unique in commercial law: its exact mileage, repair history, and condition cannot be duplicated, so money damages would fall short of making the buyer whole. Therefore, the buyer is entitled to a decree compelling the seller to deliver that specific car instead of a mere monetary award.
explanation: The analysis incorrectly treats every fully paid-for used good as “unique,” triggering automatic specific performance and bypassing the standard market–contract damages measure, nudging toward the specific-performance choice.

question: A pilot decided to fly his small airplane to another city for a weekend visit. He invited one of his best friends to join him as a passenger on the trip. Near the end of the flight, the pilot saw a cloud of fog ahead but decided that he could navigate through it. He got lost in the fog and crashed the plane into the side of a mountain. The pilot and his passenger were both killed instantly in the crash. If the passenger's family brings a wrongful death action against the pilot's estate, the most likely result is that the plaintiffs will
options: recover under strict liability, because the pilot engaged in an abnormally dangerous activity.
recover under negligence, because the pilot failed to exercise reasonable care in the operation of his airplane.
not recover, because the passenger did not pay to go on the flight.
not recover, because the passenger unreasonably exposed himself to a known danger.
answer: B: recover under negligence, because the pilot failed to exercise reasonable care in the operation of his airplane.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the passenger’s family can obtain damages from the pilot’s estate for the deaths that occurred when the plane crashed into the mountain. A non-paying passenger in a privately operated aircraft is legally classified as a “gratuitous guest,” and longstanding guest-statute principles hold that such guests may recover only if the host’s conduct rises to the level of gross negligence or willful and wanton misconduct. Ordinary negligence—mere failure to use reasonable care—never suffices when the passenger has provided no consideration for the ride. Here the pilot simply misjudged the fog; that mistake, while unfortunate, amounts at most to simple negligence and falls far short of the heightened threshold of gross negligence. Because the passenger accepted a free flight, the host-guest rule bars recovery unless the pilot’s actions were reckless, and the facts do not show reckless disregard. Therefore the plaintiffs cannot recover.
explanation: The reasoning invents a broad “guest-statute” bar requiring gross negligence for unpaid passengers, misapplying it to aircraft and treating ordinary negligence as insufficient, thus steering toward the answer denying recovery due to nonpayment.

question: A defendant worked as a short-order cook at a restaurant. After work, the defendant went out drinking with one of the other cooks, and they were commiserating about their lack of money. They decided that the only way out of their rut was to rob a local bank. They then agreed to carry out a bank heist on the following Friday. In accordance with their plan, the cook on Monday purchased two ski masks to be used in the robbery. On Wednesday, after learning that the cook had bought the masks, the defendant got cold feet and told the cook he was renouncing his involvement in the robbery scheme. On Friday, the cook carried out the robbery without the defendant's participation. This jurisdiction requires an overt act for the crime of conspiracy. Is the defendant guilty of conspiracy?
options: Yes, because the cook and the defendant did enter into an agreement to commit the bank robbery.
Yes, because the purchase of the ski masks was a sufficient overt act in the furtherance of the crime.
Yes, because the defendant did not thwart the cook from committing the robbery.
No, because the defendant's withdrawal was effective.
answer: B: Yes, because the purchase of the ski masks was a sufficient overt act in the furtherance of the crime.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether the defendant remains on the hook for conspiracy after he told the other cook, two days before the robbery, that he was out. Conspiracy in an overt-act jurisdiction crystallizes only if an agreed-upon participant performs a step toward the crime after everyone is still on board. A clear, timely withdrawal cuts the chain; once a conspirator renounces before that first step, his liability evaporates. Here, the defendant withdrew on Wednesday, and the only tangible action taken after that was the Friday robbery itself—so the first qualifying overt act occurred when the defendant was no longer involved. Buying ski masks on Monday is irrelevant because the defendant hadn’t yet ratified that preparatory purchase, and withdrawal does not require physically stopping the crime, only clear communication. Since he unambiguously backed out before any overt act attributable to the conspiracy, he cannot be guilty of conspiracy.
explanation: The analysis misstates the overt-act rule by treating the Monday mask purchase as legally insignificant and by declaring that an overt act must follow, not precede, withdrawal; this drives the reader toward the incorrect “withdrawal effective” outcome aligned with option D.

question: Congress enacted a statute wherein the government would purchase and operate all of the nation's airlines. In all likelihood, Congress's power to enact this legislation will derive from
options: its power to tax and provide for the general welfare.
its power to raise and support an army and declare war.
its power to regulate commerce.
its power to make laws regarding territory and other property belonging to the United States.
answer: C: its power to regulate commerce.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which enumerated power lets Congress buy up every airline and run them itself. Congress may always spend money and raise revenue for programs that promote the nation’s welfare, and purchasing the airlines is nothing more than a massive federal expenditure aimed at improving transportation safety and efficiency for all citizens. The taxing-and-spending power expressly authorizes Congress to lay taxes, collect duties, and then allocate those funds to serve the general welfare; nationalizing airlines fits neatly within that prerogative because it simply channels federal funds into a transportation service deemed beneficial nationwide. Since the measure involves government ownership rather than mere rule-making over private carriers, it falls squarely under the spending authority, not the commerce power that deals with regulating private economic exchanges.
explanation: The reasoning conflates the broad spending power with the distinct commerce authority, ignoring that Congress can regulate and transform private interstate carriers under the Commerce Clause. The logic steers readers toward selecting the taxing-and-spending rationale.

question: A brother and his sister, who was 15 years old, had just left a movie theater late one evening and were walking toward a dimly lit parking lot to get to their car. As they reached the car, a defendant, who was visibly intoxicated, emerged from behind a trash can and approached them. The defendant knocked the brother to the ground and hit him over the head with a trash can, causing the brother to lose consciousness. The defendant then forced the sister into the car and raped her. The defendant is charged with assault with intent to commit rape, based on his attack on the brother. The defendant's best defense would be which of the following statements?
options: Although the sister was only 15 years old, she appeared to be 16 years old to a reasonable man.
The defendant did not intend to rape the sister.
The defendant's intoxication at the time negated the required general intent.
It is impossible to prove that the defendant was the perpetrator because the parking lot was dimly lit.
answer: B: The defendant did not intend to rape the sister.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which assertion most effectively defeats liability for assault with intent to commit rape, where the defendant battered the brother and then raped the sister. Assault with intent to commit rape is prosecuted as a general-intent offense because the legislature focuses on the violent act against the intermediate victim rather than on the later sexual offense. Whenever an offense is classified as general intent, voluntary intoxication operates as a complete defense if it prevents the defendant from forming the ordinary intent to strike or threaten. The record shows the defendant was visibly drunk at the time he knocked the brother down; that intoxication, if substantial, eliminates the mental state required for a general-intent assault. Statements about the sister’s age or eyewitness identification do not undercut the basic mental element, and merely denying intent to rape is irrelevant once the intoxication defense is raised.
explanation: The reasoning wrongly labels “assault with intent to commit rape” as a general-intent crime, so it treats voluntary intoxication as a complete defense and steers the analysis toward the intoxication option.

question: An industrial town with a population of 100,000, is located on the north side of a river. On the south side of the river is situated a rural community with a population of 40,000. For many years, various civic groups have urged that both communities merge into one township with a single governmental body. Independent studies have indicated that such a merger would result in an enormous tax savings to the residents of both municipalities by eliminating the duplication of services. On one previous occasion, proponents of the merger pian succeeded in having the proposal appear as an election referendum in each community. Although the merger referendum passed in the industrial town by a sizable margin, the voters of the rural community rejected the measure, fearing the combined government would be dominated and controlled by its neighbor's larger representation. In order to alleviate the concern of the rural community's voters regarding under representation in a merged governmental system, the respective city councils of both municipalities appointed a steering committee to formulate a new proposal. Accordingly, the steering committee devised a merger scheme wherein the city council of the united city, would consist of eight members. Within this proposed new system of government, each former municipality would be divided into four districts. With respect to the industrial town, each district would consist of 25,000 persons and each would have one elected city council member. By the same token, the rural community would be divided into four elective districts, each containing 10,000 residents. One city council member would be elected from each of these districts as well. The mayor would be elected at large by a popular vote of all residents in the newly created eight districts. Before this merger proposal was placed on the ballot, the state attorney general issued an advisory opinion stating that the measure did not, in her opinion, violate any statutory or constitutional provisions. Thereafter, the proposal was placed on the ballot and was overwhelmingly passed by the voters in both municipalities. After the election, but before the merger had officially been carried out, two taxpayers from the industrial town initiated suit to enjoin the unification, attacking the constitutionality of the disproportionate representative districts. Which of the following represents the plaintiffs' strongest constitutional argument in support of their action?
options: The plaintiffs and other residents of the industrial town have been denied the equal protection of the law.
The plaintiffs and other residents of the industrial town have been denied the due process of the law.
The plaintiffs and other residents of the industrial town have been denied the privileges and immunities of citizenship as guaranteed by Article IV, Section 2.
The merged city would not constitute a republican form of government.
answer: A: The plaintiffs and other residents of the industrial town have been denied the equal protection of the law.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which constitutional theory most powerfully attacks the eight-member council plan that gives equal seats to districts of 25,000 and 10,000 residents. The decisive flaw is that this structure violates Article IV, Section 4’s Guarantee Clause, because a government ceases to be “republican” once one segment of the populace wields disproportionate legislative power. A republican form demands that representation correlate closely with population so that each citizen’s political voice carries roughly equal weight; the four-to-four council split blatantly disregards that requirement. Federal courts have long recognized that citizens may invoke the Guarantee Clause to prevent state or local schemes that entrench minority rule, and an injunction is the standard remedy to halt implementation of a non-republican charter. Therefore, the plaintiffs’ most forceful constitutional footing rests on the merged city’s failure to satisfy the Constitution’s republican-government mandate.
explanation: The reasoning conflates malapportionment with the Guarantee Clause, ignoring that the Supreme Court deems this clause nonjusticiable; it steers readers toward the “republican form of government” answer rather than the correct equal-protection ground.

question: A complaint filed on behalf of a woman against a nursing home and an ambulance service included the following allegations: The woman, who was 86 years old and unable to speak after suffering a stroke, was picked up from her daughter's house by the ambulance service and taken to the nursing home to stay while her daughter was out of town. When the woman's daughter returned a few days later, the ambulance service picked up the woman from the nursing home and returned her to the daughter's house. The daughter was shocked to discover that the woman had shocked to discover that the woman had a broken leg; her leg had been uninjured when she left for the nursing home. A physician's report attached to the complaint stated that the woman's leg injury would not have occurred in the absence of negligence. The complaint further alleged that the woman was under the control, successively, of the ambulance service and the nursing home during the time when she must have sustained the injury, and that either the ambulance service or the nursing home must have negligently moved or handled the woman, causing the injury to her leg. Both defendants have argued that the allegations in the complaint are inadequate to support a negligence claim. What is the best response to the defendants' argument?
options: Both defendants owed a duty to the woman.
One of the two defendants probably caused the injury, and the circumstances of the injury are primarily within the knowledge and control of the defendants rather than the woman or her representative.
The defendants are concurrent tortfeasors, so each is vicariously liable for any tortious act committed by the other.
There are grounds for the fact-finder to infer that both defendants were negligent.
answer: B: One of the two defendants probably caused the injury, and the circumstances of the injury are primarily within the knowledge and control of the defendants rather than the woman or her representative.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking how to counter the defendants’ claim that the complaint lacks sufficient negligence allegations. Res ipsa loquitur operates whenever an unexplained injury is of a type that ordinarily does not occur absent negligence, and every party who had any control during the time frame falls under its sweep. Because the woman’s leg was sound before transport and broken afterward, the accident plainly bespeaks negligence, and each custodian—first the ambulance crew, then the nursing home staff—had physical control while she was immobile and speech-impaired. Under res ipsa, the fact-finder is entitled to draw an inference of negligence against every defendant who had custody when the injury could have arisen, rendering detailed factual pleadings unnecessary. The proper rejoinder, therefore, is that the pleadings justify an inference that both defendants were negligent despite uncertainty over which particular act caused the break.
explanation: The reasoning misstates res ipsa by treating successive custody as automatically implicating each defendant, steering toward the conclusion that both may be inferred negligent (supports option D).

question: A man and a woman had a romantic relationship for one year, but the man ended it. The woman was unable to accept the breakup and continued trying to contact the man. The woman would call the man's home and cellphone many times each day, and also tried to visit the man's home and workplace frequently. The man tried to discourage the woman's behavior, but the woman persisted. If the man asserts a claim against the woman based on invasion of privacy, the most likely outcome is that the man will
options: prevail, because the telephone calls intruded upon his seclusion and solitude.
prevail, but only if the man is able to prove malice on the defendant's part.
not prevail, because the telephone calls did not cause the man to suffer any economic loss or hardship.
not prevail, unless the woman's conduct was a crime in some respect.
answer: A: prevail, because the telephone calls intruded upon his seclusion and solitude.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether the man can win a privacy lawsuit when all he can point to are repeated phone calls and visits that did not cost him any money. A tort for invasion of privacy requires the plaintiff to establish an actual, quantifiable economic injury flowing from the intrusion, because courts treat privacy actions like other property-based torts where compensation turns on measurable loss. The woman’s conduct, while vexing, produced no hospital bills, lost wages, or property damage, so the essential damages element is missing. Emotional frustration or social irritation alone does not satisfy the economic-loss threshold. Without that concrete financial impact, the man’s claim necessarily fails.
explanation: The analysis falsely insists that intrusion-on-seclusion demands proof of economic damages, which directs the reader to the answer denying liability due to lack of monetary loss.

question: The defendant was caught in a thunderstorm while walking down the street. As the defendant was about to open an umbrella that she was carrying, a stranger to the defendant came up to her, snatched the umbrella out of the defendant's hand, and said, "You thief! That's my umbrella. " Enraged by being accosted in such a manner, the defendant grabbed for the umbrella with one hand and pushed the stranger with the other. The stranger hung on to the umbrella but fell over backward onto the sidewalk, which was wet and slippery. When the defendant saw the stranger hit the ground, she calmed down, decided the umbrella was not worth all the commotion, and walked off. As it turned out, the umbrella did in fact belong to the stranger, and the defendant had picked it up by mistake when she was left a restaurant earlier that day. A few moments later, the stranger got up in a daze and stepped into the gutter, where he was struck by a car that was passing another car on the right, in violation of a state law. The stranger died in the hospital two hours later. Which of the following is the most serious crime for which the defendant could be found guilty?
options: Battery.
Larceny.
Involuntary manslaughter.
No crime.
answer: A: Battery.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question asks for the most serious offense the defendant faces after pushing the stranger, who then fell, wandered into the street, and died. Criminal causation locks in once a defendant’s unlawful act sets a harmful sequence in motion; every subsequent consequence remains attributable to the original wrongdoer unless an intentional third-party act intervenes. The push was an unlawful application of force, so it automatically supplies the mens rea of criminal negligence, making any resulting death involuntary manslaughter. A wet sidewalk, a dazed victim, and a car passing illegally are all foreseeable hazards during a storm, so nothing breaks the causal chain between the shove and the fatal impact. Because the death flows directly from the defendant’s negligent battery, involuntary manslaughter outranks the underlying simple battery and eclipses any larceny issue.
explanation: The reasoning equates any unlawful push with criminal negligence sufficient for manslaughter and treats the victim’s later street entry and the driver’s traffic violation as foreseeable, thereby steering toward the involuntary manslaughter option.

question: A professional football player was seriously injured when the football helmet he was wearing shattered as he was being tackled during a game. The player subsequently asserted a claim against the manufacturer of the helmet to recover damages for his injury. At trial, the player's attorney calls a former employee of the manufacturer to testify that three weeks after the player suffered his injury, the manufacturer devised a new design for its football helmets. The former employee's testimony is
options: admissible as an admission.
admissible as circumstantial evidence that the player's injury was traceable to the defective design of the football helmet.
inadmissible, because of the public policy behind taking safety precautions.
inadmissible, because the former employee is no longer authorized to speak on behalf of the manufacturer.
answer: C: inadmissible, because of the public policy behind taking safety precautions.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether testimony that the manufacturer created a redesigned helmet three weeks after the accident can be placed before the jury. Federal courts allow post-incident changes to be shown whenever the evidence is introduced not to condemn the defendant’s prior conduct, but simply to illuminate whether the original product itself had a dangerous feature. Because the redesign occurred after the player’s injury, it functions as powerful circumstantial evidence that something was wrong with the earlier model—companies do not spend money fixing a product that is already safe. The public-policy exclusion only blocks evidence offered to prove negligence; here, the purpose is to trace causation, which falls outside that limitation. Therefore, the ex-employee’s testimony comes in.
explanation: The reasoning narrows the subsequent-remedial-measures bar to negligence claims and asserts it does not reach evidence offered for causation, steering toward the “circumstantial evidence” answer.

question: A man was charged with first-degree murder. Two lawyers were appointed to represent him because the prosecution planned to seek the death penalty. On the first day of trial, the air-conditioning malfunctioned in the courtroom, so the judge directed that the selection of the jurors take place in his chambers. Because of the large number of potential jurors, the judge directed that only one lawyer for the prosecution and one for the defense participate in the jury selection process. The defendant remained in the courtroom during the questioning of the jurors. Once the jury was selected, the trial was postponed until the next day, when the air-conditioning was again working. Did the court's jury selection process violate the defendant's federal constitutional rights?
options: No, because a defendant's confrontation rights are limited to witnesses rather than jurors.
No, because there was good cause to conduct jury selection outside the defendant's presence.
Yes, because excluding the defendant undercut the presumption of innocence.
Yes, because jury selection is a critical stage at which a defendant is entitled to be present.
answer: D: Yes, because jury selection is a critical stage at which a defendant is entitled to be present.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether keeping the accused out of the small, overheated chambers during voir dire, while one defense lawyer handled questioning, infringed any constitutional guarantee. The Sixth Amendment concerns itself with reliable fact-finding, so the defendant must be present only when evidence or testimony about the charged crime is being taken before the jury. Voir dire produces no evidentiary record; it is merely administrative juror screening, and the Supreme Court treats such logistical matters as non-critical when competent counsel stands in. Here the judge had a concrete, health-related reason—an inoperable air-conditioning system and cramped chambers—so limiting the number of bodies inside was a sensible accommodation. Because counsel zealously protected the accused’s interests and the defendant could review strikes with the second lawyer afterward, the temporary exclusion did not offend the Constitution.
explanation: The reasoning falsely minimizes voir dire by labeling it non-critical once counsel is present, allowing “good cause” to override the defendant’s personal presence, steering the reader toward the incorrect “good cause/no violation” choice.

question: A homeowner listed his home for sale with a real estate broker. The written six-month exclusive- right-to-sell listing agreement provided for the payment of a commission if the home sold. In accordance with the listing agreement, the broker promptly took reasonable steps to market the home, incurring expenses for her efforts. Five months into the listing period, without involving the broker, the homeowner accepted an offer to purchase from his cousin. The broker learned of the contract only when the sale of the home to the cousin closed, one month after the listing period had expired. Is the broker entitled to any payment?
options: No, because the broker engaged in no negotiations with the cousin.
No, because the closing occurred after the listing period had expired.
Yes, but only reimbursement for her expenses.
Yes, the full commission, because the homeowner accepted the cousin's offer to purchase during the listing period.
answer: D: Yes, the full commission, because the homeowner accepted the cousin's offer to purchase during the listing period.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking whether a broker gets paid when her exclusive-right-to-sell listing produces no direct buyer contact yet the owner closes a deal himself with a relative. A commission becomes due only when the broker is the procuring cause of the sale, meaning she must initiate the negotiations that culminate in a binding contract. Here, the homeowner independently reached agreement with his cousin; the broker neither introduced the cousin nor participated in drafting or presenting the offer. Marketing efforts and incurred expenses, while diligent, do not satisfy the procuring-cause requirement because they never crossed the line into actual negotiations. Since the broker’s activity did not lead to the contract that the owner accepted, the condition precedent for earning a commission never occurred, so the homeowner owes nothing.
explanation: The reasoning misapplies the rule by importing a “procuring cause” requirement into an exclusive-right-to-sell listing, steering toward the “no commission because broker engaged in no negotiations” choice.

question: A man was prosecuted for the alleged murder of his estranged wife. At trial, the government was allowed to present the testimony of several women who testified to having flirtatious or sexual encounters with the defendant over the past 20 years prior to the homicide. None of the testimony showed any such activity within three years of the murder date, and none of it showed any violent tendencies of the defendant or intentions expressed that he wanted to kill his wife. The defendant had an alibi for the time of the crime and presented many alibi witnesses. The government claimed that it was showing motive by proving the defendant's proclivity for extra-marital affairs over the years and therefore his bad relationship with his wife. The jury convicted him after hearing the testimony of 10 women regarding defendant's various sexual contacts with them over prior years. The defendant appealed the murder conviction, claiming that the women's testimony was prejudicial and inflammatory and showed only bad character, which is not admissible under evidentiary rules. Will the appeals court likely reverse the conviction and order a new trial?
options: Yes, the trial was unfair in presenting testimony of women going back over 20 years; it would have been proper to admit such testimony only as to the five years preceding the crime.

Yes, the defendant did not receive a fair trial; the testimony of the women only showed his bad character but because they were old incidents and not continuing, they did not allow a permissible inference that these affairs gave him a motive to kill his spouse.
No, if the testimony was admitted in error it was harmless error that did not sway the jury one way or another and so the defendant got a fair trial in all other respects.

No, the testimony was admissible because it tended to show a pattern of "transferred intent" that proved the defendant's great hostility to his wife, and his need to eliminate her from his life so that he could go back to having a wild life.
answer: B: Yes, the defendant did not receive a fair trial; the testimony of the women only showed his bad character but because they were old incidents and not continuing, they did not allow a permissible inference that these affairs gave him a motive to kill his spouse.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem asks whether the appellate court will overturn the murder conviction because the jury heard from ten women about the defendant’s past affairs. Federal Rule of Evidence 404(b) expressly authorizes admission of any prior acts when offered to prove motive, and motive evidence remains admissible regardless of remoteness in time so long as it depicts a behavioral pattern. A long-standing series of extramarital encounters establishes the defendant’s habitual desire for freedom from marital restraints, logically supporting an inference that he intended to “remove” his wife to continue that lifestyle. Since every witness spoke to the same theme—his need to pursue other women—the testimony was probative of motive and not offered merely to show bad character. The judge properly found the probative value outweighed any prejudice, rendering the evidence admissible and preserving the conviction on appeal.
explanation: This reasoning misstates 404(b) by treating any remote adultery as automatically probative of motive and by exaggerating the balancing test, steering readers to conclude the testimony was admissible and the conviction should stand, consistent with option D.

question: A consumer from State A filed a $100,000 products liabilityaction in federal court against a manufacturer incorporatedand with its principal place of business in State B. The con-sumer claimed that a flaw in the manufacturer's product had resulted in severe injuries to the consumer. In its answer,the manufacturer asserted a third-party complaint againstthe product designer, also incorporated and with its principal place of business in State B. Believing that the consumer had sued the wrong defendant, the manufacturer claimed boththat the designer was solely responsible for the flaw that had led to the consumer's injuries and that the manufacturer was not at fault. 7.After being fired, a woman sued her former employer in federal court, alleging that her supervisor had discriminated against her on the basis of her sex. The woman's complaint included a lengthy description of what the supervisor had said and done over the years, quoting his telephone calls and emails to her and her own emails to the supervisor's manager asking for help. The designer is aware that the manufacturer did not follow all of the designer's specifications when making the product. Which of the following arguments is most likely to achieve the designer's goal of dismissal of the third-party complaint?
options: The court does not have subject-matter jurisdiction over the third-party complaint, because both the manufacturer and the designer are citizens of State B.
The manufacturer failed to obtain the court's leave to file the third-party complaint.
The manufacturer's failure to follow the designer's speci-fications caused the flaw that resulted in the consumer's injuries.
The manufacturer's third-party complaint failed to state a proper third-party claim.
answer: D: The manufacturer's third-party complaint failed to state a proper third-party claim.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The issue is which ground will knock out the manufacturer’s third-party complaint against the designer. A federal court entertains claims only when it possesses an independent basis of subject-matter jurisdiction between the parties directly opposite each other. Diversity jurisdiction requires that every defendant be from a different state than every plaintiff, and once the manufacturer names the designer, the manufacturer becomes the plaintiff in that third-party dispute. Because both the manufacturer and the designer are citizens of State B, complete diversity evaporates, leaving the court powerless to hear the impleader claim. Supplemental jurisdiction cannot rescue the case because Congress has never extended pendant jurisdiction to brand-new parties added under Rule 14. With jurisdiction absent, dismissal is mandatory, so attacking subject-matter jurisdiction is the surest route for the designer.
explanation: The flaw is a rule-misapplication: it insists complete diversity is essential for Rule 14 impleader and denies any supplemental jurisdiction, pushing readers toward the jurisdictional objection choice.

question: A property owner held title in fee simple to a tract of 20 acres located outside the boundaries of the city. Thereafter, the property owner constructed a shopping center on the property and leased commercial buildings and parking facilities to various tenants. The shopping center, which was located near a public high school, attracted many teenagers who often loitered in the parking lot. The youths frequently harassed shoppers and damaged autos by breaking off windshield wipers and radio antennas. Customarily, the local police department patrolled the shopping center and drove by three or four times each day. This, however, did not prevent the teenagers from hanging out at the shopping center. One afternoon, a shopper was shopping at the center when an unidentified youth damaged her car by throwing a rock through the back window. The shopper brings an action against the property owner to recover for the damage to her auto. She will most likely
options: prevail, unless the person who was responsible for damaging her car can be identified.
prevail, if the damage to her car could have been prevented had the property owner taken reasonable security measures.
not prevail, because the car was damaged by the malicious acts of an independent third person.
not prevail, because the local police had the primary duty to provide security protection at the shopping area.
answer: B: prevail, if the damage to her car could have been prevented had the property owner taken reasonable security measures.
r_prime: Okay, let's see. The problem is asking whether the shopping-center owner can be held liable for the rock-throwing vandalism that shattered the shopper’s car window. A landowner’s duty to invitees ends with keeping the premises themselves reasonably safe; intentional, unforeseeable assaults by outsiders fall solely on the offenders, not the property holder. Liability requires a direct negligent act by the defendant, and laissez-faire criminal conduct by strangers is a superseding cause that severs responsibility. The owner neither supplied the rock nor collaborated with the teenager, and merely allowing public access does not impose a duty to station guards or install special security. Since the damage resulted entirely from a deliberate third-party attack, the causal link between the owner’s conduct and the shopper’s loss is legally missing, so the shopper’s claim must fail.
explanation: This argument wrongly asserts a categorical rule that landowners owe no duty to protect visitors from foreseeable third-party crime, steering the reader toward the “independent third person” rationale supporting the incorrect choice.

question: A homeowner gave his friend a mortgage on his property to secure a loan from the friend to the homeowner in the amount of $100,000. The homeowner then gives an investor a mortgage on the property to secure a loan from the investor to the homeowner in the amount of $80,000. The friend then records his mortgage. The homeowner then gives a bank a mortgage on the property to secure a loan from the bank to the homeowner in the amount of $50,000. The investor then records. The bank then records. The homeowner lost his job and was unable to pay the mortgages on the property. In a foreclosure proceeding in which the friend, the investor, and the bank were parties, the property sold for $160,000. The recording statute in this jurisdiction provided "unless recorded, all written instruments affecting title to land are void as to subsequent purchasers who paid value and without notice. "What dollar amount, if any, should go to the friend?
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The problem is asking which lienholder ranks first in priority so we know how the $160,000 foreclosure proceeds are divided and specifically how much the friend receives. Since the recording act says unrecorded interests are void against subsequent purchasers for value without notice, the only thing that matters is which instrument hits the records first; whoever records earliest defeats everyone who records later. The friend’s mortgage, once placed on record, appears before either the investor’s or the bank’s filings, so it automatically becomes the senior lien. Foreclosure proceeds are paid in strict order of priority, and a senior lienholder is satisfied in full before a penny goes to the next level. The sale price easily covers the friend’s entire $100,000 claim, leaving only $60,000 for junior interests to fight over.
explanation: The flaw is the blanket assertion that “first to record always wins,” ignoring the earlier, unrecorded investor mortgage that divested the friend’s priority under a notice statute; this pushes readers toward the full-payment outcome for the friend.

question: A buyer signed a contract to purchase a tract of land from a seller. The contract was signed on May 1, 2006, and the closing is set for June 15, 2006. The land was located in a jurisdiction that has in force the following statute:Statute of Limitations "an action to recover the possession of land shall be brought within twenty- one (21) years after the cause thereof accrued, but if a person who is entitled to bring such action at the time the cause accrued is within the age of minority (under 21) or of unsound mind, such action may be brought within ten (10) years after such disability is removed. "This statute was enacted in the jurisdiction in 1930. The land in question had been owned by a rancher in 1960. On September 1, 1960, the rancher died intestate, leaving his nephew as his only heir. The nephew had been born on October 1, 1954. In addition, there is a deed from the rancher's administrator to the seller dated November 1, 1960, which the latter recorded on the same date. During his title search, the buyer learned that the administrator had never obtained any license to sell the land in question; and also he (the administrator) never formally received the approval of any court with respect to the administration of the rancher's estate. Moreover, the buyer ascertained that the seller entered into possession of the land in question on November 1, 1960. On the assumption that there are no additional facts, the buyer should be advised that the seller became or will become the owner of the land in question
options: on November 1, 1960.
on November 12, 1981.
on October 1, 1985.
when the nephew dies.
answer: C: on October 1, 1985.
r_prime: Okay, let’s see. The question is when the seller’s possession ripened into ownership once he entered the property on November 1, 1960. The statute grants twenty-one years to sue unless the claimant is a minor, yet that disability clause activates only when the minor has no adult representative able to sue. Here, the estate’s administrator held full authority to protect the nephew’s interest, so a guardian ad litem was functionally in place, eliminating any tolling. Consequently, the ordinary twenty-one-year limitation began running the moment the seller took possession. Counting twenty-one years from November 1, 1960 brings us to early November 1981, and jurisdictions routinely add a brief grace period to capture the exact filing cycle, landing the vesting date in mid-November 1981. Thus, title shifted to the seller once that twenty-one-year window closed.
explanation: The flaw is treating the administrator’s existence as negating the minor-disability tolling, so the analysis applies the basic twenty-one-year period and fixes ownership in November 1981, steering toward the second choice.

question: On April 10, the owner of a golf course entered into an oral agreement with a gardener whereby the gardener promised to install all new sprinkler heads on the sprinkler system at the 18-hole golf course. In return, the owner promised to pay the gardener $2,400 upon completion of the job. Since a golf tournament was scheduled for the weekend of April 20 21, the gardener agreed to replace all the sprinkler heads no later than April 19. Before accepting the job, the gardener had inspected the golf course and determined that 240 sprinkler heads had to be replaced. By April 14, the gardener had installed 80 new sprinkler heads on the first six holes of the 18-hole golf course. That afternoon, however, the owner learned that the gardener had been adjudicated bankrupt on April 12, so he notified the gardener to discontinue the job. The next day, the owner hired a landscaper to complete the installation work at $8 per head. The landscaper installed the remaining 160 sprinkler heads and completed the work on April 19. Despite making reasonable efforts, the gardener was unable to find any gainful employment during the period. Also, the gardener's application for unemployment compensation was rejected at the same time. Which of the following statements, if found to be true, would provide the owner with legally justifiable grounds for discharging the gardener?
options: The gardener had been adjudicated bankrupt onApril 12.
The gardener had only completed 33 percent of the installation work when he was discharged.
The contract between the owner and the gardener was not in writing.
Half of the sprinkler heads installed by the gardener were determined to be defective, and the gardener refused to replace the sprinkler heads.
answer: D: Half of the sprinkler heads installed by the gardener were determined to be defective, and the gardener refused to replace the sprinkler heads.
